webTitle: Wilkinson backs plan for qualified managers

fields.headline: Wilkinson backs plan for qualified managers
fields.standfirst: New bosses will need to pass coaching test under FA plan
fields.trailText: New managers emerging in English football will from 2003 need a formal qualification if a Football Association proposal backed by its technical director Howard Wilkinson is successful.
fields.body:
New managers emerging in English football will from 2003 need a formal qualification if a Football Association proposal backed by its technical director Howard Wilkinson is successful.

Wilkinson yesterday threw his weight behind the proposal by the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier that every new manager must have an FA-approved coaching qualification.

Crozier wants to bring England in line with most other European leagues and Wilkinson firmly believes the country cannot afford to operate in isolation any longer.

In the future, said Wilkin son, managers would have a licence "equivalent to the pro licence which exists all over Europe. It's a pro licence you need to go and work in Serie A, in the Dutch league and even in the Bundesliga. People who want to go and work at the very top will have to have it."

Wilkinson, who is preparing his England Under-21 squad for their European championship play-off against Yugoslavia in Barcelona tomorrow night, says it is time the English game started producing top coaches.

"The move was inevitable," he said. "At the moment there is hardly a country in Europe where you can get a job if you are not qualified. When are we going to start exporting coaches at the rate other countries do? At the end of the day qualifications raise standards. Where would medicine be without qualifications? Where would teaching be without them?

"No, they don't guarantee that you are going to be good at the job. What they do guarantee is a certain level of competence. They also show you really want to do the job because you have committed yourself to the time it takes to get that qualification."

Wilkinson, the former Leeds and Sheffield Wednesday man-ager, said current managers who are unqualified had nothing to fear and that the change would not take place overnight.

"It won't mean wholesale knife-job changes. It is our intention that people already in employment, people who have proved their ability to do the job, shouldn't suffer from this. But in future, if the move is successful, then players as they start to finish their career as they do in Germany, France, Italy and Holland will have to start preparing for management more thoroughly."

As in the Under-21s' last match, Wilkinson's selection is likely to swing the spotlight on to the bench as he follows an apparently agreed policy not to ask too much of Joe Cole too soon. Though Kevin Keegan described the West Ham teenager yesterday as probably "the one player in the country who could come on and change a game if the score was 0-0", he is unsure whether to take him to Euro 2000.

Keegan said Cole was probably the nearest thing to Paul Gascoigne in the English game, despite having "different qualities, build and personality". But he added: "The problem for me and Harry Redknapp is when is the right time to bring him in."

Wilkinson lost five players yesterday, including three strikers with ankle injuries: Carl Cort of Wimbledon and the Leeds pair Michael Bridges and Alan Smith. David Thompson (Liverpool), Andy Campbell (Middlesbrough), Danny Cadamarteri (Everton) and Kevin Davies (Southampton) have been called up.

webTitle: McIlroy looks to outsmart Maltese with crosses

fields.headline: McIlroy looks to outsmart Maltese with crosses
fields.trailText: Sammy McIlroy, the Northern Ireland manager, will continue with his wide-man policy for tonight's friendly against Malta at the Ta'Qali stadium, with Keith Gillespie and Michael Hughes working the flanks.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy, the Northern Ireland manager, will continue with his wide-man policy for tonight's friendly against Malta at the Ta'Qali stadium, with Keith Gillespie and Michael Hughes working the flanks.

"Hughes is a key figure in our build-up before the start of the World Cup qualifiers," said McIlroy. "At last he is figuring weekly in the Wimbledon set-up, which is essential if he is to maintain a challenge for an international place."

The Irish, depleted by the withdrawals through injury of Gerry Taggart, Jim Magilton, Aaron Hughes and Peter Kennedy, are anxious to win to boost morale.

"We meet Malta in our opening World Cup campaign and, frankly, I would prefer not to have this fixture," added McIlroy. "It can reveal too many of your tactical secrets, although all our regulars will hopefully be back by then."

Northern Ireland (probable, 4-4-2): Carroll (Wigan); Nolan (Sheff Wed), Williams (Watford), Griffin (St Johnstone) Murdock (Preston); Gillespie (Blackburn), Lomas (West Ham), Lennon (Leicester), Hughes (Wimbledon); Quinn (West Brom), Healy (Port Vale).

fields.headline: Absentees pick Brown's team
fields.trailText:
Scotland v France

Craig Brown yesterday announced a team that never was and then settled down to finding any side at all for Scotland's friendly with France at Hampden Park.
fields.body:
Craig Brown yesterday announced a team that never was and then settled down to finding any side at all for Scotland's friendly with France at Hampden Park. It was a classic illustration of the frustrations that always beset him.

"When I knew we had this match I thought we could go with the same players who won our last game, against England at Wembley," he said. "We would just have replaced John Collins, who has retired, with Paul Lambert which would have made no big difference."

Instead he has had to rule out the defenders Tom Boyd, David Weir and Brian O'Neil, and Matt Elliott's three-week-old son is seriously ill with a bronchial condition. "At least that puts a game of football into perspective," he added.

Brown has added Russell Anderson, Aberdeen's young centre-back who has coped as others around him choked this season, and Hearts' Gary Naysmith, who has long been regarded as a future Scotland player. If things get worse, the manager has not ruled out the possibility of pulling in Hibs' Kenny Miller as well as Hearts' Steven Pressley or Kilmarnock's Jim Lauchlan.

Between them the squad can muster only 22 goals and 202 caps, 89 of them belonging to the veterans Kevin Gallacher and Colin Hendry. Only six of the pool are in double figures for their country. But the squad may hearten those who criticise Brown's tendency to stick with the old guard.

For the world champions Zinedine Zidane did not travel to Glasgow because of a knee problem and the goalkeeper Fabien Barthez is doubtful.

Scotland (probable; 3-5-2): Sullivan (Wimbledon); Dailly (Blackburn), Hendry (Derby), Ritchie (Bolton); McNamara (Celtic), Cameron (Hearts), B Ferguson (Rangers), Hutchison (Everton), Davidson (Blackburn); Dodds (Rangers), Gallagher (Newcastle).

fields.headline: Online store makes unbeatable offer
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One of America's largest on-line retailers, Buy.com, yesterday launched an attempt to crack the British market by offering the cheapest prices anywhere for computers, software and accessories.
fields.body:
One of America's largest on-line retailers, Buy.com, yesterday launched an attempt to crack the British market by offering the cheapest prices anywhere for computers, software and accessories.

The company, which has 2.3m customers in the US, plans more internet "superstores" later this year offering other product categories such as clothes, music and books.

However, its UK launch coincided with the publication of two reports suggesting that internet shopping faces a rocky road ahead.

Retail consultancy Verdict criticised e-retailers for spending too much on "glitzy" marketing at the expense of customer services.

Verdict director Mike Godliman said: "A lot of the emphasis has been on marketing, websites and advertising. There's been loads of investment going into the glitzy end, rather than into the boring end - actually delivering the goods."

Deloitte Consulting sounded another note of concern, warning that a lack of face-to-face contact could prove a real turn-off for consumers.

Both consultancies cast doubt on optimistic projections claiming that the internet will mean a complete revolution in shopping habits.

With backers including Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Buy.com is one of the most significant entrants yet onto Britain's internet "high street".

Buy.com's chief executive, Murray Hennessy, admitted there were worries in some quarters: "Last Christmas, so many e-commerce companies had so much demand that they had a lot of trouble fulfiling it."

However, he insisted that Buy.com had sufficient means to provide a reliable service: "We've got significant resources behind us in the US and we've put a lot of time, effort and money into making sure we can deliver."

Buy.com's US parent is the world's second largest e-commerce player, following Amazon.com.

The company is guaranteeing rock-bottom prices - if customers find a better deal elsewhere, Buy.com will refund the difference and pay an extra £1 for the inconvenience.

In the UK, its in-house operations consist of just a head office in London, with a few dozen staff. Calls and emails are taken by an 80-strong call centre in Exeter which is run by an outside company, Client Logic. Goods are held in warehouses run by the distribution specialist Ingram Micro and delivery has been outsourced to the parcel carrier UPS.

Mr Hennessy said the company had already dealt with 11,000 test contacts and delivered 1,300 trial orders.

There was some encouraging news for e-retailers generally in Verdict's report, which said nearly two-thirds of Britons have had products delivered to their homes in the last year.

However, Mr Godliman said companies were lagging behind customers' expectations: "We've seen home shopping beginning to mushroom - initially through catalogues and now through the internet and television. Consumer expectations in terms of service are increasing quite substantially but actual delivery isn't changing much."

He said it remained too difficult to get delivery in the evening or at weekends: "You can have the best website in the world but if people don't get what they want, they won't come back."

Deloitte Consulting found that 21% of consumers expect to use the internet to make purchases over the next five years. However, 40% said they expected their trust in companies to diminish if remote channels were the only available option.

The survey's author, David Owen, said feedback was often difficult. "Consumers need to know complaints are dealt with as voraciously as purchases," he said.

He added that there were substantial national differences in attitude, with French and Italian customers, for example, still considering face-to-face contact particularly important.

Mr Owen said: "US multinationals run the risk of treating different countries as homogeneous. I'm not saying people shouldn't be doing innovative things and taking commercial risks, but they need to adopt a multi-channel approach."

fields.headline: Inhale those vibes
fields.standfirst:
Cypress Hill
Astoria, London
****
fields.trailText: Cypress Hill, Astoria, London
fields.body:
The ongoing debate about the decriminalisation of cannabis seems redundant when a substantial proportion of the 1,800 people shoehorned into the Astoria have voted with their weed and followed the exhortative directions to "get high, so high". Hazily visible through the pungent fog, Cypress Hill's helium-voiced mouthpiece B-Real is celebrating reports that the herb may soon be sanctioned for medicinal purposes in the UK. "We rock overseas," he declares, inhaling deeply, "and we smoke all the trees."

Ten years of toking doesn't appear to have had an adverse effect on Cypress Hill. The Los Angeles trio are both hip-hop pioneers and a 12m-unit-shifting crossover phenomenon. What's more, the rap-rock hybrid that currently prevails in mosh-pits everywhere from Brixton to Brazil is a groove pretty much patented by Cypress Hill - B-Real, Sen Dog and their genius producer DJ Muggs.

Lest there be any doubt about this, the Hill are returning with a thematically split album: Skull & Bones, featuring actual rock skills from members of Rage Against the Machine and Fear Factory, plus Sen Dog's own funk-metal project SX10, as well as more orthodox hip-hop elements. The latest live show is arranged along similar lines. It's testimony to the primal properties of such classics as I Ain't Goin' Out Like That and Cock the Hammer that the added layers of fretboard viscera don't diminish their impact.

The irony is, however, that while many hip-hop groups may usefully incorporate "real" instruments in to their moribund live shows, Cypress Hill don't actually need to. It's hardly subtle, but with Muggs at the helm and Eric Bobo adding extra percussive ballast, B-Real and Sen Dog make for brilliantly pugilistic cabaret, at once intimidating and funny. So much for the supposed debilitative properties of the chronic - this is urgent, choreographed mayhem.

Any off-duty police on the premises might have experienced tremors of unease - pig-bashing is almost as favourite a Cypress Hill pastime as gardening - yet for all their authentic accounts of thug life and gunplay, the Hill's self-image favours humour over aggro. When B-Real emerges bewigged and garlanded in marijuana as his Dr Greenthumb alter-ego, three outwardly sensible girls clamber onstage for a self-conscious dance. And as they close with new single Rock Superstar, perhaps the definitive rap-rock crossover from the band that's done more than most to define the concept, the blunt-line according to Cypress Hill feels more potent than ever.

fields.headline: When ignorance isn't bliss
fields.trailText: One colleague at work is making another's life miserable by completely ignoring him. It has gone on for several months and the ignored colleague is about to leave. Should he confront her before he goes?
fields.body:
The problem

One colleague at work is making another's life miserable by completely ignoring him, and even crossing the street if she sees him. He does not understand why and is angry about it. It has gone on for several months and the ignored colleague is about to leave. Should he confront her before he goes?

The solution

Yes, he should confront her. Why not - he has nothing to lose now. Her behaviour sounds rather extreme and goes beyond the sort of general moodiness that some people unfortunately exhibit. It sounds like she has a reason or some perceived injustice that she feels she has experienced at your colleague's hands.

Has this woman been like this with anyone else? If not, you can assume that she feels aggrieved by this man and that now he is leaving, the problem should not recur. From what you say, it does sound like this is a one-off and it may be that this woman has a very good reason for being upset with your colleague. Only by confronting her, will you know.

Of course, another option would be for you to confront her, rather than your exiting colleague. Or, perhaps you could get both people together and act as a kind of arbitrator so that they can try and sort out their differences. Obviously, it is too late for your leaving colleague, but such action may help prevent this happening again.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Isa investors catch dot.com fever
fields.trailText: Small investors poured more than £350m into global technology funds in February in the end-of-tax-year rush to use up Isa investment allowances.
fields.body:
Small investors poured more than £350m into global technology funds in February in the end-of-tax-year rush to use up Isa investment allowances.

The Association of Unit Trusts said yesterday sales of share-based Isas are on course to beat last year's £4.1bn total for their predecessors, personal equity plans. Net Isa sales in February were £1.03bn, up 59% on January and two-thirds higher than net sales of Peps in the same month last year.

Total sales of unit trusts, including non-Isas, rose to £4.75bn in February from £3.2bn a year before.

"Isas had a very slow start but they have been picking up an an extraordinary rate," said AUT director Anne McMeehan. "They have captured the public imagination at a far greater speed than Peps."

In February 1999 investors put only £22.8m into "global specialist" funds, the sector containing the majority of technology trusts. Retail investors put £366m into the sector last month, including £173m through Isas.

Jason Hollands at BestInvestments said around nine out of 10 clients wanting to use up their Isa allowances were requesting application forms for technology funds.

fields.headline: Theatre review
fields.standfirst: Flesh and Blood ** Hampstead Theatre, London
fields.trailText: Flesh and Blood ** Hampstead Theatre, London
fields.body:
Helen Griffin's first play is very strange - a vulgar comedy that makes serious points about racism, a state-of-the-Welsh-nation play that never gets out of the living room, a drama that is almost totally unbelievable yet absolutely spot-on in some details.

Vernon is a stereotypical Welshman who gives his wife Marge a bad time because he's fed up with the Queen, the Welsh Assembly and his own life. This comic oaf rules the roost from the sofa, to which he has retired in disgust at the state of the world, the length of his daughter's skirt and his son's warped idea of a practical joke.

But Vernon's casual racism and homophobia have taken poisonous root elsewhere in the family, and when his daughter Serena falls in love a predictable tragedy ensues.

This is a heartfelt play, but also a clumsy one, and Griffin is too inexperienced a writer to get the balance between the serious and the comic right. The evening feels like an anti-racism lecture with jokes, although she writes with insight about the dynamics of families. Just how good a writer she may become is signalled in the final blistering scene between an uncomprehending mother and her desperate son. Here you see the kindly Marge torn between love and revulsion and beginning to realise that she and Vernon may have been guilty of creating the conditions that allowed hatred to flourish.

 Till April 8. Box office: 0171-722 9301.

webTitle: Expansive QXL snaps up auction rival

fields.headline: Expansive QXL snaps up auction rival
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: QXL.com yesterday underlined its determination to become the dominant on-line auctioneer in Europe by announcing the continent's largest internet takeover.
fields.body:
QXL.com yesterday underlined its determination to become the dominant on-line auctioneer in Europe by announcing the continent's largest internet takeover.

The £347m all-share deal to take over Scandinavian rival Bidlet AB is the fourth acquisition QXL has made since floating in October and follows successful bids for rivals in Norway, Denmark and Poland.

Analysts believe QXL is trying to mimic the strategy of American companies such as Cisco which moved swiftly after floating to build dominant market positions through acquisitions. Goldman Sachs analyst Phil Clark said: "Consolidation is going to leave only two or three big players in this sector and you would expect QXL to be one of them."

However, QXL founder Tim Jackson is unlikely to take part in the minutiae of future deals after stepping down as a non-executive director to concentrate on his new venture capital role at Carlyle Internet Partners Europe and at a charitable foundation he is setting up. He will, however, remain as a special adviser to Mr Rose and QXL.com chairman Jonathan Bulkeley.

"Old founders never die they just send emails from home," Mr Jackson joked yesterday.

He said his resignation from the board was an indication of his faith in Mr Rose and his team's ability to develop the business.

Most of Mr Jackson's time will be taking up by managing the $800m (£500m) Chase internet investment fund. However, he is also becoming a trustee of a charitable foundation he has set up and is being registered by the Charity Commission.

Around £70m of Mr Jackson's £265m shareholding in QXL is being put towards good causes.

"It is important that entre preneurs who have made a lot of money very quickly put money back into the community," Mr Jackson said.

His move mirrors a trend among wealthy hi-tech entrepreneurs in the US. Bill Gates, Michael Dell, Jim Clark and Paul Allen have all established charitable foundations after making their fortunes.

Chief executive Jim Rose said the Bidlet acquisition will be financed through the issue of 23.5m new shares at £14.75 each and further deals were on the cards. Analysts would like to see QXL.com increase its presence in France and, in particular, in Germany.

Ricardo.de, Germany's second largest auction site which yesterday paid $30m for Switzerland's Auktion24.ch and is valued in excess of £1bn, is rumoured as a possible target.

Mr Rose said: "We want to be a leader in the consolidation process and talk to a lot of players all the time.

"Ricardo.de would be a great fit and would not be beyond us but there are others too. We'll look at everything."

Bidlet, which is Sweden's leading internet auction site and has services in Norway, Denmark and Finland, made a loss of £3.8m on revenues of £2.5m in the year to December last year.

It operates in a region that has been one of the earliest adopters of wireless devices and Mr Rose said Bidlet management's experience of serving a particularly internet wise customer base would help QXL.com roll-out its multi-platform strategy across the rest of Europe.

Following the deal, QXL will be active in 11 European countries and nine different languages.

Bidlet chairman Peter Sederowsky is expected to take up the post of non-executive director vacated by Mr Jackson. QXL shares closed down 9% at £13.32 after a 30% jump on Friday.

fields.headline: 'Golden hellos' in Met recruit drive
fields.trailText: New recruits to the Metropolitan police are to receive "golden hellos" as part of a £285m "crime fighting package" detailed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.
fields.body:
New recruits to the Metropolitan police are to receive "golden hellos" as part of a £285m "crime fighting package" detailed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.

The extra money, which was the Home Office's allocation in the Budget, is also to be used to accelerate the recruitment of 5,000 officers over the next two years instead of over three years as envisaged by Mr Straw last year at the Labour party conference.

Mr Straw said, however, that despite the extra intake he could not guarantee police numbers would not be lower at the next election than when Labour took office in May 1997.

The extra Treasury funds will also be used to step up the pace of technological change across the criminal justice system with the introduction of video-taping of police interviews and a government centre to eavesdrop on email messages and other types of electronic communication.

The police service will receive £91m of the extra £285m, some £11m of which will be used on recruitment.

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, has complained that the cost of living in the south-east of England has badly affected police recruitment in London. Each month the Met needs to take in 150 recruits but it has only been able to attract between 50 and 90. One recent graduate training course at Bramshill police college had to be cancelled because of lack of interest.

Mr Straw said the problem was not to do with the image of the police after the Stephen Lawrence murder case; the police in the capital were still getting each year about 48,000 inquiries concerned with joining up. However, the numbers actually joining had dropped sharply, partly, he said, because a housing allowance for Met officers was abolished.

The home secretary now intends to restore the value of this lost housing allowance for recruits and those who joined in the past six years.

The recruitment drive across England and Wales means that an extra 2,000 will join the forces this year instead of the 1,000 at first planned. Next year there will be an extra 3,000, instead of 2,000.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said Labour was still failing to get more officers back on the beat. "Two weeks ago the Home Office predicted police numbers would continue to fall over the next year so that by March 2001 they would be 2,600 lower than at the last general election. Even with this money it is extremely unlikely that police numbers will recover, let alone increase."

fields.headline: Banks consider ATM phone top-ups
fields.trailText: Millions of people with pre-paid mobile phones will soon be able to top up their call time at cash machines (ATMs) under a scheme being discussed by banks today.
fields.body:
Millions of people with pre-paid mobile phones will soon be able to top up their call time at cash machines (ATMs) under a scheme being discussed by banks today.

Building societies and banks belonging to the Link cash machine network are also expected to rule out the possibility of customers being double charged for withdrawing from cash machines, following an outcry over their plans to introduce surcharges for customers of rival banks who use their machines.

The phone plan will help to improve the banks' image. Sources say the proposals is already at an "advanced stage" of planning and could potentially allow people to add credit to their mobiles at up to 27,000 cash machines across the country, thereby freeing them up from having to buy top-up vouchers from shops.

The scheme would involve banks and societies linking up with the mobile phone companies, which would probably issue customers with special cards that would enable them to transfer money from their bank accounts to increase their call time, a banking source explained.

The idea has been agreed in principle and it is now a case of sorting out the various technical aspects and getting the phone companies interested. "Apparently most of them are [interested]," he said.

Pre-paid phones are the fastest-growing sector of the mobile phone market. In order to obtain call time, a customer typically buys a voucher from a retailer and then has to ring the phone company and tap in a special number. This automatically tops up the phone with the credit purchased.

John Hardy, chief executive of Link, declined to comment on the scheme but said a whole range of subjects was under discussion on "bringing forward additional value services at ATMs".

At today's Link meeting in Harrogate members will consider a recommendation which, if passed, would put an end to the threat of people using other banks' machines facing both a disloyalty charge from their own bank and a surcharge from the institution owning the machine.

Those opposing charges yesterday stepped up their campaign, with Yorkshire building society presenting trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers with a 100,000-signature petition calling for a ban on new charges for withdrawals.

fields.headline: Anarchists at play
fields.standfirst:
Chumbawumba
Duchess of York, Leeds
***
fields.trailText: Chumbawumba, Duchess of York, Leeds
fields.body:
"I get knocked down," they sing, "and I get up again." Not, though, if you are the legendary Duchess venue, due to be knocked down next week after 12 years playing host to the likes of Nirvana and The Verve.

Local heroes turned international hitmakers, Chumbawumba are the last to play, although this is less a riotous send-off than a downbeat goodbye. The nature of the event puts a noticeable damper on the atmosphere. In the toilets, people frantically graffiti "Farewell, Duchess". In the audience, l half expect someone to cry.

It's left to Chumbawumba to raise the spirits, and if a crowd can't rouse themselves to a 10-piece band of anarchist punk rockers armed with a brass section and gold lamé outfits, there must be something wrong with them.

Actually, there is something wrong with them - as if preparing for their fate, the Duchess's beer pumps have given up the ghost.

Mind you, the Chumbas themselves also sound a little creaky. It is almost three years since the working-class pride anthem-cum-terrace chant Tubthumping took the veteran pranksters to the top of the charts, and they have yet to recover. What do a bunch of anarchist former squatters do when they come in to a truck load of money? Put themselves in storage?

Still, as a clutch of new songs show that their mischievous pop nous is undiminished, things begin to levitate. She's Got All the Friends may be trivial (a rant at Tara Palmer-Tomkinson), but it is deliciously singable and viciously funny. Equally wickedly, a musical list of the band's hate figures manages to somehow equate the Manics' Nicky Wire with General Pinochet.

Beneath the mischief, though, there's genuine danger when Enough Is Enough (dedicated to events in Vienna) advocates the murder of fascists. Genuine pop terrorism, but not quite as scary as when Duchess promoter John Keenan - dressed as Elvis - joins the band to wail, excruciatingly, the Stranglers' Duchess. It's business as usual for Chumbawumba, the end of an era, and, hopefully, the end of an Elvis.

Chumbawumba play Rocket, London N7, tonight. Box office: 0171-753 3200.

fields.headline: Painful requiems
fields.standfirst:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/Davis
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: BBC Symphony Orchestra/Davis, Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
The 20th century didn't exactly have the best track record in historical terms. War and devastation, the waste of lives prematurely lost, persecution, dispossession and exile form the grim catalogue of events. So it's not surprising that the musical response to such experiences have produced some of the most searing works ever written. Andrew Davis's outstanding BBC concert pulled together three pieces which all confront the horror and attempt to counterbalance it by asserting the fundamental human right to individual dignity.

Mark-Anthony Turnage's Silent Cities was inspired by a visit to war graves on the Somme, but instead of conjuring up a landscape of countless sepulchres, he gives back to the dead an accusatory voice. A jazz theme represents the life which political intransigence denied to millions. Dismembered into a myriad fragments, it rises from Turnage's deep nocturne as a terrifying, babbling ululation of rage. It is deeply disquieting stuff. The performance, rightly, subordinated virtuoso playing (of which there was plenty) to emotional ferocity.

The Concerto for Orchestra was the first major score Bartok produced after the Nazi invasion of Hungary forced him into exile in the United States. Many conductors treat it as an ebullient expression of newly found freedom, though Davis is more cautious. He imbues the work with a sense of pained nostalgia. The Hungarian folk melodies flicker in and out of focus like memories of a despoiled Eden. Only in the finale does sorrow finally find release in joy.

The trigger for Berg's Violin Concerto was more acutely personal. Dedicated to "the memory of an angel", it is essentially a requiem for Manon Gropius, the teenage daughter of Berg's friend Walter Gropius and Alma Mahler, though it's also Berg's final statement of his own commitment to the 12-tone compositional system of Schoenberg - a system already under threat from the Nazis, who condemned it as "degenerate".

The soloist was the fabulous Greek violinist Leonidas Kavakos, infinitely expressive and wonderfully pure-toned, a consoling figure who gradually manages to assuage the orchestra's seemingly inconsolable grief. The final section - in which Berg quotes a Bach chorale while the violinist gently seems to usher Manon's soul into a realm of infinite peace - had many of the audience (me included) in tears, as it should.

fields.headline: Blah
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

After a major reorganisation, our chief executive is retiring and this has created a lot of uncertainty and dramatically lowered morale. Two people (out of a staff of 20) have already handed in their notices and more are attending interviews. Since the reorganisation, my role has been undermined and I am no longer performing many of the functions for which I was employed.

I report directly to the chief executive and I am nervous that my role may change permanently if I do not act to stop it.

The solution

This is a classic case of an organisation's poor management of change. However, there is not an awful lot you can do to safeguard your position, which is why so many of your colleagues are looking to leave. Although an employer cannot legally change the terms of your contract (which is effectively what they are doing if you are no longer doing the job you were employed to do) without negotiation with you, they could argue that it is reasonable for your job role to change. For instance, the reorganisation may mean that some of your former tasks are no longer necessary and thus you are having to perform different ones.

You don't have much choice but to put up with it. Had you been there more than one year, you could, in theory, have left and tried to claim constructive dismissal, but even then this would have been hard to prove. All you can do is to try and negotiate with the new chief exec as and when he or she is appointed. You will need to use all your impression management, communication and negotiating skills to try and convince the new boss that what you were doing before will work just as well now. Whilst I rarely recommend my own books, Psychology Goes to Work (see below) could help you with this.

If, at the end of the day, it all goes pear-shaped, I advise you to hang on in there for another year and then start looking to leave like your colleagues. But, you never know, your new boss might sing from the same hymn book as you.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Scottish Premier League round-up
fields.trailText: Millar's tale
fields.body:
Millar's tale

The new signing Marc Millar made an incredible start to his St Johnstone career with a dramatic late winner to give the home side a 2-1 victory over Dundee.

Gary Bollan had put Saints ahead in the first half only to see his goal cancelled out two minutes after the restart by Dundee's Willie Falconer. With time nearly up the substitute Millar - only on the park for nine minutes - hit a glorious 25-yard shot giving the goalkeeper Robert Douglas no chance.

After a week to forget for Aberdeen, the Pittodrie side at least stopped the rot with a 1-1 draw at Dundee United. Ebbe Skovdahl's men lost to Celtic in the CIS Cup final and were then crushed by Hearts in the league. But Joaquim Ferraz's 27th-minute header frustrated the visitors after Arild Stavrum's early goal. The draw keeps the Dons at the foot of the table.

A goal early in the second half from the French striker Jerome Vareille gave Killie three valuable points against Hibernian. Ally McCoist started for the first time since breaking his leg in October but he limped off after 15 minutes with a calf injury.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Chester go nap
fields.body:
Chester go nap

The bottom club Chester managed their biggest win of the season, a 5-0 defeat of Mansfield, to move within a point of Carlisle, 3-2 losers at Rochdale but still with three games in hand. Shrewsbury, managed by the former Chester No1 Kevin Ratcliffe, lost 4-2 at Macclesfield and and are now only three points clear of the Deeside club but with a game in hand.

 Third-placed Darlington made up ground on the leaders with a 1-0 win at Hull, where Lee Nogan scored on the stroke of half-time. The top club Rotherham were held 1-1 at home to Peterborough and Swansea played out a 0-0 draw with their visitors, Leyton Orient.

 Northampton moved into fourth place with a 2-0 win over visiting Southend thanks to goals from Dave Savage and Jamie Forrester, who signed from Utrecht on transfer-deadline day.

 Barnet stay in sixth place despite going down 1-0 at home to Brighton , Gary Hart getting the goal before Mark Arber was dismissed for the home side after 79 minutes for his second bookable offence.

 Exeter slipped deeper into trouble at the wrong end of the table with a 2-1 home defeat by Cheltenham, who moved into seventh place and above Hartlepool, 2-1 losers at York.

 In the West Country derby a hat-trick from Paul McGregor helped Plymouth to a 4-0 win at Torquay, their fourth away victory of the season moving them up into ninth place.

The top club Rotherham were held 1-1 at home to Peterborough and Swansea played out a 0-0 draw with their visitors, Leyton Orient.  Northampton moved into fourth place with a 2-0 win over visiting Southend thanks to goals from Dave Savage and Jamie Forrester, who signed from Utrecht on transfer-deadline day.  Barnet stay in sixth place despite going down 1-0 at home to Brighton , Gary Hart getting the goal before Mark Arber was dismissed for the home side after 79 minutes for his second bookable offence.  Exeter slipped deeper into trouble at the wrong end of the table with a 2-1 home defeat by Cheltenham, who moved into seventh place and above Hartlepool, 2-1 losers at York.  In the West Country derby a hat-trick from Paul McGregor helped Plymouth to a 4-0 win at Torquay, their fourth away victory of the season moving them up into ninth place.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Wild Rovers
fields.body:
Wild Rovers

Bristol Rovers' manager Ian Holloway did not seem disturbed by his team's 3-0 defeat at Millwall. "All my friends will wonder what's the matter with Holloway but I was very pleased with today's performance," he said. "I couldn't have asked any more from my side."

Rovers have fallen four points behind Preston at the top of the table after two defeats in a week. "We've got to put the ball in the back of the net, which has not been a problem until this week," Holloway said.

Nathan Ellington hit the post early on but Millwall survived to take the lead with Neil Harris's 17th goal of the season.

 Iain Anderson, the Scottish winger on loan from Toulouse , scored Preston's winner for the second time in a week. His 20-yard drive soon after half-time gave the leaders a 1-0 win over Wrexham.

 Neil Redfearn, the veteran midfielder more accustomed to relegation struggles than promotion chases, scored Wigan's goals in their 2-0 win over Notts County, his first since his £112,000 move from Bradford City this month.

 Bjarni Gudjonsson scored his first goals for Stoke and won the man-of-the-match award in the 3-0 win over Blackpool. The Iceland international striker, the son of the Stoke manager Gudjon Thordarson, scored his first from close range and his second from 20 yards to begin and end a burst of three Stoke goals in nine second-half minutes.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Wolves falter
fields.body:
Wolves falter

Wolves are four points adrift of the play-off places after they could manage only a draw at home to Stockport. County's manager Andy Kilner, though, felt his side deserved all three points.

"We were cheated out of it by the referee," said Kilner. "We have been done by the small-club syndrome. The penalty was two yards outside the area and our keeper was fouled for the second goal. But we are only Stockport so we don't get it."

Neil Emblen's last-minute equaliser condemned Stockport to an unwanted club record of 16 matches without a win.

 Huddersfield remain in the top six after a 3-0 win over Crewe. Kevin Gray opened the scoring and Chris Beech's double secured victory. "These are exciting times and we should enjoy them," said the manager Steve Bruce.

webTitle: A loud appeal for Lara's return

fields.headline: A loud appeal for Lara's return
fields.standfirst: West Indies top order fails once more in the absence of their former captain
fields.trailText: Yet another unimpressive top-order batting performance had the West Indies at 228 for seven before tea against a weakened Zimbabwe attack here in Jamaica on the third day of the second Test. Indeed it had the former coach and current radio commentator Sir Vivian Richards calling on air for the former captain Brian Lara's return in time for the forthcoming Test series against Pakistan.
fields.body:
Yet another unimpressive top-order batting performance had the West Indies at 228 for seven before tea against a weakened Zimbabwe attack here in Jamaica on the third day of the second Test. Indeed it had the former coach and current radio commentator Sir Vivian Richards calling on air for the former captain Brian Lara's return in time for the forthcoming Test series against Pakistan.

On a batting pitch good enough to prevent Courtney Walsh, Curtly Ambrose, Franklyn Rose or Reon King getting Zimbabwe's No11 Henry Olonga out after 79 minutes of trying, the West Indies batsmen, apart from Sherwin Campbell and Ridley Jacobs, looked tentative.

Only Campbell, Jimmy Adams, Rose and Jacobs got past 15 moreover, with the latter lucky to survive an appeal that would have had him caught off the first ball he faced from the leg-spinner Brian Murphy. He went on to make 27.

Lara, for personal reasons, took a break from cricket at the beginning of Zimbabwe's visit, declaring his hope of returning a better player and in time for the England tour, which begins in June. But the unspectacular Windies batting, if that is not too bold a word to describe an activity that has yielded a sub-200 score 27 times in the past 20 Tests, persuaded Richards repeatedly to express the hope that the double world-record holder will sort his problems out before Pakistan get to the Caribbean on Sunday.

The leading commentator Tony Cozier and the long-serving broadcaster Joseph "Reds" Perreira concurred that should he be willing, Lara must return as soon as possible.

Cozier suggested he could be picked for a warm-up match against Pakistan, before the first Test that starts on May 5. Perreira thought Lara could play in the triangular one-day tournament, which begins here on Saturday.

However the former Test fast bowler Michael Holding feels that no pressure should be put on the former captain to do anything other than concentrate on solving his problems, a view not shared by Colin Croft, who thinks that Lara, having expressed a clear intention to stay away from cricket until the England tour, should not return before then.

Croft, one of few commentators in the Caribbean who believes that the coincidence of the Trinidad Carnival - at which Lara traditionally plays an active part - had nothing to do with his decision to opt out of the Zimbabwe tour, added that if Lara came back before the England tour he would have to reconsider his view that the former captain had taken a break to rest.

fields.headline: Relentless Waugh feeds record-breaking habit
fields.trailText: Australia's captain Steve Waugh yesterday became the first man to score 150 against all eight other Test-playing nations, at the same time propelling his side towards an equally prestigious record.
fields.body:
Australia's captain Steve Waugh yesterday became the first man to score 150 against all eight other Test-playing nations, at the same time propelling his side towards an equally prestigious record.

With two days to go in the second Test against New Zealand at Wellington, Australia are on target to win their ninth Test in a row - which would eclipse the national record of eight straight wins by Warwick Armstrong's 1920-21 side.

Standing in the way are Chris Cairns, the first-'innings century-maker, and the Kiwi captain Stephen Fleming. The pair have so far added 105, giving New Zealand a slender lead of 68 runs with five second- innings wickets in hand.

Waugh had earlier carried his score to 151 not out, thanks to support from Damien Martyn and batting bunny Glenn McGrath, who hung around long enough to help his skipper past the landmark. "I can't see it [the record] going to 200," Waugh joked later. "It's nice to have the record and that will take some beating."

New Zealand were in danger of losing inside three days as Brett Lee and Shane Warne ripped through the top-order. But then Cairns revived memories of his bludgeoning father Lance, thudding six sixes and three fours in an unbeaten 61 from 65 balls. "He was similar to Ian Botham at his peak," Waugh observed. "He's obviously not that fragile, is he?"

webTitle: Blues to lose Babayaro for Olympics

fields.headline: Blues to lose Babayaro for Olympics
fields.trailText: Chelsea may lose the services of Celestine Babayaro for up to four weeks at the start of next season, after Nigeria's qualification for the Olympic finals.
fields.body:
Chelsea may lose the services of Celestine Babayaro for up to four weeks at the start of next season, after Nigeria's qualification for the Olympic finals.

The Blues have clashed twice with the Nigerian Football Association in the past couple of months over international call-ups for the full-back. He missed a month in January and February to take part in the African Nations Cup, only to return more than a week late after the final.

Then he was called up for the under-23 side's final Olympic qualifying match this weekend, only to pull out with a groin injury. The Nigerian FA's protest was overruled by Fifa and he therefore missed yesterday's game against Zimbabwe, but Nigeria, the reigning champions, still qualified with a 4-0 win - their final goal deep into injury-time ensuring they finished ahead of Angola on goal difference.

Nigeria will almost certainly ask Babayaro to play in Australia. Chelsea therefore may be required to release him on September 4, 10 days before the tournament begins, and he could be involved until the final on October 1.

Croydon beat Leeds United 2-1 to reach the FA Women's Cup final where they will meet the eight-times winners Doncaster Belles.

webTitle: Undaunted Watford still high on believing

fields.headline: Undaunted Watford still high on believing
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 1 Tottenham
fields.body:
The Elton John song of the day here was Daniel. Perhaps Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds, the Watford chairman's version of the Beatles' tribute to LSD, would have been more appropriate.

Only someone who has taken plenty of it would believe that Watford will avoid relegation or that Tottenham can challenge for major honours.

A match of few highs was kicked into life in the 52nd minute, following Chris Armstrong's fortunate opener. The Watford goalkeeper Alec Chamberlain, who had made three excellent saves, attempted to clear a Stephen Clemence through-ball only to see it rebound off Armstrong.

The striker, who had missed an open goal early in the first half, managed to steer the ball into the unguarded net for his fifth goal in as many games.

Tottenham's dominance, particulary in midfield where Darren Anderton and David Ginola ran the show, saw them create enough chances to secure victory. This is the third time in recent matches that the north Londoners have failed to take maximum points from teams in the relegation zone, leaving the manager George Graham to moan afterwards that Spurs should be at least six points better off.

"It seems to be getting a habit. There was not enough quality in the attack, it seems to be the same old disease," said Graham reciting the same old excuse.

Watford's main threat came from the midfielder Nordin Wooter, who provided the pass for the 78th-minute equaliser. The Dutchman weaved into the Tottenham box and Allan Smart sneaked in behind a static defence to flick the ball over an advancing Ian Walker.

It was no less than Watford deserved. Smart had missed an easier chance early in the first half, shooting straight at Walker, and Watford always looked capable of salvaging something with Spurs failing to take their chances.

Graham hinted afterwards that the best his team could hope for is a top-six finish; Watford are playing like a team that already know their destiny: they are going to go down but they might as well go down fighting.

Next up for the Hornets are Everton away followed by major encounters against Derby and Southampton.

"We have to take nine points from those matches," said Graham Taylor, in optimistic mood. "Then we face Arsenal, Manchester United and Leeds. We finish the season with Coventry at home. Who knows, we might even qualify for Europe?"

Now they must be putting something suspect in the tea at Vicarage Road.

webTitle: Sky blues fall in on Ogrizovic

fields.headline: Sky blues fall in on Ogrizovic
fields.trailText: Arsenal 3 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
Arsenal completed a run of nine games in 28 days yesterday with what any team faced with such a punishing schedule deserves: a breather.

That is what a home match against Coventry represents these days, for Gordon Strachan's team are the only side in the four divisions not to have won away, and the ineptitude of yesterday's performance went a long way to explaining why.

The comprehensive nature of Arsenal's victory, which lifted them to fourth in the table and a little closer to the Champions League qualifying spot they covet, was never reflected in the scoreline.

Only a series of acrobatic saves from Steve Ogrizovic that no normal 42-year-old should think about attempting kept the Arsenal tally below double figures.

In the first half the Uefa Cup semi-finalists had been struggling to break down Coventry's massed defence. But in the second half they raised a gear and grew stronger the longer the game went on. Goals from Thierry Henry, Gilles Grimandi and Nwankwo Kanu pocketed the points and left Strachan with nowhere to hide.

"We were beaten by a more intelligent team, a quicker team, a better team," he was honest enough to admit. "It was a non-event for us and disappointing when you know you've wasted a week at training."

As for an explanation of his side's desperate away form, Strachan remains stumped. "If I knew what the answer was I wouldn't have spent the last nine months worrying about it. Maybe we're not used to not worrying about relegation. Maybe we're missing the thrill of everyone's job being on the line."

At least in the first half Coventry mounted some resistance, with six men regularly funnelling back into their area to prevent Arsenal - welcoming back David Seaman, Dennis Bergkamp and Emmanuel Petit from injury - profiting from their endless possession.

It took the home team half an hour to test Ogrizovic, playing his first senior game since December 1998, but the veteran goalkeeper, called up at the last minute after Magnus Hedman suffered a back spasm, was soon repairing the reputation of oldie goalies everywhere following Neville Southall's recent flabby appearance for Bradford.

His first save was a well-timed block from Thursday's hat-trick hero against Werder Bremen, Ray Parlour; his second a flying one-handed stop to deny Oleg Luzhny. Shortly after the break he thwarted Marc Overmars, who had been released by Bergkamp's sumptuous through-pass.

However, three minutes later, Ogrizovic was once again left exposed by his uncoordinated back four as Patrick Vieira's through-ball found Thierry Henry, who tucked away his 18th goal of the season

Arsenal were now in the mood, but so was Ogrizovic. Petit, influential all afternoon, curled in a 25-yard free-kick that the goalkeeper pushed wide. Then when then the Frenchman hit the post it rebounded to Overmars, whose shot found Ogrizovic's giant frame arriving in the nick of time.

The second oldest keeper to play in the Premiership behind John Burridge then outdid himself with a one-handed tip-away to deny an 18-yard first-time shot from the unbelieving Overmars. However on 78 minutes Arsenal, with some inevitably, increased their lead when Petit's free-kick was half-cleared to Grimandi, who scored from close range.

And though Ogrizovic blocked well from Overmars - yet again - and Fredrik Ljungberg, Arsenal's ability to spring Coventry's offside trap brought the home side a third goal. The through-ball was Petit's, the cool finish Kanu's.

So the points went to Arsenal. The absence of the injured Martin Keown and Tony Adams was hardly noticed. But the plaudits went to Ogrizovic. "He was a bit nervous before the kick-off," said Strachan. "It was like a debut for him. But he was a credit to himself and proved what a great servant he is of this club."

Arsenal's run-in: Apr 1 Wimbledon (a); Apr 16 Leeds (a); Apr 23 Watford (a) Apr 29 Everton (a); May 2 West Ham (h); May 6 Chelsea (h); May 14 Newcastle (a). TBA Sheffield Wednesday (h).

Only a series of acrobatic saves from Steve Ogrizovic that no normal 42-year-old should think about attempting kept the Arsenal tally below double figures. In the first half the Uefa Cup semi-finalists had been struggling to break down Coventry's massed defence. But in the second half they raised a gear and grew stronger the longer the game went on. Goals from Thierry Henry, Gilles Grimandi and Nwankwo Kanu pocketed the points and left Strachan with nowhere to hide. "We were beaten by a more intelligent team, a quicker team, a better team," he was honest enough to admit. "It was a non-event for us and disappointing when you know you've wasted a week at training." As for an explanation of his side's desperate away form, Strachan remains stumped. "If I knew what the answer was I wouldn't have spent the last nine months worrying about it. Maybe we're not used to not worrying about relegation. Maybe we're missing the thrill of everyone's job being on the line." At least in the first half Coventry mounted some resistance, with six men regularly funnelling back into their area to prevent Arsenal - welcoming back David Seaman, Dennis Bergkamp and Emmanuel Petit from injury - profiting from their endless possession. It took the home team half an hour to test Ogrizovic, playing his first senior game since December 1998, but the veteran goalkeeper, called up at the last minute after Magnus Hedman suffered a back spasm, was soon repairing the reputation of oldie goalies everywhere following Neville Southall's recent flabby appearance for Bradford. His first save was a well-timed block from Thursday's hat-trick hero against Werder Bremen, Ray Parlour; his second a flying one-handed stop to deny Oleg Luzhny. Shortly after the break he thwarted Marc Overmars, who had been released by Bergkamp's sumptuous through-pass. However, three minutes later, Ogrizovic was once again left exposed by his uncoordinated back four as Patrick Vieira's through-ball found Thierry Henry, who tucked away his 18th goal of the season Arsenal were now in the mood, but so was Ogrizovic. Petit, influential all afternoon, curled in a 25-yard free-kick that the goalkeeper pushed wide. Then when then the Frenchman hit the post it rebounded to Overmars, whose shot found Ogrizovic's giant frame arriving in the nick of time. The second oldest keeper to play in the Premiership behind John Burridge then outdid himself with a one-handed tip-away to deny an 18-yard first-time shot from the unbelieving Overmars. However on 78 minutes Arsenal, with some inevitably, increased their lead when Petit's free-kick was half-cleared to Grimandi, who scored from close range. And though Ogrizovic blocked well from Overmars - yet again - and Fredrik Ljungberg, Arsenal's ability to spring Coventry's offside trap brought the home side a third goal. The through-ball was Petit's, the cool finish Kanu's. So the points went to Arsenal. The absence of the injured Martin Keown and Tony Adams was hardly noticed. But the plaudits went to Ogrizovic. "He was a bit nervous before the kick-off," said Strachan. "It was like a debut for him. But he was a credit to himself and proved what a great servant he is of this club." fields.headline: Shreeves mixes his semaphores
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 1 - 0 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
Just after half-time Peter Shreeves ventured from his dugout and mimed the forward defensive stroke. The signal was lost even on his English players. It was a puzzling afternoon.

Shreeves, replacing Danny Wilson on Tuesday, had nine games to save Wednesday, eight points to make up. He needs wins. He had only Gilles de Bilde up. Later he said: "I feel terrific." It was a whistle in the dark of the caretaker's hutch.

As a job contender Shreeves is an employer's dream. He never applies. "If they want me, they'll contact me," he said. They found him last week jogging, which was as energetic as Wim Jonk got. The rest did not lack effort, just confidence and cohesion.

Shreeves said: "The organisation was excellent. I was delighted." The organisation was summed up by Peter Atherton's back-pass that sent Kevin Pressman turning from simple collection 18 yards out to desperate dash and sliding flip off his line.

Pressman, nursing a groin strain and not built for acceleration, could have been penalised for handling but the referee was probably laughing too much to blow. The goalkeeper heroically disentangled himself from the net to block Juninho's follow-up shot.

It was the second time Andy d'Urso was lenient to Pressman, the second the keeper had denied Juninho. The first was from a penalty, conceded as he floored Andy Campbell, who had earlier scored with a chip. Pressman escaped with a yellow card, Juninho with a half-time rocket. "If Christian Ziege's on the pitch, he's the penalty-taker," said Bryan Robson. Juninho fluffed D'Urso's award at Old Trafford, too.

It did not matter here as Wednesday are the Premiership's shyest shooters. With 12 points from six games Boro must now be safe. Robson has to keep them together for only a couple of years to take the veterans' event by storm.

By then Shreeves will surely have moved on again. Last time in charge at Hillsborough he won his only match 5-0 against Bolton. Last week he said: "I'm always interested in staying employed." But who would wish to with a club under the influence of New Labour's control freakery? Already they have higher-profile designs: Joe Kinnear or Howard Wilkinson.

Shreeves, whatever he says, seems happiest out of the driving seat, as coach or No2. On Saturday, uneasy in dark suit, he wore the anxious visage of a fish that has been out of water a fraction too long. Glad to be back in the swim, he has earned his prefix "much-travelled". His other job is a taxi-driver. Now he has 10 days to crack the puzzle of real organisation.

webTitle: Phillips signs up with solo sensation

fields.headline: Phillips signs up with solo sensation
fields.trailText: Sunderland 2 - 1 Everton
fields.byline: David Hopps  at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Sunderland have strung together no more brilliant move all year than the one where Peter Reid deftly slipped a new five-year contract into Kevin Phillips' path and, with the eye of a natural goalscorer, he finished it off with a single flourish.

Compared to that, the build-up to Phillips' spectacular winning goal against Everton on Saturday was hardly worth mentioning. It owed everything to the quick-wittedness of a striker who these days is left to fend largely for himself: a random chance on the left edge of the area, an instantaneous curled finish into the top corner for his 26th goal of the season and an afternoon wonderfully transformed.

Phillips may one day regret his decision to remain on Wearside. Remove his talents and Sunderland have the air of a deteriorating side who want nothing more than the season to end as quickly as possible.

Reid can rarely have been booed as unforgivingly as when he briefly appeared on the touchline to berate his struggling side. This is the manager who had virtually secured Sunderland's Premiership status by Christmas, but 11 matches without a win had left few supporters willing to take the long-term view.

No fans reflect upon the game more loudly at the final whistle than Sunderland's. "They were getting anxious, we needed that," bellowed one man. "Phillips got us out of jail, the rest were useless," said another. This was the triumph of a goalscorer, not his team.

Much of Sunderland's work remained unimpressive. Nicky Summerbee's seventh-minute goal, a free-kick from 20 yards which wormed past Paul Gerrard, might have settled them but a collection of miskicks and misunderstandings ensued. Phillips almost scored from one of them, after a mistake by Abel Xavier left him clear, and probably would have done had he not just been tying his bootlace.

But there are signs that Sunderland are starting to recognise the strengths of Kevin Kilbane who, on the few occasions he was given the ball at speed, promised to barge aside all who stood in his way. To ask him to beat a full-back from a standing start, however, is a waste of time.

When Nick Barmby flayed in an equaliser from 20 yards, Everton might have won. But, as their manager Walter Smith said: "Phillips was the difference." Sympathy should not be wasted, however, on a side that tackles its problems with a loan deal for a 36-year-old striker. It is a common British fault to place faith in those who have "been there, done that", rather than those half their age who are desperate to prove themselves.

So it was that, when John Collins flicked the ball over Sunderland's defence, Mark Hughes' bullocking volley flew off target when, five years ago, he would probably have scored. Journeys down memory lane rarely finish where everybody would like them to.

webTitle: Peerless Beckham eases United into spring overdrive

fields.headline: Peerless Beckham eases United into spring overdrive
fields.trailText: Braford 0 - 4 Man Utd
fields.body:
The open-top bus has not been booked just yet but it is surely only a question of time. Manchester United have finally come to the boil and those with the audacity to challenge their authority are in danger of having their fingers burned.

With United in this tyrannical frame of mind, the rest of the Premiership might as well hoist the white flag.

Certainly their sense of timing is impeccable. For long spells they have shuffled along rather than gliding imperiously with the majestic strides of last season. Now, with the stakes increasing at home and abroad, they are coasting.

The Real Madrid coach Vincente del Bosque had his infiltrators in west Yorkshire and the verdict will prompt much consternation inside the Spanish camp ahead of their Champions League quarter-final on Wednesday week.

Not only are United fast approaching their exhilarating best but Dwight Yorke will be available after negotiating his release from international duty with Trinidad and Tobago, while David Beckham is producing the form that makes him the finest natural footballer in this country.

If Beckham had been culpable of going through the motions earlier in the season, his focus has been restored and he is playing with the carefree abandon of someone who could float a 60-yard pass into a basketball hoop. This was his most peerless performance this season, scoring one and being an accomplice to the other three.

Even those with an in-built disposition against United were converted by the cohesion of Ferguson's team. The barracking that had accompanied Beckham's every touch was replaced by a hushed anxiety. Ryan Giggs was applauded off when he was substituted. And when Paul Scholes lashed in a sumptuous right-foot volley from Beckham's corner, a gasp of incredulity engulfed Valley Parade.

Scholes's goal was the pièce de résistance in a match which had started sluggishly for the champions-elect before a quick one-two late in the first half from Yorke rendered the outcome a foregone conclusion. Beckham completed the rout.

"It's simple really, if we keep winning our games no one will be able to catch us," said Ferguson. "We're finding the form of last season and the sense of the big occasion is finally getting through to the players."

For Bradford, there are two morals. First, that it is no disgrace to lose so heavily to a team of United's im mense resources; and second, Jorge Cadete is not going to live up to his billing as the saviour of their season.

Whether they can haul themselves out of the quicksand depends on how they fare in the next three home games against Southampton, Derby and Wimbledon.

As David Wetherall put it: "The only thing we can take out of this game is that at least we won't have to play them again."

webTitle: Houllier has firm hand on Anfield tiller

fields.headline: Houllier has firm hand on Anfield tiller
fields.trailText: LIverpool 2 - 1 Newcastle
fields.body:
At the end of a period of improbable upheavals it always seemed likely that Gérard Houllier would underscore the fact that he is a man for all seasons and not only the one currently scurrying towards its end.

His position as Liverpool manager was not reinforced by the announcement that his long-time friend and confidant Peter Robinson was to divorce himself from his beloved club this summer. Indeed it possibly prompted Houllier to consider, fleetingly, his own future at Anfield.

Whether Robinson was the victim of a political spat is now irrelevant, for once his departure had been confirmed the onus was on Houllier to mark out his territory, to announce by way of firm deed that, even if the king-maker had been slain, the king lived on.

This he did on Friday by putting down a well-heeled foot with sufficient force to send ripples of disquiet through the previously orderly world of Michael Owen.

The striker, believing he was at last free of the hamstring trouble which has all but ruined his season, wanted to play here. Houllier was having none of it, opting to rest him.

After a win which confirmed Liverpool's candidature for one of next season's Champions League berths, Houllier insisted that Owen had not suffered another physical setback, and by implication that he had gambled by asking his potent striker to wear a frown rather than boots.

"There's nothing wrong with his hamstrings; he's fine, he'll be OK," said the Frenchman. "I just felt he wouldn't be as fresh today as I would have liked."

The inevitable question about Owen's availability for this summer's European Championship was comfortably fielded by Houllier. "The most beneficial thing for Michael would be to be fit and to play in Euro 2000," he said with sufficient volume to attract the attention of the England coach Kevin Keegan, who was pumping hands in the corridor outside.

If the news of Owen's health will have delighted Keegan, that joy will have been tempered by the performance of the youngster's possible long-term partner for both club and country, Emile Heskey.

Liverpool are only now truly feeling the loss of Owen and Robbie Fowler, which is perverse when they have recently invested the small matter of £11m on Heskey, the forward with a fascination for wing-play.

Heskey's contribution was again disappointing: he was a peripheral figure and, worse, one who is already looking decidedly uncomfortable with his new status. He has the ability, he has the desire; we shall simply have to be patient.

Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson, though disappointed, has been around the block sufficient times to appreciate that not all defeats sustained in the dying seconds are unfortunate or unfair.

"There is no doubt Liverpool had a larger percentage of the ball but I thought we played quite well in the last 20 minutes," he said. "But there is nothing to be really mournful about. We set out to maintain our Premiership status and we have done that."

One of only two Newcastle efforts on target went in, Alan Shearer's fine header from an Aaron Hughes cross on 67 minutes eluding everyone to cancel out Titi Camara's proficient finish 16 minutes earlier.

Liverpool appeared to have tossed away another two points until Jamie Redknapp, a late substitute, rose splendidly to send a firm header from Danny Murphy's corner looping into the roof of the net via Warren Barton's forehead two minutes from time.

It was no more than Liverpool deserved and as Redknapp milked the applause, as Houllier punched the air in glee, Owen left his seat in the main stand, probably muttering something about life's unfairness.

Liverpool's run-in: April 1 Coventry (a), April 9 Tottenham (h), April 16 Wimbledon (a), April 21 Everton (a), April 29 Chelsea (a). May 3 Leicester (h), May 6 Southampton (h), May 14 Bradford (a).

webTitle: Hoddle shows Chelsea the way forward

fields.headline: Hoddle shows Chelsea the way forward
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Southampton
fields.body:
It may have been comforting for Chelsea supporters to hear Glenn Hoddle put their club's week of so-called failure in perspective on Saturday evening. "Seven or eight years ago the fans would never have thought they'd be playing in a Champions League quarter- final against Barcelona," he said. But these are very different times, with much weightier expectations.

The man credited with kick-starting the foreign revolution at the Bridge indeed went on to trumpet his old club's chances of overturning the tournament favourites, citing "their ability to turn it on at the right time". But his argument smacked of diplomacy after his own Southampton side had just exposed Chelsea's weaknesses.

Appropriately, Hoddle planned for this match "like a European tie". He fielded five men in midfield and, on the counter-attack, "waited for the one moment". It arrived, on the breakaway, with Jo Tessem's 25-yard drive.

Chelsea, restoring their captain Dennis Wise among four Englishmen, were indebted to a farcical own-goal by Dean Richards for their point.

Opportunities are trickling through Chelsea's hands and their challenge for Champions League requalification via a top-three place - the bottom line of their season - is receding. Publicly, Gianluca Vialli remains optimistic: "If we try that hard something's going to change, hopefully very soon."

The month of truth is here: in April Chelsea play nine games, the first three shaping their campaign on three fronts. Next Saturday's league visit to Leeds is followed by the home leg with Barcelona and the FA Cup semi-final against Newcastle.

Vialli in midweek was lambasted for his omission of Wise; now he was open to criticism for reverting to the combination of big strikers, Chris Sutton and George Weah. Chelsea fell to the temptation of serving up high crosses, simple fare for Richards and the Moroccan Tahar el Khalej.

"At the moment," sighed Vialli, "we think we can't score or that we are unlucky." He might have been speaking of Sutton, who froze when presented with a tap-in by Albert Ferrer's cross and had two strong penalty claims rejected.

Chelsea, though, were saved by Richards, who headed into his own goal in a three-man mix up also involving El Khalej and the goalkeeper Paul Jones.

Hoddle has now almost completed his immediate mission of keeping Southampton up. But did he regret not continuing the pioneering work he started at Chelsea seven years ago? "I felt success was around the corner but I made the decision to go. Sometimes you get a phone call and you go ... aah. I don't regret for one minute taking on the England job."

Chelsea's run-in: Apr 1 Leeds (a); Apr 12 Coventry (h); Apr 15 Sheff Wed (a); Apr 22 M'boro (h); Apr 24 Man Utd (a); Apr 29 Liverpool 9 (h); May 6 Arsenal (a); May 14 Derby (h).

webTitle: Di Canio and Kanoute make waves

fields.headline: Di Canio and Kanoute make waves
fields.trailText: West Ham 2 - 1 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio lifted both feet off the ground to score with a volley that was breathtaking for its technical execution, its accuracy and especially for its sheer audaciousness. All other contenders for goal of the season can withdraw now, although Harry Redknapp insists the Italian has struck better this season.

From a narrow angle and a distant part of the penalty area it was an outrageous thought to contemplate beating Neil Sullivan without at least one touch to control Trevor Sinclair's driven cross. In the mind of Di Canio such caution is foreign. He called it a "lucky" strike - lucky because "I have tried it many times in training and every time I miss" - but he was fooling no one.

Di Canio's mesmerising performance had the Wimbledon defence tied in knots and only poor finishing, Sullivan's reliability and some inexplicable refereeing decisions prevented them conceding at least four goals for the third time in succession on their travels. Yet this was also a day when Upton Park greeted the arrival of a brand new forward force.

Frédéric Kanoute joined this week on loan from Lyon and the word is it will take around £6m to prise him away from France. That is not an over-valuation on this performance, Redknapp rating it a "fantastic debut, one of the best I have ever seen". Besides scoring a fine second goal, Kanoute led the line with pace, mobility and an instinctive touch. He also hit the bar and had a shot cleared from the line.

There was a spring and a spark to West Ham's football. Sinclair and Frank Lampard both lent generously to the team cause and there was nothing to worry about until Michael Hughes reduced the arrears with a crisp shot 15 minutes from time. It induced a rally of sorts from Egil Olsen's strugglers but any other outcome would have been a serious injustice.

Di Canio got the show off and running on eight minutes and from that moment Wimbledon had not a clue how to take the ball off him. He exploited their indecision to the full, twice setting up Kanoute for earlier opportunities to open his account. Rio Ferdinand also missed from close in and Marc-Vivien Foe had Sullivan struggling to save.

Either side of Kanoute's goal, an astute shot on the turn past the on-rushing goalkeeper after Sinclair had spied a yawning gap, the hosts had three penalty claims denied by Rob Harris. "It's frightening to think he did not give at least one of those," added Redknapp.

Still, it was a day for Harry to savour. "He does that every day in training," said the manager of the Di Canio special. "For me he is the player of the year."

webTitle: Carbone strikes, kisses the crest, then calls Villa 'a joke'

fields.headline: Carbone strikes, kisses the crest, then calls Villa 'a joke'
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 2 - 0 Derby
fields.body:
Aston Villa's manager John Gregory could be forgiven for wishing it had been as easy to get Benito Carbone to sign a long-term contract as it was for the Italian to autograph the pieces of paper pushed under his nose as he sat by the dugout after gracefully giving way to Dion Dublin for the final 10 minutes.

However, there followed a post-match outburst from Carbone, who has reportedly reduced his wage demands to a tax-free £1m a year and a £1,000-a-week rent allowance rather than £40,000 a week. "I thought we were getting very close to tying things up," he said. "Now I find the club have changed everything we have been talking about for the last few weeks. Perhaps they think it is a joke for them. It's not funny.

"The club is a joke. I am ready to break my legs for this club. But with the club having changed everything again, I don't know what is going to happen."

Gregory, having pronounced the parties to be near agreement and his confidence in concluding a deal at the end of the season, is sure to find this latest distraction particularly unwelcome in the run-up to Sunday's FA Cup semi-final with Bolton.

Earlier the manager had expressed his delight at the Italian's badge-kissing antics after running the length of the pitch to celebrate with the Holte End after scoring with a low shot into the corner from outside the area.

"The more Beni scores the more he can push the price up," he said. "He's our player until the end of the season; the longer it goes on, the greater the risk [of missing out on him]. He will not lose out whatever happens."

Quite so. "Are you watching Doug Ellis?" and "Sign him up" was the response of the faithful, who are becoming increasingly annoyed with the wage structure imposed by the chairman, which has previously cost Villa the services of Robbie Keane and Juninho and leaves them as a top-seven club with a nice ground.

It was a pity that this latest spat overshadowed an imperious performance from Paul Merson, Villa's captain for the day who, as well as making Carbone's goal, also hit the bar with a deft chip and then superbly found the head of George Boateng for the second.

"That's what I'm in the team for, to make goals," said Merson. "I think [playing for] England's a bit be yond me now, though. I'll just concentrate on winning the FA Cup for Villa."

So it is eyes down for Sunday and with Dublin likely to begin on the bench but keen to play a full part after making a first appearance since breaking a neck vertebra in December.

Derby, who began to play only when the rested Malcolm Christie came off the bench at 2-0 down, have less to look forward to and the manager Jim Smith has set a safety target of 38 points. Their next two away games, at Watford and Bradford, should prove to be decisive.

Villa's run-in : Apr 5 Sheff Wed (a), Apr 8 Leeds (h), Apr 15 Spurs (a), Apr 22 Leicester (h), Apr 29 Sunderland (h), May 6 Wimbledon (a), May 14 Man Utd (h)

fields.headline: Roma trio hurt in derby
fields.trailText: Brazil, France and Italy were counting the cost yesterday of a bruising Rome derby which deprived all three nations of Roma players for matches this week.
fields.body:
Brazil, France and Italy were counting the cost yesterday of a bruising Rome derby which deprived all three nations of Roma players for matches this week.

The Brazilian right-back Cafu damaged knee ligaments in Roma's 2-1 defeat by Lazio at the Olympic Stadium and pulled out of the party to face Colombia in a World Cup qualifier tomorrow.

France's left-back Vincent Candela hurt his left thigh in an awkward fall and is out of the friendly against Scotland at Hampden Park on Wednesday.

The Italy striker Vincenzo Montella's was also hurt, after putting Roma ahead, and misses Italy's game with Spain in Barcelona on Wednesday.

Pavel Nedved equalised before Juan Veron struck Lazio's winner with a superb free-kick as Sven Goran Eriksson's team cut Juventus's Serie A lead to six points.

In Spain Real Madrid, Manchester United's Champions League opponents next week, were surprisingly held to a 0-0 draw by their city rivals Rayo Vallecano.
