fields.headline: Reuser the last-minute man
fields.trailText: Ipswich 1 - 0 Fulham
fields.body:
Ipswich Town should buy a stake in Lastminute.com. The way the club's luck is running it would probably shore up the share price overnight. Not content with snapping up Martijn Reuser as a last-minute signing on transfer deadline day, Ipswich brought him on as a substitute on Saturday and saw him score the winner in, of course, the last minute.

It was a goal that brought a double whammy. Not only were Ipswich able to tighten their hold on the second promotion slot ahead of Barnsley, who play tonight, and Manchester City; it as good as put paid to Fulham's hopes of reaching a play-off spot.

Their manager Paul Bracewell attempted to be upbeat afterwards: "We've got 21 points to play for and until we're told we can't do it we'll keep plugging away."

But the sight of his players trooping off the pitch with heads bowed told another story and Mohamed Al Fayed is probably out in the back yard of Harrods this morning sharpening his trustiest axe.

Fulham never looked convincing whereas Ipswich, at times, were inspired and the speed of their approach play frequently took the breath away. The only area they were deficient in was in front of goal where David Johnson and Jamie Scowcroft merely served to emphasise that the deadliest goalscorers are in the Premiership. Which is where Reuser comes in.

"I had him watched a few times," said the Ipswich manager George Burley. "We were looking for an attacking midfielder who could score goals and he fitted the bill."

The unheralded Dutchman replaced Jermaine Wright in the 76th minute and a quarter of an hour later he was a household name. Ipswich swept upfield on the counter-attack, Jim Magilton laid the ball off and Reuser took it in his stride to tuck it away confidently under Maik Taylor. It was his first goal in any domestic league this season, though he said he had scored one for Ajax in the Champions League.

"When you get 15 minutes of a game there's a lot of pressure on you and you want to show the people what you can do," he said. "It was just a relief, an unbelievable feeling to score."

Reuser is on loan from Vitesse Arnhem, via Ajax, from whom he was bought by Vitesse in the first place. The two clubs are locked in some unfathomable contractual wrangle and Burley said he would wait until the end of the season before deciding whether to sign the 25-year-old, who has one international cap, permanently.

The manager had better check on whether Reuser, a charming and self-assured young man, wants to come. "Hopefully I can help Ipswich get to the Premiership and then I will see what happens. If they get to the Premiership then, yes, I would like to stay with them," he said diplomatically. Ipswich would drink a toast to that. Probably a sweet martini.

webTitle: Oxford up the creek without a paddle

fields.headline: Oxford up the creek without a paddle
fields.standfirst: Cambridge avenge boat race defeat to leave varsity rivals stuck in the mud and heading for relegation
fields.trailText: Cambridge 2 - 0 Oxford
fields.byline: Adam Sills  at the Abbey Stadium
fields.body:
Wallowing in their rare boat race victory, Oxford's gowned brigade are unlikely to have been knocked out of their lubricated stride upon hearing of Cambridge's one triumph of Varsity Day. But in the depths of the Second Division Roy McFarland's side stole a potentially decisive march on their relegation rivals in conditions more suited to rowing.

Such was the sopping state of the pitch after a morning deluge that the game was in doubt until five minutes before kick-off. It was not a day for pretty football; Oxford tried to please but in the end sank.

The club are swimming against the tide off the pitch as well. While the university has endured an eight-year wait for success on the Thames, the club have spent five years trying to float a new stadium.

It remains half-built and will be so for the foreseeable future after the high court granted leave for a judicial review of the city council's decision to give planning permission for a cinema multiplex at the Minchery Farm site, seen as vital to fund the development.

Enough to turn the club's chairman, Firoz Kassam, to drink? Certainly not on the new site. A local brewery, eager to protect its match-day sales, has served an injunction on the club stating that alcohol cannot be sold within half a mile of its Blackbird Public House.

Project Relocation has turned into Project Pandemonium. As the manager Denis Smith said on Saturday, the club can go nowhere while it remains at the Manor Ground. Except, that is, down to the Third Division.

Cambridge's hopes of avoiding a return to the league they escaped from last season were boosted by Saturday's win, only their third at home in the league since November, which moved them above Oxford and out of the relegation zone.

In contrast to Oxford, their expansion plans have been given the go-ahead. For Cambridge, though, the wait has been even longer: 15 years.

Agreement has finally been reached with the owners of neighbouring allotments and building on the Abbey should start next year. But first new allotments need to be prepared and the green-fingered have told the club they must, as the gardening calendar dictates, be ready to plant on March 1. Vegetables versus the vexed: only one winner.

Smith should perhaps consult the gardeners as to their battleplan. Certainly his side will need their determination to keep afloat. Instead his players will be given the once over by a psychologist this week and they may need it after the carpeting they received.

Oxford's defence parted to allow Trevor Benjamin to give Cambridge the lead within 10 minutes. Then, on the stroke of half-time, Phil Whelan, who has a degree in accountancy, got his sums wrong with a back-pass that stopped in a puddle, gifting John Hansen a second goal.

"The last thing we said, which we said about 20 times, is you can't pass back on any account on this pitch," Smith grumbled afterwards. "I can't believe the players at times."

Meanwhile, back in Oxford, the university celebrations were just beginning . . .

webTitle: Holdsworth trusts in Blues' collective calm

fields.headline: Holdsworth trusts in Blues' collective calm
fields.trailText: Sheff Utd 1 - 2 Birmingham
fields.body:
It might be a marathon not a sprint but it is handy to be able to sprint at the end of a marathon, which is what Birmingham City are doing.

They have taken 28 points from the past 36 and in two months have clawed back 14 points on Manchester City, nine on Ipswich and kept pace with Charlton. It has moved Blues from mid-table at the turn of the year to sixth place.

They have switched on the after-burners to become the team who, traditionally, arrive late and frighten the front-runners. They believe they can swoop on the finishing line.

Last year it was Watford who surprised themselves by sneaking into the play-offs before beating Birmingham on penalties in the semi-final. The season before Trevor Francis watched his side fail to reach the top six on goals scored. Goal difference, like now, and they would have made it.

So Francis has not enjoyed the best of play-off luck at St Andrews and perhaps the man who is a City legend deserves a break after injuries ruined the first half of his club's season and put a question mark over his own future.

The City defender David Holdsworth believes it will be third time lucky in the high-anxiety zone. "It's all about people staying calm and collected now, holding themselves together when the nerves and jitters start," he said. "We have the character to do that. The players are a very level-headed, down-to-earth bunch.

"We're a match for anybody in this division; what we need is a bit of luck and others to slip up slightly. If it happens, we'll grab it. The confidence is very high and we're going for it."

Marcus Bent put United ahead but a Rob Kozluk own- goal early in the second half and a Bryan Hughes winner two minutes later ensured justice was done.

webTitle: Goater puts chairman out of his agony

fields.headline: Goater puts chairman out of his agony
fields.trailText: Man City 2 - 1 WBA
fields.body:
A week may be a long time in politics but 90 minutes is seeming like an eternity to David Bernstein.

The Manchester City chairman admits he is finding it difficult watching the Blues stutter and stumble their way towards the end of the season.

This victory ended a run of seven matches without a win, a sequence that had threatened to derail their play-off hopes, never mind their automatic promotion ambitions.

But even this win, against a team that could be heading out of the First Division at the other end, came with more than its fair share of agonies.

Albion took the lead with a beautifully crafted shot from Lee Hughes on the hour and then put up defensive barricades that City seemed to lack the wit or nerve to break down.

Mark Kennedy, the only player unruffled by the tension, found the breakthrough with a 25-yard shot after 77 minutes. And, with only a minute of injury-time remaining, the Bermudian international Shaun Goater slotted home his 26th goal of the season to give Bernstein his first comfortable moment.

"The most difficult thing about being chairman is watching matches," said Bernstein afterwards. "I am not a good spectator. I get very tense, go very quiet and introverted. But I guess that it's all part of the passion of the game and, if we can get promotion, it will be fantastic."

Going up would not just save Bernstein's nerves. Pounds, millions of them, are the difference between success and failure. "Promotion is incredibly important," he said. "We will double our income if we get promoted. The boost of TV income makes a fantastic difference. Every year we are away from the Premiership we lose a massive amount of income and fall further away from the Premiership clubs."

There is little doubt that City are feeling the pressure of a tight promotion battle. Pressure is something West Brom will also get to know well over the next few weeks with relegation a growing possibility.

Their new manager Gary Megson has won only one of his four matches. And he is honest enough not to set much store by Joe Royle's message that Albion are too strong to go down.

"I didn't think that City would get relegated when they went down but it happens to big clubs," Megson said. "We are in big trouble and will have to battle and scrap if we are to get out of it."

"The most difficult thing about being chairman is watching matches," said Bernstein afterwards. "I am not a good spectator. I get very tense, go very quiet and introverted. But I guess that it's all part of the passion of the game and, if we can get promotion, it will be fantastic." Going up would not just save Bernstein's nerves. Pounds, millions of them, are the difference between success and failure. "Promotion is incredibly important," he said. "We will double our income if we get promoted. The boost of TV income makes a fantastic difference. Every year we are away from the Premiership we lose a massive amount of income and fall further away from the Premiership clubs." There is little doubt that City are feeling the pressure of a tight promotion battle. Pressure is something West Brom will also get to know well over the next few weeks with relegation a growing possibility. Their new manager Gary Megson has won only one of his four matches. And he is honest enough not to set much store by Joe Royle's message that Albion are too strong to go down. "I didn't think that City would get relegated when they went down but it happens to big clubs," Megson said. "We are in big trouble and will have to battle and scrap if we are to get out of it."

webTitle: Fans turn on Platt as Ward keeps Rovers rolling

fields.headline: Fans turn on Platt as Ward keeps Rovers rolling
fields.trailText: Nottm Forest 0 - 1 Blackburn
fields.byline: Martin Palmer  at the City Ground
fields.body:
David Platt was urged to quit by long-suffering Nottingham Forest supporters as they moved a step closer to their second successive relegation with a 1-0 defeat at home to Blackburn.

Ashley Ward's seventh-minute strike divided the teams but Forest's lack of confidence and creativity was apparent as they struggled to create any worthwhile chances.

"I don't think we can look at the positives now," Platt admitted. "Everything is getting tight and we need a couple of quick wins. There are teams in worse situations than ourselves but survival is the key word.

"We deserved a penalty but we gave away a daft goal and didn't create a great deal after going a goal down. It was disappointing."

Whistles and verbal abuse greeted the Forest players as they left the field and Platt insisted only a major improvement in the final seven games would turn the tide.

Platt added: "The discontent is growing and I can understand why when we perform like that at home."

The referee Ken Leach waved away Forest penalty appeals in the 38th minute after Alan Rogers was felled in the area by Simon Grayson. Earlier, on the half-hour, the striker Marlon Harewood had forced a good save from Alan Kelly.

Ward's early goal, scored from a couple of yards after David Dunn and Damien Duff split open Forest's defence, kept up Blackburn's outside hope of making the play-offs.

Graeme Souness, reflecting on his new side's second successive win, believes the play-offs are an unrealistic target but said: "If we keep on winning, who knows?'

webTitle: Celtic are second by a distance

fields.headline: Celtic are second by a distance
fields.trailText: Rangers 4 - 0 Celtic
fields.body:
Rangers had Celtic for their Sunday lunch, devouring rivals who made only the most perfunctory attempt to prevent the championship being won long before the end of the season.

They scored four goals and could have expected many more in one of the most one-sided Old Firm games of recent years. True, they played well but Celtic were quite awful at a ground where they last won in 1994. This contest is supposed to be between equals but that simply was not the case yesterday.

Kenny Dalglish may have taken the media to Bairns Bar, a Celtic stronghold, before the game but there was little likelihood of him returning there last night to face the wrath of supporters who felt badly let down by a side who simply did not seem to realise the importance of the occasion.

Rangers clearly did, and they were inspiringly led by their captain Lorenzo Amoruso while Jörg Albertz, the scorer of two goals, and Barry Ferguson ran the midfield. Clearly motivated by a series of articles in the build-up to the match in which Celtic claimed to be the best club in Glasgow, if they had had a couple of strikers with their sights finely tuned they might well have rewritten the record books.

"If I had a hat I would take it off to this team," said Rangers' manager Dick Advocaat. "We are 15 points ahead of Celtic and that's not easy in this league."

Dalglish mumbled: "The performance was unacceptable and everyone needs to know where they stand. A few home truths will have to be spelt out and we'll do that internally. I feel as if we have let down our supporters."

Things started to go horribly wrong for Celtic as early as the fourth minute when they conceded the kind of opening goal that leaves coaches wondering just what is the point of all those weekday defensive drills. Giovanni van Bronckhorst's inswinging corner from the right was high and swirling but a man of Andrei Kanchelskis's stature should not have been allowed a far-post header which he placed back across the goal for Albertz to ease the ball over the line with his forehead from two yards.

The loss of Stéphane Mahé, carried off on a stretcher two minutes later, was disconcerting for Celtic, even if Olivier Tebily stepped straight into his left-back position, and they found it difficult throughout the game to get anywhere near the Rangers goalkeeper Stefan Klos.

When they did push forward they were punished. In the 40th minute Van Bronckhorst, looking up at an ominously square defence, pushed the ball through to Kanchelskis in the clear and the Ukrainian was allowed a free run at the stranded Jonathan Gould, who made only a token effort to save the simplest of shots.

In the second half Rangers had the ball on a piece of string and the arrival of Neil McCann as substitute gave them extra width. The margin might have stayed the same but for the anger felt in the dressing room about those Celtic comments.

In the 84th minute McCann sprinted to the byline and supplied a cross which Albertz twisted round to push over the line. Moments later Kanchelskis cut down the other flank and, after Rod Wallace's shot had been blocked, Van Bronckhorst struck well from 15 yards for the fourth goal.

webTitle: Charlton brush off Palace on brink of the abyss

fields.headline: Charlton brush off Palace on brink of the abyss
fields.standfirst: Late strikes help the top three step up their push for promotion as Birmingham switch on the after-burners
fields.trailText: 1st Crystal Palace 0 - 1 Charlton
fields.body:
Grim reality is rearing its ugly head in south London. On Saturday there was an obvious gulf in class between the runaway leaders Charlton and Crystal Palace, but next season it could be extended to a chasm of six divisions.

While the substitute Paul Kitson's late goal took Charlton another step towards the Premiership, Palace's next south London derby could be against Croydon Athletic in the third division of the Ryman League. The visiting fans chanted: "We'll never play you again". They could be right.

The Eagles have been comatose in administration for a year but the life-support machine is on the verge of being switched off. With no prospect of a deal being brokered with two of the club's largest creditors, Strasbourg and Juventus, the televised match at Ipswich on April 25 , two weeks before the end of the season, could be the last in Palace's history.

"We will go out of business when the money runs out," confirmed their manager Steve Coppell. "The administrator told me this week that that day will come before the end of the season.

"Strasbourg and Juventus have told Fifa to get stuffed," said the administrator Simon Paterson. "But the Football Association still insist that we need a Fifa-agreed deal. How can we do a deal with two clubs who want to see Palace fold so they can take on the FA?

"We are officers of the court and, if third parties won't allow us to sell, we are obliged to wind the business up. What is being asked now just can't be delivered."

The FA spokesperson Steve Double disagreed: "Crystal Palace have to reach agreement over the outstanding debt with Strasbourg and Juventus. If I owe you £10 and I give you £10, it's always possible to reach an agreement." Palace owe nearer to £5.5m.

"The authorities are stringing us along to make sure we complete the fixtures," added Paterson. "If we did pull the plug, Palace's results would be expunged from the league and that would upset a few people."

Not least would be the fans who have pledged almost £1m to the Crystal Palace Supporters' Trust in an attempt to stave off the inevitable. That total includes £300 donated by an Ipswich fan, although the cat-calls from the Charlton supporters while a member of the trust addressed the 22,577 crowd at half-time suggested there is little sympathy in SE7.

On the pitch Charlton prevailed, passing up numerous chances to earn their first win at Selhurst Park - other than when they shared this ground between 1985 and 1991 - since 1935 before Chris Powell's low cross was turned in at the far post by Kitson for his first goal in his second substitute's appearance since joining from West Ham on loan until the end of the season.

Charlton are almost assured of promotion - and the championship - but their manager Alan Curbishley recalls worse times. "I was in a [Charlton] team that shared this ground in the 1980s and we were in a similar situation to Palace," he said. "We were playing here in front of crowds of 3,000."

Crowds of even that size are unheard of in the Ryman League.

fields.headline: A house of men
fields.standfirst: Male journalists dominate in the Commons. But women should not have to choose between work and family, says  Harriet Harman
fields.trailText: Male journalists dominate in the Commons. But women should not have to choose between work and family, says Harriet Harman
fields.body:
The news from parliament is conveyed to the country almost entirely through male eyes. Many newspapers have all-male lobby teams and the last official count of national newspapers and broadcasting media lobby correspondents shows 72 men and only 15 women. Nearly all the most senior members of the lobby, the powerful political editors, who can make or break stories and reputations, are men. That same count shows only three women out of the 28 political editors. So political news is reported in a way that appeals to and interests men. Issues of particular concern to women are, inevitably, lower on the agenda. This reinforces the sense among women that politics is a male activity of no relevance to them.

But it's not easy to be one of the very few women in the lobby. And it's enormously difficult to be a mother in the press gallery. It's not just that lobby journalists have to work long hours. Journalists expect that. The problem is that they have to work night shifts - all the time. Except for Thursdays, the House of Commons chamber does not even start its work till 2.30. It then goes through, usually till 10, but often till the small hours of the morning. The lobby journalists have to be there to report what's going on in the chamber. But they can't clock off when their copy deadline is passed. Because it's late at night MPs have given up on their paperwork and can't make work or personal phone calls because everyone else is in bed. So that's when journalists get the chance to chat with MPs , can hear the whispers and get that precious off the record "lobby briefing". So when her children are just finishing their day at school, the lobby journalist is only starting her day's work. And while children need their mother to be predictable and reliable, the Commons hours are anything but that. There's no timetabling or planning from day to day or week to week.

So men dominate in the lobby and the male flavour in political reporting obstructs the connection between women and their parliament.

Though women are as likely as men to vote, all the evidence is that they are less likely to think that politics and government are concerned with their lives. Thatcher strongly appealed to women voters, and so does Tony Blair. But women's votes remain doubtful and untrusting and they are the ones most likely to switch their allegiance. Political reporting, for much of the time, simply passes them by. Of course it's the case that there are many men who feel politics is irrelevant to them - but it is far more the case for women. It's not just that the priority given to different issues reflects male priorities, it's also to do with the language which is used to write about politics.

Political reporting accurately reveals to men in the country the conversation between men in the lobby and men in parliament. Approving talk of "big hitters", "big beasts" and "big guns" is clearly nothing to do with women. It is about men writing about men for other men. No woman would be encouraged to see a "big beast" in charge of our schools, "a big gun" leading the peace process as secretary of state for Northern Ireland or a "big hitter" in the Home Office. Few women talk approvingly of each other as "heavyweight"! Political debate couched in these terms leaves women cold.

It is not inevitable that political debate should exclude women. The women's magazines, written by women for women, connect with their readers' lives on issues which are highly political - an example is the recent reporting on the issue of maternity pay and leave in Prima Baby magazine. This is not a difference of depth. Some of the daily tabloids don't go into politics in great depth. And some women's magazines tackle highly complex issues in a sophisticated way. Rather, it's about style and who you're talking to.

During the past two decades I've seen young women arrive in the lobby. They've got there against the odds. Each time I hope the journalist's enthusiasm and intelligence will mean that she will break the mould and set a new pattern for the future. I see her networking with the few other women journalists, building relationships with her male colleagues, dodging the leering looks of too many male parliamentarians, while she tries to get to the heart of political stories.

For the first few years she does exceedingly well. But just as she gets to the age where she is at the foothills of serious authority in the lobby she gets, too, to the age when she starts a family. Even if she comes back after having a baby, she's on borrowed time. By the time she's had her second child she can't help noticing that there are other ways she can be a journalist. She can work as a freelance, on the news desk or in features. Unlike MPs, she has a choice. She doesn't have to work till late at night. She doesn't have to do a job which requires her to match the bizarre and uncivilised hours of the parliament. So she doesn't - she leaves. That is unfair on her, it's a shame for the women MPs, but it's a major problem for the reporting of what is known around the world as the "mother of parliaments".

Women in the lobby remain an endangered species. Julia Langdon, one of the pioneer women there, justly rose to be a political editor. But her exit from the Sunday Telegraph coincided with her having a baby. Eleanor Goodman has lasted and is Channel 4's political editor. And Scotland is lucky to have Catherine McLeod in a senior position at the Herald. But why isn't Jackie Ashley (formerly of ITN) a political editor? When she had her first child, she battled to win the right to be part-time in the lobby. But now she has three children - and is freelance. Where is Anne Perkins, formerly of the Guardian lobby team? Now she's a mother and a freelance. The Scotsman has let Joy Copley choose to work two days a week when she returns to work in May after having her daughter. We cannot afford to lose the current generation of women in the lobby the way we have lost so many over the past 20 years.

It's no good just hoping that, in time, things will change. Editors should determine to recruit more women to work in the lobby. All political editors should ensure they have some women on their team and should groom them for political editorship. But the biggest cause of the lack of women in the lobby is the fault of MPs. We must change the hours of the Commons, so we work during the day, and not day and night. That is important for MPs - men as well as women. But it is essential if we are to see more women in the lobby.

Women journalists should not have to jeopardise their family life in order to report parliament, or leave their career in the lobby to balance work and family life. A Commons creche and changing the hours will help women and men in parliament and it will help male journalists, too. But above all it will refresh our democracy by letting women in the country in on our political debate.

Harriet Harman is Labour MP for Camberwell and Peckham

fields.headline: Breaking news
fields.standfirst: Look at pictures from inside and outside the ceremony.
fields.trailText: 6.30am: American Beauty triumphs. Kevin Spacey wins Best Actor, and Sam Mendes Best Director within five minutes of each other. Accepting his award, Spacey dedicates the Oscar to "my mentor Jack Lemmon" whose performance in The Apartment directly inspired his role as Lester Burnham. Seconds later, American Beauty wins Best Picture.
fields.body:
6.30am: American Beauty triumphs. Kevin Spacey wins Best Actor, and Sam Mendes Best Director within five minutes of each other. Accepting his award, Spacey dedicates the Oscar to "my mentor Jack Lemmon" whose performance in The Apartment directly inspired his role as Lester Burnham. Seconds later, American Beauty wins Best Picture.

6.15am: Hilary Swank fights off stiff competition from sentimental favourite Annette Bening to win for Best Actress for her gender-bending role in the low-budget breakthrough picture Boys Don't Cry. Concluding her victory speech, the young actress offers a posthumous thank you to Brandon Teena, the true-life inspiration behind the picture.

6am: Beginning what looks to be a late surge, American Beauty beats strong competition to take Best Original Screenplay (for Alan Ball's script), to go alongside its Best Cinematography Award (for Conrad Hall). The big awards are still to come.

5.45am: Warren Beatty collects the Irving Thalberg Award for Lifetime Achievement from his old friend and sparring partner Jack Nicholson. "It's a bit soon to be giving this to a guy in his early 40s" jokes Beatty before paying tribute to his pregnant wife, Annette Bening: "She is my treasure."

5.30am: The Matrix's technical team triumphs yet again, as the film wins Best Editing Oscar.

5.10am: Pedro Almodovar takes the Best Foreign Film Oscar for All About My Mother. The award is presented by Spanish compatriots Antonio Banderas and Penelope Cruz, who later drag him off the stage when his speech threatens to turn into a ramble.

4.40am: The Matrix continues its sweep of the technical awards, adding Best Visual Effects to its statuettes for Best Sound Effects Editing and Best Achievement in Sound. Meanwhile, Polish film-maker Andrzej Wajda scoops an Honorary Oscar for his career in cinema.

4.10am: Just as the Wall Street Journal said he would, Michael Caine wins Best Supporting Actor for The Cider House Rules. Caine accepts the award with choked modesty and magnanimity, and compliments his fellow nominees. To Tom Cruise, Caine offers the consolation that his price per movie would have fallen had he won. "Do you have any idea how much supporting actors get paid?" he quips.

3.50am: Phil Collins wins Best Original Song for his tune You'll Be in My Heart, in Disney's animated Tarzan film, but the real attention is on Robin Williams's star-spangled rendition of the controversial nominee Blame Canada, from South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut. webTitle: Oscar ceremony sticks to the script

fields.headline: Oscar ceremony sticks to the script
fields.trailText: Working to a classic Hollywood script, the 72nd Academy Awards built to a crescendo in its final moments as American Beauty mounted a late surge to sweep the principal Oscars for Best Film, Best Director (Sam Mendes) and Best Actor (Kevin Spacey).
fields.body:
Working to a classic Hollywood script, the 72nd Academy Awards built to a crescendo in its final moments as American Beauty mounted a late surge to sweep the principal Oscars for Best Film, Best Director (Sam Mendes) and Best Actor (Kevin Spacey).

In the space of some six minutes, this dark-edged tale of suburban angst became the undisputed winner of this year's ceremony. Embracing backstage after the final presentation, Mendes and Spacey sported the drained and exhausted look of two prize-fighters who'd just gone the distance. The suspenseful way the Academy stage-manages these events, it seems, takes a toll on the winners as well as the losers.

But even the cavalier dash of Oscars closing minutes could not quite disguise the faint whiff of predictability in the air. In effect, the Oscars were effectively announced on Friday, when the Wall Street Journal published its exit-poll predictions of where the major awards were going.

The paper may have surveyed a slender 6% of eligible Academy voters, but its conclusions were to prove unnervingly accurate. Mendes won, just as it had said he would. Hilary Swank came from the outside to collect Best Actress for Boys Don't Cry, just as it had said she would. Ditto Michael Caine (Best Supporting Actor for The Cider House Rules), ditto the bee-stung Angelina Jolie (Best Supporting Actress for Girl, Interrupted). If you were taking the Journal as gospel, the sole surprise was Spacey, who won what appeared to be a narrow contest with the paper's tip, Denzel Washington (nominated for The Hurricane).

All of which conspired to take some crackle off the night's proceedings. If anything, Oscar 2000 was just too polished and genteel to fully satisfy. The speeches were kept to a Spartan minimum, the victors were dewy-eyed, but never hysterical. Even host Billy Crystal's satirical barbs at the nominees were too well rehearsed and neatly packaged to bite the way they should.

Even so, this year's Academy Awards boasted a few sights that will linger in the memory. We had Pedro Almodovar (winning Best Foreign Language Film for All About My Mother) having to be dragged forcibly from the stage when his speech threatened to last longer than the film itself.

We had Isaac Hayes choking on a thick waft of dry ice as he tried to sing the theme from Shaft ("How do you lose Isaac Hayes?" shrilled Crystal). Later, novelist John Irving (winner of Best Adapted Screenplay for The Cider House Rules) provided the night's only political moment when he acknowledged the National Abortion Rights Action League in his victory speech. The Cider House Rules, which centres around a New England abortion clinic, provoked a protest outside the ceremony from enraged pro-lifers. Irving's response showed that he was not about to shy away from the controversy.

Most entertaining of all, however, was Robin Williams' exuberant rendition of the Oscar-nominated South Park song, Blame Canada. A scabrous satirical ditty, Blame Canada had already become one of the night's big talking points, with rumours abounding that the broadcasters were poised to bleep the tune's offending portions.

In the event, the song aired in a PG version that still managed to retain much of the original content. Williams may have arrived on stage with tape over his mouth, but Blame Canada still mentioned kids who "fart and curse" and run away to join the Ku Klux Klan as well as a reference to "that bitch Anne Murray". Only one decidedly R-rated verse (about a mother who is told to "go fuck herself") was replaced by a more user-friendly alternative.

Elsewhere, the ceremony was rather better behaved. Accepting his award for Best Supporting Actor, Michael Caine lavished praise on his rival nominees and consoled Tom Cruise (nominated for Magnolia) by pointing out that his asking price would have plunged had he won. "Have you any idea how much supporting actors get paid?" Caine quipped. Still guaranteed an estimated $20m a movie, Cruise could afford to laugh off the loss.

In terms of Hollywood aristocracy, the evening's main event was the presentation of the Irving Thalberg Lifetime Achievement Award to Warren Beatty. Accepting the honour from his old friend and sparring partner Jack Nicholson, the 62-year-old Beatty joked: "It's a bit soon to be giving this to a guy in his early 40s," before going on to thank his wife Annette Bening ("She is my treasure").

The heavily pregnant Mrs Beatty, meanwhile, was providing a fascinating side-show all on her own. She was nominated for Best Actress (for American Beauty) and there were worries that she would not be able to haul herself up the stairs to collect the award. "If she wins, she'll crawl up here on all fours," her co-star Spacey assured the audience. But in the end, she kept her seat to leave Swank (virtually unknown until Boys Don't Cry shot her to fame) to stroll on stage and take the award.

Bening may have missed out, but her loss was just a blip in an otherwise glorious night for American Beauty, which finished the night with five Oscars in total. Accepting his award, Spacey gave fulsome praise to his "mentor", the actor Jack Lemmon, whose performance in The Apartment was a direct inspiration for Spacey's turn as suburban everyman Lester Burnham.

Moments later, Sam Mendes took to the stage to collect his award for Best Director. Still only 34, the Oxford-educated director has come a long way since his days of managing the Donmar Warehouse in London. His last-minute win capped a fruitful night for British hopes; an award to set alongside Michael Caine's, an Oscar for Phil Collins (for Best Original Song, though it didn't sound so original) and the two trophies (for Costume and Make-Up) won by Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy.

And so the Oscar congregation breaks up into a welter of after-show parties and news interviews and behind-the-scenes schmoozing. Most of the assembled guests have been here before and know the scene like the back of their manicured hands. But for one man, it is the end of something special and the start of something new.

61-year-old Willie Fulgear observed the entire ceremony with a look of wry bemusement. The salvage worker's discovery of the missing Oscars had won him a free ticket to the awards and reward of $50,000. Fulgear says he plans to return to his native Mississippi and buy himself a home there. For him, this Hollywood story is now drawing to a close.

fields.headline: Bowled over in Bangladesh
fields.standfirst: Every Monday during the winter wisden.com spoke to a county cricketer about what he was doing in the close season. In March, Nottinghamshire and England A fast bowler Paul Franks spilt the beans - and this week he was named in the England one-day squad for July's Triangular Tournament
fields.trailText: Paul Franks, 21, is one of England's most promising fast bowlers. He performed outstandingly on the A tour to Bangladesh and New Zealand (taking 21 wickets at 18.80) and was named bowler of the tour by manager Mike Gatting. He made his debut for Nottinghamshire in 1996 and was the youngest Notts player to take a hat-trick (v Warwickshire at Trent Bridge in 1997) aged 18 years, 163 days
fields.body:
Paul Franks, 21, is one of England's most promising fast bowlers. He performed outstandingly on the A tour to Bangladesh and New Zealand (taking 21 wickets at 18.80) and was named bowler of the tour by manager Mike Gatting. He made his debut for Nottinghamshire in 1996 and was the youngest Notts player to take a hat-trick (v Warwickshire at Trent Bridge in 1997) aged 18 years, 163 days

I spent nine weeks from October on tour. It was my first full A tour (though I was called up as a replacement last year) and it was very, very pleasing to be selected. It was what I was working towards last season.

We maintained the A team's unbroken record which again was very pleasing. I was with a great bunch of guys. I knew a few of them beforehand - Chris Schofield, Michael Gough, Vikram Solanki - and the team was an excellent blend. It was great to be chosen as bowler of the tour by the manager, a real vote of confidence. I learnt a lot. You had to adapt to the various situations and the different pitches and conditions. I don't think you could have two more contrasting places to tour.

Asia is very alien whereas New Zealand is in many ways very similar to England. In Bangladesh we played in front of massive crowds. In a place called Chittagong, on the south coast, the crowd was upwards of 30,000. They were locking people out of the ground on the third day. It was quite an intimidating experience for the guys to handle. They are absolutely wild about cricket there - cricketers are treated almost like royalty, which again a lot of the guys weren't prepared for.

I got back just before Christmas and since then I've been trying to rest a bit. I didn't do anything especially on New Year's Eve. I certainly didn't spend it bungee-jumping off tall buildings. It seemed a bit bizarre really because I'd only just got back from touring on December 23. I went to the Canary Islands before the A tour but I haven't been away since - I've been too busy with my new house. It is much closer to Trent Bridge, so I won't have to spend so much of my time driving. I'll be sharing with one of my new teammates, Giles Haywood, for the summer.

We've got lots of new players at Notts this season and I've been getting to know them. We've been on team-building courses and we started back properly on March 1. Training is Monday to Friday, 9-4, consisting of two separate sessions - sprint training, distance running, swimming and aerobics in the morning, and technical work in the afternoon.

We go [they left last Tuesday] on a pre-season tour to South Africa, staying in Jo'burg and playing against Middlesex and a couple of provincial teams.

I've not been in contact with any of the England selectors. I try not to read the papers as guys who read everything tend to be very let down. But I did read bits about the central contracts. I wasn't particularly disappointed not to get one - I've only just turned 21 and I've got time on my side. I'd be lying if I said I wasn't thinking about an England place but it is not at the forefront of my mind. If I do well for Notts and the selectors come and see Paul Franks play and they think Paul Franks is any good then I might be with a chance. I don't think I'd let anyone down.

Playing for England is something I have wanted since I was 13 or 14 and I'd love to play over the next 12 or 18 months. I was thoroughly disappointed with my batting last year and I've been working hard at it. I've also been working a little on my mental approach, to control my aggression.

I've worked quite a lot with Dennis Lillee [at the MRF Academy] in Madras. I've learnt loads. They only send the best to him so the basics are already there and he just has a tinker - he doesn't try and change you wholesale. If I ever felt I was standing still, I wouldn't have any hesitation in going back. He is just a fantastic bloke. The first time I went I was 17. I was just sitting there waiting for him to turn up and when he did everyone just stood up. He has such an aura about him. I couldn't have two better mentors than him and Clive Rice [director of cricket at Notts]. If I'd wanted to go this year Notts would have said 'no problem', but they wanted me to have time off to rest because I had played solidly from February to December.

When I've got time I go to the cinema and, like most cricketers, I like to play golf as often as I can. Otherwise I just spend time with friends and family. I'm not one of these guys who burns the midnight oil, though I do like the odd drink. I've just been trying to relax really, cricket can be very intense at times.

Paul Franks was talking to Tanya Aldred

fields.headline: Grammar ballot petition halted
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The campaign to abolish the country's remaining 165 grammar schools will be dealt a fresh blow today when anti-selection campaigners in Kent announce that they are suspending petitioning that could trigger a vote among parents.
fields.body:
The campaign to abolish the country's remaining 165 grammar schools will be dealt a fresh blow today when anti-selection campaigners in Kent announce that they are suspending petitioning that could trigger a vote among parents.

The campaigners in Kent, which has 33 grammar schools, blame "political confusion" over the issue, complexity of the rules governing the ballots, and a tight deadline.

They need to get 46,000 signatures of eligible parents for a vote to take place, but are understood to have secured fewer than 7,000.

The news comes just two weeks after parents in Ripon, North Yorkshire, voted by a two-thirds majority to retain their grammar school - the oldest in England - in the first ballot under legislation introduced by Labour.

Labour has been accused of "sitting on the fence" over the highly sensitive schools issue by allowing local parents to decide their fate through the new system of ballots. In Ripon, the anti-grammar school campaigners complained that the rules were unfair because they gave disproportionate influence to parents with children at private schools.

In another government defeat last week, peers voted to repeal the legislation on ballots in the learning and skills bill, which goes to the Commons on Thursday.

The amendment is expected to be easily overturned, however.

The Kent anti-selection campaigners said they had a "Herculean" task to collect the signatures required within a very tight time scale.

A spokesman, Martin Frey, said: "If a petition is gathered before May this year it could be validated and accepted before the end of July. But if that same petition were presented in June or July, or if the validation process takes longer than anticipated, it could fail."

The "political confusion" following controversial remarks by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, and the peers' decision had contributed to the decision to make a fresh start with a new petition in September, at the beginning of the new academic year.

"There must be clarity from the government. When we started the petition process in earnest earlier this year we rightly anticipated neutrality from ministers, not confusion. fields.standfirst: Ian Dury dies of cancer
fields.trailText: Ian Dury, who has died of cancer aged 57, was one of few true originals of the English music scene, the only man to successfully combine the energy and excitement of rock 'n' roll and funk with the bawdy humour, wit and home-spun philosophy of music-hall and of his native Essex. He was truly brave - both physically and in the way he approached his music.
fields.body:
Ian Dury, who has died of cancer aged 57, was one of few true originals of the English music scene, the only man to successfully combine the energy and excitement of rock 'n' roll and funk with the bawdy humour, wit and home-spun philosophy of music-hall and of his native Essex. The fact that he had been crippled since childhood, and was severely ill during his final years as a performer, merely added to his stature. He was truly brave - both physically and in the way he approached his music.

That bravery was evident at his first major London concert, at the Hammersmith Odeon in May 1978, at the height of the punk era. The audience were told to prepare for "one of the jewels in England's crown", and on came not Dury but his hero, the veteran music-hall star Max Wall, who was barracked by the boisterous crowd until Dury stormed on to quieten them down. When he reappeared with his band, he hobbled across the stage, supported by a stick, looking like some spivvy Cockney update of a Dickensian villain. The punks were suitably impressed.

Here was a man already in his mid-thirties who looked crippled but dangerous, and had an armoury of quite extraordinary songs, ranging from the realistically romantic to the outrageous. He could belt out a thoughtful rock song like Sweet Gene Vincent, and then introduce a distinctive Essex spin. Even hardcore punks were taken aback by the stories of Plaistow Patricia or Billericay Dickie, dealing as they did with the life and loves of losers, chancers and wide-boys from the East End and beyond. No one then, or since, could match lyrics like "a love affair with Nina in the back of my Cortina, a seasoned-up hyena couldn't have been more obscener".

The man responsible was born in Harrow. His father was a bus-driver and later a chauffeur, who split up with his university-educated mother soon after the war. The young Ian went to live in Upminster with his mum, but was struck down by polio at the age of seven. He spent several years in hospital and at a school in Sussex for the disabled, and then moved to the Royal High Wycombe Grammar School. He left with three O-levels and moved back to Essex, to Walthamstow Art School.

Then came the Royal College of Art, a stint teaching art in Canterbury, and in 1970 the formation of his first band, Kilburn and the High Roads. They developed a minor following on the emerging London pub-rock scene and their first album, Handsome, in 1974. It included some distinctive Dury lyric but was not successful. Dury had yet to fully develop his exaggerated Cockney stage persona.

The transformation came after Dury started writing with pianist Chas Jankel and signed to the independent Stiff label, co-founded by David Robinson, one of the great showmen and the godfather of British funk.

Dury toured with his fellow Stiff artists including Elvis Costello, and in October, 1977, released his classic New Boots And Panties. The album, which went on to sell over a million copies, included the erotic Wake Up And Make Love With Me.

In April 1978 Dury notched up his first Top Ten single, What A Waste, followed later the same year with the number one hit, Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick, and a year later Reasons To Be Cheerful (Part 3). In 1980, the compilation album Juke Box Dury packaged these hit singles along with Dury's best-known stage anthem, Sex & Drugs & Rock 'n' Roll.

At the time, Dury insisted to me that, as an unlikely pop star, he was merely continuing his career as an artist: "I was a painter for seven years, a successful illustrator for two years, and now I'm a rock 'n' roll singer. I still feel I'm doing the same thing, but I'm not painting with paints." As for his physical disability, he had confidently used it as a part of his stage act.

"I'm charismatic and I'm not ashamed about my physical appearance," he said.

"Even good-looking people have got a weakness. My weakness is so obvious that there's no point in worrying about it. Luckily I'm quite interesting to look at.

I know 'cos I painted myself as an art student about 500 times."

He succeeded partly because of the care and attention he put into his work,explaining: "I ain't a poet, I'm a lyricist," and spending weeks carefully perfecting his songs. He described his influences as "the Stax and Motown labels and Max Miller, with a lot of television thrown in".

During the 1980s, with the waning of the punk era and rise of the New Romantics, Dury gradually fell out of fashion, despite some glorious tours with his band the Blockheads. But he still continued his policy of musical bravery, collaborating with trumpeter Don Cherry on the 1980 set Laughter, and travelling to Nassau the following year to record with the reggae rhythm section Sly and Robbie for Lord Upminster.

This was the Year Of The Disabled, and Dury contributed the thoughtfully realistic Spasticus Autisticus. The song, which contained lines like "I dribble when I nibble," was considered to be in such bad taste that, despite Dury's own disability, it was banned from radio play.

The departure of Chaz Jankel from the Blockheads proved a more serious blow and, in 1984, after the release of the unsuccessful album 4000 Weeks Holiday, Dury took a rest from live performance, and concentrated on acting. He appeared in a series of unremarkable films, including Polanski's Pirates (1986) and Hearts Of Fire, a vehicle for Bob Dylan.

He had more success on stage the following year, in the Royal Court production of Jim Carter's Road. Two years later, he was back at the Court with a musical, Apples, which he had co-written with former Blockhead Mickey Gallagher. It was not a success, but Dury had continued with his policy of doing exactly what he wanted.

Never too concerned about personal wealth, he had turned down an offer from Andrew Lloyd Webber to provide the lyrics for Cats - a commission that reportedly earned millions for Richard Stilgoe. Dury had a simple explanation for turning Lloyd Webber down: "I can't stand his music."

In 1990, the Blockheads came together again, initially to play a benefit for their former drummer Charlie Charles, who was suffering from cancer. The reunion was so successful that further shows followed over the next two years, and several members of the band collaborated on Dury's 1993 album, The Bus Driver's Prayer And Other Stories. Then, just as his career was heading for another upswing, Dury was diagnosed as suffering from cancer. In 1996 a tumour was removed from his colon, but two years later, further tumours were detected on his liver.

He reacted, in typical fashion, by plunging himself back into work, and 1998 will be remembered as his finest period since the glory days of the late 1970s. Once again reunited with Chas Jankel and the Blockheads, he embarked on a series of concerts that showed he had lost none of his old verve, wit or musical skill. Their songs ranged from the funk and black humour of Mash It Up Harry and Jack Shit Georgie (an attack on the education system) through to an unashamedly emotional, semi-spoken love song, You're My Baby.

 Ian Dury, singer, songwriter and actor, born May 12 1942; died Mar 27 2000

webTitle: "Know what you own and know why you own it"

fields.headline: "Know what you own and know why you own it"
fields.standfirst: Jason Hollands, Deputy Managing Director, Best Investment Brokers
fields.trailText: In the world of investment it's important to learn from your mistakes.
fields.body:
In the world of investment it's important to learn from your mistakes.

A couple of years ago a friend gave me a hot tip on a share quoted on the high tech US NASDAQ market. They'd done all the research and it was a "sure bet" to make a killing. At that point greed took over and I invested a few thousand pounds buying the shares at $34. Shortly afterwards the share price fell to $7. A few weeks later I invested in a speculative oil exploration company. My investment of £3,000 is now worth less than £100.

These were expensive lessons but ones that have done me the world of good as an investor: a few serious losses help focus your mind and develop your investment technique. The first lesson is never to invest in anything you don't really understand or as US investment guru Peter Lynch states "know what you own and know why you own it". The second lesson is "when you are in a hole, don't try and dig your way out of it". When my first speculative share punt failed I tried to make the money back with another equally speculative bet. The first cut is the deepest.

The stock market is full of "hot tips" and there are no end of people willing to espouse get-rich-quick advice; you should ignore all of this. Whilst a lucky few may have the Midas touch for picking individual shares or markets that shoot up within a short space of time, a much more sensible way to invest is to scatter your money widely across shares and markets through well managed funds. You may not become a millionaire overnight but you will make sound returns and be able to sleep at night.

I now make my money not through gambling on the fringes of the market but by recognising that there are a great many talented professional investors out there whose funds I can readily buy. They have a clear head start over the private investor in research resources and economies of scale in dealing costs and when they foul up I can sack them by selling the fund rather than having to face up to my own stock picking blunders.

webTitle: What is this thing called Love's Labour's Lost?

fields.headline: What is this thing called Love's Labour's Lost?
fields.standfirst: Sarah Gristwood joins Kenneth Branagh on the set of his all-singing, all-dancing version of Shakespeare's play
fields.trailText: Sarah Gristwood joins Kenneth Branagh on the set of his all-singing, all-dancing version of Shakespeare's play
fields.body:
Under the fake shade of fake trees, a group of actors have set up camp with an air of conviction that makes sunshine seem like a reality. On the foot of a swirling staircase Alicia Silverstone is curled up asleep, her scarlet evening dress capped by sneakers, hair net and a giant puffa jacket (a more realistic reaction to the temperature), a towel cuddled, teddy bear-like, to her chest.

While the crew perches on cold simulated stone to discuss piles and other personal problems picked up elsewhere ("Just wait till you've done the Ouarzazate Quickstep") the cast, at 9.30 on a chilly morning, is faced with the task of laughing loudly and musically.

This is one of Shepperton's biggest sound stages, decked out with walls, willows and punts to make a kind of "movie Oxbridge" - otherwise known as the court of Navarre - for Kenneth Branagh's film of Love's Labour's Lost. It is, he says, "a larger-than-life atmosphere in which people would naturally burst into song."

Branagh, who adapted, directs and plays the romantic hero, Berowne, is wearing a dinner jacket and has a tiny moustache. He used to dislike the comparison, but his resemblance to Laurence Olivier is extraordinary. Branagh has set the story of four young men sworn to abjure women, and four young women who make them change their minds, in the 30s. And he has replaced two-thirds of the words with the songs of George Gershwin, Cole Porter and Irving Berlin - "artists who have a chance of sitting alongside Shakespeare and not being embarrassed by it".

The production team tried writing original lyrics. It didn't work. Neither did using the composers' lesser numbers, which would have been cheaper. "But," says Branagh, "when you have Berowne going on about the transforming power of love, saying that when love speaks, the voice of all the gods makes heaven drowsy with it, it seems very appropriate to start singing 'Heaven, I'm in heaven'. So far, the play has not bucked against our treatment."

Branagh's previous Shakespeare films (Henry V, Much Ado About Nothing and Hamlet) were more straightforward. But Baz Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet moved the goalposts. A musical Love's Labour's Lost may be a gamble but the initial response (the reception at the Berlin film festival, the Variety review) suggests it has paid off. Unlike the four-hour Hamlet, this clocks in at a brisk 90-odd minutes, and that's nothing to do with Harvey Weinstein, whose firm Miramax is distributing it in many territories: "This is the director's cut," says Branagh firmly.

Perhaps he has hedged his bets by going for one of Shakespeare's less popular plays. Love's Labour's Lost couples a simple plot with an elaborate poetry packed with topical references that "make it seem as if it's written in code", as Richard Briers (who plays the curate Nathaniel) puts it. Branagh says the play responds best to heroic treatment: "In this century there have been only five significant productions and they've all had quite strong directors." He refers to Harley Granville Barker's line that it is "a fashionable play 300 years out of fashion" and says that, like Romeo and Juliet, its youthful energy is a great plus.

Back in his RSC days Branagh played the King of Navarre to Roger Rees's Berowne. He admits he didn't understand the work. Perhaps you need to be edging towards middle years to appreciate youthful verve. Now the 39-year-old Branagh says Berowne is less cynical, less set against love, than Benedick in Much Ado About Nothing: "This is the film about the look across a crowded room."

Drawing on the late 30s works thematically as well as stylistically. Besides the showtime element - "very perky and silly and full of fun" - the period produced a spate of films "where women called the shots while the men do the posturing". A recurring theme was men's constancy - "or inconstancy" - and women got their turn at "the game of torturing the boys", as Silverstone (who plays the Princess) calls it.

In the play, the romantic games are ended when the sudden death of the King of France makes the Princess sweep her ladies home. In the film, the visuals give his death a political context; this is 1939 and France is falling to the Germans. As the Princess and her entourage leave Navarre, the film reference is to Casablanca. A plane stands on the tarmac as the cast sing They Can't Take That Away From Me. In crackling black and white news footage the Princess and her ladies are led away to internment camp, while the King of Navarre and his men join the services.

"The play benefits from being set very specifically in time and place, and it fits the prewar generation," says Branagh. "There's something ennobling about that last hurrah." It makes sense of the couples' arbitrary separation, the one that has led many Shakespeareans to postulate a long-lost sequel, Love's Labour's Won, and gives a poignancy to their two-day love.

Branagh is stirring a rich soup of references, but he sweeps everyone along. On set, he is above all reassuring. He has to be. On the basis of three weeks' rehearsal - "Shakespeare boot camp" - a cast not exactly famed for its musical experience is being asked to perform the numbers we are used to seeing done with real panache. Broadway star Nathan Lane, many times a musicals award winner, plays Costard the clown but sings only one number (There's No Business Like Showbusiness, appropriately). Briers, and Geraldine McEwan as Holofernia, get to sing The Way You Look Tonight. Timothy Spall as a Dali-eseque Don Armadio combines RSC experience with Topsy-Turvy, and Adrian Lester as Dumaine combines professional dance and Sondheim's Company with Rosalind in the all-male As You Like It. But many other cast members, including Silverstone and Matthew Lillard as Longaville, mention neither Shakespeare nor musicals on their CV.

Eclectic is too mild a word for it - but a mixed cast is something Branagh has used before, even more conspicuously. Hamlet featured Billy Crystal and Charlton Heston alongside John Gielgud. Much Ado had Denzel Washington and Keanu Reeves alongside British unknowns, and Emma Thompson told graphically of how the disparate group had to be welded together by impromptu spaghetti parties - rather as Merchant Ivory casts, in their poorer days, had to be placated with Ismail Merchant's curries. But it is noticeable how many older members of the cast, and the production team, have worked with Branagh regularly. None more so than Briers, who was regarded only as a TV actor when Branagh first cast him on stage in Twelfth Night. Through Branagh's Renaissance company Briers went on to play Lear. "Lear after The Good Life!" says Briers incredulously. "It would have been awful if I had got into my 70s and never had those opportunities." As a director, Briers says, Branagh's special gift is to draw ever more emotion out of his performers. "If you're English middle class, it's very difficult to yield it easily."

Branagh is planning more Shakespeares: Macbeth should be coming shortly, followed by As You Like It. That's another sort of gamble. His producer, David Barron, says: "Where Shakespeare films have made money, they've made money. Where they haven't, they really haven't." But the energy triggered by Shakespeare in Love and Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet is still pumping. Ethan Hawke's Hamlet and Julie Taymor's terrifying Titus have been praised in the US, and Tim Roth recently announced plans to direct King Lear as adapted by Harold Pinter: "I'm not interested in a bunch of people standing around a castle talking," Roth says.

It seems only fair that, given the length of his relationship with Shakespeare, Branagh should ride the wave. But he could have been swept away. Lillard says reading a scene with Branagh is "like shooting hoops with Michael Jordan," but also that in Branagh's company, "I'm sitting with the grandfather of the Bard." It is a double-edged compliment.

"We have broken away from the various earlier periods of Shakespeare movie-making that were linked more closely to theatre," says Branagh. "Now these stories are free for exploration in a way they weren't before. The canvas is blank again. There's a generation out there who have never seen one of Orson Welles's Shakespeare films, or Zeffirelli's - or even one of ours. What we've done with Love's Labour's Lost might provoke hostile debate, but even that's a good thing."

Loves Labour's Lost opens on Friday.

Branagh has set the story of four young men sworn to abjure women, and four young women who make them change their minds, in the 30s. And he has replaced two-thirds of the words with the songs of George Gershwin, Cole Porter and Irving Berlin - "artists who have a chance of sitting alongside Shakespeare and not being embarrassed by it". The production team tried writing original lyrics. It didn't work. Neither did using the composers' lesser numbers, which would have been cheaper. "But," says Branagh, "when you have Berowne going on about the transforming power of love, saying that when love speaks, the voice of all the gods makes heaven drowsy with it, it seems very appropriate to start singing 'Heaven, I'm in heaven'. So far, the play has not bucked against our treatment." Branagh's previous Shakespeare films (Henry V, Much Ado About Nothing and Hamlet) were more straightforward. But Baz Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet moved the goalposts. A musical Love's Labour's Lost may be a gamble but the initial response (the reception at the Berlin film festival, the Variety review) suggests it has paid off. Unlike the four-hour Hamlet, this clocks in at a brisk 90-odd minutes, and that's nothing to do with Harvey Weinstein, whose firm Miramax is distributing it in many territories: "This is the director's cut," says Branagh firmly. Perhaps he has hedged his bets by going for one of Shakespeare's less popular plays. Love's Labour's Lost couples a simple plot with an elaborate poetry packed with topical references that "make it seem as if it's written in code", as Richard Briers (who plays the curate Nathaniel) puts it. Branagh says the play responds best to heroic treatment: "In this century there have been only five significant productions and they've all had quite strong directors." He refers to Harley Granville Barker's line that it is "a fashionable play 300 years out of fashion" and says that, like Romeo and Juliet, its youthful energy is a great plus. Back in his RSC days Branagh played the King of Navarre to Roger Rees's Berowne. He admits he didn't understand the work. Perhaps you need to be edging towards middle years to appreciate youthful verve. Now the 39-year-old Branagh says Berowne is less cynical, less set against love, than Benedick in Much Ado About Nothing: "This is the film about the look across a crowded room." Drawing on the late 30s works thematically as well as stylistically. Besides the showtime element - "very perky and silly and full of fun" - the period produced a spate of films "where women called the shots while the men do the posturing". A recurring theme was men's constancy - "or inconstancy" - and women got their turn at "the game of torturing the boys", as Silverstone (who plays the Princess) calls it. In the play, the romantic games are ended when the sudden death of the King of France makes the Princess sweep her ladies home. In the film, the visuals give his death a political context; this is 1939 and France is falling to the Germans. As the Princess and her entourage leave Navarre, the film reference is to Casablanca. A plane stands on the tarmac as the cast sing They Can't Take That Away From Me. In crackling black and white news footage the Princess and her ladies are led away to internment camp, while the King of Navarre and his men join the services. "The play benefits from being set very specifically in time and place, and it fits the prewar generation," says Branagh. "There's something ennobling about that last hurrah." It makes sense of the couples' arbitrary separation, the one that has led many Shakespeareans to postulate a long-lost sequel, Love's Labour's Won, and gives a poignancy to their two-day love. Branagh is stirring a rich soup of references, but he sweeps everyone along. On set, he is above all reassuring. He has to be. On the basis of three weeks' rehearsal - "Shakespeare boot camp" - a cast not exactly famed for its musical experience is being asked to perform the numbers we are used to seeing done with real panache. Broadway star Nathan Lane, many times a musicals award winner, plays Costard the clown but sings only one number (There's No Business Like Showbusiness, appropriately). Briers, and Geraldine McEwan as Holofernia, get to sing The Way You Look Tonight. Timothy Spall as a Dali-eseque Don Armadio combines RSC experience with Topsy-Turvy, and Adrian Lester as Dumaine combines professional dance and Sondheim's Company with Rosalind in the all-male As You Like It. But many other cast members, including Silverstone and Matthew Lillard as Longaville, mention neither Shakespeare nor musicals on their CV. Eclectic is too mild a word for it - but a mixed cast is something Branagh has used before, even more conspicuously. Hamlet featured Billy Crystal and Charlton Heston alongside John Gielgud. Much Ado had Denzel Washington and Keanu Reeves alongside British unknowns, and Emma Thompson told graphically of how the disparate group had to be welded together by impromptu spaghetti parties - rather as Merchant Ivory casts, in their poorer days, had to be placated with Ismail Merchant's curries. But it is noticeable how many older members of the cast, and the production team, have worked with Branagh regularly. None more so than Briers, who was regarded only as a TV actor when Branagh first cast him on stage in Twelfth Night. Through Branagh's Renaissance company Briers went on to play Lear. "Lear after The Good Life!" says Briers incredulously. "It would have been awful if I had got into my 70s and never had those opportunities." As a director, Briers says, Branagh's special gift is to draw ever more emotion out of his performers. "If you're English middle class, it's very difficult to yield it easily." Branagh is planning more Shakespeares: Macbeth should be coming shortly, followed by As You Like It. That's another sort of gamble. His producer, David Barron, says: "Where Shakespeare films have made money, they've made money. Where they haven't, they really haven't." But the energy triggered by Shakespeare in Love and Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet is still pumping. Ethan Hawke's Hamlet and Julie Taymor's terrifying Titus have been praised in the US, and Tim Roth recently announced plans to direct King Lear as adapted by Harold Pinter: "I'm not interested in a bunch of people standing around a castle talking," Roth says. It seems only fair that, given the length of his relationship with Shakespeare, Branagh should ride the wave. But he could have been swept away. Lillard says reading a scene with Branagh is "like shooting hoops with Michael Jordan," but also that in Branagh's company, "I'm sitting with the grandfather of the Bard." It is a double-edged compliment. "We have broken away from the various earlier periods of Shakespeare movie-making that were linked more closely to theatre," says Branagh. "Now these stories are free for exploration in a way they weren't before. The canvas is blank again. There's a generation out there who have never seen one of Orson Welles's Shakespeare films, or Zeffirelli's - or even one of ours. What we've done with Love's Labour's Lost might provoke hostile debate, but even that's a good thing." Loves Labour's Lost opens on Friday.

fields.headline: Dobson stands down
fields.standfirst:
(No, not himthe other one)

Read his resignation letter
fields.trailText: Independent London mayor candidate Frank S Dobson announced his withdrawal from the race today  - but warned his Labour party namesake that he would not hesitate to stand again.
fields.body:
Independent London mayor candidate Frank S Dobson announced his withdrawal from the race today - but warned his Labour party namesake that he would not hesitate to stand again.

The retired publisher entered the race earlier this month on an anti-mayor and assembly campaign ticket, claiming to represent those who do not want an extra level of government in London.

He says his decision to step down came because the electoral system had been organised to make it difficult for anyone, other than someone representing a major political party, to stand as a candidate.

However, in a letter pledging his support to the Labour candidate, he warned that he would be ready to cause confusion again should Mr Dobson prove to be a poor mayor. "Whilst you are performing your office, I am sure that you will do it wisely," he said. "Otherwise you must remember that there is another election in four years' time and I could stand again."

And while Mr Dobson acknowledges that he may have been merely a "minor irritation" to his namesake, he insists his campaign was a serious attempt to give a voice to Londoners who object to the "expense and bureaucracy of a mayor and London assembly".

When Mr Dobson announced his candidacy he denied that he was deliberately trying to mislead voters.

"It is just pure coincidence that we have the same name. I had it first, I'm older than him," he said.

But the former health secretary's campaign team was concerned that the retired publisher would syphon votes from Labour's official candidate.

webTitle: 'What else is there in West Cumbria?'

fields.headline: 'What else is there in West Cumbria?'
fields.standfirst:
The issues explained: Sellafield
More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The enormous size of the Sellafield reprocessing plant dominates the landscape in a way which is absolutely symbolic of its importance to the economy of a classic 'forgotten' strip of peripheral Britain.
fields.body:
Any notion that the nuclear industry is dead and buried disappears when you top the rocky hill above Ravenglass, negotiate the nasty Z-bend round Muncaster Castle and look North across a magnificent panorama of mountains, sand and sea.

Even in this spectacular setting, the enormous size of the Sellafield reprocessing plant dominates the landscape in a way which is absolutely symbolic of its importance to the economy of a classic 'forgotten' strip of peripheral Britain.

Albright and Wilson may still make chemicals at Whitehaven, and if you have a Kangol beret it will almost certainly have been made in Cleator Moor, but such employers are dwarves beside the 6,000 full-time and 4,000 contract jobs at the beleaguered plant.

"What else is there in West Cumbria?" asks farmer Jim Skivington rhetorically. "Not just for jobs, but any charitable work, any society (his own is the Cumbria Ferret Association) will have British Nuclear Fuels in there, giving it a helping hand."

But such predictable phrases go in tandem, these days, with an acknowledgement that such dependence on a single employer is folly, especially as the coastal fringe between Carlisle and Barrow has been through all this before. First its ports, in the 1930s, and then its mines 20 years later were made redundant by cheaper competitors with devastating effect; whole streets abandoned as their owners left for Yorkshire and the Midlands to find work.

For the past decade, as Sellafield has slimmed from over 15,000, local efforts have been made at all levels to avoid another such catastrophe, most impressively at the Westlake business park which offers a cleaner and more acceptable version of the frontiers of science.

Helped by European money, an old mansion near Whitehaven has been converted and hugely expanded with handsome outbuildings to house small, very hi-tech businesses. Their personnel departments recruit deliberately and directly from BNFL brains who want to go non-nuclear.

Larger, less-skilled workforces may meanwhile be wanted by the call-centre companies, still scouting cheap areas of the North and happy with anywhere so long as the locals have a friendly accent - one of the undoubted assets of Cumbria. Kangol's new management is planning a gradual expansion too, and one of the great advantages of a gradual BNFL retreat would be the effect on assisted area status (AAS) and similar deprivation-linked Government or European aid.

The area's Labour MP Jack Cunningham still smarts from a meeting with Margaret Thatcher and Sir Keith Joseph, who withdrew AAS from almost all of his Copeland constituency because Sellafield made it look like a boomtown. "It was ironic," he recalls, "that the presence of the plant prevented us from getting exactly the targeted aid we needed to help build up alternatives for the day - if and when - BNFL wound down or closed."

The greatest psychological counter to depression about a Sellafield shutdown also relates to the plant's overbearing presence in the landscape. Local councillor Margaret Woodburn has been a school governor for some 30 years and is all too familiar with the 'Sellafield effect'.

"You wonder how many jobs we've actually lost because of Sellafield," she says. "I couldn't count the number of times that someone's accepted a teaching job here and then rung up a few days later, rather embarrassed, to say: 'Um, well, it's my partner, you see. When I told them exactly where the job was they said: What? Near that nuclear place? No way!'"

webTitle: To Dobson, from Dobson. Why the independent Frank stood down.

fields.headline: To Dobson, from Dobson. Why the independent Frank stood down.
fields.trailText: Dear Mr. Dobson
fields.body:
Dear Mr. Dobson

I would imagine that I have been a minor irritation to you over the last few weeks. I would like to stress that my campaign has been a serious attempt to give a voice to all those Londoners who object to the expense and bureaucracy of a Mayor and London Assembly. The government put substantial resources behind getting a 'yes' vote in the original referendum but still only managed to obtain the approval of less than 25% of London's five million voters.

When I have been out talking to electors, I have had a consistent 20% who will refuse to vote as they disagree with the principle of the Assembly. They are backed up by very many more who did not want the Assembly but, as it is obviously going to exist, they feel that they should vote.

The system for the election of Mayor has been organised so that it is extremely difficult for anyone, other than a major political party, to stand as a candidate. Nevertheless, I gained a sponsor for the deposit and sufficient support across London to obtain the necessary 330 voters' signatures. A substantial amount of the additional £10,000 for the leaflet had also been pledged.

Now that we have reached the time for nominations to be registered, I have had to think very hard about my next step. I have received an incredible amount of publicity in the media and I acknowledge that this is due in no small part to our shared name. Despite this attention, I have been somewhat disappointed to find whilst canvassing that, although many people agreed with my policy, few people knew of me or else they confused me with yourself. I thought that my only way of getting better known to the voters would be through the official leaflet, but how many people are going to read 16 pages of political speeches? Therefore, as I would appear to have little chance of getting better known, or being elected, I have decided to withdraw from the election.

Equally important is the confusion that voters may find with our names. As I said at the outset, it was never my intention to cause difficulties for the voters. Up to now only three of us have received much publicity from the media; these being the two Frank Dobsons and Ken Livingstone. As I am not going to be Mayor myself, I consider that you are the one most likely to spend the budget wisely and economically. Therefore, I am still looking forward to seeing Frank Dobson as Mayor of London.

Whilst you are performing your office as Mayor, I am sure that you will do it wisely. Otherwise you must remember that there is another election in four years' time and I could stand again.

Yours sincerely

Frank S. Dobson
