webTitle: Stab victim says athlete was stalked by racist gang

fields.headline: Stab victim says athlete was stalked by racist gang
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The boyfriend of the British Olympic gold medal hope Ashia Hansen said last night he believed she had been stalked by the racist gang that subjected him to a vicious knife attack and tried to scalp him.
fields.body:
The boyfriend of the British Olympic gold medal hope Ashia Hansen said last night he believed she had been stalked by the racist gang that subjected him to a vicious knife attack and tried to scalp him.

Chris Cotter, 28, who is white, was knifed in the back and face by a gang of up to five men outside the black triple jumper's home in Birmingham on Tuesday.

"Ash now thinks that, looking back, she was followed, sometimes to and from training," Mr Cotter said. "It would not have taken much for these people to have established her routine. It is well-regimented."

The world record-holding triple jumper has told police of her fears that she was shadowed near her home and training ground in the months leading up to the attack.

As police continued to hunt down the group that left Mr Cotter with facial injuries and stab wounds, the couple were recovering from their ordeal under guard at a secret address in the West Midlands.

Hansen, 28, who is widely seen as Britain's best hope of a gold medal at the Sydney games this summer, had received a hate letter related to the attack, West Midlands police said.

The note, in letters torn from a magazine, read: "You were lucky last night. We won't make the same mistake again."

Mr Cotter, a financial adviser, was set upon by the men as he pulled up outside Hansen's home in Erdington, Birmingham, on Tuesday night.

He was stabbed three times from behind and slashed across the face. He said he was convinced that the gang had intended to maim his girlfriend.

Mr Cotter was stabbed after refusing to let the gang into her house. He revealed that in the days running up to the attack he had received racially abusive calls on his mobile phone.

Yesterday's Sunday Express quoted a police source saying that before the attack someone had tampered with the security lights at the back of Hansen's home. She noticed they were not working when she went to put the rubbish out.

fields.headline: Ian Dury dies of cancer
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText:
Musician Ian Dury today lost his long battle against cancer. Dury, 57, who is best remembered for his song Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick, had suffered from cancer of the liver. He died this morning.
 
Despite his illness, Dury continued to work, helping children's aid organisations and appearing in television advertisements.
fields.body:
Musician Ian Dury today lost his long battle against cancer. Dury, 57, who is best remembered for his song Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick, had suffered from cancer of the liver. He died this morning. Despite his illness, Dury continued to work, helping children's aid organisations and appearing in television advertisements.

As well as writing a string of hit songs, Dury was an accomplished actor and broadcaster. His agents confirmed that the musician died from cancer but were unable to say where or at exactly what time.

"We will have more details later this afternoon," a spokesman said.

Disabled by polio as a child, Dury proudly flew the flag for the acceptance of disability. Ironically, news of his final illness brought about a career resurgence. He travelled with Robbie Williams into the Sri Lankan war zone to highlight efforts to vaccinate children against polio. He also continued to performed at concerts, including Paul Weller's annual outdoor London festival in August 1998, and appeared in a number of television advertisements.

Attached to a drip, he made the most of his final months, speaking bravely and matter-of-factly about facing death. He sought to remove the taboos about the disease that had already taken some of his closest friends. He had managed to conceal his cancer for three years, but went public in a Sunday paper interview when it spread to his liver and became inoperable. Forever counting his reasons to be cheerful, he said: "You don't have cancer; it has you. The 'chemo' [chemotherapy] won't get rid of it. But it's another lease of - well, however long it is. You just don't know, but it's better than being hit by a bus tomorrow; you have time to sort yourself out."

He had reservations about using private medicine "because I'm a socialist, but I don't want to go on no waiting list and end up a dead socialist".

He leaves two grown up children from his first marriage to Elizabeth, which ended in divorce in 1985, and two young children from his second marriage, to sculptress Sophie Tilson.

webTitle: Co, Clock and Comfortable two-bed flat

fields.headline: Co, Clock and Comfortable two-bed flat
fields.trailText: BERTI THE BHOY
fields.body:
BERTI THE BHOY

There's a real buzz about Celtic these days. They're entertaining - they've just played a major part in a four-goal Old Firm thriller. They're successful - they're in with a great chance of pipping Heart of Midlothian to second place in the Scottish Premier Premiership. And they're ambitious - they're expected to make former Germany manager Berti Vogts their new head coach within the next 48 hours.

It's positive news which comes at the right time for this particularly downtrodden bunch of abject losers. As well as seriously embarrassing themselves at Ibrox, the poor old Bhoys were humbled when Willem II coach Co Adriaanse, who was sounded out for the managerial vacancy despite having far too few letters in his first name to be taken seriously, decided he'd rather stay in Holland.

Anyway, Vogts was always the Celtic board's first choice. Yes he was. That's because they know a winner when they see one (so long as they haven't pulled on a Liverpool shirt at any point during their career). Little Berti's track record is better than good, assisting Franz Beckenbauer when Germany won Italia 90 and leading his country to their universally popular victory at Euro 96. Most importantly, he's a good friend of Manchester United overlord Alex 'Alec' Ferguson. And that's more important than tangible success, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EVERYBODY LOVES AN ADVERT

Economist.com - Forthright opinion and lively analysis of global politics and business, plus handy summaries of the week's news. www.economist.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CLOCK WORK

Tick tock, tick tock. There's a clock next to Kelvin Koogan's bed and it moves inexorably towards the start of Euro 2000. Each morning it not only reminds Kelvin that the little hand moves a lot slower than the big hand, but also that he must soon make some of the toughest decisions of his managerial career. Like who might get a game for England this summer.

"If I had a blank sheet of paper I would put five names on it - Shearer, Adams, Campbell, David Beckham and David Seaman," Koogan revealed today, inspiring a nation with confidence by remembering the names of only five players - two of whose England places are a matter of national debate. Fortunately for Koogan he's got another three games (count 'em) to decide the other 17 places in his squad.

"Why doesn't the Fiver get off Koogan's back?" the world wonders. "He hasn't done anything wrong so far." Perhaps the world is right. fields.headline: Arts: going down the tube?
fields.trailText: Last year, independent producer John Wyver bravely attacked the desperate state of arts programmes on television. His assault was met with the echoing sound of cultural dead bats, as the broadcasters defended themselves with the determination of Geoffrey Boycott keeping out West Indian fast bowlers. These were "old" arguments, arts programmes were "ambitious and adventurous".
fields.body:
Last year, independent producer John Wyver bravely attacked the desperate state of arts programmes on television. His assault was met with the echoing sound of cultural dead bats, as the broadcasters defended themselves with the determination of Geoffrey Boycott keeping out West Indian fast bowlers. These were "old" arguments, arts programmes were "ambitious and adventurous".

In the intervening months, everything has pointed to Wyver being right. Other genres - current affairs, sitcom, documentary - may have problems but arts programmes are in a major crisis from which they may never escape.

The BBC deserve credit for creating ArtZone, the brand new Sunday night block, but it paints the unmistakable image of an arts wagon train forming a circle against the men with bows and arrows. Even BBC2 controller Jane Root says fatalistically, "OK, it may fail, but unless you try something new you are doomed."

The as yet unanswered question is, will the ArtZone be a useful signpost for the audience or is it telling the uncommitted viewer to Keep Out? The new programme block promises, in that ghastly BBC word, several "landmark" series, but will being fenced off somehow diminish promising series like Neil McGregor's examination of Christ in art?

I hope the bold new strategy succeeds, but ArtZone cannot really disguise the fundamental problems arts television faces. Since Kim Evans left, apparently disillusioned, for the Arts Council last summer, the BBC have not replaced her as arts head. It is unimaginable, indeed incredible, that an organisation John Birt described as "an important reason for the extraordinary cultural vitality of the UK" could be without permanent leadership in this area for so many months. This, after all, should be one of the most exciting jobs in British television.

At Channel 4, Janice Hadlow has arrived from the BBC. No one doubts her talents, but she is expected to be the John Prescott of Channel 4, running a jumbo department and offering creative leadership not only in the arts but in history and religion too.

In the meantime, the regular week-to-week representation of arts and culture on television is withering away. The big series exemplified by Renaissance are still there, but Close Up, Tx, Bookmark and Art House have all disappeared. The key problem is ratings. In an era of intense competition no genre can live in the past. Television needs to reflect changes in the arts world itself, as well as in the way television is made and viewed. Audiences for arts programmes are passionate, but often small. Week one of both ArtZone and the Channel 4 series Howard Goodall's Big Bangs peaked at around 700,000 viewers.

There is also an identity crisis in arts programmes. On the one hand, if popular cultural figures such as Michael Flatley or Vic and Bob appear in arts programmes, those series are quickly accused of dumbing down. On the other, all that culturati conversation inside the London arts and media bubble is attacked for insular elitism.

The arts community itself must bear some responsibility for this confusion. It expects television coverage by divine right without always recognising the need to communicate with the audience. Even worse, few of them seem to watch arts programmes on television, despite being the first to moan about their absence.

My own view is that the purpose of arts programming is to encourage, or even inspire, viewers to explore their own cultural life, and the cultural life of their community. A series such as This is Modern Art should move you to see art in a different way and want to see some paintings. Equally, a documentary about Cher or George Michael is only worth showing if it illuminates their music in a way that makes you want to listen to them afresh.

In 2000, Britain will resound to the click of scissors cutting ribbons as new arts institutions open, from Walsall's new gallery to the Tate Modern. Culturally, we are more eclectic and better educated than ever. Damien Hirst and line dancing, Glyndebourne and Geri Halliwell could all be on one person's cultural menu. We are among the world leaders in many artistic disciplines.

To avoid extinction, arts television needs bold thinking, leadership that gives programme makers confidence. It needs regular strands, not only to give the audience a pattern to their viewing, but also to attract the brightest programme makers into arts output. It also needs the arts industry to work with the broadcasters to bring the high costs of reproducing performance on television down before it is too late.

None of this is easy, quite the reverse, but if arts television becomes the preserve only of those who can afford to pay for it, then not only will broadcasting be the poorer, but so will the nation at large.

John Willis is chief executive of United Productions

webTitle: We must stop this talent drain

fields.headline: We must stop this talent drain
fields.trailText: Another week, another new media executive leaves a newspaper group. Danny Meadows Klue, publisher of the electronic Telegraph has announced he is off to do something "dot.com-ish". Before that, as reported on these pages last week, Martin Dunn had announced he was leaving Associated's new media arm.
fields.body:
Another week, another new media executive leaves a newspaper group. Danny Meadows Klue, publisher of the electronic Telegraph has announced he is off to do something "dot.com-ish". Before that, as reported on these pages last week, Martin Dunn had announced he was leaving Associated's new media arm.

The full list of departures from newspapers' new media operations is now so lengthy that we could fill the rest of the column with it. Should we be bothered? Well, no and yes. No, because the turnover in newspapers, though very visible, is nowhere near as high as in other industries, and because it also allows for internal promotions and career development at the sort of blistering pace that is standard in new media. But yes, because there is the danger that the industry could be permanently losing really good talent unnecessarily.

So why do they go? Some will simply have reached the end of a bit of their career and it is time to move on. The common theory is simply that they run off to earn money and become dot.com millionaires. But to assume that this is the only reason is firstly being rather presumptuous about people's values, and secondly means ignoring other causes that might be more difficult to accept but are ultimately easier to resolve.

It is true that many of those who left at first (often rather abruptly) just weren't up to the job. The net had not been deemed important, most executives thought it was simply a fad, and as a result it often fell into the hands of those who were there and willing to do it, regardless of quality. If you'd read half of Nicholas Negroponte's Being Digital and could use a computer with a mouse, you were in.

Many companies, incidentally, are still at that stage. Very few magazine companies have had the courage to put their best editorial and commercial people on their internet operations. As a result it is simply not taken seriously by the staff who hold the most sway in the organisation.

Soon, however, things changed, and in their place came a bunch of big hitters from the traditional business. Names such as Ellis Watson, formerly marketing director at the Sun, made the move to new media, gladly swapping their suits for chinos. It was the equivalent of putting a flag up outside the building saying "We take the net very seriously. Honest." But they too have now started to leave. Watson, for example, left to form his own start-up after a matter of months. This is the real problem.

When you speak to ex-newspaper new media people the same grumbles occur time after time - and money is not usually top of the list. The process is normally that they get increasingly annoyed and finally that persistent headhunter who keeps on ringing, or the half-baked idea they've had in the bath starts to look like a God-given escape route.

And what are those grumbles? It is always the same. They never get any help from the editorial team; they have to fight to get a mention of their own site in the paper while competitors are spending millions of pounds advertising on their pages; there's no money to invest in content or technology or marketing or staff. And finally there is the politics - having thought they'd left that behind for the fast-moving, cuddly world of new media, they find themselves embroiled in endless turf wars between the old and the new.

Lack of support from senior editorial staff is a frequent grumble - both on a day-to-day and a strategic level. Had I been working at Associated New Media last year when Paul Dacre announced at the Daily Mail's summer party: "A lot of people say that the internet is the future for newspapers, well, I say to that: bullshit.com." I would have left within the week (which, it has to be said, is probably a fair sign that I wouldn't have been working there in the first place).

Of course, not everywhere has these problems. Many organisations, old and new, are learning to put aside their initial suspicions of each other and get along famously. When they do, the results can be most impressive (I will modestly put Guardian Unlimited's award-winning news operation forward as an example).

It's important to realise that this is not exclusively newspaper, or even media territory. I recently met a very smart head of internet strategy at a major travel retailer who was telling similar tales of woe.

He had gone through a phase initially of having the group's management shunning the internet operation, which had brought about one set of problems and resulted in him not being able to get anything done. Now he was having to deal with them all trying to own it, which brought a new set of problems, but also resulted in him not being able to get anything done. He reckoned they had lost almost half of this year fighting internal political battles.

"Why are you still there?" I asked. He didn't reply. They would be foolish to lose him, but they probably will.

 Simon Waldman is head of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Craig Kelly
fields.trailText: What are you driving?
fields.body:
What are you driving?

A black BMW 320i. It's quite sporty but not flash.

What does that say about you?

I like to have fun.

What do you like about it?

I love it because it's easy to drive - it has a good kick to it with lots of power and I feel safe.

Why did you buy it?

I had just started to earn money as an actor and I needed a car. I'd always wanted a BMW and this one just called out to me from the car lot.

What kind of driver are you?

Good. I don't batter the car. I'm pretty careful but there's a difference between careful and boring. I don't crawl along at 20 miles an hour.

Any bad habits?

I'm not going to admit to any.

Any driving test tales?

I passed third time when I was 17 - although I looked 12.

What was your first car?

A battered Ford Escort mark II that cost £200. At the time I thought it was brilliant.

What do you use your car for?

It's a luxury. I use it when visiting friends or my parents.

Have you experienced road rage?

Yes. It's always frustrating but I'm calm on the roads and tend to approach things sensibly. Once or twice I've had to get out of the car and say "Be careful" to other drivers.

What sort of state is your car in?

It's pretty tidy except for the glove compartment, where it's carnage - full of tapes and books, cloths, all sorts - but that's ok, it shows it's lived in.

What's in the boot?

Two big Sony speakers that I'm trying to get repaired.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

No, but I've had a few snogs.

What music do you listen to on the road?

I make compilation tapes of whatever music I'm into. Recently it's been Marvin Gaye, Supergrass, Moby, the Charlatans. I love being on a long stretch with my tapes.

What would be your dream car?

An old 60s Mercedes 280SL - the epitomy of cool except the image of its driver is that of retired gents who play golf. I want to reclaim it for the youth.

Who would be your dream passenger?

Someone like Helena Christensen. She'd be a good passenger for Sunday picnics.

Did you get to keep the jeep from Queer as Folk?

No it was given as a raffle prize to the Terrence Higgins Trust.

fields.headline: Test drive
fields.standfirst: BMW Z8 v Porsche 911 Turbo
fields.trailText: Fancy that: just when we're pondering the wisdom of blanket 20mph speed restrictions, two manufacturers launch road-ready race cars capable of breaking speed limits by more than 100 miles per hour. But the all-new BMW Z8 and the latest version of the Porsche 911 Turbo are, like any other car, only as dangerous as the drug crazed city trader who's driving them. In fact, as the two media launches showed, both are exceptionally good at going very slowly.
fields.body:
Fancy that: just when we're pondering the wisdom of blanket 20mph speed restrictions, two manufacturers launch road-ready race cars capable of breaking speed limits by more than 100 miles per hour. But the all-new BMW Z8 and the latest version of the Porsche 911 Turbo are, like any other car, only as dangerous as the drug crazed city trader who's driving them. In fact, as the two media launches showed, both are exceptionally good at going very slowly.

The venues proved the point. BMW unveiled the car that Pierce Brosnan used in his latest 007 caper in the go-slow of downtown LA. Once you come unstuck from the inner-city glue, you can let rip on the coast road, as long as you stay under 55mph. And if that isn't frustration enough, the 400bhp roadster with a 0-60 time of just 4.7 seconds was accompanied en route by a team of highway police, hired by BMW to make sure everyone stayed calm.

The Porsche launch, a few days later in southern Spain, was equally hamstrung. A man with a cane pointed to the fast bits of the route shown on the projector - but the bosses made it clear that we must observe all speed limits. Given the 420bhp of muscle that waited outside (Porsche's most powerful car to date) it seemed Porsche might have had more luck convincing a pack of starving greyhounds not to feel interested in the world's most chewable rabbit.

There was a serious reason for BMW's decision to air its first batch of supercars in LA. The Z8 is capable of Tysonesque brutality, but that was not, of course, the maker's key point. More significant to the agenda was that this is "a sports car virtually purpose-built for a country with boulevards and freeways simply begging you to cruise along in style" a country, "where the elite shape their bodies to ultimate beauty". Dodgy analogy indeed, but the Z8's key charm is its tuxedoed gentility.

Of course it's shockingly expensive, though this won't put people off. Only 70 Z8s will come to the UK in the first year and when sales start this May, you'll be lucky to get a sniff - unless you booked a place in the queue a long time ago and are prepared to wait two years.

Set for normal response, the Z8 surges forward in town with an unmistakable V8 burble; switch to the sport setting and you get an instant, drag-car punch. In the event, BMW allowed us onto a test track. And when it's pushed hard and the Dynamic Stability Control button is off, the Z8 handles with far more precision and balance than its mighty frame might suggest. Despite the fact that the ride is seriously silky, the aluminium body conceals true supercar potential. It's not 911-nimble, but as a straight-line racer, it's breathtakingly quick.

Quickness is, however, a relative concept, as I found when I settled into Porsche's latest. For many reasons, the 911 Turbo is the car that needs no PR. Firstly, it has the kind of heritage that comes only with a model that can trace its roots back to Ferdinand Porsche's first design doodles in the 1930s. Sporty offshoot of the Beetle, the first-throw 911 emerged in 1963, but it wasn't until 1974 that the first turbo came along. With an output of 260bhp, the car was a shocker and it heralded a styling trend that, in the 1980s, would establish Porsche as the tarmac equivalent of the shoulder pad.

Moving relentlessly up the power range, the latest incarnation shifts to 62mph in just 4.2 seconds and belts on relentlessly to a permitted maximum of 189mph. Bearing British sensitivity to speed in mind, I asked Porsche's bosses whether they didn't feel sensitive to the social implications of making cars that go faster and faster? For the record, no, they don't. But you can't say I didn't ask.

Beneath its skin, the new Turbo harbours big changes. No longer air-cooled, as was the predecessor of 1998, it now relies upon a standard-fit super-intelligent four-wheel drive system which shifts traction to wherever the road best offers grip. Power comes from a six-cylinder engine first designed for use in the Boxster.

To prevent the kind of lift-off oversteer that has Audi TT salesmen sweating in their sleep, the Turbo has a PSM (Porsche Stability Management). But with so much technology on board, is it not, perchance, a teeny bit dull to drive? The answer to that is in my test notes: "Ooh, is that supposed to happen? Blimey! What the_?" In the first few miles, it does make you go all dizzy. The gearchange is surprisingly light, given its job, but the steering is obsessed with providing you with a forensic report on the road - every tiny twist in the tarmac is faithfully fed back and on the first (slightly unexpected) bend, the trouble downstairs is reported - and ruthlessly ironed out. Given the limitless acceleration and the huge willingness of third and fourth gears to deal with all range of speeds, it's not long before you start to settle in and relax. As looks go, the turbo has returned to the safe side of overt. There is a hinted measure of aggression in the deep front air intakes, while the scoops on the rear haunches make it clear from any distance that this is a one-off car. But its muscularity is far more of a suggestion than a full-on scream.

So which is better? Unfortunately, we were not able to run a nose-to-tail test, but the psychological imprint from each test is long-lasting. For the ultimate dynamic drive, the 911 pulls a clear nose ahead of the Z8. Both machines sit comfortably at the pinnacle of supercar status. Yet if shameless decadence is your bag, the BMW may just edge ahead as a true transport of delight. This sort of dosh, however, has to be all about performance. In which case, the only thing you need know is that the Porsche so many of us secretly want has just got that bit better.

webTitle: Would you buy a second hand car from this website?

fields.headline: Would you buy a second hand car from this website?
fields.standfirst: Dave Simpson made all the classic mistakes buying a car on the internet. But it was worth it in the end
fields.trailText: Dave Simpson made all the classic mistakes buying a car on the internet. But it was worth it in the end
fields.body:
Buying a car on the internet looks easy on the Vauxhall ad. One click and, as the little boy exclaims, "Mum, Dad just bought a car!" How wonderful. Now the trend is sweeping into used car sales. One dealer tells me that around 35% of his business originates via the web. However, for the uninitiated, finding a used car online can bring both bargains and pitfalls.

My online nightmare began when I found myself looking for my first car at the age of 36. My girlfriend, 34, who has also never owned a car, asked some workmates for advice. "Check it's got four wheels and a steering wheel," they said, before falling about laughing. A mate of a mate of a mate who was a mechanic wasn't much help either. "You want to see my mate Phil," he said.

In exasperation, I turned towards something I did at least know a little about: the net. Innocently enough, I thought it helped that I knew exactly what I wanted (Fiat Punto SX, around £5000, in rialto blue or turquoise, or silver at a push). Within minutes going online and typing in a search for "Used cars", I found a car. T reg, five grand. What a bargain!

As instructed, I sent an email. A salesman phoned me back. "Sorry, mate," he breezed. "We've sold that one." There were lots of other Puntos, everywhere, but in the wrong colour, at the wrong price, or at the other end of the country. However, after a couple of weeks of failed enquiries and increasingly square eyes, I was up and off again. A car supermarket called to say they had my dream car. Sure, they were 100 miles away and I didn't have a car to get there, but I wanted that vehicle. I thought about putting down a phoned deposit to hold the car but didn't bother, because a friend had warned me it would look too keen. I was excited and set off. Four trains later, as I approached the garage at dusk I pondered the merits of viewing a car in semi-darkness. I met the slightly sheepish-looking salesman at 4.30. He sat me down and made me a cup of tea as he explained everything: how good the internet was for business, how they got online inquiries from 200 miles away, and how another salesman had sold my car at 1pm. I had left my house at 12.55.

By now, I was hardly sleeping, computer crazed and vulnerable. Alarm bells should really have rung when I saw the rialto blue SX on the website of a dealer less than an hour away, as the branch much closer to home had just mysteriously closed down. But I was exhausted, and decided that this shiny motor was my car. In desperation I ignored the filthy engine (including two dead wasps), the huge dent in the passenger door and the knackered wheel trims that suggested that the car been driven by several boy racers. Fatefully, I handed over £100 deposit, but what remained of my mental faculties prompted me to get an AA inspection. My first good move. Not only did the car have several other faults, but catastrophically was minus its essential Fiat immobiliser key (these cost £1000 to replace) and thus was virtually unsalable. I pulled out of the deal.

The whole fiasco cost me hours of online phone bills, the £100 deposit, £150 on the AA inspection/HPI test and a couple of millimetres of my hairline.

However, I've finally taken delivery of a beautiful, bargain Punto, courtesy of the first website I visited, who kept my details. It's not turquoise, rialto blue or silver, but a strange "metallic burnt orange" that my girlfriend insists matches my remaining barnet. The engine is clean as a whistle, without so much as a fly. It's not exactly what I wanted, and technically a gingernut, but my lovely car is highly desirable. How do I know this? Because last time I looked, it was still being advertised on the web.

The idiot's guide to buying a used car on the net

1 Know your sites Don't spend hours trawling - identify around half a dozen (usually bigger) sites with good access to the vehicle you're after, and visit them daily. Car supermarket sites (such as www.directcars.co.uk in Sheffield and www.fow.co.uk in Cheshire) list hundreds of cars each.

2 Be flexible Have a good idea about the car you're looking for, but don't be too inflexible - you stand a better chance if you have a range of options.

3 Use a vehicle locator Register your requirements at locator websites such as www.carsource.co.uk or www.fish4cars.co.uk. They will search the internet (locally, region ally or nationally) for you, mailing you daily with the results.

4 Keep looking elsewhere Don't base your search entirely on the net. Keep an eye on used car magazines, such as Autotrader, for dealers specialising in the make you're after. They will often list a web site as well.

5 Watch out for infrequent updates The best sites are updated several times daily, but some lie unchanged for days, even weeks at a time.

6 Found that car? Sites usually ask you to email them, for a salesman to contact you by telephone. Don't wait for that - phone them straight away.

7 Consider a credit card deposit Giving a deposit over the phone means they'll hold the car for you until you get there.

8 Be patient Occasionally the excessive traffic to sites will sever your net connection, but don't be put off.

9 Be wary If something sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Watch out for things like photos used "for illustration only", of another, more desirable motor.

10 Wheel that deal Inspect the vehicle thoroughly, negotiating price reductions for any defects. An HPI check into the vehicle's history/mileage is advisable, along with an AA or RAC vehicle inspection.

fields.headline: Bogside revisited
fields.standfirst: As the inquiry into one of the most shocking events in Northern Ireland's troubled history gets under way,  Derek Brown recalls the time he spent in Londonderry in the year leading up to Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: Bloody Sunday was no one-off event. It did not just erupt spontaneously. It  was the culmination of an extraordinary period of terror, political and  military bungling and cynical opportunism by the paramilitary hoodlums of  Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Bloody Sunday was no one-off event. It did not just erupt spontaneously. It was the culmination of an extraordinary period of terror, political and military bungling and cynical opportunism by the paramilitary hoodlums of Northern Ireland.

In a sense, the civil rights marchers who walked into a hail of paratroop regiment bullets were desperately naive. They, and others like them, had launched the province on a process of irrevocable change, with the mass demonstrations of the late 1960s. But by January 1972, when they gathered in Londonderry's Bogside, their day was long over. The streets belonged to the gunmen, in and out of uniform.

Nearly a year earlier, in February 1971, I set foot in Northern Ireland for the first time, dispatched by the Guardian's Manchester newsdesk in response to the death of Gunner Robert Curtis, the first British soldier killed in the modern Troubles. Already, the security situation in the province had deteriorated, from chaotic riot control to organised murder.

As the year wore on, I made ever more frequent trips across the Irish sea, from my less-than-demanding post as the Guardian's number two man in the Leeds district office. In August a whole boat race crew of us hurriedly descended on Belfast to cover the spectacularly dreadful events attending the introduction of internment without trial.

Thousands of Ulster families were forced from their homes in that frenzied week. Many of them made their way, in panic, to the Irish Republic to seek sanctuary. It was, we reckoned, the biggest forced population movement in Europe since the end of the second world war. Today, we call it ethnic cleansing.

As new ghettos appeared in Belfast, Londonderry was also dividing itself. On the east side of the Foyle river, a scattering of Catholic families uprooted themselves from the mainly Protestant housing estates. On the west bank, the Protestant minority was concentrated within the massive 17th century walls of the old city. Beyond those walls, the sprawling and unlovely estates of Bogside and Creggan were overwhelmingly Catholic, and deeply permeated by radical republicanism.

A new phenomenon, the notion of a no-go area, took tangible form. It was the outcome of an extraordinary two-year contest known as The Battle of Bogside. The words "You Are Now Entering Free Derry" were neatly painted on a gable wall at the entrance to Bogside.

Bizarre things happened: for a short period the old Official IRA and its much more deadly offspring, the Provisional IRA, took turns at guarding a ramshackle checkpoint equipped with an ancient and almost certainly unserviceable heavy machine gun.

The army presence in Free Derry was reduced to tokenism. (The Royal Ulster Constabulary had long since been excluded). Convoys of 'pigs' - the local name for elderly Humber armoured personnel carriers - made their way through a hail of stones and petrol bombs to the military camp in Blighs Lane, Creggan, and other isolated outposts.

There was a strange ritualism about violence. Almost every day, youths would gather at 'Aggro Corner', at the entrance to Bogside, to hurl stones and obscenities at the barricaded troops and RUC men. A deadly prank was invented: lads would thwack a plank against the ground, to imitate the crack of gunfire. All too often the bullets were real, as snipers and army marksmen fought duels in the densely inhabited estates.

The IRA ran the show. By contrast with the gung-ho gunmen and bombers of Belfast and the border counties, the Derry 'brigade' was a notably disciplined outfit. Under the leadership of young militants like Martin McGuinness, it took pride in avoiding (many) civilian casualties.

But it did not lack ruthlessness: soldiers and policemen were sniped, kidnapped and dispatched without mercy. Towards the end of 1971, there was a vicious, cowardly campaign in which young Londonderry girls who had committed the crime of going out with soldiers were tarred and feathered.

This was the Londonderry where the civil rights marchers gathered on what was to be Bloody Sunday; a city already wracked by violent bloodshed. The organisers of the march swore, and are swearing still, that theirs was a peaceful, unarmed demonstration, and that they were attacked without warning or justification by the paratroopers.

But those who were there (I was not, on that day) have a different story to tell. There was prolonged and violent rioting, and the first shot, before the paras were unleashed, was almost certainly fired at the soldiers and not by them.

What happened subsequently was, by any measure, vile and unjustifiable, and it changed Northern Ireland forever. Less than two months after Bloody Sunday, the unionist provincial government was swept aside and replaced by direct rule from Westminster, in the amiably bumbling form of Willie Whitelaw.

Operation Motorman, in the summer of 1972, smashed down the physical barricades around Free Derry, but left the mental barriers intact.

It is a period of Northern Ireland's history that people seem unable to see in anything other than black and white. There are some unionists who believe to this day that Bloody Sunday was cynically contrived by the republicans as a propaganda coup. There are many, many nationalists for whom the shootings and their aftermath remain the ultimate proofs of British depravity and duplicity.

The Saville inquiry may throw up new facts and new interpretations but it is unlikely to dispel those hardcore convictions. Bloody Sunday will remain embedded in the history, folklore and psychology of Northern Ireland.

Battle of the Bogside
fields.bodyText: Bloody Sunday was no one-off event. It did not just erupt spontaneously. It was the culmination of an extraordinary period of terror, political and military bungling and cynical opportunism by the paramilitary hoodlums of Northern Ireland. In a sense, the civil rights marchers who walked into a hail of paratroop regiment bullets were desperately naive. They, and others like them, had launched the province on a process of irrevocable change, with the mass demonstrations of the late 1960s. But by January 1972, when they gathered in Londonderry's Bogside, their day was long over. The streets belonged to the gunmen, in and out of uniform. Nearly a year earlier, in February 1971, I set foot in Northern Ireland for the first time, dispatched by the Guardian's Manchester newsdesk in response to the death of Gunner Robert Curtis, the first British soldier killed in the modern Troubles. Already, the security situation in the province had deteriorated, from chaotic riot control to organised murder. As the year wore on, I made ever more frequent trips across the Irish sea, from my less-than-demanding post as the Guardian's number two man in the Leeds district office. In August a whole boat race crew of us hurriedly descended on Belfast to cover the spectacularly dreadful events attending the introduction of internment without trial. Thousands of Ulster families were forced from their homes in that frenzied week. Many of them made their way, in panic, to the Irish Republic to seek sanctuary. It was, we reckoned, the biggest forced population movement in Europe since the end of the second world war. Today, we call it ethnic cleansing. As new ghettos appeared in Belfast, Londonderry was also dividing itself. On the east side of the Foyle river, a scattering of Catholic families uprooted themselves from the mainly Protestant housing estates. On the west bank, the Protestant minority was concentrated within the massive 17th century walls of the old city. Beyond those walls, the sprawling and unlovely estates of Bogside and Creggan were overwhelmingly Catholic, and deeply permeated by radical republicanism. A new phenomenon, the notion of a no-go area, took tangible form. It was the outcome of an extraordinary two-year contest known as The Battle of Bogside. The words "You Are Now Entering Free Derry" were neatly painted on a gable wall at the entrance to Bogside. Bizarre things happened: for a short period the old Official IRA and its much more deadly offspring, the Provisional IRA, took turns at guarding a ramshackle checkpoint equipped with an ancient and almost certainly unserviceable heavy machine gun. The army presence in Free Derry was reduced to tokenism. (The Royal Ulster Constabulary had long since been excluded). Convoys of 'pigs' - the local name for elderly Humber armoured personnel carriers - made their way through a hail of stones and petrol bombs to the military camp in Blighs Lane, Creggan, and other isolated outposts. There was a strange ritualism about violence. Almost every day, youths would gather at 'Aggro Corner', at the entrance to Bogside, to hurl stones and obscenities at the barricaded troops and RUC men. A deadly prank was invented: lads would thwack a plank against the ground, to imitate the crack of gunfire. All too often the bullets were real, as snipers and army marksmen fought duels in the densely inhabited estates. The IRA ran the show. By contrast with the gung-ho gunmen and bombers of Belfast and the border counties, the Derry 'brigade' was a notably disciplined outfit. Under the leadership of young militants like Martin McGuinness, it took pride in avoiding (many) civilian casualties. But it did not lack ruthlessness: soldiers and policemen were sniped, kidnapped and dispatched without mercy. Towards the end of 1971, there was a vicious, cowardly campaign in which young Londonderry girls who had committed the crime of going out with soldiers were tarred and feathered. This was the Londonderry where the civil rights marchers gathered on what was to be Bloody Sunday; a city already wracked by violent bloodshed. The organisers of the march swore, and are swearing still, that theirs was a peaceful, unarmed demonstration, and that they were attacked without warning or justification by the paratroopers. But those who were there (I was not, on that day) have a different story to tell. There was prolonged and violent rioting, and the first shot, before the paras were unleashed, was almost certainly fired at the soldiers and not by them. What happened subsequently was, by any measure, vile and unjustifiable, and it changed Northern Ireland forever. Less than two months after Bloody Sunday, the unionist provincial government was swept aside and replaced by direct rule from Westminster, in the amiably bumbling form of Willie Whitelaw. Operation Motorman, in the summer of 1972, smashed down the physical barricades around Free Derry, but left the mental barriers intact. It is a period of Northern Ireland's history that people seem unable to see in anything other than black and white. There are some unionists who believe to this day that Bloody Sunday was cynically contrived by the republicans as a propaganda coup. There are many, many nationalists for whom the shootings and their aftermath remain the ultimate proofs of British depravity and duplicity. The Saville inquiry may throw up new facts and new interpretations but it is unlikely to dispel those hardcore convictions. Bloody Sunday will remain embedded in the history, folklore and psychology of Northern Ireland. Useful links: News Unlimited special report on Northern Ireland Battle of the Bogside

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday: the never-ending inquiry
fields.standfirst: As the Saville inquiry into the Bloody Sunday shootings in Londonderry opens, Derek Brown, a Guardian correspondent in Northern Ireland from 1971 to 1977, explains the enduring passion and pain surrounding the events of January 30, 1972
fields.trailText:
Why is Bloody Sunday back in the news?
Since 1969 more than 3,250 people have died in the Northern Ireland troubles. None has been mourned more publicly than the 14 who were shot dead by British paratroopers during a civil rights protest in the Bogside district of Londonderry on January 30, 1972. This morning, more than 28 years after the event, a new public inquiry headed by Lord Saville of Newdigate opened into the shootings.
fields.body:
Why is Bloody Sunday back in the news?
Since 1969 more than 3,250 people have died in the Northern Ireland troubles. None has been mourned more publicly than the 14 who were shot dead by British paratroopers during a civil rights protest in the Bogside district of Londonderry on January 30, 1972. This morning, more than 28 years after the event, a new public inquiry headed by Lord Saville of Newdigate opened into the shootings.

Hasn't the Saville inquiry been under way for some time?
It was announced by Tony Blair in January 1998. He was responding to the persistent demands of the Irish government, a key player in the faltering peace process, for a new and definitive inquiry. Since then, Saville and his co-judges have amassed at least 60,000 pages of written submissions. They have interviewed nearly 1,500 civilians, soldiers, police officers, journalists and government officials. They have been embroiled in interminable legal arguments about the identification of military witnesses. Saville wanted the former soldiers involved in the shootings to be named, but the House of Lords ruled that they were entitled to the protection of anonymity.

So what is happening today?
Saville is starting to take public evidence in Londonderry's Guildhall, an ornate Victorian building which has been transformed for the hearings into a hi-tech showpiece. Computer screens will show graphic reconstructions of the Bogside as it was in 1972, when the Provisional IRA had made it effectively a no-go area for security forces.

Can any genuinely new evidence come to light, so long after the event?
There will be keen interest in the testimony of forensic experts, whose science has progressed enormously since the early 1970s. At the Widgery inquiry which followed the shootings, it was damningly suggested that several of the victims had been in contact with firearms or explosives. That finding has been demolished by re-examination of the evidence, using modern techniques.

What did Lord Widgery say?
He concluded that although there was no evidence that any of the victims had been armed, there was "a strong suspicion that some others had been firing weapons or handling bombs". That finding caused outrage among nationalists and republicans, who have always insisted that the human rights march which preceded the riot had been an entirely civilian and peaceful protest.

What was Widgery's judgment on the soldiers involved?
He said that their action had "bordered on the reckless" - a conclusion which many felt was, to put it mildly, inadequate to the occasion. Even the Northern Ireland coroner, Major Hubert O'Neill, concluded that the soldiers "ran amok that day and shot [the victims] without thinking what they were doing".

Are the Bloody Sunday weapons used still available for examination?
Some have been sold, and others destroyed. Three of the army rifles which fired fatal rounds during Bloody Sunday were mysteriously scrapped less than three months ago. The Ministry of Defence says it happened because of a bureaucratic cock-up, but there are suspicions that the rifles had been deliberately adapted for use on just such an occasion as Bloody Sunday, and that their destruction was deliberate.

Says who?
Earlier this month, veteran Northern Ireland reporters Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson revealed the existence of a secret memo, in which a senior British army commander recommended shoot-to-kill tactics to deal with riots. The memo pointed out that the then standard issue Self Loading Rifle was so powerful that its use in riots would carry a heavy risk of "collateral damage" (ie bullets could pass through the body of a target and go on to kill an innocent bystander). The general recommended the use of smaller-calibre rounds to minimise the risk.

What does the army say about shoot-to-kill?
It has always stoutly denied issuing any such orders. Throughout the troubles, it says, soldiers have been bound to follow rigid rules, set out in the controversial Yellow Card, allowing them to fire only to protect their own and other lives.

fields.headline: Big girl's browse
fields.standfirst: Eve Pollard explains why in a market swamped with teenage obsessions she had to launch her own woman's magazine
fields.trailText: So, you are a woman over 35 who has a serious magazine habit, but every title is full of teenage obsessions. What do you do? If you are like Eve Pollard you launch your own title, and reveal why the industry needs to speak to people like her
fields.body:
It seems like only a dot comma ago that once a woman reached her prime, the best she could look forward to was a graceful slide into the slow lane wearing comfy floral flip-flops, big bow blouses with pleated skirts and a serviceable beige cardigan to cover up as much as possible of a body heading in a southerly direction.

But wait. Try a Spring 2000 reality check. Aren't these exactly the clothes and accessories that have been adorning the designer catwalks and boutiques this season? So if today's 30+ woman is wearing them, isn't she flashing her fashion cred rather than thinking that these are the garments to acquire for her advancing years? After all, don't most of us believe we are so much younger than that ridiculous date in our passports?

An ICM poll commissioned by Aura, the magazine for "grown-up" women that launches on Thursday, reveals that most women aged 35-40 think of themselves as 28; 41-45 year olds feel 31, and even 46-50 year olds feel only 35. So, if these grown-up women still feel so youthful, why don't they simply stick with magazines designed for the age group to which they imagine they belong?

Real life, that's why. There's no point reading about multi-orgasms when your partner is more unloaded than Loaded these days. No point reading about how to deal with your bossy mother when suddenly she's frail and vulnerable and relies on you to make decisions for her. No point reading fanzine pieces on Liam or Leonardo when what's wanted are men we can get our hands on.

Yet these 30+ women are magazineaholics. They've been reading their glossy fix ever since they became hooked on regular doses of Honey or 19 or Petticoat or Jackie or Cosmopolitan. They need to feed their mag habit, and as they have grown older it's been harder to get satisfaction from just one title.

Woman's Journal and Women and Home, whose readers' median age is in their early 50s and Good Housekeeping whose readers' median age is 47, have been the only standard bearers for the older woman. But these magazines were established some 70 or more years ago. They are certainly mature brands. What about the 35- to 50 year old ABC1 sector of the female population which is growing by leaps and bounds?

When I first announced plans for Aura some six months ago, it was in the certain knowledge that since this had been such a hitherto unexploited route, nobody else would want to go down it. How wrong I was. Suddenly, targeting the older woman is all the rage, with newspaper supplements, magazine banded-on supplements and rumours that two more magazines targeted at the older woman are hoping to launch in the autumn. Suddenly this woman who had nothing to read is going to be swamped. But this awakening is not before time.

By 2004, women aged 35+ will number 17m. They are the fastest-growing sector of the population. More than 80% of them work, with 35-49 year olds making up the largest part of the female workforce. Their personal income comes to £100bn annually.

So, they have money, spending money. Much more than their younger sisterhood. The baby-boomers born between 1946 and 1964 are the biggest-spending group of consumers in history. These women have worked for this cash. They own it. And they possess the right to blow it. Not only that, they want it and they want it now, whether it's glam holidays, chic homes or the cosmetic polyfilla that most efficiently evens out those early wrinkles. These are not disbursements that can be delayed.

"If not now, when?" is this woman's credo. After all, no point in having that snazzy convertible if you wait until the streaked hair has bits of grey in it and your bad back will not let you buy a chassis that's too low on the ground. And buy them they do.

But when you watch TV commercials you'd never know it. When did you ever see a woman old enough to have teenage children featured in one of those adverts that show dramatic Schumacher-style driving techniques on one of those mountain roads so uninhabited that it could be filmed and re-filmed by helicopter camera teams overhead? (Even less likely is it to see a woman in this situation with real childbearing hips, but that's another story.)

Adland and, in the main, magland is populated by babes. This must change. Retailers and major companies know it is women that are buying - in our first issue, Vanessa Feltz writes about her car and why she chose it. Toyota's agency saw the piece and booked advertising. I am the self-appointed president and chairman of the movement.

Apart from the ageist argument, this is the most educated group of females the world has ever known. Why shouldn't Aura magazine include articles on politics, e-commerce and property? Research shows that women, on the whole, find women's magazines patronising, bland and out of touch with their lives. Aura won't be: it will be urbane, relevant, newsworthy, practical and not afraid of being intellectually adventurous.

I believe that when it comes to women's magazines, the differentiating factor between the first-class magazine and any other magazine is its relevance. Brilliant magazines like Vanity Fair recognise that women can enjoy in-depth pieces. OK! and Hello! are successful because they recognise that people are nosy. Aura's reality check is that today's woman is intelligent and independent and very busy.

We don't have a cover mount on our first issue because, for example, we know that these women already have a smart make-up bag and don't need a plastic one. What they do need is a magazine they want to read - something that is at once entirely new and absolutely essential. There are no embarrassing cover lines readers wouldn't want their children to see; nor the 50 ways with a chicken breast that makes you want to chicken out. In the first issue of Aura we talk to Cherie Blair, Germaine Greer and Susan Sarandon and we devote a regular monthly section to tackling the problems of the time famine experienced by this audience (and incidentally by the 40-something working mothers who work on the magazine). We also cover medicine and health, career changes, relationships and finance. The entrepreneurial spirit is flourishing among our target readers, too. The growth in self-employed women is much stronger than the growth in self-employed men. Almost a million work for themselves, 30% more than in the 1980s. Women are seeking more flexible working patterns and freedom from large, male-dominated companies.

Interestingly, Lloyds Bank monitored companies that were set up a year ago and found that of the businesses that achieved a turnover in excess of £1m, half were run by women.

A new Small Business Research Trust report shows that women are more eager to reap the rewards of information technology than men, and older female entrepreneurs in particular are the most keen to make technology work for them. This confirms that today's women are more open-minded and adventurous than most chaps.

There's no escaping the fact that some aspects of getting older are very, very boring. For example, I now have to have two sorts of shoes: ones with the high heels I used to wear for those occasions when I know I'll be sitting down and flatter ones when I'll be standing up. When I have any spare time to daydream I inwardly debate the possibility of a little light plastic surgery round the eyes. But when I talk to my friends, most of whom have already indulged, I wonder will this be a bit like painting the hallway and where will it end?

All this used to be inadmissible. But nowadays research shows we're actually happy to be growing older - statistically, a woman of 40 has more life to look forward to than back on. She is likely to live well into her 80s. If she wants to have a baby at 40 she can Blair, Bowie or Madonna it. If she wants to start a new career a high proportion of the new female entrepreneurs kick off at 35 plus.

So can we change the zeitgeist which dictates that invisibility comes into play once the chin begins to crumble and oestrogen goes on the missing list? Perhaps we may never achieve the wise matriarch status of women in more sensitive societies, but if your partner directs TV commercials and is going off on a shoot with a 23-year-old, why not ask him why she's not 43?

And speaking up for that part of female population past the first flush of youth could become fashionable. We hope so. After all that's what our big girl's browse, Aura, is all about. As a sector we are not giving up, we are not giving in. We want a magazine that shows us as we are. We may not be at our most pulchritudinous but we are less callow and more accepting of who we are.

And after all whatever adjustments we have to make, getting older is so much better than the alternative.

fields.headline: Out of fashion
fields.standfirst: Hip American men's magazine Details is facing the axe.  Edward Helmore reveals how a one-time trendsetter lost the plot
fields.trailText: It's a virtual condition of employment at the magazine giant Condé Nast that the axe may fall without warning at any time. Usually its editors wake up and learn from the morning's papers that they have no job. But even for Condé Nast last Monday was unusual: it was the turn of an entire magazine and its staff to arrive for work at 4 Times Square only to learn there was nothing to do, and as of Friday there would be no reason to come in at all.
fields.body:
It's a virtual condition of employment at the magazine giant Condé Nast that the axe may fall without warning at any time. Usually its editors wake up and learn from the morning's papers that they have no job. But even for Condé Nast last Monday was unusual: it was the turn of an entire magazine and its staff to arrive for work at 4 Times Square only to learn there was nothing to do, and as of Friday there would be no reason to come in at all.

Since 1989, when 73-year-old Condé Nast king SI Newhouse bought a hip, gay, downtown Manhattan listings magazine called Details, a succession of editors has laboured at the helm. Some were successful and used the magazine, roughly comparable to Arena, as a springboard to richer pastures in publishing. But most failed to live up to their employer's expectations and were soon cut adrift from the business of interpreting pop culture - the Condé Nast way. "You're always expecting the knock on the door, to be taken out back and shot," confirmed one former employee who was fired last week.

Though the magazine has not been killed outright - there are plans to resurrect it in the autumn under the umbrella of Condé Nast's Fairchild Publications, with an emphasis on men's fashions - the demise of Details as a sharp GQ for a younger audience adds to the list of five American men's magazines that have folded so far this year, partly as a result of the onslaught of Maxim and FHM.

Five years ago Details was the toast of magazine publishing. Under the editorship of 41-year-old James Truman, a British expatriate who had caught the eye of Newhouse while working as Vogue's music editor, it had doubled in circulation from 250,000 to 500,000 in a little under two years.

For his successors, however, Details proved a poisoned chalice and each was dispatched after little more than a year for failing to push circulation much above 500,000, a huge figure in Britain but an uneconomic one for a corporate Goliath such as Condé Nast in the US.

The company said it could not reconcile its economics with publishing a magazine that showed no signs of wanting to grow, and came to recognise the battle was lost. "We have been trying to move Details for four or five years to a place it didn't want to go," said Truman. "We really cannot make a go of a magazine unless it is selling upwards of 750,000."

In many ways, the decline and collapse of Details illustrates how hard it has become to run a magazine that depends on keeping one step ahead of trends when trends themselves are so commodified and mainstream. During its brief heyday in the mid-90s, Details had little competition in reading the runes of the culture, deciding what was unusual and then marketing that to a generation of young urban hipsters. But the invasion of other magazines, the internet, and the way television and newspapers learnt the same technique meant the game became too crowded and, by definition, uncool.

"Details was once an alternative music magazine but now everything is alt.something," says Bill Shapiro, executive editor of the magazine in its final incarnation. "Nowadays, something is alternative for 10 minutes, then it goes out on the internet and 20 minutes later everybody knows about it. Shapiro and his boss, editor Mark Golin, were drafted into service at Details last year from Maxim, the British import that in a little over three years since it was launched has achieved a staggering circulation of nearly 2m. Newhouse has become infatuated with the beer-and-babes model of men's magazine publishing and wanted some action for himself. But it seems clear that the will to transform Details into an out-and-out lads' magazine was lacking if Condé Nast could not bring itself to strip off its clothes and go all the way.

"Condé Nast's big thing was to get more sex but the SI Newhouses of the world didn't know how far they needed to go," says one former employee. "They weren't prepared to go far enough. Maxim and FHM are really raunchy and they work standing on their own, but Details comes with Vogue, Glamour and Self and they were afraid it would devalue their other magazines."

Over at 4 Times Square, the out-going staff at Details have shown no signs of going quietly. Cases of beer and spirits have been smuggled in and the stereo has been turned up loud. Mark Golin, never at a loss for a quip, said of his sudden demise as editor, "I think they saw my plans for the future and it had largely to do with farm equipment and hand puppets, and they decided it should be more of a fashion magazine."

fields.headline: Written to order?
fields.standfirst: A bitter row between St James's Palace and the Sunday Times has again put the paper's reporting style under the spotlight.  Roy Greenslade on the dangers of 'wish list' stories
fields.trailText: The Sunday Times publishes some excellent material, an echo of its illustrious past and a tribute to its continuing commitment to proper international coverage. Any paper that has Jon Swain and Marie Colvin among its foreign reporting staff can't be all bad.
fields.body:
The Sunday Times publishes some excellent material, an echo of its illustrious past and a tribute to its continuing commitment to proper international coverage. Any paper that has Jon Swain and Marie Colvin among its foreign reporting staff can't be all bad.

But the gems are harder to find in the main section nowadays amidst the dross too often masquerading as home news. Last autumn I highlighted a series of stories about anarchists and ecology campaigners which were laced with the kind of innuendo which ran counter to the Sunday Times's best traditions for impartiality and fairness. During my researches for that piece, a young man who had briefly worked for the newsdesk told me such stories were the result of "the system". He had too little experience of the business to explain what he meant and I didn't take it too seriously.

After my article was published though, I was contacted by a former Sunday Times reporter who was surprised that I should have been surprised. "Surely you know what happens," he said. "Young and inexperienced reporters spend their week trying to stand up a "wish list" of stories conceived on a Tuesday. They're under pressure to perform."

He pointed out that several reporters had left the paper because they were demoralised by working on "concept stories". Last week I spoke to two people who had done just that and both confirmed the allegation about the paper's culture. "It's not a case of following up a tip," said one. "It's about the desk having an agenda and then coming up with ideal stories to suit it. Having sold the story ideas to the editor, they then have to do their best to make them work."

It isn't a new phenomenon, especially on red-tops where someone conceives of a headline and then expects a writer to make a story or feature fit it. But the Sunday Times, a supposedly respectable broadsheet, is manifesting all sorts of tabloid qualities of late.

The most obvious recent example is its run of stories about the royal family, especially Prince William who has, in the main, benefited from revisions to the editors' code of practice which constrained the press in the wake of his mother's death. This change of heart has not inhibited the Sunday Times.

The first of its trio of tabloid-style royal stories came on January 20: Prince caught in sights of a low-flying earl, the headline said. This claimed that Prince Charles had demanded that the Earl of Suffolk stop flying over Highgrove and, in retaliation, the Earl had threatened to ban the Beaufort hunt from his estate. A month later the paper carried what its website coyly refers to as "a clarification". It was, in fact, a complete retraction of every alleged fact in the story.

Sunday Times managing editor, Richard Caseby, explains: "The story was supplied by a freelance with whom we no longer have a relationship." The second story, given front page prominence on February 6, was headlined: Charles and William in nightclub row. This claimed they had had a "stand-up confrontation" because William wanted to hold his 18th birthday in a nightclub. In journalistic jargon, this was "a flier", a speculative story without a discernible source which gives it deniability and makes it relatively safe to run.

I understand that St James's Palace has written to the Sunday Times editor, John Witherow, stating that the story is totally untrue. But the paper is standing by its source and, while willing to carry a letter contesting the story, refuses to publish an apology. Caseby says: "We don't need to apologise. We are totally happy with the story and are standing by it. We have three sources for the story, including someone in a position to know the truth. I know who the person is, as does John Witherow."

In that article there was a clue to the story the paper had been hoping to publish. It was alleged that Charles was becoming "increasingly concerned" that his son was mixing with people who take drugs.

Three weeks later the same allegation surfaced in a new form in the paper's third story, again on the front page: Police fears over William's friends. It was alleged that members of the royal protection squad looking after William, alarmed at drug-takers in his circle, have sought "clarification" from their superiors about what action they should take.

The whole basis of this front page story is contested by the Metropolitan police. They cannot verify any such request from any officer. "As far as we are concerned, the story is not true," says a spokesman. The squad's senior officer, Commander Peter Clarke, is evidently unaware of any such action. The allegation rests on the word of a source who, the paper said, "asked not to be identified".

Sunday Times executives argue that neither the Met press office nor Commander Clarke would know about it because of "the level" of police officer involved.

Other details in the story which attempts to link William with drug-takers were tenuous. Much was made of a named "leading socialite" who attends Edinburgh university and who is alleged to have been seen taking cocaine. But William has never knowingly met the woman. He is also not on close terms with two other people named as being in his circle.

There was one obvious similarity between the three stories: they all carry the byline of the Sunday Times's royal correspondent, Christopher Morgan, who was shortlisted as specialist writer of the year in the British Press Awards last week. Palace officials believe Morgan has become obsessed with linking Prince William to drug-takers. But his superiors scoff at the claim. "He is one of our most successful reporters, a serious man with a great contacts book," said a newsdesk executive. "He has impeccable sourcing both within and without the Palace for these stories. He is pressing buttons and the Palace doesn't like it. I am satisfied that his stories tell the truth." Caseby agrees. "Christopher is the best royal reporter in national journalism. He has been instrumental in exposing drug-taking among friends of Prince William."

But why has the Sunday Times shown such interest in an area previously the preserve of the tabloids? Caseby says: "It is a matter of genuine public interest. William is the son of the heir to the throne and, though we are sensitive to the issue of his privacy, we regard his circle of friends as a legitimate area of concern."

That high-minded defence brings a wry smile to the faces of the princes' aides. They believe the stories are largely founded on "third-party gossip". Caseby also takes issue with the claim that reporters are pressured to produce preconceived stories. "The Sunday Times demands flair, drive and accuracy from its reporters. But it has no agenda beyond challenging orthodoxies and presenting readers with intelligent and well-sourced scoops."

The Sunday Express has also upset Prince William. An "exclusive" story headlined "Isabella, the blonde tipped to be Prince William's wife" turned out to be unsubstantiated gossip retailed as fact.

It all started with a silly squib in December's Tatler which informed readers about Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe: "Pretty as a picture with a great brain and tipped to be the future Mrs Prince William. Isabella is no fairytale princess: she might be squeaky clean, but she's no bore."

The presentation and context indicated that it shouldn't be taken literally. But the joke took off. GQ joined in with a similar prediction, as did the Edinburgh University student newspaper.

This didn't matter until Sunday Express reporter Shekhar Bhatia came along. His story said that "glossy magazines" had "tipped" Isabella to marry William, which was a truth of sorts. But then he over-egged the pudding by adding: "Royal insiders say the 19-year-old blonde has formed a close bond" with the Prince.

A "tip" had become a "fact" attributed to our old friend "anonymous sources". The inclusion of that quote, plus the story's appearance in a national paper, gave it credence. Isabella evidently said: "I am sorry I cannot say anything."

Was her quote misunderstood by the paper? Whatever the case, the result was aggravating and embarrassing for her. She was pursued by reporters and photographers, and her boyfriend was none too pleased either. In fact, Isabella and William have never met. Sunday Express spokesman Greg Sage said: "We don't want to comment."

Doubtless the paper expects a Press Complaints Commission censure later this week, following a complaint from Isabella's father. What this silly episode illustrates, yet again, is how inaccuracy leads to intrusion with all its attendant problems.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's Diary
fields.trailText: • Legendary tabloid hack Don MacKay is in the news again. Sent to Wales after a colourful career at the Mirror in London (he was considered more dangerous than the Serbian forces when on assignment in Kosovo), MacKay is now news editor of the Welsh Mirror.
fields.body:
 Legendary tabloid hack Don MacKay is in the news again. Sent to Wales after a colourful career at the Mirror in London (he was considered more dangerous than the Serbian forces when on assignment in Kosovo), MacKay is now news editor of the Welsh Mirror.

A disagreement with Paul Starling, the paper's political editor, at the Labour party's Welsh conference quickly descended into a "robust exchange of views" as the pair discussed the finer points of assembly politics over a curry. Although details are sketchy customers were treated to the unedifying sight of the two men lost in a morass of flying poppadoms and lamb masala. Starling has now resigned, muttering darkly about the reasons he could no longer work with his boss.

 Gay PM presenter Nigel Wrench's Pink Paper revelations about "barebacking" caused much furrowing of brows in the BBC news empire, particularly when they gained a wider audience via the Guardian. But don't make too much of his current absence from the airwaves; back from sick leave, Wrench expects to return within a couple of weeks. Nevertheless, senior sources at BBC News say top managers "don't know what to to do" about him. Can he return to PM as if nothing's happened? "Don't bet on it," says my source in the bushes.

 James Boyle, the outgoing controller of Radio 4, must have been dreading crocodile tears and false good wishes as his tenure comes to an end, and he heads back to his beloved Edinburgh and early retirement. So his leaving do was held with the proviso that there were to be no speeches, no presentations, just a party, at the West End's Cafe de Paris, bolstered by a large contingent from BBC Scotland, where he'd spent happier times. "It was odd, but rather typical. He is quite shy," says a guest. If the rumours are right, Bob Shennan, head of BBC sport, has nosed ahead in the race to follow Roger Mosey as controller of Radio 5 Live.

 Exhibiting a selfless concern for truth and justice, the London Evening Standard last week trumpeted its backing for the author and journalist Tom Bower who is being sued by Richard Branson over a Standard article querying his motives for wanting to run the lottery. Strangely missing from the Associated-owned paper's editorial, though, was any mention of the fact that Bower's wife, Veronica Wadley (who is pally with editor Max Hastings from their days on the Telegraph), is an executive working for Associated - she is features editor of the Daily Mail. Small world, journalism.

 When anxious BBC staffers meet Greg Dyke, gearing up for his big shake-up on April 3, what should they look out for? "The first thing to notice is his effective use of interpersonal skills, customised for an entertainment business," writes Professor Gareth Jones - the in-house management guru unmasked here last week - in his book The Character of a Corporation. At Pearson Television, writes Jones, Dyke made "much use of humour, usually to encourage people but just occasionally with a slight edge. He collects much soft information data about people's motives, capabilities and values. He skilfully manages social distance, he is good at getting close to people as a friend as well as being able to distance himself as a boss." And if your job's in jeopardy in the shake-up, don't let him catch you being stuck-up: "He is highly dismissive of those who parade their status differences," Jones reports.

You can contact Maggie Brown on maggiebrown@btinternet.com
