fields.headline: Hold on to your hats
fields.standfirst:
The world is waiting with bated breath - Ali G is back. But in the battle to find the next big television star is Channel 4 leading broadcasters down a dangerous route - sacrificing young talent on the rock of hype?
The Ali G debate: special report
fields.trailText: The world is waiting with bated breath - Ali G is back. But in the battle to find the next big television star is Channel 4 leading broadcasters down a dangerous route - sacrificing young talent on the rock of hype?
fields.body:
It takes a certain type of animal to dig out the truffles. And when that rare delicacy, a good idea, falls into their lap they are apt to use it up and wear it out. It happens with performers and programmes alike, and none more so than with those connected to comedy. Well, comedy is, according to Mark Freeland, head of Sky Production, "next to premier football, the reason people stay in and watch television".

Along with the docusoap and lifestyle programmes, the comedy panel show is the format that has been reproduced ad nauseam of late, as though Julian Clary and Jo Brand tossing one-liners to friends is on a par with Dorothy Parker at the Algonquin. The comedy panel show has become the final resting place for a generation of comedians who have spread themselves thinly over sitcoms, sketch shows, dramas, documentaries and broadsheet columns, to the extent that there is nowhere left for them to go. Never has a joke been stretched so far, and never has the market been so wide open for new talent. "There's a goldrush at the moment," says Addison Cresswell of the agency Off the Kerb. "Every new comic is doing a pilot."

In this clearing, a comedy act is therefore more likely to board the bullet train, rise through the ranks and find itself heading for the mainstream fast, while also quickly becoming the face that brands a channel. These are the adjuncts to the phenomenal success of Ali G, and why all eyes will be on his first series, Da Ali G Show, beginning on Friday.

Either a career is about to burn itself out when it has barely begun, or the contract and cash for a second series, a tour, and a film contract will be in the post; film is rapidly becoming the next link on the track for TV comedy, now that Harry Enfield's Kevin character is the subject of a big-screen venture, and The Royle Family are Hollywood-bound.

The expectation and anticipation surrounding the new Ali G series is such that industry insiders are going to extremes to get access to information. You could be forgiven for thinking we were about to witness something as significant as Princess Diana's Panorama routine.

The pilot for the series got in the wrong hands and inevitably found its way on to the internet. Heat magazine acquired a copy of the tape and published screen grabs from it. Audience members and musical guests from the series have been pursued by journalists eager to discover stories, new catchphrases or characters that Ali G's alter ego, Sacha Baron Cohen, may be introducing. It's almost as though Channel 4 didn't need to invest in the obligatory billboard campaign which started last week - Ali G had already been talked up, hyped up and marked up to a frightening degree.

Thus far, a journalist wishing to see programmes in the series requires a summons to Horseferry Road to view the tapes inside the Channel 4 nerve centre, presumably under armed guard and followed by a strip search.

The comedian's refusal to do interviews, and the reluctance to offer any information regarding personal details - apart from the fact that he is a Jewish north Londoner who went to Cambridge University and supports the campaign to cancel third world debt - has only contributed to the intrigue.

The key to his greater success has been the targeting of a particular audience and the way in which he, alongside Graham Norton, is being used to brand the channel. There have been numerous photo shoots - one with Naomi Campbell - and like Dom Joly of Trigger Happy TV, he made the perfunctory appearance on the podium at the Brit awards. Also Channel 4 apparently insisted that he deliver the alternative Queen's speech on Christmas Day.

"The speed at which this has happened has been extraordinary", says Kevin Lygo, head of arts and entertainment at Channel 4. "All he has done are those three-minute interviews, tucked away in a show that transmits at 11 o'clock at night, and suddenly he is written about in the Sun and talked about by kids in playgrounds. He's been promoted beyond his audience base, partly because of clever positioning and by using him strategically."

According to Jon Plowman, head of comedy entertainment at the BBC, this is part of a wider trend within television comedy. "The landscape has changed," he says. "A certain type of comedy used to have to elbow its way towards the mainstream to make an impact. Now we look at something like the League of Gentlemen and wonder how we can get it to as wide an audience as possible."

The character of Ali G was born nearly two years ago when Harry Thompson, producer of the new series, and Channel 4's Andrew Newman plucked Cohen from the obscurity of a batch of amateur videotapes, in which he was discovered portraying an east European reporter. He subsequently developed Ali G, whom Thompson has described as the "disaffected wannabe homeboy of the suburbs, the kid stuck in Staines who dreamed of Compton or Watts".

For this, his first series, the hallmark one-to-one interview has been abandoned in favour of a studio-based show with a live audience and music, video parodies, panel discussions and sketches. Despite the claims by Channel 4 that he has reinvented the spoof interview, while Dom Joly has reinvented the hidden camera show, there is nothing particularly distinctive or innovative in the actual style or formats that these comedians choose. For real innovation, witness the manner in which Spaced has reinvented the sitcom, and how Chris Morris has subverted the sketch show with the current Jam, and how, elsewhere, the League of Gentlemen has completely shaken up the idea of what constitutes TV comedy.

For the series, Cohen has reprised the reporter character that got him noticed, and christened him Borat, a "journalist from Kazakhstan". The explanation of the new character's origins may be a swipe at those black comedians who took against Ali G.

Perhaps the most significant aspect of Ali G's success is that, like Alf Garnett and "Loadsamoney" in the past, he lampoons the very people who make up its audience - in this case the exact market that Channel 4 is courting. In keeping with television's pathological need to reproduce a successful idea until the life is wrung out of it and it is finally put out of our misery, both Channel 4 and BBC2 now appear to be rabidly pursuing youth, and only youth. A call reputedly echoed throughout the corridors of TV centre last week, pointing out that Channel 4 had successfully tapped into the younger audience that the BBC should pursue.

"Television has always had an appetite for young comedy people," says Plowman. "It's simply that instead of tucking them away on a Tuesday night, they now build marketing campaigns around having youth comedy. We now recognise the value of these people and how much we need them."

Ironically, Ali G came into being because of his creator's abhorrence of youth television. "There is an obsession with youth and new acts," says Thompson. "But it is as much to do with the pursuit of fashionability as with talent. A really talented 35-year-old is going to find it much harder than, say, a faintly promising 21-year-old."

At the BBC, the head of comedy, Geoffrey Perkins, is in partial agreement: "I think this is the remit of the moment for Channel 4, because of the advertising. But BBC2 is actually more scripted and involved with performance-based series."

A further theory within TV centre is that comedy has become like music, with teenagers not wanting to watch the comedy that their parents like. The BBC is so keen to seem hot on the tail of new young talent that it has embarked on a nationwide campaign in search of it.

With so many comedy writers and performers stretched beyond their capabilities, and with the big names creaming off huge parts of programme budgets, the corporation has tumbled that good ideas at a cheap rate may be found within those who provide the material for docu-soaps: the public. For the first time in its history, the BBC has realised that the funniest, the cleverest, the most talented people in this country may not all congregate at Cambridge.

This sudden surge of interest in new young talent is also making the traditional comedy route that begins with comedy clubs and evolves through radio and on to television, redundant. Thompson points out that "it used to be that a comedian's career would have time to build. Now they get picked up when they've only been in the business a few weeks. They get a series - but if they don't get an audience they might be dropped. Someone like Phil Kay, for instance, appears to have been dropped long before reaching his peak."

This need for the "new" also emerges as there becomes increasingly more time to fill in a multi-channel environment - what John Birt described as "the digitopia". "Well, now Sky are getting in on homegrown comedy," says Addison Cresswell. "Then there's all those dreadful acts cluttering up BBC Choice, which seems to be a training ground for the main channel."

Sky's big signing, Al Murray, with his pub landlord character, seems to have been strategically held back from television, until now - with a loyal fan base behind him, a Perrier award, and a one-man West End show. Mark Freeland says that Sky "has been after this act for two years. Our hit rate has to be as high as possible. Murray is a perfect face to brand Sky."

But he speaks for many television channels when he says: "We would love a face like Ali G as a brand." Just don't overstretch him, that's all.

Da Ali G Show begins on Channel 4 this Friday at 10.30pm

fields.headline: Stop buying soft soap
fields.standfirst: It's taken six years and 350 hours of footage to make - and on saturday it was at the centre of another television row. The man who made the controversial Power into Art series, Karl Sabbagh, reveals why Channel 4 has some serious questions to answer about it's programmes on the Tate Modern
fields.trailText: It's taken six years and 350 hours of footage to make - and on saturday it was at the centre of another television row. The man who made the controversial Power into Art series, Karl Sabbagh, reveals why Channel 4 has some serious questions to answer about it's programmes on the Tate Modern
fields.body:
When in 1994 I first started making my "fly on the wall" series Power into Art, about the new Tate Modern, there was no such thing as a "docusoap". The world had not been treated to endless programmes about traffic wardens and shopping centres and airports and learner drivers and hotels and package holidays, all purporting to convey the gritty reality of ordinary life.

There had been, of course, Roger Graef's sober series analysing processes in institutions, but here the search for drama and entertainment was not the main point of the exercise - light was as important as heat. The drama simply emerged, as the producers knew it would do, from the material itself.

Now, for an audience trained by their diet of docusoaps to expect rows, tantrums, firings and public displays of incompetence, a series like mine, which set out to show the complexity and interest of designing and building the new Tate Modern, faces an uphill struggle with the new breed of television commissioning editors, who are disappointed if they don't get a crisis every 10 minutes as a series evolves.

This is why it can seem as if Power into Art is "a tale of tantrums, clashing egos and errors" as described in Saturday's Guardian. There are two reasons why the overall impression of drama is heightened in the series. One is that inevitably, behind every short crisp sequence describing, say, a mistake in the staircase design or a disagreement with some consultants, lies a story that is much more complex and less black and white than can be conveyed in the five or six minutes that it has to be boiled down to in the programmes.

The other is that, however rich and complex the overall series is at the editing stage, under the relentless pressure of commissioning editors who have a jaundiced view of the audience, sequences conveying good news or stories that are just interesting are removed because they are seen as "too boring", or "slowing things down".

As Harry Gugger, one of the Tate Modern architects, was quoted as saying in Saturday's story, I am "a fan of the building and think it is a great success". It's all the more regrettable, therefore, that the only way Channel 4 wants to tell this sort of story in the current television climate is to play down the success and concentrate on the inevitable challenges and problems.

They have even imposed a subtitle on the series, calling it "The Battle for the New Tate", when there was no battle, only a difficult and challenging task. Of course problems did occur and of course I see it as essential to include them in the story. But for me, and I suspect for the director of the Tate, Nicholas Serota, and the rest of the Tate team, the interest lies as much in seeing how the problems are overcome - to end up with a building that, in spite of a succession of blows any one of which could have delayed the project, will open on time and within its original budget.

For me, the techniques I use in my documentaries to try to capture "real life" produce far more riveting material than the traditional "interventionist" approach of the documentary director who feels he has to intervene if the shot isn't quite right or the "performance" of the person he is filming doesn't quite come up to expectations.

I first became dissatisfied with this approach when I used fixed, unmanned cameras to record GP's consultations. There was no preparation, no pre-briefing, no reshooting. What we recorded we recorded; what we missed we missed. One small example shows how this approach got results: a patient comes in and says, 'Well, I had my eye out, doctor,' and the doctor freezes, his eyes moving to the patient's notes as he frantically tries to get up to speed without showing the patient that he hadn't given him a moment's thought since he referred him to hospital for an eye operation.

If we'd been filming this conventionally, the doctor would have looked at the notes beforehand and so when we followed the patient into the surgery, the doctor would say with a smile, 'How are you Mr X? And how did the operation go?' and we would be into a consultation that was entirely different from the one that actually took place.

Like the other series I've made over the years - including Skyscraper and 21st Century Jet - with Power into Art I tried to avoid setting up sequences, briefing participants beforehand or intervening in the events it films.

The production itself carries with it a series of superlatives. Six years in the making! Three hundred and fifty hours of footage! Half a million words of interviews! Ninety-nine per cent of the material on the cutting room floor! But we have also gathered the most detailed record ever of a complex cultural process, even if what the television viewer sees is a tiny and often simplified slice of that complexity.

Now, of course, none of this is absolute. The Tate team will tell you there is a difference between having a meeting in a room with a production team and one without, but the participants in the series have become accustomed to finding us nestling in the corner of the room, ready to film whatever happens, usually for hours on end.

Of course, the unedited material is only useful as a cure for insomnia, but it's like fishing. If you sit for hours very quietly, sometimes you catch something - a moment that illuminates the story. One of those moments was when a construction manager suddenly announced that asbestos had been discovered in the building and was likely to cause a five-week delay in a very crowded schedule. That moment - the worry on his face, the reactions of the Tate people, the fears of the effect on the budget - was worth waiting for and could not really have been organised or prepared for.

The main problem with these series is viewing all the material we have shot with an informed eye. There will often be situations where the significance of the footage isn't apparent till years later, so viewing the material at the time of editing, when the main outlines of the project are clear, is essential - and almost impossible on a Channel 4 budget, which in turn is set by the number of programmes.

In their wisdom, Channel 4 felt that our 350 hours of material on the country's most significant cultural event for a decade was worth only four hours of television. Actually it was then cut to three hours and eight minutes, since we were told a few weeks ago to make the last programme even shorter by 25% to allow the channel to schedule more sport.

Furthermore, the first three programmes are scheduled at 8pm on Saturday and the last at 6.15pm. So people who settle down to watch the last, and in some ways the most satisfying, episode at 8pm on April 22 will find they have missed it.

It's highly unlikely that such a long-term television arts project will ever be commissioned again, in a climate where flagship series such as the South Bank Show and Omnibus gather easy ratings with plug-tainted "profiles" of comedians and pop stars, and "science" series such as Equinox seek only stories that are scandalous, macabre or catastrophic.

The "tantrums and errors" of Power into Art could have been augmented by a dozen other stories about art, architecture, engineering and management that were just damned interesting. But at least you can read about those in my book.

Power into Art begins on Channel 4 on April 1 and Karl Sabbagh's book of the series is published by the Penguin Press on April 6. The Guardian and Observer are sponsors of the launch of the Tate Modern gallery.

fields.headline: I died out there
fields.standfirst: A one-off column in praise of those who have had a very bad time at the British Press Awards
fields.trailText: No 1 (and last)
fields.body:
No 1 (and last)

In retrospect I should have followed my instinct which had been to say no. My agent had asked the question: "Tony, would you like to do a 20-minute cabaret at the British Press Awards at the London Hilton?" "OK, I'll give it a go, but it could be tough," I answered.

And tough it was. I faced an audience of 800 hard-nosed, cynical hacks who revealed themselves to be be less than keen to laugh at the observations of a wry comedian (if I may be so bold as to describe myself thus).

Stand-up comedy is a hazardous business and I don't expect your sympathy, but spare a thought for me as I delivered my first three lines to almost complete and stony silence. These lines were what I considered my "bankers" - rock-solid funnies which warm the audience up. Silence is a most disconcerting response.

It is exactly at this point that the brain of the comedian has to split into two, one part continuing the routine while the other trawls around for some section of material which might rescue the situation.

fields.headline: The corporate lawnmowers
fields.trailText: Merger mania is here with a vengeance. Vodafone and Mannesmann. AOL and Time Warner. SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo. And the same thing is happening in the advertising industry.
fields.body:
Merger mania is here with a vengeance. Vodafone and Mannesmann. AOL and Time Warner. SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo. And the same thing is happening in the advertising industry. Will all of us end up working for one mega American group? Or perhaps Dentsu? No, I don't think so, but there have been some interesting developments in this latest burst of corporate lawnmowing.

The most significant recent moves in the advertising industry have been the consolidation of Lowe International and Ammirati Puris Lintas within Interpublic; the joining together of Leo Burnett and D'Arcy (and a bit of Dentsu) under BDM, their new US holding company; and the Havas purchase of Snyder Communications which has created the fifth-biggest network in the world. But where do the clients feature in all this?

The advertising industry mirrors the client community. As the client community consolidates, the advertising industry follows. They're forced to. When Smith Kline Beecham and Glaxo merge they will want a global powerhouse agency. At least one of their existing agencies is bound to lose out, with potentially severe financial penalties. No wonder agencies are consolidating like crazy.

Does this mean that the middle ground is a dangerous place for advertising agencies to be? Absolutely! Most of them have already been swallowed up or formed strategic alliances. Who's left?

First and foremost there's M&C Saatchi, which is in a category of its own - large and independent. They've said they would never go public but they would be an intimidating bunch to buy, so we'll have to watch this space. Then there's Leagas Delaney - having extricated themselves from AMV BBDO, they've sorted themselves out.

St Luke's are very fashionable and growing fast, but their iconoclastic style would make them difficult to merge with any other existing operation. Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters are strong, consistent performers who are rumoured to have missed out on a number of recent deals. Coming up fast are Mother and Mustoe Merriman. And finally, there's Roose & Partners. But that's pretty much it.

So where are all the new agencies? What's happened to all those young high-flyers who used to set up on their own? The dot.com revolution is what happened. Several young people have left agencies to start internet businesses instead. I predict, however, that once the dot.com frenzy has passed a lot of new advertising agencies will start up again. A couple of people with one telephone and loads of chutzpah can start an ad agency. So, fewer middle-sized agencies. New agencies on the horizon, maybe. What about the big boys? What is their game plan? Are there discernible differences?

WPP is one of the biggest and most rounded, and certainly the most aggressive in pursuing a broader communications platform. Although they own J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, two of the world's great advertising brands, for many years now half their revenue has come from non-advertising communications companies, and they have been particularly adept in their purchase of internet-based businesses (and their minority investments in companies such as mine!).

Omnicom have built a collection of some of the most successful and creative (and longest-name) advertising brands - BMP DDB Needham, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and TBWA GGT Simons Palmer - and, through DAS, are diversifying into some good non-advertising services.

Interpublic is the company that interests me. Of the advertising agencies in their stable, McCann Erickson and Lowe Howard-Spink are strong, but Ammirati Puris Lintas was always a troublesome child and even now the jury has to be out on the creation of Lowe Lintas. If ever there was a merger of two disparate cultures in the UK, this has to be it. Lowe is creative, confident, talented. Lintas is decent, hard-working, but struggling. You can't argue with Interpublic's numbers or its success, but you can wonder where it goes next and what else it might be looking to acquire.

Havas seems to be simply going for size, whatever it costs. The French have consistently failed to crack America, but now Havas are having a tilt with their purchase of Snyder. And the Japanese? They've at last realised their isolationist days are over. No longer can they rely on Japanese businesses only asking Japanese ad agencies to handle their advertising. Hakuhodo's recent joint venture with TBWA to service its $1bn Nissan account is a good example of the change of mind-set there.

But, back to size. I believe there's no such thing as centralisation or decentralisation. There's centralising and decentralising - vectors. As soon as you reach one end you start coming back the other way. Or to put it more elegantly, as Sir Isaac Newton did, for every action there is a reaction. So it'll probably all be different this time next year.

Rupert Howell is president of the IPA and chairman of HHCL and Partners

fields.headline: Fresh blow to nuclear plant
fields.standfirst: Plan to end reprocessing of waste fuel at Sellafield
fields.trailText: The government is expected to abandon nuclear reprocessing altogether at the strife-torn Sellafield plant in a green paper on nuclear waste to be published in the next two months.
fields.body:
The government is expected to abandon nuclear reprocessing altogether at the strife-torn Sellafield plant in a green paper on nuclear waste to be published in the next two months.

A senior minister said the crisis of credibility in British Nuclear Fuels management, exacerbated by a worldwide loss of markets and weekend reports of internal sabotage at the plant, had left the government with no option but to accept that the Cumbrian plant had no future in reprocessing.

It is understood that the former managing director at BNFL, John Taylor, had already told ministers he accepted that Sellafield's future lay in waste storage, not nuclear reprocessing.

The green paper is also likely to propose a more independent body of nuclear experts to examine the scientific options for storing existing nuclear waste, either in sealed bunkers underground or on the surface. It will propose, additionally, an elaborate public consultation exercise designed to win support for the hugely sensititive task of locating sites for waste storage.

After a planning inquiry ruled out Sellafield as a long-term option, government insiders said that some of the most likely store sites were in East Anglia.

A switch from a reprocessing system - which separates spent nuclear fuel into plutonium, uranium, and nuclear waste - would mean the closure of Sellafield's Thorp site, which was opened in 1993 at a cost of more than £1.8bn. A separate MOX (mixed oxide) reprocessing plant has been built for £300m. It has yet to open and would not do so if reprocessing were abandoned.

Sellafield employs about 6,000 workers, although 1,500 are involved in reprocessing. Before stopping reprocessing, contracts with major clients would have to be renegotiated.

In a severe blow to BNFL last week British Energy, which accounts for a third of Sellafield's reprocessing industry, confirmed that it wanted to shift from reprocessing to waste storage because it was cheaper. Japan, which accounts for another third of BNFL's contracts, has already banned all shipments from the plant after the discovery that key safety data on its fuel rods had been falsified.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, has long been privately pressing for an end to reprocessing, but has met resistance from the Foreign Office, the Department of Trade and Industry, and Downing Street. The Foreign Office has defended reprocessing since its abandonment might damage Anglo-Japanese relations, but those relations have now been soured by the false documents.

A House of Lords select committee last year called on the government to accept that Britain's rapidly exanding plutonium stocks should not be regarded as a resource, but as waste. It pointed out that the collapse of the fast-breeder reactor industry in Japan, Britain and France had left little commercial purpose for the use of plutonium.

The committee proposed that the government maintain a minimum strategic stock of civil plutonium and declared the rest to be a waste. A senior minister said events at Sellafield and the commercial world were propelling them to accept this recommendation. He said: "BNFL's prospects are not good at all at the moment. They deserve everything they get. It would be ridiculous to let it go entirely. There is an immense amount of capital and expertise tied up there. It may survive as a lower-level nuclear waste-management operation."

The minister added that there was now no prospect of a majority stake in BNFL being sold before the election.

The change in government mood came as the hunt was stepped up yesterday for a saboteur among the workforce at Sellafield. The normally deeply loyal union leadership at the plant mounted an unprecedented appeal to 10,000 staff to inform on a disaffected colleague who had cut robot cables in a radioactive processing unit.

A joint union letter to all Sellafield staff describes the situation as "drastic", following the halt on all major foreign contracts after staff were discovered to have compiled fraudulent quality control data on batches of reprocessed radioactive waste.

The Irish energy minister, Joe Jacobs, is meeting his Danish counterpart, Sven Auken, in Dublin today to formulate legal moves to ban waste discharges from Sellafield, to be put to Scandinavian countries at an international energy conference in Copenhagen in June. MPs from the Irish capital, where concern has grown about tidal pollution bringing traces of radioactive waste across from Cumbria, also want a start on plans for a safe, permanent closure of the plant.

Depression bordering on despair was described as the growing mood at Sellafield, which is by far the biggest employer in west Cumbria, and which would leave economic and social devastation if it were to abruptly close. Union leaders criticised "ostrich-like" attitudes among their own members and accused a "shell-shocked management" of failing to stress how desperate the situation had become.

"Our workforce has to realise that this is the most critical time in our history, but for many people it doesn't seem to have sunk in," said John Kane, plant convenor of the General and Municipal Union. "They are thinking that the problem will either go away, or that we don't have a problem." The unions' letter asking staff to identify the saboteur is designed to revitalise the search by UK atomic energy authority police for the culprit who disabled six robot arms last month and closed a major reprocessing unit for three days. Fingerprints are being taken from up to 300 workers on the vitrification line, where the robots are used to seal liquid high-level waste in molten glass, before cooling and burial in concrete for storage.

fields.headline: A man for all seasons
fields.trailText: Little is really known about the policies of Russia's newly elected president Vladimir Putin, but expectations are great for this representative of a new generation, writes Ian Traynor in Moscow
fields.body:
The post-Yeltsin era arrived in Russia yesterday when Vladimir Putin was confirmed as president of the largest country on earth with almost 53% of the national vote.

Putin has so far served three months' probation in the Kremlin. He has done little and announced even less, apart from having his troops occupy most of the unruly republic of Chechnya and reducing its capital Grozny to rubble.

But despite the paucity of policy, Russians like what they see - a new face from a new generation who promises to make them feel good about themselves for the first time since the early 80s. If the Russian embrace of Putin is warm, he also has high-powered pals in the West desperate to give him the benefit of the doubt.

With indecent haste, Tony Blair rushed to Putin's native city of St Petersburg to hail him as an impressive moderniser, although so far Putin's talents have been deployed not creatively, but destructively - in Chechnya.

President Clinton, too, is keen to ''do business with'' Putin, hoping the new leader can start to turn Russia around and bask in that reflected light before bowing out of the White House.

The ex-KGB career officer, whose instincts appear to be more authoritarian than democratic, has until May - his inauguration date - to come up with a coherent programme for ruling for the next four years.

He has carefully avoided making any commitments or policy statements. He is all things to all Russians. That tactic paid handsome electoral dividends. Soon he will have to start disappointing some, offending others, dismissing yet more of the courtiers battling for his ear. Hard choices.

Putin looks likely to steer Russia towards more economic reform - gradually rather than radically - to try to attract the western investment and IMF help he thinks are necessary to Russia. Western leaders will welcome such moves.

But they will find him a more robust defender - compared to Boris Yeltsin - of what he perceives to be the Russian national interest when it comes to other areas of foreign policy - arms control, foreign trade, nuclear non-proliferation, arms sales, and the projection of power.

Everything in Putin's background marks him out as a loyal defender of the state and its interests, a high-powered civil servant. If he has any political philosophy at all, it is ''statism''. He bridles at the depths to which the Russian state has sunk.

Usually when heads of state change, diplomats are dispatched promptly to send reassuring signals about foreign policy continuity. Not with Putin. Igor Ivanov, Russia's foreign minister, instantly announced imminent changes in foreign policy more in tune with the times and international realities.

The talk in Moscow is of a new ''super foreign ministry'' - combining traditional diplomacy with economic and foreign trade portfolios, security issues and military policy.

Gone are the days of Yeltsin who related personally to western chums and referred to them as ''my friend Bill [Clinton]'' and ''my friend Helmut [Kohl]''. Although Blair has been quickest off the mark in trying to bond with the new president, Putin sees not friends, but interests.

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday inquiry opens
fields.standfirst: Bloody Sunday inquiry site
fields.trailText: The Saville public inquiry into Bloody Sunday began taking oral statements today on the 1972 shooting of 14 Catholic protesters in Londonderry, one of the most calamitous episodes in the Northern Ireland conflict.
fields.body:
The Saville public inquiry into Bloody Sunday began taking oral statements today on the 1972 shooting of 14 Catholic protesters in Londonderry, one of the most calamitous episodes in the Northern Ireland conflict.

Relatives and friends of the victims filled Londonderry Guildhall for the biggest public inquiry in British legal history. The hearing, before three judges led by Lord Saville, is expected to last two years and will take evidence from about 500 people.

"What happened, whatever the truth of the matter, was a tragedy, the pain of which for many has endured down the passage of the years," Christopher Clarke, an inquiry lawyer, said in opening remarks. "The tribunal's task is to try to discover, so far as is humanly possible in the circumstances, and with the means now available, the truth... however complex, painful or unacceptable to whomsoever that truth may be."

The events under investigation occurred on January 30, 1972 when British troops opened fire on Catholics protesting against the internment without trial of IRA suspects. The soldiers claim they fired after being provoked by IRA gunmen - an assertion that has long infuriated Roman Catholic residents of Londonderry, who insist the soldiers fired first and killed only unarmed people.

The shootings were a seminal moment in the troubles, turning republican sentiment against the British and prompting scores of Catholics to join the IRA. An inquiry later that year by Lord Widgery, the then lord chief justice, in effect cleared the army, sparking fury among the bereaved. They fought hard for a fresh inquiry and prime minister Tony Blair bowed to their request in January 1998, a decision the Ministry of Defence is understood to have opposed.

Families of the dead said they hoped the inquiry would provide them with some answers. "The injured and the victims of the dead are depending on the Saville team to establish the truth and justice for all those who were murdered," said John Kelly, whose brother Michael was killed. "We were promised an open, impartial inquiry. Let's hope they can put that in place."

Preparations for the inquiry have cost an estimated £15m. More than 600 civilians and 500 soldiers have already been interviewed and inquiry staff are collecting printed, photographic, film and audio evidence. Mr Clark said the tribunal had scoured the world for military witnesses and traced 97% of the 2,110 people it was seeking, "on every continent with the exception of Antarctica".

Controversy has dogged the inquiry. It emerged recently that the army began to destroy rifles used on Bloody Sunday just three days before Mr Blair announced a fresh inquiry. Families of the victims said the episode indicated that senior figures in the armed forces were intent on frustrating the Saville inquiry.

The army went on to destroy 14 of the 29 rifles, while 10 were sold to private companies. It also destroyed two of the remaining five rifles three months after Lord Saville had decreed they should be kept safely for his tribunal.

Examination of the rifles now would have thrown light on the ramifications of a controversial memo issued three weeks before Bloody Sunday by Major-General Robert Ford, who was in day-to-day command of troops in Northern Ireland, and was in Londonderry on Bloody Sunday.

Maj-Gen Ford recommended that rioters should be shot, and suggested modifying rifles to fire smaller bullets less likely to cause what he termed collateral damage. It is known that he had 30 of the rifles sent to Londonderry for training purposes, though it is unclear if any were used on Bloody Sunday.

The inquiry was also delayed by arguments over whether to grant anonymity to soldiers at the shooting, whose identity will now not be revealed after a court of appeal ruling upholding their right not to be identified.

Relatives and friends of the victims filled Londonderry Guildhall for the biggest public inquiry in British legal history. The hearing, before three judges led by Lord Saville, is expected to last two years and will take evidence from about 500 people. "What happened, whatever the truth of the matter, was a tragedy, the pain of which for many has endured down the passage of the years," Christopher Clarke, an inquiry lawyer, said in opening remarks. "The tribunal's task is to try to discover, so far as is humanly possible in the circumstances, and with the means now available, the truth... however complex, painful or unacceptable to whomsoever that truth may be." The events under investigation occurred on January 30, 1972 when British troops opened fire on Catholics protesting against the internment without trial of IRA suspects. The soldiers claim they fired after being provoked by IRA gunmen - an assertion that has long infuriated Roman Catholic residents of Londonderry, who insist the soldiers fired first and killed only unarmed people. The shootings were a seminal moment in the troubles, turning republican sentiment against the British and prompting scores of Catholics to join the IRA. An inquiry later that year by Lord Widgery, the then lord chief justice, in effect cleared the army, sparking fury among the bereaved. They fought hard for a fresh inquiry and prime minister Tony Blair bowed to their request in January 1998, a decision the Ministry of Defence is understood to have opposed. Families of the dead said they hoped the inquiry would provide them with some answers. "The injured and the victims of the dead are depending on the Saville team to establish the truth and justice for all those who were murdered," said John Kelly, whose brother Michael was killed. "We were promised an open, impartial inquiry. Let's hope they can put that in place." Preparations for the inquiry have cost an estimated £15m. More than 600 civilians and 500 soldiers have already been interviewed and inquiry staff are collecting printed, photographic, film and audio evidence. Mr Clark said the tribunal had scoured the world for military witnesses and traced 97% of the 2,110 people it was seeking, "on every continent with the exception of Antarctica". Controversy has dogged the inquiry. It emerged recently that the army began to destroy rifles used on Bloody Sunday just three days before Mr Blair announced a fresh inquiry. Families of the victims said the episode indicated that senior figures in the armed forces were intent on frustrating the Saville inquiry. The army went on to destroy 14 of the 29 rifles, while 10 were sold to private companies. It also destroyed two of the remaining five rifles three months after Lord Saville had decreed they should be kept safely for his tribunal. Examination of the rifles now would have thrown light on the ramifications of a controversial memo issued three weeks before Bloody Sunday by Major-General Robert Ford, who was in day-to-day command of troops in Northern Ireland, and was in Londonderry on Bloody Sunday. Maj-Gen Ford recommended that rioters should be shot, and suggested modifying rifles to fire smaller bullets less likely to cause what he termed collateral damage. It is known that he had 30 of the rifles sent to Londonderry for training purposes, though it is unclear if any were used on Bloody Sunday. The inquiry was also delayed by arguments over whether to grant anonymity to soldiers at the shooting, whose identity will now not be revealed after a court of appeal ruling upholding their right not to be identified.

webTitle: Scholes or Di Canio? Vote now

fields.headline: Scholes or Di Canio? Vote now
fields.trailText: It's not often two goal of the season contenders are scored on the same weekend. On Saturday, Manchester United's Paul Scholes volleyed in a Beckham corner from 25 yards against Bradford. It was such a thumper that many thought the goal of the season had been decided there and then.
fields.body:
It's not often two goal of the season contenders are scored on the same weekend. On Saturday, Manchester United's Paul Scholes volleyed in a Beckham corner from 25 yards against Bradford. It was such a thumper that many thought the goal of the season had been decided there and then.

Trust Paolo Di Canio to totally confuse the issue less than 24 hours later. Again on the volley, he whipped the ball around Wimbledon's Neil Sullivan with both feet off the ground from a frankly cheeky angle. So was that better than the Scholes strike? Er...

We can't decide. But can you?

fields.headline: Lazio back in Scudetto hunt
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle sizes up the state of play across the major European leagues, in our new weekly round-up
fields.trailText: Serie A
fields.body:
Serie A

Lazio closed the gap on Serie A leaders Juventus to six points after they came from behind to beat city rivals Roma 2-1 in a bruising Rome derby.

Italian striker Vicenzo Montella put Roma ahead, but goals from Pavel Nedved and Juan Veron helped Swen Goran Eriksson's side to all three points.

The result sets up a potential title decider between Juventus and Lazio next Saturday. Juventus are still favourites, but have the harder run in - and they go into the game reeling after Friday night's 2-0 defeat at Milan.

Roma meanwhile dropped to sixth place in the league, and are counting the cost of the derby. Three of their top internationals went off with injuries. Brazilian captain Cafu, French left-back Vincent Candela and striker Vincenzo Montella were all hurt and will miss their countries' respective internationals this week.

Elsewhere Lecce reversed their recent slump with a surprise 1-0 win over Inter, while Verona pulled out of the relegation zone after thrashing fellow strugglers Torino 3-0.

Primera Liga

Nicholas Anelka has returned to Real Madrid to resume training on his own - but the club are insisting he must make a public apology before they'll consider playing him.

With first-choice striker Fernando Morientes out through injury, speculation was rife that the club might end Anelka's suspension and play him against Manchester United in the Champion's League quarter-finals.

But Real team manager Jose Martinez told the Spanish press that the ban remains in place. "Anelka committed a grave error and he has asked for my forgiveness, but he has not spoken to anyone else," he said. "We have put the training facilities at his disposal, but the punishment continues. It would be advisable for him to ask forgiveness from the fans, his team-mates and the coach. If he does that then we'll see what happens."

In the league, Deportivo La Coruna regained top spot after a thumping 3-1 win over relegation strugglers Real Oviedo. Two first half goals from 15 goal Dutch striker Roy Makaay put Deportivo on their way, before Frederic Danjou pulled one back for the visitors. But Donato sealed the victory six minutes later to put Deportivo back on top, two points ahead of Barcelona who won at Malaga on Saturday. Real Madrid were held to a 0-0 draw by their city rivals Rayo Vallecano.

Le Championnat

Monaco beat Nantes 2-0 to go 13 points clear in the French Championship. They will capture their sixth Championnat if they can beat relegation strugglers Marseille next week. Lyon, who beat fifth-placed Sedan 2-0, moved into second while Paris St Germain, who beat Le Havre 2-1, are third.

Paris St Germain keeper Bernard Lama has been making headlines off the pitch after criticising the coaching at the famous club. "I notice a kind of internal satisfaction that ensues a glaring lack of ambition. A lot of people are content with very little. It makes me angry," said the French international. "The team is not inspring fear as happened in the past. The team now only has the potential to be in the three best."

Bundesliga

Bayern Munich stay top of the Bundesliga despite a 2-2 draw against Kaiserslautern. Nearest rivals Bayer Leverkusen could only manage a 1-1 draw at home to relegation threatened SC Freiberg. The top two both have 54 points with eight games to go, but Bayern have the better goal difference.

fields.headline: Assembling the jigsaw of expertise
fields.standfirst: In their third step along the road to online fame and fortune our heroes begin hiring
fields.trailText: In their third step along the road to online fame and fortune our heroes begin hiring.
fields.body:
We were not about to be seduced into thinking that setting up an internet business was going to be easy. There was a huge amount to be accomplished, from building strong relationships with online retailers to developing the site itself.

Mindful of the bad press a number of start-ups had received, we also needed to ensure that we offered the highest level of service, building the loyalty with customers that would ensure a sustainable business.

We were able to put together a core team of six people in under a week. They were mostly contacts we had worked closely with in our previous lives as consultants, and included two programmers from our old employer. We had discussed with them on several occasions the possibility of setting up an internet business so it was easy to switch them over to the idea. With the small working capital provided by our seed investors we were able to pay reasonable salaries and give everyone options in the company. We are keen that everyone is in a position to benefit from the business's success.

Initially we organised ourselves around four key areas: operations, technology, strategic partnerships and marketing. An important strategic decision that faced us then and we keep revisiting is the extent to which we outsource key functions. In some areas - in particular with some of the IT development - it makes sense, in the same way that most people would not try to fix their own television sets. In other areas such as customer service, it can seem a bit too much like authors getting other people to write their books for them.

With a strong core team in place we felt we would be able to meet one of the many requirements of a new inter net business, working at lightning speed. We were not in a position to do everything ourselves and it was important for us to build a quality network of external experts.

Our extended virtual team included web designers, animators, lawyers and financial services consultants. In addition we were able to pay for one of the world's best-known technology companies to help support us with development of the website and database. What we did not know, we learnt or we called on one of our many business advisers to impart some of their expertise.

Our team will grow as we develop but recruitment will be a huge challenge and getting the right people will be critical. The main criteria for selecting people, beyond their skills and experience, are enthusiasm and drive. We look for people with passion who are excited by the adventure of starting something new and who have the ambition and ability to develop a world class business. However, with the considerable challenges that lie ahead it is how this team works together that will determine the success of the venture.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com

webTitle: American Beauty dominates, but British talent gets more than a nod

fields.headline: American Beauty dominates, but British talent gets more than a nod
fields.standfirst: He was, as he put it, "just a bloke from English theatre" but it was Sam Mendes's night at the Oscars. Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles
fields.trailText: He was, as he put it, "just a bloke from English theatre" but it was Sam Mendes's night at the Oscars. Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles
fields.body:
He was, as he put it, "just a bloke from English theatre" but it was Sam Mendes's night at the Oscars. American Beauty, the first film directed by the British director, swept the board, winning best picture, best director, best actor, best screenplay and best cinematography awards at a ceremony which also managed to celebrate transexuality and abortion rights.

Sam Mendes said hello to all his "friends watching in his flat in Primrose Hill" and Pedro Almodovar listed all the saints to whom his sisters had lit candles to ensure his victory in the best foreign language film category for All About My Mother before being dragged off stage by Antonio Banderas for exceeding his time limit. "We live in a different culture," he told the audience, explaining that in Spain it was already "six years in the morning."

The ceremony lasted slightly less time, but by the end of it most of the predicted winners had thanked their parents, spouses and visionary producers, and headed off for the far more testing task of getting past security and into the post-Oscar parties in Beverly Hills.

The success of American Beauty was the undoubted theme of the night, even if it had been predicted for the last three months, but there were other highlights, not least the attendance of Annette Bening who was due that very day to give birth to her and husband Warren Beatty's fourth child. (Cue many jokes about productions.)

Hilary Swank won the best actress award for her part in the $2m independent film, Boys Don't Cry, based on the true story of a woman who passed as a man and was murdered because of it. She used her acceptance speech to call on people to "celebrate our diversity".

One of the loudest rounds of applause for the night went to the man who described the Oscars ceremony as a "meaningless, self-serving meat parade": George C Scott, who died last year, appeared in the In Memoriam spot which honours film business people who have moved on.

The man who had already picked up more Oscars than anyone on stage was there as guest of honour: Willie Fulgear, the 61-year-old freelance salvage worker who found 52 of the 55 stolen Oscars in LA's Koreatown last week, looked more of a star with his snappy fedora than many of the real ones.

Britain done well. Michael Caine made a suitably urbane acceptance speech as he took the best supporting actor award from Dame Judi Dench: "I'm basically up here as a survivor," he said. Phil Collins won best original song Oscar for You'll be in My Heart from Tarzan, and the first Oscar of the night, for costume design, also went Britain's way.

Lindy Hemming who designed the spectacular outfits for Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy made a gracious and brief speech of thanks that "our little film" had been honoured. The orchestra accompanied her on to the stage with The Lord High Executioner from the Mikado, hinting that this might be the night when death row (The Green Mile features an electric chair execution) really made it big. That was not to be.

But Topsy-Turvy provided the audience with another more humane acceptance speech after Christine Blundell and Trevor Proud took the make-up Oscar. "Mike Leigh, top guy," said Ms Blundell. "Thanks to the rest of our team. Thank you." And that was it. No wonder the audience, steadying itself for three hours of tears and dedications applauded so loudly.

The Matrix took Oscars for the sound, visual effects and editing, and Sleepy Hollow for art direction. The first of the acting awards went, as predicted, to Angelina Jolie, for her supporting role in Girl, Interrupted.

Alexandre Petrov who won the Animated Short Oscar made what is believed to have been the first acceptance speech in Russian. One Day in September beat the critics' favourite, Wim Wenders's Buena Vista Social Club to the documentary feature award.

Before the ceremony, the actresses had had to face the traditional Mastermind questions on their way down the red carpet: "who made your dress?" "Why did you choose that colour?" Some television crews, unable to be heard above the din, held up signs with instructions: "Please spin around!" They may have got more than they bargained for when one dress-wearer spun round to reveal Trey Parker, the husky co-writer of animated film South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut, who had come in drag. They might have got even more than they bargained had he and his colleague Mark Shalman won the best song prize for their scatalogical Blame Canada.

There was an honourary Oscar for Polish director Andrzej Wadja presnted by Jane Fonda who was welcomed "home" by Billy Crystal. The Irving Thalberg award went to Warren Beatty, who said that he regarded it as a greater prize than the White House in which direction many of the audience had hoped he might have been heading.

Politics made a brief appearance. Billy Crystal referred to the Robin Williams film about a robot who wants to become a human being: "it's called the Al Gore story". To show balance, he suggested that the list of winners of the awards was the best-kept secret in America - "with the possible exception of what George W Bush did in the 70s" (a reference to the question the Texas governor is often asked about whether in his youth he had used recreational substances not manufactured by Nike.) John Irving received cheers when he paid tribute the National Abortion Rights League in his acceptance of best Oscar for the adapted screenplay of The Cider House Rules.

The building next door to the Shrine in this slightly run-down part of LA is the 32nd Street school carries a bold injunction to its students on one wall: "live, learn, recycle." Doubtless words that any of the night's disappointed producers are even now taking to heart.

fields.headline: Pope offers prayer for forgiveness
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II yesterday stood humbly before the great stone slabs of the Wailing Wall and slipped a prayer into its crevices, bearing a plea for forgiveness for the sins of many generations.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II yesterday stood humbly before the great stone slabs of the Wailing Wall and slipped a prayer into its crevices, bearing a plea for forgiveness for the sins of many generations.

His visit to the holiest site of Judaism, the last remnant of a temple destroyed in 70AD, lasted only moments, but the memory of his presence here during the twilight of his papacy will undoubtedly prove the most resonant of his journey to the Holy Land.

"We are deeply saddened by the behaviour of those who, in the course of history, have caused these children of yours to suffer and, asking your forgiveness, we wish to commit ourselves to genuine brotherhood with the people of the Covenant," the prayer said.

It was immediately plucked from the Wailing Wall, and entrusted to the archives of Yad Vashem, Israel's Holocaust memorial.

Yesterday's visit to the holiest sites of the three main faiths - Islam, Christianity and Judaism - all within the ancient city walls of Jerusalem - offered the most rigorous test of the Pope's crowning achievement during his pilgrimage: his ability to hover serenely above the fray, and yet somehow satisfy the region's feuding factions.

Around 7,000 Israeli security forces were deployed in the old city's winding alleys in case the passions stoked during the Pope's visit - especially over rival Palestinian and Israeli claims to Jerusalem - became explosive.

In fact, the last day of his visit ended without violence but was marked by several minor squabbles. When the Catholic prelates in the papal entourage set foot in the Muslim sanctuary of the Dome of the Rock, where the prophet Mohammed is believed to have ascended to heaven, they were greeted by activists shouting: "Homos, go home."

On Saturday the supreme Muslim cleric of Jerusalem, Mufti Ikrema Sabri, dismayed Israelis by denying the Holocaust, saying: "It is true, the number was less than six million and Israel is using this issue to get sympathy worldwide."

Yesterday Mr Sabri used the papal audience to appeal for the Vatican's endorsement of Palestinian claims to Jerusalem, and to seek its support in ending the Israeli occupation of the eastern part of the city, captured after the 1967 war.

There were small scuffles, too, at the Wailing Wall, where an Orthodox Jewish woman stood in the centre of the plaza before the ceremony and shouted: "There are so many churches around the world to visit, why do you have to come here?"

Hours later, after a visit to the Holy Sepulchre, which houses the tomb of Jesus, the Pope was gone - borne aloft by a plane called Jerusalem. It was the final reminder from an Israeli government which has relentlessly exploited the Pope's visit to press its claims to the holy city.

There were small scuffles, too, at the Wailing Wall, where an Orthodox Jewish woman stood in the centre of the plaza before the ceremony and shouted: "There are so many churches around the world to visit, why do you have to come here?" Hours later, after a visit to the Holy Sepulchre, which houses the tomb of Jesus, the Pope was gone - borne aloft by a plane called Jerusalem. It was the final reminder from an Israeli government which has relentlessly exploited the Pope's visit to press its claims to the holy city.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Ferrara's Driller Killer receives an airing on C4, Biography king Morton gets his own biopic, Peter "There's Something About Mary" Farrelly talks about his next movie, Danish queen and Bond veteran prepare to celebrate Andersen's birthday in style, the latest US box-office figures and more film awards nominations, this time from Latin America
fields.body:
 Abel Ferrara's notorious Driller Killer, which was given a film rating by censors only last year, is to be shown on Channel 4 next month. The original "video nasty" appears as part of a linkup with the subscription service, FilmFour. While Channel 4 argued that they were "keen for viewers to judge for themselves", the decision to show the film was condemned as "ill-advised" by a spokesman from the National Viewers and Listeners Association, who presumably thinks we'll all drill one another to death after seeing it.

 Andrew Morton, author of two Princess Diana biographies and one on Monica Lewinsky, is to be the subject of a new British film, The Biographer. Paul McGann (of Withnail & I fame) is to star. According to co-star Hugh Bonneville (Notting Hill), it's set to be "a bit like the Watergate scandal; it's lots of meetings in underground car parks I think it's a chance to hear Andrew Morton's side of the story and I think it's a fascinating insight into how the [Diana] book got written" - an insight which, some would argue, the world doesn't really need.

 Peter Farrelly (There's Something About Mary) has been talking about his next movie, Shallow Hal. "It's about a guy, Hal. The movie opens with his father on his deathbed and he's all jacked up with morphine and Hal's 11-years-old Cos his father's all jacked up with morphine, he gives him all the wrong advice. He's saying, 'Big tits, just find big tits! Forget about love!' Hal says 'Really? Forget love?!' We cut to 25 years later," Farrelly continues, "and Hal's a mess. The movie is basically Hal trying to find true love and finally finding the decent guy who was inside him. It's a lot of fun," the director concludes. Tom Cruise is said to be in the running for the prized Hal role, while the definitely small-chested Gwyneth Paltrow has already bagged the role of the hero's sweetheart.

 Queen Margrethe of Denmark and Bond veteran Roger Moore will celebrate the 195th birthday of writer Hans Christian Andersen next month in the storyteller's hometown. The monarch and the dextrous-eyebrowed one - who'll be there as a special ambassador for Unicef - will attend ceremonies in Odense on April 2.

 The Julia Roberts starrer Erin Brockovich finished on top of the US box office for the second weekend running, pulling in an estimated $19m. Action movie Romeo Must Die landed second place with an estimated $18.6m, while the teen horror film Final Destination garnered third place with $7.1m.

 Antonio Banderas has been nominated in the Best Actor and Director categories for two different movies at the American Latino Media Arts Awards. Banderas received his actor nom for The 13th Warrior - inexplicably - and his director nod for Crazy in Alabama. The ALMA ceremony will take place on April 16.

fields.headline: Healing wounds
fields.standfirst:
The Bloody Sunday inquiry could do for Northern Ireland what the Macpherson report did for Britain

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: This is a tale of two monuments. One sits on the Bogside in Derry; a grey, granite marker to commemorate the 14 people killed by the 1st parachute regiment of the British army on January 30 1972 while campaigning for civil rights.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two monuments. One sits on the Bogside in Derry; a grey, granite marker to commemorate the 14 people killed by the 1st parachute regiment of the British army on January 30 1972 while campaigning for civil rights.

The other stands over 4,000 miles and an ocean away at the foot of St Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama; a plaque honouring the 600 protesters who were trampled, truncheoned and teargassed by Alabama state troopers while demonstrating for the right of black people to vote on March 7 1965.

Both events were named Bloody Sunday. Both resonated far beyond the small towns in which they took place to the very democratic fabric of the nations in which they occurred. But the second was erected by the Alabama Historical Commission, a federally funded body dedicated to "raising the awareness" and "reflecting the heritage of all Alabamians". The first exists solely thanks to the nationalist community of Derry. They not only had to mourn their dead but ensure that the injustice that killed them was not forgotten either.

Today may herald the beginning of the end of that incongruity. As Lord Saville of Newdigate begins to take oral evidence at Derry's Guildhall this morning in the inquiry into Bloody Sunday, the nationalist community is feeling cautiously optimistic. "My greatest hope is that the truth of what happened on the day is finally told," says Patricia Macbride, the manager of the Bloody Sunday centre in Derry. "That the people killed and injured on the day are finally vindicated as innocent and that those who were responsible are held accountable for their actions."

It is a substantial wish list, punctuated with scepticism. They have been here before. An inquiry in 1972 by Lord Chief Justice Widgery effectively exonerated the army of all wrongdoing, arguing only that some of their actions had "bordered on the reckless". More recently the army has admitted to destroying rifles that could have provided fresh and vital evidence to the inquiry, even after Lord Saville asked the Ministry of Defence to keep them safe.

Nonetheless, Saville already promises far more than Widgery could ever deliver. The Widgery report was a 39-page document, written in 10 weeks. The Saville tribunal has already been running for a year and a half, and has collected around 60,000 pages, more than 5,000 photographs and 36 hours of videotape.

As such, Saville has the potential to do for Northern Ireland what Macpherson did for Britain. It could confirm what a minority has been insisting for years, by elevating a long-held grievance to an established fact. It might illustrate how those responsible for maintaining law and order can and do use bureaucracy, malice and prejudice to ensure that those facts never emerge. And, by drawing a clear line of command from the pen pushers to the army snipers, it could show that the flaws that brought them about are not individual and erratic but institutional and endemic.

The parallels are not lost on locals here. "We have every sympathy with the way Neville and Doreen Lawrence were treated by the police," says Mickey McKinney, whose brother Willie was shot dead on Bloody Sunday. "There was no sense of shock here that something like that could happen in Britain because we've all been through it."

But even a partially favourable outcome will allow not just the families of those who perished but the entire city of Derry to move on. For so long as there is a logjam in the judicial process there will be a hold-up in the grieving process. The city has become defined by the events of Bloody Sunday. Coming into the Bogside you are struck by a huge white edifice announcing "You are now entering Free Derry". On the walls of the flats, which have now been renovated, are huge murals depicting what happened on the day. One row of flats, in Glenfada Park, has not been touched up. It bears a mural of an RUC man and a soldier beating a protester and bullet holes from Bloody Sunday which may be useful for the inquiry. The event is even being commodified. The Bogside has become one of the city's major tourist attractions; within Derry's historic walls you can buy T-shirts marking the event.

Given the current state of the peace process, the political ramifications of an inquiry which finds the authorities guilty of systematic and pervasive wrongdoing could be immense. If nothing else it will provide a tangible context for the "lack of trust" which republicans refer to as the obstacle in the path of decommissioning and remove the facade that the British government is nothing more than an honest broker in a local religious dispute.

"Trust is a two-way street," says Macbride. "Trust has not been forthcoming from them so there's not going to be much trust going to them."

But a critical report from Lord Saville will not only provide a boost for the people of Derry but a jolt for the British, who practise a selective amnesia when it comes to ugly parts of our recent history. It could force us, not by guilt but by intellect, to redefine who we are through what we, as a nation, have done. "I inherit from the past of my family, my city, my tribe, my nation a variety of debts, inheritances, rightful expectations and obligations," writes Alasdair MacIntyre in his book, After Virtue: A Study in Moral Theory. "I am born with a past; and to try to cut myself off from that past is to deform my present relationships. The possession of an historical identity and the possession of a social identity coincide."

Which brings us back to the two monuments. For through the different ways in which the American and British establishments recognise their specific Bloody Sundays one begins to see where greater trust could emerge. The plaque in Selma shows that when it comes to the past the US has an ability to sacrifice parts in favour of the whole. They will admit a specific wrongdoing so that you may still retain some faith in the country's broader ideological narrative. Such an approach suggests that the nation's political culture is underpinned by a notion of right and wrong. By admitting it has been wrong it has the ability to claim that it has also been right. This does not make American history more morally acceptable. But it does make the official versions of it more believable.

The absence of any common marker in Derry indicates how, in the United Kingdom, there is no such distinction. For when a nation rarely admits it has done wrong, even in the face of undeniable evidence, it denies the opportunity for any critical support. You can either believe in the whole or you can reject the whole. You cannot take it in parts. You cannot think that what happened in Derry was wrong and still believe in the union flag since the establishment still insists those wrongs were committed in the name of the union flag. Nowhere are these contradictions clearer than in Ireland. By apologising for the potato famine and expressing regret for Bloody Sunday, Tony Blair has made some commendable headway here. By setting up an inquiry he has set the ball rolling. Once again it will be down to a lord to pick it up and run with it.

webTitle: Travolta and Will Smith caught in religious rows

fields.headline: Travolta and Will Smith caught in religious rows
fields.trailText: In yet another fine weekend for protest groups, the anti-scientology group FactNet has warned that "lawsuits may soon be flying" over John Travolta's upcoming Battlefield Earth.
fields.body:
In yet another fine weekend for protest groups, the anti-scientology group FactNet has warned that "lawsuits may soon be flying" over John Travolta's upcoming Battlefield Earth.

FactNet accuses the movie - adapted from a sci-fi novel by cult founder L Ron Hubbard and starring celebrity scientologist Travolta - of accommodating "subliminal messages to surreptitiously recruit new members from the movie audience". FactNet goes on to allege that the would-be religion - beloved of Tom Cruise, Nicole Kidman and other film stars - secretly financed the film, as well as being involved in its development, production and promotion.

Religious trouble is brewing for Will Smith too. The Robert Redford-directed The Legend of Bagger Vance, in which the rapper-turned-actor stars as a mysterious caddy to Matt Damon's 30s golfer Ranulph Junnah, has raised the hackles of the Hindu community.

A spokesperson for the National Council of Hindu Temples explained: "Bagger Vance is a distortion of the Hindu word for God - Bhagavad." Hindus will find it offensive, the spokesperson continued, "to see Will Smith on the screen being called what is basically the word for God".

webTitle: Election voted best at indie awards

fields.headline: Election voted best at indie awards
fields.trailText: Easily ignored amid the Oscar-related brouhaha, the Independent Spirit Awards - the traditional indie alternative to Hollywood's beanfeast - rewarded Alexander Payne's Election as the indie movie of the year at a ceremony on Saturday.
fields.body:
Easily ignored amid the Oscar-related brouhaha, the Independent Spirit Awards - the traditional indie alternative to Hollywood's beanfeast - rewarded Alexander Payne's Election as the indie movie of the year at a ceremony on Saturday.

The black comedy on teacher-pupil relations, starring Matthew Broderick and Reese Witherspoon, bagged Spirit awards for Best Feature, Best Director and Best Screenplay. Runners-up were David Lynch's The Straight Story, Sugar Town, Steven Soderbergh's The Limey and Robert Altman's Cookie's Fortune.

Excluded from the main awards - on account of being first features, for which there are separate categories - Oscar and box-office favourites Boys Don't Cry and Being John Malkovich both featured prominently.

Hilary Swank foreshadowed her Academy success with a Best Actress gong, while co-star Chloe Sevigny won Best Supporting Actress. Richard Farnsworth took Best Actor honours for The Straight Story.

Spike Jonze's film won Best First Feature (with a budget over $500,000) and Best First Screenplay, while The Blair Witch Project was named Best First Feature (with a budget - considerably - under $500,000).

webTitle: Could a sex swap sell a story?

fields.headline: Could a sex swap sell a story?
fields.standfirst: The lead character of  Sharon Krum's novel is male - so publishers advised her to change her name to Stanley...
fields.trailText: If only I had consulted a psychic and asked to speak with the Brontë sisters. It wouldn't have mattered which sibling - Emily, Charlotte, Anne (aka Ellis, Currer and Acton Bell) - they all would have proffered the same advice: if you want to get published, it helps to be a traitor to your gender.
fields.body:
If only I had consulted a psychic and asked to speak with the Brontë sisters. It wouldn't have mattered which sibling - Emily, Charlotte, Anne (aka Ellis, Currer and Acton Bell) - they all would have proffered the same advice: if you want to get published, it helps to be a traitor to your gender.

Of course, I would have dismissed their suggestion immediately, laughing and insisting the psychic inform them that more than a century after Wuthering Heights and Jane Eyre, women no longer have to undergo a sex change to publish.

There is no more subterfuge. We put our own names on the cover. We are no longer shackled to the genres of quivering romance and kitchen sink drama. We can and do write about sex, politics - even (gasp!) the interior lives of men.

I've since discovered those Brontë girls were right then (even though forced by circumstances) and they are right now. If you want to get published, it helps to be a man. And if you write a novel starring men, you'd better be a man.

I learned this ugly truth 12 months ago when my novel, Walk of Fame, a satire about America's obsession with fame and celebrity, started doing the rounds of American publishers.

Its lead character, Tom Webster, is a man. A red-blooded, 43-year-old American male - baseball mad, newly separated, midlife crisis. Then an offer comes his way too good to resist, an offer to become famous overnight and to see where it leads him. Fame, he discovers, leads him straight to the ninth circle of hell. And he loves it.

Tom narrates his journey complete with interior monologues about sports, male bonding, sex and women. I live in a world half male; I love men, I observe men, and I didn't, and still don't, think it's brain surgery to fictionalise them. And yet the book was rejected by a number of American publishers because, I was told repeatedly, no one would read a novel about a man written by a woman.

Better yet, few publishers believed I even was a woman. My agent received a slew of calls insisting she cough up my "real name". We don't believe Sharon Krum exists, they said. We don't believe a woman can get inside a man's head like that, they said. I was flattered, then insulted. They were convinced I was male and the name a hoax - a gimmick to give the book an edge.

I quickly learned publishers are terrified of women who write fiction about men, that I was their worst marketing nightmare. I was advised, in all seriousness, to change my name to Stanley Krum, cancel my subscription to Vogue and throw out my beloved high heels.

"Your gender is holding you back," one editor who liked the book but wouldn't buy it because I have XX chromosomes said to me privately.

"Men don't believe women can get inside their heads. Men don't think women can be funny about them. Change your name if you want to sell it."

On further prodding I discovered the industry thought Helen Fielding was a good girl because she wrote a comic book about a woman, and she was one. Nick Hornby was a good boy because he was a man writing wickedly about men.

But I was a bad girl because I crossed the line, putting my protagonist in a suit instead of a dress. If I had written Fever Pitch, it would, they swore, still be in my drawer. I wondered aloud whether JK Rowling used her initials because her protagonist was male. Was she worried little boys everywhere would reject Harry Potter if they knew his creator was a woman?

Americans consider themselves the most equal-opportunity nation on earth, but when it comes to reading, forget about it. Publishers confessed in hushed tones that American men won't rush to read a novel - even if it's is about them - unless the author reeks of testosterone. They just refuse to believe women can x-ray their minds.

Here in the UK, the recent Orange Prize gender survey concluded the situation is just as bad. It found men divide books into "male" and "female" reads, and run for the hills from the latter.

Ian McEwan's Enduring Love was considered a "female read" by 78% of men but only 38% of women. And only 13% of men, compared with 70% of women, would consider reading The English Patient. The problem? They thought it a book about nursing and therefore clearly "chick-lit" territory to be avoided at all costs.

The survey concluded that "men are far more biased towards books written by men than women are to books written by women".

And that is exactly why prizes like the Orange are crucial, to chip away at that gender bias, to validate and promote women's writing, to highlight great books men otherwise may not be inclined to read.

There is, you will be pleased to know, a positive ending to my story. I refused to change my name. I still wear skirts and cherry red lipstick. The book sold in five countries outside the US (in the UK, thankfully, my gender was not an issue for the publisher, but the public is yet to cast its vote) and we are now in talks with an American publisher prepared to take a risk on Sharon, not Stanley.

But I still think those Brontë girls were smart. They never gave anybody an excuse not to read their books.
