webTitle: Do I know you, Ms Plath?

fields.headline: Do I know you, Ms Plath?
fields.standfirst: On digging up the dirt on literary figures
fields.trailText: I read the Plath diaries in the Guardian with mixed feelings: fascination and a sneaking self-disgust. After the last extract, I took down my old copy of Ariel (overdue 37 years, I discover, from Leicester University library). Did I, after all this time, understand those desperate poems better? (Would I have understood them better still had Hughes not destroyed the final diary, thus denying this newspaper its lurid fourth instalment?)
fields.body:
I read the Plath diaries in the Guardian with mixed feelings: fascination and a sneaking self-disgust. After the last extract, I took down my old copy of Ariel (overdue 37 years, I discover, from Leicester University library). Did I, after all this time, understand those desperate poems better? (Would I have understood them better still had Hughes not destroyed the final diary, thus denying this newspaper its lurid fourth instalment?)

I never met Plath or Hughes. The nearest I came was a "danced with the Prince of Wales" connection through a colleague who had shared a house with them at university. He had a good story about how one night Ted snaffled from their pond some exotic ducks which the Chinese ambassador had ceremonially presented to the city of Cambridge. The future poet laureate strangled them, plucked them and feasted (with Sylvia and my colleague) on their flesh. It beats stealing library books.

The idea of Hughes the poacher enhanced my reading of "Pike". The only other thing I learned was that Ted and Sylvia f'd (Sylvia's euphemism) very noisily. "Like f'ing alley cats," my friend said. Not helpful.

I did know Philip Larkin when I was an undergraduate. He had something going with my tutor at Leicester and would come down from Hull at weekends. As Andrew Motion testifies, he was a very funny conversationalist. "Inside every fat bastard, there's a thin bastard trying to get out," I remember him musing about some loudmouthed prat at the bar. I've repeated the jest often as my own (it's not just poets' books one steals).

As an act of juvenile homage, I wrote an answer on Larkin in my finals. I think (in 1963) I may have been the first undergraduate in England to do so. Nowadays, as he predicted, schoolgirls study "They fuck you up, your mum and dad" for GCSE. I was astounded to learn that Larkin - no mean poacher himself - sneaked an illicit look at my script, which was being externally marked at Hull. "Only sensible thing that's ever been written about me," he reported back. The remark meant more to me than my final first-class degree.

I've dined with Heaney, drunk with Blake Morrison, met Hugo Williams at conferences and hob-nobbed with Andrew Motion at publishers' parties. I don't of course "know" them, although one has that false sense of intimacy from knowing the published privacies of their poetry.

I worked for four years with Stephen Spender at University College London in the 1970s. Thirty years later, I'm writing his life and have access to his private papers. I scoured the relevant years, looking for references to that brilliant young fellow Sutherland about whom all the department was talking excitedly.

Nothing. A colleague who was close to Spender said that after some boozy party Stephen asked him: "Who is that boy with the pale face over there, I can never remember his name." I had been working two office doors away for three years. Meet Dr Prufrock.

Did the poet have some uneasy premonition that one day the pale-faced Sutherland would be privy to his innermost secrets? I've just been examining a cache of papers that survive from the break-up of Spender's first marriage in 1938. It was a period when all the poets in London seemed to be f'ing each other up.

The letters are as powerful as anything in the Plath diaries. Spender himself thought they had been destroyed. He had strong views on biographical intrusion, maintaining that his life was his property - not the public's, nor posterity's.

Will I use the material? No I won't - except in a carefully digested way. I advised the current holders to restrict access. It's the most vexatious problem in literary biography. What right do strangers like me and you have to the privacies of poets?

On his deathbed, apparently, TS Eliot instructed his young wife: "No biography." Mrs Eliot has gallantly kept the jackals at bay ever since. Last week, red-faced professor that I now am, I examined the best thesis I've ever read, by a pale-faced boy called Jason Harding. It defends Eliot against Anthony Julius's charges of anti-Semitism - convincingly. Harding's letters to Valerie Eliot were never answered nor was he permitted to quote unpublished material. Admirable, perhaps. Wrong-headed, certainly.

"How unpleasant to meet Mr Eliot", one of Old Possum's poems begins. Was it? Most of us will never know.

webTitle: Wild, Wild Worst sweeps up at anti-Oscars

fields.headline: Wild, Wild Worst sweeps up at anti-Oscars
fields.trailText: The Oscars weren't the weekend's only opportunity for Hollywood movies to earn their just desserts. The celebrated anti-Oscars - the Golden Raspberry Awards, or Razzies - were gleefully distributed on Saturday night, in an evening that served as an irreverent counterpoint to the backslapping to come at the Academy Awards only 24 hours later.
fields.body:
The Oscars weren't the weekend's only opportunity for Hollywood movies to earn their just desserts. The celebrated anti-Oscars - the Golden Raspberry Awards, or Razzies - were gleefully distributed on Saturday night, in an evening that served as an irreverent counterpoint to the backslapping to come at the Academy Awards only 24 hours later.

The big winner was Barry Sonnenfeld's Wild Wild West: the abysmal TV remake bagged Worst Film, Worst Director, Worst Screenplay, Worst Song (the title rap) and Worst Screen Couple (the ill-matched Will Smith and Kevin Kline). As for Kenneth Branagh, he was spared a well-deserved prize - the award resembles a golden raspberry on a chewed-up film reel and is valued at $4.27 - for his own abortive contribution to the dodgy western.

Censured as Worst Actor and Actress were Adam Sandler in Big Daddy and Heather Donahue in The Blair Witch Project. In the supporting categories, Denise Richards won a well-earned Razzie for her turn as a nuclear physicist in The World Is Not Enough, while rasta frog Jar Jar Binks (voiced by Ahmed Best) bagged the unwanted gong for his role in The Phantom Menace.

In special millennial categories, Worst Actor of the Century went to Sylvester Stallone, and its female equivalent to Madonna. The Worst Picture of the 90s, meanwhile, was won - and who could argue with this? - by Paul Verhoeven's risible Showgirls.

fields.headline: Did you know...
fields.trailText: • Jane Campion is the only female director to have been nominated for Best Picture and Best Director (The Piano, 1993).
fields.body:
 Jane Campion is the only female director to have been nominated for Best Picture and Best Director (The Piano, 1993).

 The Color Purple holds the joint record (with The Turning Point) for most nominations (11), but no wins.

 Warren Beatty is the second person in Academy history to be nominated simultaneously in four categories (producer, actor, director and writer). He's been nominated for all four twice (Heaven Can Wait, 1978, and Reds, 1981).

 Hilary Swank's Oscar makes her the second actress to win for playing a member of the opposite sex. The previous winner was Linda Hunt (Year of Living Dangerously, 1983).

 The first 1,000 guests at Elton John's after-show party will get gift bags valued at $650 each. That's nothing however compared with the gift baskets the Oscar presenters are to receive. Those are worth up to $15,000 and include a baseball autographed by Joe DiMaggio and a Montblanc pen.

 Hedd Wyn is the first and only Welsh-language film to be nominated for Best Foreign Language film, in 1993.

 The only sequel to win Best Picture is Godfather II.

 Guests arriving for the Oscar ceremony in 1940 could buy the 8.45pm edition of the Los Angeles Times in which the winners were announced. The following year, the sealed-envelope system was adopted.

 Last year, all the Best Picture nominees were for period films set at least 50 years earlier.

 It isn't entirely clear why the Awards are known as the Oscars. The most popular story has it that an Academy librarian and eventual executive director, Margaret Herrick, thought the statue resembled her uncle Oscar and said so. A reporter standing conveniently nearby is alleged to have overheard her and helped brand the golden guy. The Academy itself didn't use the nickname officially until 1939.

 Walt Disney received an Oscar and seven miniature statuettes when he was honoured for Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs in 1938.

 In support of the war effort, the Academy handed out plaster Oscar statuettes during world war two. After the war, winners were able to exchange their plaster awards for golden statuettes.

 This year, there are 5,607 voting members of the Academy. Members represent 13 branches of arts and sciences of motion pictures - Actors, Art Directors, Cinematographers, Directors, Executives, Film Editors, Music, Producers, Public Relations, Short Films and Feature Animation, Sound, Visual Effects and Writers.

 The Silence of the Lambs is the only horror film to have won Best Picture.

 Shirley Temple was the youngest winner when she won a juvenile Academy Award, aged six. The youngest winner of a "regular" Academy Award was Tatum O'Neal, who, at age 10, won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar for Paper Moon. The oldest winner was George Burns (Best Actor, aged 80).

 Instead of collecting his Best Director award for Annie Hall in 1977, Woody Allen was playing the clarinet in Michael's, a New York jazz bar.

 Alfred Hitchcock was nominated for Best Director five times, but never won.

 Steven Spielberg bought at auction Clark Gable's Best Actor Oscar (for It Happened one Night) for $550,000.

 Katherine Hepburn and Meryl Streep hold the joint record for most nominations (12 each). Jack Nicholson takes second place, with 11 nominations.

 The only blind Oscar winner is Stevie Wonder (in 1984, for I Just Called To Say I Love You).

 1987 is the only year when none of the nominees for Best Director were born in the US.

 The Awards have only been rescheduled three times in their 73-year history. The first occasion was in 1938 when floods all but washed out Los Angeles and delayed the ceremony by a week. Following the assassination of Martin Luther King in 1968, the ceremony was postponed by two days out of respect for the murdered civil rights leader. In 1981, the Awards were postponed for 24 hours due to the assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan.

 In 1974, the ceremony was interrupted by a streaker (prompting presenter David Niven to quip: "Just think, the only laugh that man will probably ever get is for stripping off and showing his shortcomings.")

 More people have been nominated for playing Henry VIII than for any other character, historic or fictional.

 The first black actor to win Best Actor was Sidney Poitier, in 1963 for Lilies of the Field.

 The only person to receive an award posthumously was actor Peter Finch (for Network, 1976).

webTitle: MI5 bugging exempt from privacy act

fields.headline: MI5 bugging exempt from privacy act
fields.trailText: Covert surveillance by MI5, MI6 and the police, including tapping phones and bugging homes, will be exempt from challenge under a new right to privacy contained in the Human Rights Act, it has emerged.
fields.body:
Covert surveillance by MI5, MI6 and the police, including tapping phones and bugging homes, will be exempt from challenge under a new right to privacy contained in the Human Rights Act, it has emerged.

The security and intelligence agencies will be protected from any court challenge by a hitherto unnoticed provision in the regulation of investigatory powers bill now going through parliament.

The bill covers a wide range of intrusive surveillance techniques, including systematic targeting of an individual over a period of time in order, as the Home Office puts it, "to obtain a picture of his life, activities and his associates".

It includes the bugging of private property and cars, and the use of "covert human intelligence sources" - informants or undercover officers.

Ministers will be able to issue orders allowing agencies other than the security and intelligence services to undertake covert surveillance. They include the Department of Health and Social Security, the Ministry of Agriculture, and the Department of Trade and Industry as well as local authorities.

While the bill says that warrants for intercepting communications would still be signed by cabinet ministers, authorisation for other forms of surveillance would be given by senior police officers or even local authority officials.

The act, which comes into force in England and Wales on October 2, allows individuals to go to the ordinary courts to challenge those in authority who breach the new right of privacy.

However, where the activities of the security and intelligence services - or any other group conducting secret surveillance on their behalf - are concerned this right will not exist.

Instead of being able to go to the ordinary courts to challenge violations of privacy individuals will be forced to have their cases dealt with by a special tribunal.

The proposed body is modelled on existing "complaints tribunals" covering the activities of MI5 and other agencies which have existed since 1985. However, though they have received hundreds of complaints, they have never upheld a single complaint.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said last night: "The regulation of investigatory powers bill authorises the most intrusive kinds of surveillance by some of the most secretive organisations in the country.

"The safeguards in the bill for these very significant invasions into our privacy are inadequate as it is. The most shocking thing is the government intends to give them immunity from normal challenges under the Human Rights Act."

The irony is that the special tribunal - whose decisions, according to the bill, will not be "questioned in any court" - is itself unlikely to meet the requirements of the right to a fair trial in article 6 of the human rights convention incorporated in the Human Rights Act.

However, where the activities of the security and intelligence services - or any other group conducting secret surveillance on their behalf - are concerned this right will not exist. Instead of being able to go to the ordinary courts to challenge violations of privacy individuals will be forced to have their cases dealt with by a special tribunal. The proposed body is modelled on existing "complaints tribunals" covering the activities of MI5 and other agencies which have existed since 1985. However, though they have received hundreds of complaints, they have never upheld a single complaint. John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said last night: "The regulation of investigatory powers bill authorises the most intrusive kinds of surveillance by some of the most secretive organisations in the country. "The safeguards in the bill for these very significant invasions into our privacy are inadequate as it is. The most shocking thing is the government intends to give them immunity from normal challenges under the Human Rights Act." The irony is that the special tribunal - whose decisions, according to the bill, will not be "questioned in any court" - is itself unlikely to meet the requirements of the right to a fair trial in article 6 of the human rights convention incorporated in the Human Rights Act.

webTitle: Depp to play Burns, but can he burr?

fields.headline: Depp to play Burns, but can he burr?
fields.trailText: The news that the American Johnny Depp is to play Robert Burns in a film about the life of Scotland's national poet has left many Scots wondering if they will finally get a Hollywood star who can master the accent.
fields.body:
The news that the American Johnny Depp is to play Robert Burns in a film about the life of Scotland's national poet has left many Scots wondering if they will finally get a Hollywood star who can master the accent.

Mel Gibson (Australian) grappled with it unsuccessfully as William Wallace in Braveheart; Liam Neeson (Irish) made a decent stab at it in Rob Roy; and the cast of Brigadoon (American) well and truly massacred it.

Now all eyes are on Depp, known for his method acting and attention to detail. He has been picked to play Burns in an £18m film, Clarinda, directed by Vadim Jean.

Depp will meet producers next month to discuss the role. Known for choosing offbeat parts, he has won acclaim for performances in films such as Edward Scissorhands, What's Eating Gilbert Grape? and Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.

Clarinda will be based on Burns's passion for the mar ried poet Agnes McLehose, for whom he penned Ae Fond Kiss. But even if Depp can develop the perfect burr he will have to overcome resentment that another key Scottish role has gone to an overseas actor.

Burns enthusiasts say the role was tailor-made for Ewan McGregor, but he is thought to be too tied up in the Star Wars trilogy.

"It is difficult for people, I know," said the film's producer, James Cosmo. "But we have to appeal to a world market. The poetry of Burns has an international resonance, and this is by no means a small film. We need a guy who is hugely charismatic, as Burns was."

It is understood that the film will be shot in Scotland, and the rest of the cast and crew will be Scottish. The role of Clarinda is not yet filled.

"It's a love story which concentrates on what must have been an extraordinary period," Mr Cosmo said. "Here was a man, a ploughman, with calluses on his hands, who went among the glitterati of Edinburgh society and burnt like phosphorous.

"They wrote these beautiful letters to one another which showed the depth of their love."

Depp is said to be excited at the prospect. He is known to like poetry, having read the works of Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac in poetry marathons on US television.

He has a reputation as a hellraiser, and there have been frequent clashes with the paparazzi. More recently he has settled with his girlfriend, Vanessa Paradis, and their baby daughter.

Some Burns specialists yesterday were reserving judgment until they saw Depp's performance. "It could have been worse," said an official at the Burns national heritage park. "Someone heard Gerard Depardieu was up for it."

fields.headline: Homework headache for parents
fields.trailText: Government guidelines on homework are giving parents a headache, according to a survey published yesterday. Ministers recommend that 11-year-olds spend half an hour a night on their homework, plus 20 minutes' additional reading.
fields.body:
Government guidelines on homework are giving parents a headache, according to a survey published yesterday. Ministers recommend that 11-year-olds spend half an hour a night on their homework, plus 20 minutes' additional reading.

But a survey for the education web site, learnfree.co.uk, shows parents are spending seven hours a week trying to help them - and often failing. One in two parents confessed they regularly got stuck.

In their desperation to recall from their own school days the intricacies of algebra, parents are asking their relatives and friends.

The survey, of 1,200 parents, did not ask whether children themselves spent seven hours a week on their homework, working with their parents - or whether parents put in extra hours of research on their own.

Maths and science pose the greatest problems for confused mothers and fathers. Fathers claimed to find maths easier than mothers.

One in three children used the internet to find help with their homework, and one in five parents also went online.

webTitle: Blair to help close global digital divide

fields.headline: Blair to help close global digital divide
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will respond to the growing crisis in education in the developing world by announcing today that the government is teaming up with the internet giant Cisco Systems to start to close the education gap between rich and poor.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will respond to the growing crisis in education in the developing world by announcing today that the government is teaming up with the internet giant Cisco Systems to start to close the education gap between rich and poor.

The prime minister is to meet Cisco's chief executive John Chambers to help draw up a plan to put to Commonwealth ministers in November. Cisco is to form a key part of a Downing Street team that includes charities and other internet content providers.

Mr Blair has been under pressure from charities to match the commitment of his chancellor, Gordon Brown, to reduce third world debt by leading a drive to raise plummeting educational standards in developing countries.

A Whitehall official insisted: "This is not about putting the net into mud huts. It is practical politics and education."

Cisco is the largest maker of computer network equipment in the world and is already worth £360bn.

Its senior executives believe there is a huge potential to spread education in Africa, for example, through the internet and distance learning. They have been pressing the British government to become more closely involved in the spread of political debate and information through the net.

Mr Blair said: "Education is the key to tackling poverty and extending opportunity in the developing world. The new technologies have great potential to aid the effort to spread education. However, there is a real danger of a digital divide opening between rich and poor countries. We cannot let that happen if we are to meet our goal of universal primary education by 2015."

Mr Blair is to meet campaigners for developing countries this week, when he will be urged to toughen up the agenda for a UN conference on primary education next month in Dakar, Senegal. Aid agencies say the agenda is vague.

Oxfam, which is leading a campaign for a £5bn action plan to tackle the education crisis, welcomed the Cisco initiative but warned against relying on a technology fix.

Access to the net requires access to a telephone network, a rare facility in the developing world. In Bangladesh, there are fewer than three telephone lines for every 1,000 people; in Afghanistan, the ratio is less than one in 1,000. And the barriers are not just physical - a net user has to be literate.

webTitle: Putin wins landslide victory in Russian presidency vote

fields.headline: Putin wins landslide victory in Russian presidency vote
fields.trailText: Russia was thrust into an uncertain era this morning when Vladimir Putin secured the sweeping powers of the presidency in a landslide election triumph, only eight months after being launched into national politics by his patron, Boris Yeltsin. It was the first time the acting president had faced the voters.
fields.body:
Russia was thrust into an uncertain era this morning when Vladimir Putin secured the sweeping powers of the presidency in a landslide election triumph, only eight months after being launched into national politics by his patron, Boris Yeltsin. It was the first time the acting president had faced the voters.

With nearly 70% of the vote counted in Russia's third direct presidential election, Mr Putin had won 51.17%, just over the 50% he needed to avoid a runoff on April 16. His main challenger, the communist leader Gennady Zyuganov, was on 30.37%, and complained of widespread fraud.

Mr Putin's share was expected to rise as results came in from St Petersburg and other western regions, where his support is strongest.

At a press conference early this morning he acknowledged that the Communists had done well and that his government would have to take popular discontent into account. "Our policy must be more balanced, take into account the existing realities and aim at increasing living standards," Mr Putin said.

In a swift attempt to build a national consensus behind his new team, whose policies are unclear, he went out of his way to praise Mr Zyuganov and his other main political rivals, the former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov and Moscow's mayor, Yury Luzhkov.

They had all supported him over the war in Chechnya, he said, and had never taken an "anti-state position".

At 47, Mr Putin will be the youngest person to rule Russia since Stalin succeeded Lenin as Soviet leader 76 years ago.

A a former KGB career officer whose critics denounce him as a warmonger because of his brutal prosecution of the war in Chechnya, he has sold himself to Russians who yearn for a strong leader.

The Moscow liberal, Grigory Yavlinsky, trailed in a poor third place, with 5.78% of the vote after Mr Putin's media acolytes smeared him in the closing days of a lacklustre campaign. Fearing that a bigger vote for Mr Yavlinsky could leave Mr Putin short of outright victory, state television claimed that he was supported by homosexuals and Jews, and funded by foreigners.

The turnout was put at 68%, well above the 50% required for the ballot to be valid. But throughout the day the state television broadcast alarmist reports about a low turnout to mobilise the Putin vote among the electorate of 108m - voting at 90,000 polling stations across 11 time zones.

Mr Zyuganov accused the government of widespread fraud, saying that the true Communist vote was more than 40%. "They have set up a zone of blanket fraud to cheat citizens," he said.

There were no independent reports of vote irregularities.

Mr Yeltsin, who appointed Mr Putin prime minister last August and then transferred power to him when he resigned on New Year's Eve, stressed that the reforms would continue. "The main thing is that the reform course must be maintained and it will be," said Mr Yeltsin. "Everyone is waiting for change. There will be some changes."

But Mr Putin may be chastened by a scrutiny of the results. Given that one-third of voters stayed at home, he can only claim the explicit support of one-third of voters.

His programme is unclear, and he made minimum effort to outline any policies as acting president. He is expected to rule as a "liberal nationalist" - espousing free market policies and greater state regulation, and a tougher line that favours law and order over civil liberties - but to drive a hard bargain on foreign policy and relations with the west.

webTitle: The best secretary scene: Being John Malkovich

fields.headline: The best secretary scene: Being John Malkovich
fields.trailText: The best secretary scene: Being John Malkovich
fields.body:
Unemployed puppeteer Craig Schwartz (John Cusack) is attending a job interview on floor 7 1/2 of a Manhattan office block. Stooping to make his way down the kiddie-sized corridor, he finds the office he needs and enters. A receptionist, Floris (Mary Kay Place), looks up.

"Welcome to Lestercorp - how may we meet your filing needs?"

"Erm, my name's Craig Schwartz, and I'm here for an interview with Dr Lester."

"Oh, please have a seat Mr. Juarez."

"Schwartz," he corrects her.

"Pardon?"

"My name is Schwartz."

Floris looks at Craig as if he is utterly insane.

"I'm sorry," she glares, "I have no idea what you're saying to me right now."

"My name is Schwartz."

"My name is Warts?"

Craig gives up and goes to take a seat in the corner of the office with the other applicants. A buzzer on Floris's desk alerts her that Dr Lester is ready for the next interview.

"Mr Juarez!"

At first, Craig doesn't realise this means him. Then, quickly, he stands up.

"Yes?"

Floris looks offended.

"Chest?"

"I said 'yes'."

"You suggest what? I have no time for piddling suggestions from job applicants. Besides, Dr Lester will see you now."

Craig goes to knock on Dr Lester's door, but the doctor (Orson Bean) has already opened it.

"Ah, Mr. Juarez!"

See also: Psycho, Jungle Fever, Grosse Pointe Blank

Don't see also: Working Girl

Pointless trivia: Mary Kay Place co-wrote three episodes of M*A*S*H in 1974.

fields.headline: What are you waiting for?
fields.standfirst:
Jonathon Maitland believes journalists are ideally placed to make a mint from the net. And to prove it, he morgaged his house in an attempt to turn £50,000 into a million using the web. He might just manage it

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jonathon Maitland believes journalists are ideally placed to make a mint from the net. And to prove it, he morgaged his house in an attempt to turn £50,000 into a million using the web. He might just manage it
fields.body:
Recently, a thought struck me. Why are so many journalists in danger of making millions of pounds from the net? Look at Tim Jackson, the ex-Financial Times and Independent foreign correspondent. He runs QXL, the online auction business.

He is now 111th in the Sunday Times Rich List, and "worth" £272m. Then there's Danny Kelly, former editor of Q and NME. He's the chief executive of the 365 corporation, which provides content for websites, Wap phones and digital TV. The company's current stock market value is a somewhat piffling £550m. I ask this question only because there is a small, but nevertheless real, chance, that a small fortune might be coming my way. And the fact that I'm a journalist has a lot to do with it. Let me explain.

In January, I was commissioned by Hodder and Stoughton to write a book, to be published in January 2001, called How To Make Your Million from the Internet (and what to do if you don't). It will be a diary of my attempts to turn £50,000 into £1m by using the internet to trade shares. I raised the money by mortgaging my house. Month one went well. Through a mixture of judgment, instinct and luck (and not trading every day, but going for long-term bets), I made a real cash profit of more than £30,000.

I have already received a five-figure advance for the book, and two national newspapers are inquiring about serialisation rights. Hodder tell me that several foreign publishers are interested too. But - and this is where the serious money comes in - I have started up my own website, so interested punters can track my progress. And if that works, the title of my book might - just might - become a self-fulfilling prophecy. I have an email, sent last week, from the chief executive of a stock market listed dot.com company, enquiring about buying a sizeable stake in my project.

The thing is, my experience is illuminating to all those journalists out there (yes, you) who say: "My God, shouldn't I be making lots of money out of all of this stuff?" How many people like that do you know? Lots and lots, all feeling a little bit of envy about their former colleagues making lots and lots of money. Two weeks ago Martin Dunn announced that he was leaving his post as head of new media at Associated Newspapers. Now Danny Meadow Klue has said he is leaving a similar position at the Telegraph. Both are going into the start-up business.

What's struck me is the speed, and the relative ease, with which things happen: I keep expecting someone to say "No you can't do that mate, not possible." But so far, no one has. However - and I don't want to sound disingenuous here - this project is primarily about journalism, not making money. I want to see how the stockmarket and the internet work, from the sharp end. I want to see how easy it is for someone like me, a complete cyberdunce until two months ago, to make - or lose - vast amounts of money. What I've now realised is that it's journalists who are in a much better position than most to take advantage of the net. Why? Because we have the two things that the net is crying out for. Ideas and communication skills. "As journalists, when we have a great idea, we write about it. Now, thanks to the net, we can turn it into something a lot more interesting," says David Thomas, a freelance writer currently raising funding for his Shobiz.com internet venture.

"The net is overflowing with computer wizards and moneymen, but there's a real shortage of people who can get good ideas over simply and effectively. A lot of sites out there are, quite frankly, filled with crap."

The basic journalistic skills are invaluable, all the way along the line. Take writing a business plan: the key first step to securing the all-important interest of the Men with the Wallets. "A business plan is to an internet start-up what a film script is to a movie," Thomas says. "It's the first and most important thing you need to attract investment. You can still make a bad movie from a good script: but it's impossible to make a good movie from a bad script. And the same applies to business.

"To write a good plan you have to take an idea and develop it - tell a story in fact - which is, let's face it, what journalists do every day of the week. I've lost count of the number of venture capitalists who've told me how rare it is to see a well-written document."

Crucially, journalists are also pretty good at getting publicity. Because of the incestuous nature of our business, we know plenty of other people who make it too, be they in papers, radio or television.

The key point here is that if there's one thing a young dot.com venture needs more than anything, in a hopelessly overcrowded marketplace, it's publicity. In fact you only need the slightest whiff to get your bandwagon rolling: within minutes of a small paragraph appearing in the Media Guardian diary about my project last week, I had the BBC on the phone asking to make a documentary about me. And the Mail on Sunday, asking for an interview. Net entrepreneurs also need the ability to become expert (or at least appear to be) in several different fields at once: technical, financial and logistical. They should be able to cope with vast amounts of complex information, extract the key points, and then act on them quickly. That, of course, is what journalists do with varying degrees of success. The other thing is contacts."I've spent a long time in the media. I know how things work," says Danny Kelly. "I knew good content providers, for example, because I'd met them through work. And because I'm a journalist, they took me seriously." Guardian readers will of course be familiar with the classic Marxist principle that real power stems from owning the means of production. A decade ago that was way out of reach for most of us. Now, for journalists, it's never been easier. More importantly, the net offers real excitement: even if my project goes pear-shaped and I lose a packet I'll have learned skills I never knew existed and I'll have had a great time doing it. So, what are you waiting for?

Jonathon Maitland is a reporter on ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. You can visit his website on howtomakeyourmillion.com

Now, thanks to the net, we can turn it into something a lot more interesting," says David Thomas, a freelance writer currently raising funding for his Shobiz.com internet venture. "The net is overflowing with computer wizards and moneymen, but there's a real shortage of people who can get good ideas over simply and effectively. A lot of sites out there are, quite frankly, filled with crap." The basic journalistic skills are invaluable, all the way along the line. Take writing a business plan: the key first step to securing the all-important interest of the Men with the Wallets. "A business plan is to an internet start-up what a film script is to a movie," Thomas says. "It's the first and most important thing you need to attract investment. You can still make a bad movie from a good script: but it's impossible to make a good movie from a bad script. And the same applies to business. "To write a good plan you have to take an idea and develop it - tell a story in fact - which is, let's face it, what journalists do every day of the week. I've lost count of the number of venture capitalists who've told me how rare it is to see a well-written document." Crucially, journalists are also pretty good at getting publicity. Because of the incestuous nature of our business, we know plenty of other people who make it too, be they in papers, radio or television. The key point here is that if there's one thing a young dot.com venture needs more than anything, in a hopelessly overcrowded marketplace, it's publicity. In fact you only need the slightest whiff to get your bandwagon rolling: within minutes of a small paragraph appearing in the Media Guardian diary about my project last week, I had the BBC on the phone asking to make a documentary about me. And the Mail on Sunday, asking for an interview. Net entrepreneurs also need the ability to become expert (or at least appear to be) in several different fields at once: technical, financial and logistical. They should be able to cope with vast amounts of complex information, extract the key points, and then act on them quickly. That, of course, is what journalists do with varying degrees of success. The other thing is contacts."I've spent a long time in the media. I know how things work," says Danny Kelly. "I knew good content providers, for example, because I'd met them through work. And because I'm a journalist, they took me seriously." Guardian readers will of course be familiar with the classic Marxist principle that real power stems from owning the means of production. A decade ago that was way out of reach for most of us. Now, for journalists, it's never been easier. More importantly, the net offers real excitement: even if my project goes pear-shaped and I lose a packet I'll have learned skills I never knew existed and I'll have had a great time doing it. So, what are you waiting for? Jonathon Maitland is a reporter on ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. You can visit his website on howtomakeyourmillion.com

fields.headline: Keeping faith Website targets Muslim investors
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A website claiming to be the first to allow Muslims to trade shares and buy investment products online in accordance with Islamic principles launches today with one eye on a $500m market flotation.
fields.body:
A website claiming to be the first to allow Muslims to trade shares and buy investment products online in accordance with Islamic principles launches today with one eye on a $500m market flotation.

IslamiQ.com will offer banking, finance and insurance products and services that are in compliance with Shari'ah laws. Chief executive Hasnita Dato Hashim, pictured left with venture co-founder Peter Farrid Faisal, said it would be targeted at an Islamic capital market worth $150bn, as well as the 94m Muslims who are forecast to be online by 2002.

Shari'ah laws decree that money must be productive in society and forbids investments in activities such as gaming and alcohol or conventional financial institutions. Commercial considerations must be combined with social obligations.

IslamiQ.com has raised $6m from two Middle East institutions, the International Investor of Kuwait and Jeddah-based Dallah Al Baraka Group. Dr Hashim said a second round of fundraising to attract $50m of new finance is under way and an IPO on either the Nasdaq or London stock exchanges is planned for within the next year.

"Muslims worldwide can now invest on a level playing field in terms of the technology and information available whilst still keeping to their Islamic principles," she said.

Three prominent Shari'ah scholars will sit on an IslamiQ.com advisory board to give guidance on and approval to investment decisions. Dr Hashim has eight years' experience in Islamic investment banking.

 Most online retailers fail to satisfy consumers and are providing a poor service, according to retail research consultancy Verdict.

A report published today says significant investment in delivery functions will be required if many e-tailers are to go into profit.

fields.headline: Books battle
fields.standfirst: Inspiration for The Little Prince at the centre of a literary row
fields.trailText: Three authors are engaged in a bitter literary row about their differing accounts of the woman who inspired France's most popular book, The Little Prince.
fields.body:
Three authors are engaged in a bitter literary row about their differing accounts of the woman who inspired France's most popular book, The Little Prince.

The trio of books - which are a month away from publication - will cast new light on the background to the child-like fable as they expose a stormy marriage between the pioneering aviator and author, Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, and his Salvadorean wife, Consuelo, the model for the rose to which the little prince is devoted.

The arguments threaten to overshadow this year's celebrations to mark the centenary of Saint-Exupéry's birth in Lyon.

First published in 1943, a year before Saint-Exupéry died, The Little Prince, a children's book but also seen as an account of a man's struggle to come to terms with an impossible marriage of passion, still sells a million copies a year.

The three books about his wife are a biography of Consuelo, an album of previously unpublished photos and letters, and Consuelo's 300-page diary.

The author's nephews and nieces - the couple had no children - are objecting to the biography, written by the Guardian's Paul Webster, because of its frank account of Consuelo's turbulent love life before and after she met Saint- Exupéry.

Meanwhile, Consuelo's family are anxious to block publication of the other two books because they doubt their authenticity.

The album, Oh Consuelo, is the work of the biographer Alain Vircondelet, who was given access to a box of documents unopened since 1947. Consuelo, who died in 1979, left the cache to her Spanish gardener and factotum, Jose Martinez. Mr Martinez is publishing the diary.

Mr Vircondelet said: "... anyone who thinks the documents are fake had better think again. This is the real thing, and some of it is explosive."

Mr Martinez will receive 50% of the royalties from these two books, reviving resentment among the author's relatives who failed to overturn Consuelo's will.

Bernard Lefort, editorial director at Felin, the company publishing Webster's La Rose du Petit Prince, said Saint-Exupéry's family was determined to maintain an almost saintly aura around the author.

They wanted Mr Webster, author of a Saint-Exupéry book which first revealed the link between the rose and Consuelo seven years ago, banned from many of the official centenary celebrations. They have been backed by Saint-Exupéry's mistress, Hélène de Vogüe.

"As aristocrats, they never accepted his wife, whose father was a central American Indian," Mr Lefort said. "They also hate any discussion of Saint-Ex's weaknesses, which is a pity because The Little Prince is actually a very courageous commitment to marriage at any price, giving it a very modern message."

Consuelo's family, who supplied details to Mr Webster, opposes publication of the disclosures coming out of the documents left to Mr Martinez, which reveal Saint-Exupéry's and Consuelo's inconstancy in their 13-year marriage.

"We are being refused the moral right to consult intimate papers," said Consuelo's niece, Mireille Dimas. "We should be allowed to protect her reputation."

fields.headline: Foreign Office plans Zimbabwe evacuation
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office has drawn up contingency plans to evacuate an estimated 20,000 British passport holders from Zimbabwe after the president, Robert Mugabe, refused to take action against thousands of black squatters who are occupying white-owned farms.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office has drawn up contingency plans to evacuate an estimated 20,000 British passport holders from Zimbabwe after the president, Robert Mugabe, refused to take action against thousands of black squatters who are occupying white-owned farms.

President Mugabe said he would ignore a ruling by the Zimbabwe high court that the occupation of around 750 farms was illegal and that police should remove the squatters, most of whom support his government.

His decision brought strongly worded statements of concern from the international community, with criticism from Britain, the United States, South Africa and the European Union.

Mr Mugabe's increasing isolation will make it more difficult for him to get the financial assistance his country desperately needs.

In an interview with CNN this weekend, Mr Mugabe unequivocally stated that he would not obey the court order.

"It would bring chaos if we attempted to implement the decision of the court," he said. "I view it as merely a peaceful demonstration by the war veterans. As long as it remains peaceful then we will not have to send the police in."

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain said yesterday that the farm invasions were increasing the sense of insecurity in Zimbabwe to such an extent that plans were being put in place for an evacuation of British passport holders, as well as thousands more who would be eligible for British passports.

"We hope it won't come to that," said Mr Hain. "It is important for the Zimbabwe government to understand that white farmers and other whites want to be part of their country and want to stay in the country they love.

"They should not be pushed out. The [evacuation] plan is prudent preparation for a situation that might or might not arise."

Mr Hain said the farm invasions had "harmed the production and output of the farms and that has harmed the country's exports and its economy. That is not a good thing.

"The future of Zimbabwe will not be enhanced by this kind of action, which appears to be encouraged from the very top of government."

Mr Hain claimed that Mr Mugabe's government had driven Zimbabwe's once strong economy to the depths of despair.

Britain's relations with Mr Mugabe's government are like "a dialogue of the deaf", said Mr Hain, adding that the difficult relations with Zimbabwe are "in common with other donor countries in Europe, the United States as well as neighbouring African countries who find it impossible to engage in constructive dialogue".

South Africa's defence minister, Mosiuoa Lekota, said the deteriorating situation in Zimbabwe "worries me day and night. It's a very dangerous situation. One of the critical elements of the new Africa must be the law."

South Africa's finance minister, Trevor Manuel, said he is concerned about the deepening economic crisis in Zimbabwe, because it is South Africa's largest trading partner in Africa.

The US also expressed its concern. The under secretary of state for southern African affairs, Whitney Schneidman, said in Zimbabwe last week that the Clinton administration was "concerned about the prospect of violence".

"The rule of law should be observed. When there is a violation of law, it sends a signal beyond the borders of this country.

"We want Zimbabwe to become one of the leaders in Africa, but this is only going to happen when all people uphold the rule of law," he said.

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Dan Jackson
fields.trailText: Age: 27
fields.body:
Age: 27

Who's he? Co-founder & co-managing partner, thesonicbrandcompany. Formerly at Capital Radio teaching clients how to advertise on radio.

What's the clever idea? "We are the first company to actually focus on sonic branding, ie take someone's brand identity and translate it into sound, getting brand messages across through music, voice and sound effects. We analyse the business in the same way as a visual branding agency and then convey all of that in a 2.5 second piece of music, a sonic logo. It's for all media where you have a capacity to play sound, but what's driven us is the internet - websites and banners - and interactive TV."

And the reasoning is? "I noticed how important other radio sonic logos like Intel, Direct Line, Hamlet and Carphone Warehouse had become. We wanted to put some expertise into that, put into it all the thought and thinking process that a real branding editor would do, rather than just pick a track from, say, the creative director's CD collection. Sound is everywhere now - everywhere is digital. Wherever you have a sound chip or electronic media, you can brand. What lifts the visual information on a website is a bit of music or some funny sounds on the buttons - 'earcons' ".

How does it work? "We break sound down into layers, look at the brand, assign kind of brand layers, building the music with the brand. Music and sound are a universal language, working overtime, like any logo."

Shortcomings? "Possibly load-time. It's like having another picture, so if you've got a slow connection, it might take some time. Also, music works best through flash and not everyone has the flash download, the speed of connection to run flash. The wrong sounds, used too repetitively, could annoy people off, so it's about not over-using it."

And strengths? "It adds entertainment, a branding element which isn't always there. It's very replicable across all media - ties your internet product with your TV ads, radio ads, in-store music and television hold systems. Dwell time is greater on the bits where there's sound.I think it will give the web a longer lease of life versus interactive TV. It enriches the content of the internet, which means people are more likely to go there, adding entertainment and branding where there hasn't been up till now. The real change will come in website design agencies. If anyone needs to adapt great sonic design, it's them.

What's next? "An interactive web-only voice casting agency - speechfonts. What we've done is match up the Microsoft fonts to different voices. Go online, click on the font that most closely matches your visual communication and we'll give a matching voice to go with it, like Voice-Over Man."

fields.headline: Counselling for a new career
fields.standfirst: Stuck in a rut, unsure of your aptitude?  Dolly Dhingra  investigates why some secretaries are paying 'work therapists' £300 to tell them where their future lies
fields.trailText: Stuck in a rut, unsure of your aptitude? Dolly Dhingra investigates why some secretaries are paying 'work therapists' £300 to tell them where their future lies.
fields.body:
Warning: work can be addictive, and even if you don't like your job, you could still be hooked. It's understandable if you are appreciated, well paid and get a real buzz from seeing projects delivered on time and below budget. But frustrating, unfulfilling jobs can be just as difficult to leave. Once you have been in a role for a while, familiarity is every bit as seductive as the chance of winning a pay rise.

It's all too easily done - what was intended to be a transient post gradually becomes familiar, work colleagues develop into friends, and before long framed photographs adorn the desk and you are following office gossip more closely than TV soaps. You may still pine for the dream job you promised you'd be doing by 30, but perhaps you now fear it may be too late.

The most difficult thing for workers frustrated by their role is knowing where to turn for advice. You can hardly ask your boss for an honest opinion. Step forward the career psychologist. These are "work therapists" who claim to be able to assess your skills and attitudes, feed back on your hidden aptitudes, and recommend the next step towards that elusive fulfilling career. And increasing numbers of dissatisfied secretaries are paying up to £300 a day for the benefit of their insights.

"We get a lot of people coming to us saying, 'I have had so many tests done on me telling me I'm this or I should be doing that, but I still don't feel any wiser,'" says Liz Reddish, client co-ordinator at the Tavistock clinic in London. "We prefer to talk things through with clients trying to establish what it is that has brought them to this particular juncture. People tend to come to us when they have reached a crisis point in their relationship with work."

"About 20%-30% of our clients are people working in administrative-type roles," says Sophie Rowan of career management specialists Career Psychology. "People who took a job on for six months in the hope that it would lead to something else, and three years later they are still doing it. Often, they haven't had any training, have made little or no progress and have gone without a salary review. The biggest complaint is that they feel under-challenged and unfulfilled."

The company carries out assessment tests to measure a client's aptitude, personality and interests. "It's like doing a jigsaw and finding the best compatibility of the various components of an individual," says Rowan.

Psychometric testing was developed in the US a century ago to measure how well-suited soldiers were to the pressures of war. Career management specialists offer a complete day of tests filling in forms and answering questions. Information is collated and processed to provide the client with a written assessment of their aptitudes and skills. The plan is that you can present it to future employers as a measure of your abilities.

Do not be surprised if they don't believe all they read, however. Judy James, senior associate adviser for the Industrial Society, is sceptical about career assessment tests. "Often people need a bit of a booster and want someone to thrust them in the right direction. But it really is a bit like getting your colours done before going out to buy a whole new wardrobe. If companies want to do that kind of thing they'll prefer to carry out the tests for themselves. Handing over your own test results at application is a bit like selling your house and presenting the buyer with a survey that you've done yourself. "

James is more interested in the suggestion that some workers will apply for secretarial positions as "safe options", and fail to push their career in line with their ambitions. "Secretarial work can be very seductive. If you are intending to go into a certain line of work and then stop to do a particular job - it's like wanting to climb a mountain to get to the top, stopping midway to admire the view, and then staying there. That's fine if you are happy, but there is the possibility that you might become miserable. Obviously there is a certain amount of regret in all of our lives but you want to try and limit it as much as possible."

"A lot of secretaries are not at all suited to their job," says Sheridan Hughes, a management consultant. "Some middle-aged women became secretaries because that is what women did - become secretaries, nurses or teachers. Many return to the workplace after having a family and continue as secretaries. Younger women who come to us have slipped into secretarial jobs because they learnt typing prior to their degrees so that they could temp during the holidays or after graduating when taking a year out before making their "real" career choices. You rarely find the boys doing the same."

The important thing to remember, she says, is that it's never too late to set yourself a fresh challenge. The recruitment market is booming at the moment, so candidates with good skills should have little difficulty finding a position that is more fulfilling and to which they are better suited. "There's a lot to be said for not having anything to lose," says James. "Often it makes you far more ambitious and adventurous." She even argues that sometimes being better qualified can hold you back. "If I had good secretarial skills I would have hit a glass ceiling ages ago! I certainly wouldn't have taken risks."

All agree that settling on the career that is right for you can take time. "People who are thinking of changing jobs are quite often very negative about their experiences and abilities largely because they have been unhappy for a long time," says Rowan. "Time needs to be spent identifying positive experiences and skills."

Her advice is to look into all possibilities at your current workplace before jumping ship. "Being a PA or a secretary can be a very logical stepping stone into other areas of a company such as accounts, PR or marketing. Often support staff have built up quite a strong knowledge of the firm because they have been involved in various facets of the company and are aware of the organisational structure."

Those who want to think more daringly in terms of changing career should remember that recruitment agencies can be useful sources of guidance and information."Even if you are not on our books, our consultants are happy to talk through any career problems," says Rachel Johnson, regional manager of Manpower. "If a secretary decides she wants to become a lorry driver, we could train her. Remember that work should be the creative part of a person's life - and so often it isn't."

Judy James, senior associate adviser for the Industrial Society, is sceptical about career assessment tests. "Often people need a bit of a booster and want someone to thrust them in the right direction. But it really is a bit like getting your colours done before going out to buy a whole new wardrobe. If companies want to do that kind of thing they'll prefer to carry out the tests for themselves. Handing over your own test results at application is a bit like selling your house and presenting the buyer with a survey that you've done yourself. " James is more interested in the suggestion that some workers will apply for secretarial positions as "safe options", and fail to push their career in line with their ambitions. "Secretarial work can be very seductive. If you are intending to go into a certain line of work and then stop to do a particular job - it's like wanting to climb a mountain to get to the top, stopping midway to admire the view, and then staying there. That's fine if you are happy, but there is the possibility that you might become miserable. Obviously there is a certain amount of regret in all of our lives but you want to try and limit it as much as possible." "A lot of secretaries are not at all suited to their job," says Sheridan Hughes, a management consultant. "Some middle-aged women became secretaries because that is what women did - become secretaries, nurses or teachers. Many return to the workplace after having a family and continue as secretaries. Younger women who come to us have slipped into secretarial jobs because they learnt typing prior to their degrees so that they could temp during the holidays or after graduating when taking a year out before making their "real" career choices. You rarely find the boys doing the same." The important thing to remember, she says, is that it's never too late to set yourself a fresh challenge. The recruitment market is booming at the moment, so candidates with good skills should have little difficulty finding a position that is more fulfilling and to which they are better suited. "There's a lot to be said for not having anything to lose," says James. "Often it makes you far more ambitious and adventurous." She even argues that sometimes being better qualified can hold you back. "If I had good secretarial skills I would have hit a glass ceiling ages ago! I certainly wouldn't have taken risks." All agree that settling on the career that is right for you can take time. "People who are thinking of changing jobs are quite often very negative about their experiences and abilities largely because they have been unhappy for a long time," says Rowan. "Time needs to be spent identifying positive experiences and skills." Her advice is to look into all possibilities at your current workplace before jumping ship. "Being a PA or a secretary can be a very logical stepping stone into other areas of a company such as accounts, PR or marketing. Often support staff have built up quite a strong knowledge of the firm because they have been involved in various facets of the company and are aware of the organisational structure." Those who want to think more daringly in terms of changing career should remember that recruitment agencies can be useful sources of guidance and information."Even if you are not on our books, our consultants are happy to talk through any career problems," says Rachel Johnson, regional manager of Manpower. "If a secretary decides she wants to become a lorry driver, we could train her. Remember that work should be the creative part of a person's life - and so often it isn't."

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: • Jim Ledbetter and Kenneth Li
fields.body:
 Jim Ledbetter and Kenneth Li

www.theStandard.com

In the wake of January's proposed AOL - Time Warner merger, multi-billion-dollar media marriages have become dog-bites-man stuff. A piddling $8bn deal like the acquisition of Times Mirror by Tribune Co. may not even be enough to wrap fish.

Yet this one captured attention - certainly on Wall Street, where Times Mirror's stock nearly doubled in two days of trading following the announcement. Even Tribune's shares enjoyed a second-day bounce.

The reason for Tribune's good fortune? The net, apparently. Though both companies are known for flagship newspaper properties - the Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Tribune - they also own numerous web properties that together would create one of the largest net publishers.

"It's huge," boasts Jeff Scherb, head of Tribune Interactive, who says the combined company's unique visitors across several newspaper sites will nearly double, from 1.9m to 3.4m. That would put its web traffic on par with USAToday.com and CNN.com. Some analysts agree; three investment banks have upgraded Tribune to "strong buy".

The merger, which the companies hope to complete by the third quarter, may accelerate plans to spin off their web properties into a single unit, a strategy similar to that of the New York Times Co. "We've been watching the Times Company Digital progress very closely," acknowledges Scherb.

 Michael Stroud

www.wired.com

Coming May 5 to a computer near you: a serious stab by mainstream Hollywood at producing a film specifically for the internet.

And, unlike the wobbly, streaming shorts that pass for film these days on the net, Quantum Project will be designed to download and view on a monitor or a TV screen, theoretically giving viewers the same quality experience as a DVD. Bankrolled by Sightsound.com, the $3m, 40-minute drama about a young physicist's journey into alternative realities stars John Cleese, Fay Masterson, and Stephen Dorff and is directed by Oscar-winning director Eugenio Zanetti.

"This so far exceeds what anyone else has thought of doing before that we really see ourselves in the same way as the gutsy people who developed and made The Jazz Singer," said Quantum Project co-executive producer Stephen Simon.

Viewers will pay to download the movie, which will take up to half an hour with a broadband connection. The number of people keen to download movies to their TV set will skyrocket over the next two to three years as broadband takes off, predicted Cyber Dialogue analyst Peter Clemente. "We need a launch pad for downloading film on the net and this film could be it," Clemente said.

fields.standfirst: Imogen O'Rorke  on the scramble to get an invite to Wap Wednesday
fields.trailText: It was over-subscribed even before the date had been posted on First Tuesday's website. Like its predecessor, Wap Wednesday, the hot new venue for electronic entrepreneurial schmoozing on the third Wednesday of the month, is only open to people with personal invitations and the venue is kept secret until the last minute.
fields.body:
It was over-subscribed even before the date had been posted on First Tuesday's website. Like its predecessor, Wap Wednesday, the hot new venue for electronic entrepreneurial schmoozing on the third Wednesday of the month, is only open to people with personal invitations and the venue is kept secret until the last minute.

Even so, last Wednesday, the content providers came in their biblical droves, to feed on the green field of opportunity that is opened up by internet-enabled telephony. It was the usual 400-odd people with green stickers (the entrepreneurs) chasing the 40 with red stickers (the investors, most likely investment consultants and voyeurs) around Kensington town hall.

Wap madness is already in its second wave. First came the rush for the technology, then came the pioneers: brands such as Excite, Genie, BBC, ITN and the Guardian with their experimental applications. Now the stampede. And they come in all shapes and sizes: The Wide - media corporations which see wireless as a content market not as the internet on a mobile phone; The Vertical - specialist companies who know their niche; and the Brave - small production companies, new media outfits and mavericks, all convinced that they have the business model that is going to make them rich.

Amongst the networkers there are classical music lovers looking for ways to bring harmonies to the mobile earpiece, car salesmen who believe they can flog Rovers over the phone, teenagers with crazy ideas for computer games and het-up 23 year olds with record bags and kooky-sounding company names like Ker-pow! who say very loudly that they are under a "strictly no comment policy".

They are trampling on the same boards that only months ago were trod by the wannabe net millionaires - but already the fixed-line internet is fading into the far distance.

Content for wireless can mean anything from selling CDs to betting, games, weather, pornography or mobile literature at the press of a button - anything that fills up the precious airwaves of the telecom companies for five minutes while you are waiting for a bus.

The Wap concept itself is elusively simple. It is the jargon that surrounds it that often causes confusion and the fact that the technology is obsolete before it has even been rolled out.

According to all the investment reports, content providers are well-placed to reap healthy revenues from the market and so everyone is doing the portal thing; from the operators (Vodafone, Orange, Cellnet, Virgin and One-to-One), right the way down the chain to internet search engines, handset manufacturers, publishers, broadcasters, even, it is rumoured, the mobile retailers themselves.

The question for providers, especially small companies, is where do they fit into the content tree? The operators are still trying to work out whether they are pipes (gateway providers), portals or both. This is where companies such as Nokia and Ericsson, who have relationships with all the operators, are well-placed to come in with content. Ericsson's head of corporate ventures, Justin Chamberlain, says: "We have to make sure there is compelling content so people will buy the phones."

Wap Wednesday opened with a speech from David Birch, wireless consultant at Hyperion. After the hype, a hymn to the wonderful wireless future when fridges talk to us and the browser interface fades away, came the warning: "I sit through pitches every day and most content-based pitches are delusional," he says. Wap browsers are not capable of downloading most websites - ergo, the phone crashes.

On the other hand another panellist, Cindy Daum from Phone.com - "the grandmammy of wireless internet companies" - warns providers: "Don't wait for packet data or you will lose your edge in the market." She believes that providers who stick to the "three clicks rule" - allowing customers, who apparently have the attention spans of goldfish, to reach their end destination within three clicks - will be OK.

As with the internet, there will be winners and losers. No media company worth its 15 minutes' airtime can countenance the thought of losing out. Evan Rudovsky, vice president of Excite Europe, the first wireless portal-cum-search engine to go live, admits they got the product out early before it was "fully figured out" because they wanted to "grab that beachfront property - we have to move faster than the others who want to eat our lunch".

The press release for their new much-hyped personalised service ("no other UK WAP service offers such a seamless interface between Wap and the web") already reads like a Teasmade manual from the 60s. What is more, personalisation will be a given when voice recognition comes downstream in a couple of years, but at least Excite is out there. "Many publishers are paying the price of not getting in early enough with the internet, and have been playing catch-up with internet brands ever since," says Niki Panourgias, editor of the investment news channel, Net Imperative.

Net Imperative is a perfect model of how small content providers can work. It was founded only six months ago with a staff of 24, and went live only a month ago, providing specialist news to the new media industry. "Our strength is being targeted in a small but intense market," says Panourgias.

What hopes are there for other start-ups? "As far as I understand, the market is moving towards business plans that have cross-platform delivery [interactive TV]," he says. "But basically companies who are not already working on something have missed the boat."

Publishers on the whole wear a cloak of complacency. Danny Meadows Klue , director of Hollinger New Media and publisher of the electronic Telegraph, is chary of the "mad content rush". They will not be entering the fray until the technology catches up. "Luckily publishers are mature and wise enough to have been here before. Wap itself is new but the marketing phenomenon isn't. There are some sound business models with great potential, but they are not long-term strategically sound. They will not survive. The market will be harder and harder to penetrate."

While he will not be drawn on the Telegraph's partnership plans, he confirms that it is definitely a "hot issue" for them. So hot in fact that Meadows Klue is joining the likes of Martin Dunn, Associated's former head of new media, and leaving his job to get involved in start-up wireless-wideband projects.

In the meantime, IPC Electric has not been idle. This month it quietly launched Beme.com along with UNmissable TV. The former combines news, horoscopes and entertainment, re-purposed from the portal, the latter, big and small screen listings, previews and bookings.

ITN believes it is better placed than all the publishers to exploit the future of the broadband market through the various Symbian devices such as smart phones and palm pilots, but they are not going to wait for the 3G technology. Avant go.com, which launched last week, is ITN's weapon for stealing the march. It broadcasts 24-hour news and will be transmitted via Orange's videophone technology some time this year. "We are waiting for the real revolution with video on demand," says Garron Baines, ITN's new media MD. "Then you can watch your favourite football clips and news on the train going home."

Back at Wap Wednesday, the search is on for the killer application. A company called CityKey, which provides maps, can navigate around towns to within 60m and provides information and booking facilities for entertainment and nightlife, appears to fit all the criteria: it is personal, portable and secure, it is global and localised at the same time. But CityKey could be completely blown out of the water by existing brands such as Time Out, which people might trust more than a bunch of bedroom computer geeks from Stockholm.

Ultimately no one knows what is going to catch on, we can only make informed speculation. Which is why we are here. And why you should be at the next one, wherever it is.

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst: No 12: The stapler
fields.trailText: No 12: The stapler
fields.body:
Physics teachers must love staplers. All those angles and forces and pivots, and little bits of wire with just the right tensile ductile malleability, or whatever it is physicists talk about these days. The rest of us admire their ability to hold pieces of paper together, as long as you don't try to attach more than about 10 sheets at a time and take care with wayward digits while attempting to reload them.

Staplers have been with us a long time, since 1841 in fact, when Samuel Slocum patented his spring-loaded innovation. And they have probably changed less in 150 years than almost any other office invention, mainly because there isn't much that can be done to improve them.

Apply force x here, depress the tip through y degrees, and the little metal thing punctures paper with speed z, and considerately bends to stop it popping out again. Even the advent of plastic did little to unseat the stapler - synthetic staples would never have bent properly. No one has managed to improve on the design of the wheel, after all. If it ain't broke, and all that.

Stapler purists might argue, indeed, that in the perfection of its form the staple is rather like the belly button. When finishing off rough edges, the unsealed ends of both humans and staples can be pointed in or out. And as with the humble navel, when it comes to staplers most of us are innies. Once you get to know someone a little better, however - perhaps a prospective partner - you may discover they are in fact an outie. These courageous individuals scoff at the risk of snagging sweaters on an outwardly pointing staple tip while delivering stacks of documents to their boss's desk. And they probably go away chuckling at the risk of injury to a careless reader.

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst: Taxable childcare
fields.trailText: Taxable childcare
fields.body:
Buried away in last week's Budget was a contentious little nugget that affects the provision of childcare by employers. Some - but only some - childcare will be exempt from taxation as an employee benefit.

Benefit packages are an increasingly popular way to attract staff in a competitive job market, although the Treasury has always looked on such schemes with suspicion. They began to take off in the 1970s, when pay rises were limited by law in an attempt to control inflation. To get round this, many firms began to be extremely generous with their allocation of company cars, handing them out in lieu of pay rises. Alert bureaucrats noticed that many organisations whose employees went nowhere in particular were acquiring fleet managers. And it was decided that if a car was a form of pay rise it should be taxed accordingly.

Last year, with flexible benefits becoming fashionable again for quite different reasons, it was decided that all such packages should be treated in the same way as company cars. This caused dismay among those keen to encourage employers to be more proactive in the provision of childcare.

This is a significant expense that falls principally on working mothers, to the extent that after they've paid the child-minder many might as well not be working at all. After much lobbying, the treasury has relented a little, and last week it was announced that workplace crèches will not be viewed as a benefit "in kind". But other forms of childcare benefits, such as vouchers, will be taxable from this April.

Childcare is an emotive subject. Raise it with any working mother, and it is unlikely that she will appreciate having her responsibilities treated in the same way as a sabbatical in Phuket.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText:
Salaries survey
London is still the best place to work if you are a PA or secretary. The City, traditionally known for the most lucrative salaries, has been overtaken by London's West End where top PAs can command around £24,000. This is up 25% on last year, according to Adecco's latest salary survey. Nationally, salaries for PAs and secretaries in the past year increased by 6.5% to an average £16,000. But there is bad news for workers in Scotland, whose wages dropped slightly. The poorest paid, though, are secretaries in the south west, where the median salary is £10,722.
fields.body:
Salaries survey
London is still the best place to work if you are a PA or secretary. The City, traditionally known for the most lucrative salaries, has been overtaken by London's West End where top PAs can command around £24,000. This is up 25% on last year, according to Adecco's latest salary survey. Nationally, salaries for PAs and secretaries in the past year increased by 6.5% to an average £16,000. But there is bad news for workers in Scotland, whose wages dropped slightly. The poorest paid, though, are secretaries in the south west, where the median salary is £10,722.

Airport site
Departures and arrivals at London City Airport can now be checked out on its website, londoncityairport.com. Real-time information is downloaded from the terminal flight information display system, and refreshed every three minutes. The site will also include on-line car hire, hotel bookings, currency purchasing and the latest business and financial headlines.

Conference sparkle
PAs charged with booking venues for corporate events can develop raging headaches trying to find somewhere offering something a little more interesting than a 10m pool. So they may find the cliff-top Raven Hall Hotel near Scarborough something of a find. Golfers play a round with replica hickory-shafted clubs while dressed 1900s-style in tweedy plus fours. And the more adventurous delegates can take a three-hour llama trek through the surrounding countryside. For information, telephone 01723 870353.

Easy fliers
Low-cost airlines such as easyJet have made a significant dent in the dominance of larger carriers when it comes to business travel, according to a survey by Company Barclaycard. Although more of the UK's business travellers fly with British Airways than with any other airline, easyJet and Ryanair appear in the list of top 10 frequently used airlines for the first time. Of those replying to the survey, 40% have used a low cost airline, 91% of whom say they would do so again.

Stop that stress
Irritability, lack of concentration and frequent coughs and colds are all signs of workplace stress, according to the Institute of Personnel and Development.
