fields.headline: The diary of a professor
fields.standfirst: As PA to the medical director of an NHS trust, Christine Short knows all about arranging functions on a limited budget. Tom Twentyman  reports
fields.trailText: As PA to the medical director of an NHS trust, Christine Short knows all about arranging functions on a limited budget. Tom Twentyman reports
fields.body:
"For me, the main element of a strong working relationship is trust," says Christine Short, PA to Professor Rory Shaw, medical director of the Hammersmith hospitals NHS trust. The group, based in west London, was set up in 1994 and is now an internationally renowned medical research centre and teaching facility, with four locations in the capital.

Short, 35, has been PA to the leading chest physician for a year. "Professor Shaw is based both here at the Hammersmith and at Charing Cross, and most of the time I'm effectively left alone to run his office. There's his guidance available, of course, if needed, but he knows that I can produce good work, and he lets me get on with it." She appreciates the fact that she has this freedom: "It's what I need to do my role."

Short has sole charge of the professor's diary. "He has a very busy schedule, with the usual round of meetings, plus a programme of on-site events and functions - anything from an afternoon tour for senior figures in the NHS to a conference." The processes involved in organising one apply to them all, she believes. "They're part of the same genre, and it's my responsibility to make sure that things happen."

The Hammersmith building has a number of small venues which host lunches throughout the year. They bring together new consultants with clinical directors and other managerial staff, giving people from different departments and specialities the chance to network. Short mails out the invitations. "My aim is to give them a choice of days, as this helps to create a really effective mix."

Imperial College school of medicine also has a conference centre within the hospital, where full-day events will see her staffing the reception area, handing out welcome packs and badges to the arriving delegates. She returns to her office to catch up with "my bread-and-butter work, typing and filing", coming back at regular intervals such as tea breaks. "That's one benefit of dealing with this kind of thing in-house, and I prefer to be around, just in case of any problems." She prepares evaluation forms for attendees to grade and comment on the standards achieved - the findings are later analysed to see if any improvements can be made.

Short is now working on this summer's induction day for consultants, which will be followed by an afternoon presentation and evening reception for about 200 guests. She has to choose the menu, organise audiovisual facilities with the conference centre staff and book speakers. "We should be ready to roll by June 1 when there'll still be a fortnight to go."

Short started organising this event more than a month ago. "I'm a great believer in forward planning, and doing as much groundwork as possible. This helps me to foresee problems, and deal with them. Even a little gap in the day can be useful." She confesses to being a confirmed list-maker, committing everything to "invaluable" exercise books.

Quiet moments are a rarity. "The clock will show around 4pm and I'll wonder where the time has gone. I'll be going home, still thinking over what I have to do. My brain doesn't leave it all behind me until I close my front door."

Apart from an early job with a security company, Short's career has been spent exclusively in the public sector. Not a conscious decision, she says, more "just the way life panned out. However, you do feel that you're helping to make someone's circumstances better in some way."

The major difference between the sectors when arranging hospitality, she feels, is money. "The private sector also has to work to a budget, but we in the public sector can't be seen to be extravagant - expensive hotels, foreign trips. So we must squeeze the maximum use out of our resources, and I think we offer terrific value."

Short concedes she would never say "never" to the lure of exploring what is on the other side of the fence. "I might give it a go some day," she admits. "But I'm happy enough where I am at the moment. And who could ask for more than that?"

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: Few people dread anything as much as a job interview. For most of us the hour of nerve-wracking tension is mercifully rare; but for Angela Visagie, recruitment officer for property consultants Jones Lang LaSalle, it's a regular occurrence.
fields.body:
Few people dread anything as much as a job interview. For most of us the hour of nerve-wracking tension is mercifully rare; but for Angela Visagie, recruitment officer for property consultants Jones Lang LaSalle, it's a regular occurrence. "I conduct the first interviews for support staff," she says. "We liaise with the department to get an accurate job description and forward that to the agency. I then choose candidates from the CVs they send over."

Visagie believes that interviewing is a skill that has to be learnt. "Obviously you do gain a first impression of every candidate, but it's important not to let that affect you too much. The most important thing is to get a picture of each person's competency to do the particular job - and that includes the skills they have, their past experience and personality."

Getting the candidate to relax and feel at ease is one of the most important aspects of interviewing. "There is a fine balance between conducting the interview on a personal level, so that the interviewee feels that you are really interested in them as an individual, and keeping it professional. Its not only the candidate who's under scrutiny; demand for good support staff currently outstrips supply, so you need to give the most positive image of your company to encourage them to want to work for it."

Interviews at Jones Lang LaSalle are a mix of personal interview and tests, and Visagie believes it is important to make clear the form the interview will take. "A lot of people are nervous in an interview because they worry that something unexpected will be asked of them. I always start the interview with a fairly relaxed conversation explaining the whole procedure - what tests there will be and how long it will all take."

Visagie also tries to gain more insight into each candidate by asking about their lives outside work. "It's always worth asking about hobbies or interests as people often relax more when talking about non-work topics," she says. "Success in this job depends on matching the right candidate to the right department and to do so you need a good idea of their personality as well as their abilities."

"A lot of it is about doing the proper research. It's imperative to talk to the internal client, assess what sort of department the candidate would be going into - whether it's a young crowd, informal or very straight, whether they need telephone skills or ultra-fast typing. Skills aren't just typing speeds and knowledge of WP packages - but also things such as how to interact confidently and how to use judgement."

Although Visagie believes she comes out of most interviews with a gut feeling either way, she says it is important to take thorough notes and take time to reflect on each candidate. "If you've conducted an interview properly you should come away with an impression of whether or not the candidate is right for the job," she says, "but it's still hugely important to take notes. If you reject a candidate and two weeks later they write in wanting to know why, it's extremely embarrassing if you can't remember what it was they didn't have."

fields.headline: Chechens give Moscow a reminder
fields.standfirst:
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Voting in Chechnya was disrupted yesterday by reports that rebels had recaptured a Russian-held town in the east of the breakaway state.
fields.body:
Voting in Chechnya was disrupted yesterday by reports that rebels had recaptured a Russian-held town in the east of the breakaway state.

The news of the military setback on the morning of the presidential election threatened to embarrass the favourite, Vladimir Putin, whose popularity is founded on his ruthless and largely successful campaign to crush the Chechen rebels - and the claims were swiftly denied by Kremlin officials.

Despite beefed-up security across the region, early reports suggested that Russia's army had been surprised by a group of 2,000 rebels who seized the centre of Nozhai-Yurt, 35 miles from the Chechen capital, Grozny, which has been under Russian control since January.

"An operation to encircle the rebels is underway," the regional military headquarters told a Russian news agency yesterday morning, adding that a large division of Russian soldiers had been dispatched to the area.

Later, however, the defence ministry in Moscow and the Kremlin's spokesman for Chechnya denied the report as rebel propaganda. The government spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhemsky, insisted that Nozhai-Yurt remained in Russian hands.

A rebel victory in Nozhai-Yurt would have represented a badly-timed humiliation for the Russian military, which claims to have established a firm hold in the region apart from a few small villages in the southern mountains.

As he cast his vote yesterday, Mr Putin, who is acting president, said there was no firm information about the situation in Nozhai-Yurt, but insisted that the campaign in general was "going to plan".

Senior Kremlin officials had expected to have the Chechen campaign wrapped up before the presidential vote, but the relatively fast conquest of the northern plains has stalled in the foothills of the mountains.

Military officials have made a great show of preparing for the election to show life returning to normal in the Russian-occupied areas of Chechnya. Nightly news bulletins have shown polling stations being set up in villages recently seized from the rebels.

A group of foreign journalists was taken into Chechnya yesterday to witness civilians turning out to vote amid the shattered remains of Grozny.

The city streets were lined with armed police as residents, soldiers and relief workers cast their votes. Unsurprisingly, support among local people for Mr Putin was muted and many were planning not to vote.

"I am not voting for anyone. There is not one honest candidate. The war was too cruel," said Lydia, a pensioner.

Khavra, another resident, agreed: "I am not going to vote because it's all the same to us. There was the first war, now the second war. Nothing will change. The same people will get in. They're all bandits."

fields.headline: How Russia was lost
fields.standfirst:
The west was looking the wrong way as Moscow's next authoritarian figure was rising quietly

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Ikea has arrived in Moscow. So has a tight-lipped 47-year-old KGB staffer, with clear blue eyes and authoritarian tendencies strong enough to bomb one of Russia's republics back into the middle ages.
fields.body:
Ikea has arrived in Moscow. So has a tight-lipped 47-year-old KGB staffer, with clear blue eyes and authoritarian tendencies strong enough to bomb one of Russia's republics back into the middle ages.

The juxtaposition is not frivolous. For the past eight years, the great and the good arriving by the planeload from the IMF, World Bank, LSE, and Harvard, spent more time counting the bottles of cabernet sauvignon on the shelves of Moscow's shops as an indicator of progress, than they did thinking about what life was actually like at the end of a dirt track barely 40 miles away.

After nearly a decade of failed reform, the average life expectancy of a male in Russia is higher than in Nigeria but lower than in the Philippines, and this for a country which is sitting on 13% of the world's oil and 36% of its natural gas reserves. In the pursuit of the theology of market reform, the realities of Russian life - the halving of the GNP, the destruction of its industrial base, the loss of ordinary people's savings, the mass grab of property stolen under the name of privatisation, the demonetarisation of the economy - were all wished away.

In their place came theories. First it was the "trickle-down" theory, then came the "necessary pain" theory. After that came the "good times are just around the corner" theory. And then came the crash. Now a man like Vladimir Putin has arrived to remind the IMF just how far the dark continent has slipped back into the Tsarist 19th century. The west in general and the champions of human rights in particular have little cause to complain about the crackdown Putin is planning.

For eight years, they were looking in the wrong direction for the emergence of homo sovieticus, the strong man who would restamp Moscow's authority on its wayward regions and ethnic republics. In the civil emergency of October 1993 and the last presidential election in 1996, the enemy were the communists. If they won, "reform" - whatever that meant - would have lost. It was reds versus the whites. The conscious and cynical attempt to revive the Russian peasant's innate fears of another civil war worked.

The leading figures of the Russian human rights movement, personally honest and physically courageous people, were duped. In October 1993, Yelena Bonner, Sakharov's widow, mounted a truck outside the Kremlin to justify the stand her friend Boris Yeltsin was making, which led to tanks opening fire on a parliament that had got a little too independent for the Kremlin's liking. Two months later, Russia had a constitution which emasculated parliament, (it became and felt like a private health clinic, whose sole concern was the wellbeing of its member) and inflated the presidency to proportions which exceeded those of the hated central committee of the CPSU.

These are the powers Putin inherits. Today Bonner calls him Stalin. Andrei Babitsky, the Radio Liberty reporter who came within a whisker of losing his life at the hands of fellow Russians in Chechnya, was decorated for his pro-Yeltsin work in the heady days of democracy.

The "stalinist" Putin did not emerge from the docile ranks of Gennady Zyuganov's Russian communist party. The brigades of woolly-hatted demonstrators waving Red Flags and portraits of Stalin, were led by lambs, not tigers, who repeatedly backed away from moves to impeach Yeltsin. Those who despaired, turned the violence they felt against themselves, not the state. The suicide rate shot up.

Meanwhile, Russia's next authoritarian ruler was quietly being born in the ranks of the camp of the "reform ers". Putin's first boss was Anatoly Sobchak, the mayor of St Petersburg who at one point fled abroad amid claims of corruption. Putin's next master was Pavel Borodin, the quartermaster of the Kremlin, now eagerly wanted for questioning by Swiss prosecutors investigating a multimillion-dollar money-laundering scam. It was Yeltsin's close family circle who drew the president's attention to the existence of the quietly efficient ex-KGB man from St Petersburg.

Today the great and the good are blaming each other for having "lost Russia". Some say the theories were right, it was just that the money was not there to back it. Others say the policy should have been to support principles rather than people, institutions rather than events. Such as an independent parliament?

But lost Russia they have. When Yeltsin was first elected president of Russia, and then when the Soviet Union imploded, the streets of Moscow were filled with pro-western euphoria. Russia threw open not just its front windows, but its doors, backyard and granary to the west. Today the west is seen, even by intellectuals , as venal, self-serving and hypocritical.

Re-engaging Russia would take need a major u-turn in western policy. It would involve a conscious attempt to buy Russian technology, rather than treat it as a third world source of raw materials. Nato would have to stop expanding, and the problems of Russian-speaking minorities in Ukraine and Latvia addressed. Russia would have to be treated as a serious player on the international stage. None of this is likely.

webTitle: Putin pledges to make Russia strong again

fields.headline: Putin pledges to make Russia strong again
fields.standfirst:
Yeltsin's successor has vowed to restore the Kremlin's authority, but a formidable array of problems lie in his path

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin woke up this morning as one of the most powerful men in the world, pledging to rebuild Russian clout at home and abroad and to establish a strong state as the ultimate arbiter and guarantor of economic and civil liberties.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin woke up this morning as one of the most powerful men in the world, pledging to rebuild Russian clout at home and abroad and to establish a strong state as the ultimate arbiter and guarantor of economic and civil liberties.

But his landslide victory entrenching him in the Kremlin as Russia's second directly elected president throws up more questions than answers following a campaign that failed to provide even the most rudimentary of policy clues.

And he may yet have to return to the polls in two weeks for a run-off. He took around half of the votes cast, but it was unclear whether he had amassed the 50% plus one needed for outright victory.

Mr Putin, 47, has conquered the nation's hearts by being all things to all Russians through sophisticated political marketing that has been deliberately devoid of substance. He projects tough-minded resolve, but is also extremely calculating and cautious.

Mr Mau forecasts that the first two years of the new regime will avoid radical structural reforms on the economy and that President Putin will focus on consolidating his power.

"It will be a period of low investment and vulnerability for the Russian economy."

He has floated the suggestion that the presidential term should be extended from four to seven years and that the powerful governors of Russia's regions should be presidential appointments rather than being elected by the people.

But any anti-corruption drive will lack public credibility unless at the same time he tackles the "oligarchs", the tycoons who have made fortunes through asset stripping.

These oligarchs, embodied by the oil and media magnate Boris Berezovsky, also wield enormous political clout and Mr Putin owes his rise through the ranks to them. Will he now bite the hand that fed him? Has he the authority and the courage to tackle them?

"Putin really understands the problems facing Russia. Mr Berezovsky snorts that "there is not a single new idea" in the plans being drawn up by Mr Mau and others.

Moscow is buzzing with rumours that Mr Putin may move swiftly to streamline government. Unlike Mr Yeltsin, he has the vigour for such a purge and can rely on a much more compliant parliament to support him.

fields.headline: Kilfoyle reopens north-south row
fields.standfirst:
Ex-Labour defence minister attacks Budget's impact

North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Kilfoyle will reignite the debate about the north-south divide today in his resignation speech in the Commons, two months after quitting as defence minister, when he claims that Gordon Brown's Budget has not done enough to help the Labour heartlands.
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle will reignite the debate about the north-south divide today in his resignation speech in the Commons, two months after quitting as defence minister, when he claims that Gordon Brown's Budget has not done enough to help the Labour heartlands.

Doug Henderson, who was sacked from the Ministry of Defence a year ago, joined him yesterday and said the prime minister did Labour's cause no good by going north and claiming there was no north-south divide.

Mr Henderson, MP for Newcastle upon Tyne North, has been in close touch with Mr Kilfoyle since the Liverpool Walton MP resigned.

In a sign that middle ranking ministers are acutely aware of the scale of feeling over the regions, the industry minister Dick Caborn told a weekend meeting: "A lot of people do feel they are losing out and that in terms of influencing policy and decentralising powers the English regions have missed the boat ... that they are, in a nutshell, getting short-changed by London and the Whitehall machine and outplayed by the Scots and the Welsh."

He believes Britain is no longer a level economic playing field because the new devolved administrations in Scotland and Wales have stronger powers to intervene and help businesses, while enjoying a much higher level of public spending.

Mr Henderson called on the Treasury to offer differential regional tax breaks to the north-east and the west, especially on capital gains tax and venture capital. He also urged the government to move more civil servants to the north.

He added: "The north knows there is a north-south divide. The south knows there is a north-south divide. There is no sense the government insisting it does not exist.

"Of course, there are pockets of wealth in the north. There have always been pockets of wealth in the north. In 1932, there was 70% unemployment in Jarrow and people doing well two miles away over the river in Tynemouth.

He pointed out that only 0.5% of new starts in hi-tech ventures came from the north, even though 4% of the population lived in the region.

Jeremy Beecham, the leader of the Local Government Association and a former leader of Newcastle city council, also backed Mr Kilfoyle's call for more help for the north.

In a separate attack a third former minister, Frank Field, claimed the government's welfare reforms were leading to further social exclusion.

Appointed welfare minister immediately after the election, Mr Field was sacked in 1998 amid claims that his plans were too costly or too vague.

In a preface to a collection of essays, he claimed the Budget had extended the number of families subject to means testing.

He wrote: "Welfare changes, masquerading as reform, have undermined the principle of work, mocked the idea of saving, and weighted public policy against people who tell the truth. Far from all welfare reform measures adding to social inclusion, a growing number have become an ever more powerful agent of exclusion."

fields.headline: Star system to improve hospitals
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A consumer-friendly star system for hospitals, once tried and then abandoned by the Conservative government, is to be introduced by Labour, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A consumer-friendly star system for hospitals, once tried and then abandoned by the Conservative government, is to be introduced by Labour, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced yesterday.

The system, covering sensitive issues such as success at key clinical operations, will be supplemented with an agreement that hospitals which fail to meet agreed performance standards each quarter will lose earmarked extra funds.

Outlining further details of how ministers plan to ensure the £20bn NHS cash injection does not disappear down a black hole, Mr Brown also announced that he expected the audit commission to take a detailed role in inspecting standards.

The commission would work alongside the commission for health improvement which is due to start work next week.

He wanted the star system to cover about 20 performance criteria, including clinical outcomes, patient satisfaction, efficiency, cleanliness, waiting lists and hospital-induced infections.

fields.headline: Drink-driving cave-in to alcohol lobby
fields.trailText: The government has bowed to pressure from the alcohol and rural pub lobby and rejected overwhelming support for the introduction of a "one-pint limit" to combat drink-driving.
fields.body:
The government has bowed to pressure from the alcohol and rural pub lobby and rejected overwhelming support for the introduction of a "one-pint limit" to combat drink-driving.

It has decided to ignore the advice of police, magistrates and doctors, who support lowering the blood alcohol limit to 50mg, and is to keep it at 80mg.

Consultation by the Department of Transport produced a majority in favour of a lower limit: 206 respondents voted in favour of a 50mg limit, while 163 argued for retaining the existing one.

Opinion surveys show 75% of respondents in favour of a one-pint limit or one that is lower still. Just over 20% want the limit to stay as it is. The greatest support for the 80mg limit comes from men over 25.

But the department's report, a copy of which has been obtained by the Guardian, says: "The consultation response shows very clearly the concerns of two overlapping interests about a lower limit: those of the alcohol industries and those of rural communities generally. Both are concerned primarily about the viability of rural pubs if a lower limit is adopted and properly enforced.

"Pubs and hotels can be a locally significant source of employment, and those in rural areas are particularly dependent on access by cars."

But the report questions whether many pubs are "critically dependent" on customers who expect to drink between three and four units of alcohol and would be disinclined to visit a pub if they knew they could be over the limit by drinking that much.

Those backing a 50mg limit include the AA, the BMA, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents, the magistrates' association, the transport research laboratory and the honorary medical advisory panel on alcohol.

Organisations that oppose the reduction include the brewers, distillers and other drinks manufacturers, as well as the Federation of Small Businesses, the Road Haulage Association and the national association of local councils.

The government has used an EU inquiry into the harmonisation of the blood alcohol level as the reason for refusing to act. It had intended to do so this year, but no action is likely until well after the general election. This is because the EU investigation will take several years to complete.

EU officials are known to be reluctant to act because of widely differing views held across the union.

The transport research laboratory estimates that reducing the limit to 50mg would save 50 lives and prevent 250 serious and 1,200 slight injuries every year. But the transport department report regards this as a conservative estimate.

The report says strong evidence exists to show that lower limits have led to improvements in road safety. This has happened in a number of Australian states after a reduction to 50mg in tandem with other enforcement measures such as increased breath testing. France, Sweden, Canada and a number of US states have reduced their limits with similar results.

An official source said the government feared a political backlash if it reduced the limit. "To reduce the limit again would be like asking people not to eat beef off the bone - they would just continue to do it."

webTitle: On the long road to Britain

fields.headline: On the long road to Britain
fields.standfirst:
How the trade in human traffic into western Europe operates through a network of criminal gangs

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Another sundown at Patras port and still the Albanian smugglers have not returned, so the 150 Iraqi Kurds in Norman Square light a fire, slide cardboard beneath their sleeping bags and watch the lorries disappearing into ferries, wondering when it will be their turn.
fields.body:
Another sundown at Patras port and still the Albanian smugglers have not returned, so the 150 Iraqi Kurds in Norman Square light a fire, slide cardboard beneath their sleeping bags and watch the lorries disappearing into ferries, wondering when it will be their turn.

Six nights of waiting at this Greek port is draining their money but the usual route to Italy has just been closed and the smugglers need time to open a new one.

Azad Abdullah Ali, 23, is patient. Britain will still be there no matter how long it takes, he smiles. He possesses a tracksuit, Western Union money orders from a friend in London and a belief that Britain will shelter him.

Five years ago Saddam Hussein's police arrested his father and brother in their photocopying shop in Kirkuk, northern Iraq, on suspicion of printing rebel Kurdish pamphlets. Two years ago they were hanged.

Death threat

Two months ago Azad tried to reopen the shop and was told he was next. It was time to leave. Kissing his mother and two younger sisters farewell, he joined the refugee trail to northern Europe.

Azad started his journey by contacting a local smuggler. For $1,000 (£630) he was driven with three others from northern Iraq over the mountains into south-eastern Turkey and taken to Istanbul.

It is here that Albanian and Turkish gangs gather their human cargo from all over the Middle East. Some send recruiters into Iraq offering package deals. Typically, refugees are bundled into groups of 30 and told to choose a representative to liaise with the lone guide who will accompany them on foot across Greece's eastern rugged, open frontier.

For this stage of the journey the price for each person is a lump sum of $850 or $100 a day. The groups walk by night, sleep rough by day and, if they do not have their own provisions, are given bread and water. When it snowed in January a Romanian woman and a Ukrainian woman died of exposure and 20 others suffered frostbite.

"Add two days to the trip and I make another $6,000," grins one Albanian smuggler in Patras. For an extra $500 some Kurds travel by truck or ship but the risk of interception is greater.

At Salonika Azad's group was shuttled by car to Athens and given train tickets to Patras, where they joined 130 other Kurds. And here in Norman Square they have been waiting six days to board a lorry that will take a ferry to Ancona, half-way up Italy's east coast.

Their Albanian contacts have not explained the delay, but the reason is to be found in Brussels, where tomorrow the cash-strapped Albanian government will pitch for more than $1bn in aid at a two-day funding conference.

The EU has been blunt. Money will flow only if Tirana chokes illegal trafficking. Corrupt politicians and police have helped gangs funnel a stream of humanity to the southern port of Vlore, where at night 20 inflatables used to ferry more than 30 people each to Italian beaches.

Gangs roved unmolested, kidnapping honest police officers and machine-gunning Italian coastguard patrols. Nightly revenue of up to £400,000 funded corruption. "They could have closed us down any time," says Ilyr, a retired smuggler. Now they have. In the past month nine dinghies have been seized, the police chief of Tirana airport has been arrested for alleged smuggling and five air companies have been put under investigation.

The two officers at a police checkpoint by a bullet-holed signpost for Vlore are incredulous. "We've been told to stop the immigrants." Up to 20 families in Vlore who used to rent their houses to Kurds while they waited to move on are feeling the pinch. The beachfront bars are full of unemployed mechanics and drivers. They say only one clan continues to operate, sending a lone boat once a week.

"The question," says one diplomat, "is how long after Brussels will it stay like this?"

Backlog

Two hundred miles south of Vlore, in Patras, two smugglers, sunning themselves on the beachfront, ask the same question. They say it took their bosses less than a day to select the Greek port as an alternative.

Word went out to their contacts in Italy, Turkey, Iraq and north Africa and within three days the package deals were adjusted. But the immigrants are not getting through quickly and a backlog is building, so the hunt is on for more lorry drivers.

The nightly landings on the beaches around the Italian port of Bari have ended, to the dismay of the pool of fixers, drivers and informers who smoothed the next stage of the journey. That business has moved north to Ancona.

Michele Emiliano, Bari's top anti-mafia magistrate, shrugs. In addition to geography, Italy's entry into the Schengen free-movement agreement made it an irresistible port of call. "What do you expect? These guys are versatile. If you close one door they open another. It's economics. People will always get through."

The new route from Ancona will use the rail network to take immigrants and asylum seekers north to Milan and Turin, where they will be met at the station or directed to a safe houses for the day or two it takes to assemble groups that want to go the same countries.

By 10pm the waters off Patras are black. The ferries have become bobbing lights. Some of the Kurds in Norman Square kick a ball around to keep warm. Those huddled around the fire speak in low voices of the journey ahead and their new lives.

Karzan Ahmed, 20, studied agriculture before fleeing Iraq. "I didn't want to join the army and they threatened to cut off my ears. It's what they do to those who refuse." He plans to join a friend in Germany. When a group of 40 is asked how many want to go to Britain, less than a quarter raise their hands. Germany and Sweden are much preferred.

Azad is heading for London because his friend there has a job in a hotel. "Britain is a good place for us. Safe. We can work." His truck from Turin is to take him to Calais, where an Albanian contact will put him into another bound for Britain.

The closure of Albania was a shock to the smugglers but their customers have barely noticed. The price was unaffected.

But from April 3 there will be another shock. Britain is to impose a fixed £2,000 fine on lorry drivers for each asylum seeker and illegal immigrant found in their vehicles. Every cord, strap, lock and seal must be checked under the new law.

The risk of detection is not high. Trucks carrying fresh flowers, meat and pet food are favoured because they confuse sniffer dogs. Four lorries cross the channel every minute and it takes 30 minutes for customs to check one.

Price rise

But the law's effect is likely to be immediate. According to Albanian and Italian officials and the smugglers, the price for crossing the channel will soar. "The smugglers may try to threaten some drivers, improve false passports or try to land on remote beaches, but the rise in price will be the main result," Mr Emiliano says.

Grammoz Pashko, a leading Albanian politician, says legitimate asylum seekers will be squeezed out: "Only criminals could afford to pay such a price."

Azad reacts in disbelief. He starts to stammer. "If it happens before I get there, I'll never get in. I wanted to go to Britain because I thought I would be welcome."

Britain is to impose a fixed £2,000 fine on lorry drivers for each asylum seeker and illegal immigrant found in their vehicles. Every cord, strap, lock and seal must be checked under the new law. The risk of detection is not high. Trucks carrying fresh flowers, meat and pet food are favoured because they confuse sniffer dogs. Four lorries cross the channel every minute and it takes 30 minutes for customs to check one. Price rise But the law's effect is likely to be immediate. According to Albanian and Italian officials and the smugglers, the price for crossing the channel will soar. "The smugglers may try to threaten some drivers, improve false passports or try to land on remote beaches, but the rise in price will be the main result," Mr Emiliano says. Grammoz Pashko, a leading Albanian politician, says legitimate asylum seekers will be squeezed out: "Only criminals could afford to pay such a price." Azad reacts in disbelief. He starts to stammer. "If it happens before I get there, I'll never get in. I wanted to go to Britain because I thought I would be welcome."

webTitle: Hail the redeemer. He'll be yesterday's man soon enough

fields.headline: Hail the redeemer. He'll be yesterday's man soon enough
fields.standfirst:
Greg Dyke will save the BBC. They said that about Birt once too

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Here, in one BBC newsroom not so far away, is an instructive noticeboard. It is covered, end to end, with newspaper cuttings assessing the reign of the departed Lord Birt. fields.body:
Here, in one BBC newsroom not so far away, is an instructive noticeboard. It is covered, end to end, with newspaper cuttings assessing the reign of the departed Lord Birt. The more vicious criticisms are glowingly underlined. Graffiti of the usual kind adorn any photograph of the lost leader. No management hand, obviously enough, has sought to restrain such brutal rejoicing.

You know and recognise the scene the moment you see it. You've seen it before, in the debris of Suharto's Indonesia and Ceaucescu's Romania as dictatorship ended and the mob stormed from office to office, tearing down pictures of the Hated One. This is the way regimes end, in a slew of leftover vitriol and much postponed courage. Hail Comrade Dyke! Hail the Redeemer!

How long it seems - maybe as much as six weeks - since the penguin-suited great and good of politics and broadcasting gathered in Wood Lane's biggest studio to bid farewell to the old director-general, to drink champagne and hear a large number of speeches hymning his humanity, wisdom and unique contribution to national life. But six weeks is an eternity in Beeb affairs. The knives are out, the peasants are having their fun.

And there is, one step back, something eternal about this slightly gruesome spectacle; something that should give Mr Blair and Mr Brown, for instance, pause as they shower "new" money on other walks of public life like the NHS.

We don't quite know yet what Greg, the Great Incoming Leader, intends: but the portents are gathering. He brings his own gurus from Henley college with him. He wants to cut spending on bureaucracy from 25% of revenue to 15%. Hundreds - maybe thousands - of managers will go, the layers of Birtism and its simulated internal market dismembered. Smaller teams, swifter decisions, more creative juices. The aim, it is said, will be "stonking good programmes"; nothing else matters.

Well, fine: but that - from one step back - only etches the curiosity of this transition in clearer relief. John Birt ruled the BBC for eight tumultuous years - and not all the panegyrics that went with his leaving champagne were hollow. He did a good deal that was, politically, difficult but necessary: at great public cost, with great public effort. And now, apparently, much of it will be dismembered, at further great cost in redundancy pay-offs.

Why? The rejoicings in the newsroom, perhaps, supply one answer - and yet there's a gigantic hole where more rational reasonings ought to be. We trust the running of the corporation, remember, to its chairman and its governors. Sir Christopher Bland, a long-term friend of Lord Birt, contributed one of the stickiest tributes on the Wood Lane night. He also got another chum, Greg Dyke, the succession.

If there was reason for further change, for more expen sive upheaval, for dismantlings and sackings, you might suppose that Sir Christopher and his governors would be in the van of reform. I quote from his summation of the last annual report. "We describe a BBC in excellent creative form with high programme standards, its finances strong, always striving to offer the best value to audiences." Everything in 1999 was hunky-dory; and now it's a pile of old boots.

Those of us on the outside, those of us who pay, ought to ponder this amazing transmogrification awhile - because it tells us something which profoundly affects our instincts and our purses.

At Beeb level, it's probably little beyond a switch in personalities. John Birt, who'd never run anything bigger than programmes at London Weekend, was required to turn himself into the super-manager of 23,000 distrait souls and sometimes drowned in McKinsey-speak; Greg Dyke, fresh from the thrusting Pearson empire, knows what he doesn't like (long memos and endless committees). The BBC habitually imports its supreme leaders from the private sec tor and tailors its public operations to fit whoever the choice may be. After Greg, in four or eight years, there'll doubtless be further revolution. It would be surprising, looking down the long and random tunnel from Milne to Checkland to Birt to Dyke, if there were not.

Yet see how bizarrely other sectors of public life echo these oscillations. What, for instance, was I supposed to think about the health service in those scary, fluey days after Christmas? That its doctors and nurses were coping magnificently. That we all owed them a debt of gratitude. That they were heroes and heroines. The politicians, from Milburn to Blair, told us so. When the prime minister submitted himself to another of those long Newsnights of the soul, facing assorted angels of mercy, he uttered not a single word of criticism. Unlike (say) teachers, they were terrific, every one. Sir Christopher Bland couldn't have put it better.

But now it's the fag-end of ides-ridden March, and the song is different. We know that some hospitals manage without long trolley waits, while others have them on a regular basis; that some patients can see their GP in 24 hours, while others have to wait four or five days; that some health authorities perform four times more hip replacements than others. We know this, and many similar horrors of discrepancy, because the prime minister tells us so.

We know that the NHS cost of a lung transplant can vary between £2,448 and £31,430; that the cost of replacing a knee can be £489 or £11,922, because Whitehall tells us so. We know that the sector is riddled with discrepancies and restrictive practices (many of them protected by the same saintly medics who filled our TV screens in January). A bed at Leicester royal infirmary costs £7,300 a year less than a bed at Leicester general just down the road.

Enter the hit teams and the elite squads of experts and the grand committees of plans to come, chaired by the selfsame T. Blair. It is all a bit sudden. Over-arching pundits, like Polly Toynbee, may have recognised the shambles for years - but they never got a word of it into the speeches of Dobbo or Milburn. The impact is rather like being told that your favourite uncle is Harold Shipman.

Thus, in eerie step with the Beeb, we move from the internal market to commonsense revolutions; and the managers who were kings yesterday are the Gypsies of tomorrow. That's administrative life, whether in Wood Lane or Leicester general. The question for Greg, relentlessly put, is whether it's possible to run a massive public-service broadcaster in the modern age. The question for Blair and Brown, put even more apocalyptically, is whether a National Health Service is a beast that can be tamed.

Don't hold your breath. Remember: there's never a crisis till someone on high says there's a crisis. And there's never a failure when other men, other consultants, other nostrums, wait to take over the newsroom boards.

webTitle: EU struggles to find common approach to control influx

fields.headline: EU struggles to find common approach to control influx
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Some 400,000 people are now smuggled into the European Union every year, according to one estimate, with the illegal refugees often paying huge sums to traffickers.
fields.body:
Some 400,000 people are now smuggled into the European Union every year, according to one estimate, with the illegal refugees often paying huge sums to traffickers.

Absolute figures have declined since the early 1990s when Yugoslavia began to disintegrate, but overall the EU may now contain as many as one million displaced people - the biggest number since the second world war.

Until last summer, when the EU's Amsterdam treaty came into force, immigration and asylum were strictly matters for national governments, with no formal role for the Brussels bureaucracy.

But that is changing, as the 15-member union is grappling with the realisation that its huge single market in goods and services has created a single market in people, crime and immigration.

"These issues can no longer be dealt with on a purely national basis," argues one official. "They really have to be handled on a European level. But this is not an area where it is easy to set common standards, like you can with plugs or microwaves."

Last October's Tampere summit in Finland, the first devoted to tackling these questions, established a first rough draft of the way ahead. Since then EU officials have been looking at cooperation on burden-sharing, repatriation and a database and fingerprinting system. Some of these measures worry civil liberties groups.

Support is broadest for plans focused on specific countries of origin - Somalia, Iraq, Morocco, Albania, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan - so that immigration policies can be integrated with development aid to tackle poverty and the causes of instability. Yet, as on any other EU issue, approaches differ. Smaller countries see greater benefit in working together than bigger ones.

But Fortress Europe will not work. Portugal, current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, argues that plummeting birth rates and ageing populations mean that the union urgently needs a strategy for legal immigration.

Romano Prodi, the European commission president, led calls at last week's Lisbon summit for measures to bridge the rapidly growing gap between information technology needs and trained workers. Germany is already inviting in non-EU foreigners to help fill the ranks.

According to a new UN report, Mr Prodi's native Italy would need to raise the working-age limit to 77 if it did not accept the 2.2m migrants a year needed to maintain the ratio of four working people for every retiree - vital for pension provision.

Still, though, there is unease about coordination. Britain will not opt into the Schengen system, under which EU citizens can cross borders without passport checks. Belgium temporarily suspended its partic ipation in January to cope with an influx of unregistered foreigners. "Basically," says Graham Watson, the Liberal Democrat chairman of the European parliament's justice and home affairs committee, "governments have not decided how much they want to do at EU level and how well they can make it work."

What is clear is that huge problems lie ahead as the EU takes in former Communist countries such as the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Romania, all accused of discrimination against the same Gypsies who end up begging on the London underground.

Supporters of enlargement insist that EU aid to candidate countries is designed in part to ensure that there is no mass migration, and point out that scare stories about an Iberian influx never materialised when Spain and Portugal joined.

But not everyone is convinced. "We are talking about an enormous expansion of Europe and its borders and not enough thought has gone into it," warns Timothy Kirkhope, a Tory MEP and former immigration minister.

"Too many politicians steer clear of the subject for fear that they'll be accused of being racist - or of failing to stop foreigners coming in. But Europe needs a policy, or we could end up with a disaster."

The displaced

 Of the 4.2m refugees for which UNHCR offices reported gender and age, 50.9% were female

 Of the 2.2m refugee population of Africa, 16.3% are below the age of five

 Up to 400,000 people are smuggled into EU every year

 The EU may contain as many as one million displaced people - the largest number since the second world war

 Europe is the only region where most urban refugees are female

 Typically, a refugee camp population is made up of families. Refugees in urban areas are more often adult males

webTitle: An impertinent challenge to the NHS

fields.headline: An impertinent challenge to the NHS
fields.trailText: The aspiration for New Labour to match continental levels of spending on the NHS is long overdue (Letters, March 24 and 25). However we need to appreciate just how far behind the NHS has fallen. Two simple examples. We have the lowest per capita number of intensive care beds in western Europe. Second, our five-year cancer survival rates are the lowest for the frequent cancers, such as colorectal, breast and prostate, in the west. The link between cancer outcomes and health expenditure is seen in the US, where black Americans survival rates are 20% behind white Americans. Yet Britain's five-year cancer survival rates are worse than those for Black Americans.
fields.body:
The aspiration for New Labour to match continental levels of spending on the NHS is long overdue (Letters, March 24 and 25). However we need to appreciate just how far behind the NHS has fallen. Two simple examples. We have the lowest per capita number of intensive care beds in western Europe. Second, our five-year cancer survival rates are the lowest for the frequent cancers, such as colorectal, breast and prostate, in the west. The link between cancer outcomes and health expenditure is seen in the US, where black Americans survival rates are 20% behind white Americans. Yet Britain's five-year cancer survival rates are worse than those for Black Americans.

At the moment we are in the relegation zone of GDP expended on health; if in four years we begin to match the average resource of Europe, financially we will still be only mid-table. Blair's "challenge" is a spin to hide two decades of comparative neglect of the NHS by successive governments, and in the circumstances is almost impertinent.
Prof Colin Pritchard
University of Southampton
cp1@soton.ac.uk

 Polly Toynbee thinks that consultants can be trained "... in a fraction of the eight years it takes under this medieval apprenticeship system... " (A good prognosis, March 24). The apprenticeship system evolved over a thousand 1,000 years for practical crafts, and so presumably was a most effective method of training. We are now having to train our specialist doctors under the Calman system for half the number of years, whilst trainees work a reduced working week following the junior doctors' hours reviews. Consequently, the new generation of consultants have experienced perhaps a quarter of their predecessors' caseload. This has already been found inadequate in anaesthetics, and training is having to be extended to give trainees the adequate experience required to produce safe anaesthetists.
Dr David Sutton
Southampton

 Should the proposed hospital inspectorate be titled Ofsick?
Ted Truscoe
Horley, Surrey
truscoe@cwcom.net

fields.headline: Seeds of future famines
fields.trailText: James Watson's part as a scientist in discovering the double helix structure of DNA was undeniably a huge part in promoting our understanding of science (Passion for science that lies in the genes, March 25). His faith the use of genetic screening and genetically modified food as instruments for good are misplaced. Science and the use of of it does not operate in a vacuum.
fields.body:
James Watson's part as a scientist in discovering the double helix structure of DNA was undeniably a huge part in promoting our understanding of science (Passion for science that lies in the genes, March 25). His faith the use of genetic screening and genetically modified food as instruments for good are misplaced. Science and the use of of it does not operate in a vacuum.

His use of the Irish famine as a justification for the development of GM foods shows a lack of understanding of history and the policies that contributed to the famine. The potato blight did not wipe out the Irish, it was the development of an agricultural infrastructure which led to over-reliance on a single crop. The failure of the potato crop in successive years and a political philosophy based on the principle of no government interference in the laws of supply and demand were the main contributing factors to the famine in Ireland. Other countries had blight in these years but no famine or deaths on the scale witnessed in Ireland. The use of GM foods and their control by large multinational companies contains the seeds of disaster for future famines. Large companies will change local agricultural infrastructures in the name of science and the prevention of world hunger.

James Watson is right when he calls for public ownership of such knowledge and warns against the ownership of such knowledge by a small number of companies. Science is not a neutral force for the good of society, but must be marshalled to achieve that good.
Martin Caraher
Thames Valley University
martin.caraher@tvu.ac.uk

fields.headline: PFI not dead
fields.body:
You imply that the Treasury committee calls the whole private finance initiative concept into question (MPs say PFI has had its day, March 24). The case for PFI in order to obtain extra capital investment is weaker since the introduction of the government's "golden rule", which allows borrowing for investment, but we make it clear that there is a strong case for using PFI for projects representing good value for money compared to public sector projects. A key factor is the need to ensure that projects stimulate innovation by the private sector.
Giles Radice MP
Chairman, Treasury committee

fields.headline: The drama of sport
fields.trailText: Richard Eyre (Why British culture needs elitism, March 25) is right: those who accuse the arts of "elitism" are missing the point. But the arts world needs to consider why it is criticised where sport is not. Sport relentlessly pursues an "elitist" agenda; everyone wants to see world-class sporting heroes nurtured in Britain. Yet this does not lead to accusations of insularity or arrogance. This is because of the relationship between spectator appreciation and active participation. In sport, most people enjoy both watching and playing, at some time in their lives; they celebrate the distinction, yet value each activity in different ways.
fields.body:
Richard Eyre (Why British culture needs elitism, March 25) is right: those who accuse the arts of "elitism" are missing the point. But the arts world needs to consider why it is criticised where sport is not. Sport relentlessly pursues an "elitist" agenda; everyone wants to see world-class sporting heroes nurtured in Britain. Yet this does not lead to accusations of insularity or arrogance. This is because of the relationship between spectator appreciation and active participation. In sport, most people enjoy both watching and playing, at some time in their lives; they celebrate the distinction, yet value each activity in different ways.

Thus I have a fourth ingredient to add to Eyre's list of essential developments for the arts - active participation. Arts companies and centres must offer sufficient and high-quality classes and workshops in drama, dance, visual arts, etc. Then many more people could have their experience of the arts enhanced and theatres could have many more punters. Adrian Mitchell
London

fields.headline: Blair's birthing pains
fields.trailText: You report that Tony Blair has not yet made up his mind (Will this woman's husband take paternity leave? March 24). Tony might consider a compromise and take half his paternity leave entitlement. And in true team spirit, delegate the job of running the country to Gordon, Robin, Peter, Jack and John.
fields.body:
You report that Tony Blair has not yet made up his mind (Will this woman's husband take paternity leave? March 24). Tony might consider a compromise and take half his paternity leave entitlement. And in true team spirit, delegate the job of running the country to Gordon, Robin, Peter, Jack and John.

To avoid getting out of touch, he could take the opportunity to brush up his IT skills and be available for a little bit of on-call work. But only if essential, ie anyone seriously disagreeing with anyone else. The on-call time should be restricted to 5-7pm, so he could have had lunch and a nap after changing nappies all night. Ali should ensure a few shots of the new baby we would all want to know about - and maybe an occasional comment, just so it is not forgotten who is the elected prime minister.
Sylvia Armour
London

 What a set of antediluvian attitudes (Bonding with Baby - do men want or need time off, G2, March 22). We have everything from the bolshie Mr Humphrys, who apparently has no sense of connection at all with this soon-to-be born child of his, through to the "work comes first" e-company man.

Too right we'll never catch up with Scandanavia in this, as in so many sensible social policies which affect children. The high-powered male Brit has not the remotest idea of what the benefits to him might be in being a little more present for "his" new arrival. (It seems pointless to dwell on the possible benefits to the mother and the baby.)

What a strange world we live in when high-flying middle-class couples wait for years to have a child, prepare to lavish untold sums on its care and education but where the father can't spare even a measly week to be around, to marvel at this extraordinary unique being. It beats me why some people have kids at all.
Rosemary Milne
Glasgow

 Mary Kenny tells us (Grow up Cherie, March 23) that men will never do the same amount of housework and childcare as women because their brains are not programmed for domestic detail. Common sense often tells us to disregard our biological conditioning: a man's natural instinct is to jump on every woman in sight and impregnate her; luckily, most have learned that to do so is to risk uncomfortable consequences.

Men may not be naturally inclined to care for their children or do housework, but they may face uncomfortable consequences if they don't, not least the collapse of an unfairly overstressed wife, with a consequent domino effect on the children. One in five British children has a stress-related health problem. It is in the interest of all families that our prime minister sets an example of a modern father who accepts his family responsibilities.
Shirley Conran
Chair, Mothers in Management

 On December 15 employees became entitled to parental leave. But is the prime minister an employee? As the only prime minister of the country, Tony Blair is surely an exception. His decision should not be taken as making any political statement for the rest of the country.
Quader Mahmud
London

 The short history of this government shows that without Mr Blair at the helm there is usually a mini-crisis, as occurred in the first two summers when he decamped to the continent with his family. Certainly, Cherie, he is the father of your children and has a personal responsibility to see them into this world and to play his full paternal part as they mature. But his party needs him and by extension so does the nation.
Bill Jackson
West Bridgford, Notts

fields.headline: Trimble's awful weekend
fields.standfirst:
The peacemakers need an urgent rethink

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The weekend brought three bad tidings for David Trimble and therefore for the cause of peace in Northern Ireland. First, he only narrowly defeated a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist party. His aides believed that if his opponent, Martin Smyth, polled any more than 30% of the party's ruling council then Mr Trimble would be badly damaged. In the event, Mr Smyth's stand against the Good Friday agreement won the support of 43%. When you consider Mr Smyth's obvious lack of leadership skills then Mr Trimble's narrow win looks even bleaker: a more plausible candidate might have beaten him. At best, he now leads a party split down the middle on issues of peace and compromise.
fields.body:
The weekend brought three bad tidings for David Trimble and therefore for the cause of peace in Northern Ireland. First, he only narrowly defeated a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist party. His aides believed that if his opponent, Martin Smyth, polled any more than 30% of the party's ruling council then Mr Trimble would be badly damaged. In the event, Mr Smyth's stand against the Good Friday agreement won the support of 43%. When you consider Mr Smyth's obvious lack of leadership skills then Mr Trimble's narrow win looks even bleaker: a more plausible candidate might have beaten him. At best, he now leads a party split down the middle on issues of peace and compromise.

Second, and perhaps more significantly, the council passed a motion demanding that Unionists stay out of Northern Ireland's assembly and executive unless the Royal Ulster Constabulary is allowed to keep its name and badge. Mr Trimble argued passionately against the move, insisting that while he too opposed the changes to the RUC proposed the Patten commission, there were other ways to fight back. But his appeals were ignored. The third blow came from Mr Trimble's deputy, John Taylor. He is the weathervane of Ulster Unionism: he goes where the party goes. True to form, he voted for Mr Trimble's leadership but against his stance on the RUC. But he also later made a worrying remark. He warned that if there was no resolution of the current impasse by May 22, the deadline set out by the Good Friday accord, then the party should look to "alternative policies". That sounded like a threat to switch to the anti-Agreement, anti-Trimble camp unless there is a breakthrough soon. Such a heavyweight defection could well be fatal to Mr Trimble's tenuous grip on his party.

The cumulative effect of these three grim developments is to leave the progressive, creative wing of Ulster Unionism hopelessly hemmed in. From now on David Trimble can negotiate peace only under two, severe constraints. His party have told him that he cannot go into a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein unless both the IRA disarm and London drops its plans to reform the RUC. In other words, there is now not one Unionist veto but two. The UUP is saying "No guns, no government" but also "No RUC, no government". Mr Trimble may have been able to finesse one of those issues, somehow wiggling through a compromise that kept everyone on side, but not two. As one Trimble-ite put it yesterday, "This is a return to the Molyneaux era of absentionism," when Unionists deliberately set conditions so impossible, peace and compromise were kept safely at a distance. Unionism could stay cosy and comfortable with the word it knew best: No.

David Trimble's leadership has been a five-year rebellion against that brand of old Unionism. It has sought, however grudging its presentation and style, to find an accommodation with nationalism and even republicanism. That Mr Trimble has no plans to resign is good news. But his task has become much, much harder. His allies say that simply pressing ahead with the agreement - implementing Patten but offering no IRA guns - is now impossible. The hardliners of Unionism will not wear it, just as the hardliners of republicanism will not give up their weapons. Suddenly the extremists of both sides are in charge, holding the peace process to ransom. Their shared enemy - the peacemakers of Unionism and nationalism, together with London and Dublin - need to do some fresh thinking, and to do it fast.

fields.headline: Land of the sinking sum
fields.standfirst: Japan hopes deflation will end, 10 years on
fields.trailText: Do not look now, but house prices are plummeting. Not here, but in Japan, land of the sinking sum. It is still locked into a seemingly endless period of asset price deflation. Last year property prices tumbled for the ninth year running. The price of commercial land dropped 9% and residential prices by 4%. Some commercial properties in the centre of the capital have lost 80% of their value since the infamous peak at the start of the 1990s when the grounds of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo were worth more than the whole of California. In those days Japan appeared to be an unstoppable industrial colossus which, even American business magazines reluctantly conceded, was about to seize world technological leadership from the US. It did not because of something else that was about to happen in California that no one had the slightest idea about - the commercialisation of the internet through the world wide web.
fields.body:
Do not look now, but house prices are plummeting. Not here, but in Japan, land of the sinking sum. It is still locked into a seemingly endless period of asset price deflation. Last year property prices tumbled for the ninth year running. The price of commercial land dropped 9% and residential prices by 4%. Some commercial properties in the centre of the capital have lost 80% of their value since the infamous peak at the start of the 1990s when the grounds of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo were worth more than the whole of California. In those days Japan appeared to be an unstoppable industrial colossus which, even American business magazines reluctantly conceded, was about to seize world technological leadership from the US. It did not because of something else that was about to happen in California that no one had the slightest idea about - the commercialisation of the internet through the world wide web.

Since then, California - and the rest of America - has not looked back while Japan has not stopped sinking into what must seem like a bottomless pit. This month the International Monetary Fund warned that the weakness of the Japanese banking sector (which uses land as collateral for loans) was still a key factor behind the poor performance of the economy. It hardly grew at all during the 90s, apart from a freak spurt of 5% in 1996. During the past two years the economy has contracted by over 3.5%. Yet house prices in Japan are still 13 times an average worker's salary and more in Tokyo. This suggests that prices may have some way to go before stabilising (though the scarcity of land will always keep prices high).

No one knows with certainty when the economy will start to recover, but it would be wrong to underestimate Japan's formidable strengths in consumer electronics. Traditionally, Japan has been a "second mover", exploiting other peoples' inventions. It may emerge shortly as a second mover to exploit the next stage of the internet's development. It is, for instance, a world leader in mobile phone applications but few outside Japan know because, until now, it has adopted a different set of technical standards. The moral of all this is that asset bubbles of the kind that have been happening to share markets in Britain and the United States should be taken very seriously indeed. Bubbles have a habit of bursting.

fields.headline: Tony, relax
fields.standfirst:
Your rivals are too shy to steal your job

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: To take leave or not to take leave, that has been the question. Ever since the great Blair paternity debate was sparked last week - by Mrs Blair herself - the phone-ins and feature pages have been brimming with opinions and unsolicited advice. After a weekend of hoarse-throated discussion, the prime ministerial couple must be getting pretty sick of it. But perhaps one element has not yet been fully obscured by the hyperventilation about Tony Blair's handiness around the house, his dexterity with a diaper and his skill with a bedtime story. That is: what is he so scared of?
fields.body:
To take leave or not to take leave, that has been the question. Ever since the great Blair paternity debate was sparked last week - by Mrs Blair herself - the phone-ins and feature pages have been brimming with opinions and unsolicited advice. After a weekend of hoarse-throated discussion, the prime ministerial couple must be getting pretty sick of it. But perhaps one element has not yet been fully obscured by the hyperventilation about Tony Blair's handiness around the house, his dexterity with a diaper and his skill with a bedtime story. That is: what is he so scared of?

Most people who work in offices are familiar with the colleague who will not take holidays for fear someone else will take his or her job/corner office/place in the boss's good books. Equally familiar is the head honcho who believes he is indispensable, always phoning from the beach, emailing from the ski slopes, offering maddening interventions - unable to accept that the ship is sailing just fine without him. Can Mr Blair be one of these two archetypes? Underneath that masterful veneer, is he anxious that if he goes we will not miss him? Or does he secretly worry that, the moment he turns his back - burying himself not in red boxes, but in a volume of Penelope Leach - one of his ministers will pounce?

But who? John Prescott's memories of his brief stint as acting PM will not be happy ones. The Tories will only tease him about his language troubles at the despatch box. What of Gordon Brown? It has become commonplace to describe the chancellor as the real power in Downing Street. But for that very reason he will be reluctant to seize the throne. On the contrary, he will offer daily expressions of his reluctance to do any job other than the one in Number 11. The result could be not a stampede, but a vacuum as Mr Blair's colleagues blush with self-effacement. Maybe that will reassure the PM, comforting him that he is indispensable after all.

webTitle: Something to learn from a school case

fields.headline: Something to learn from a school case
fields.standfirst: Writ large
fields.trailText: After the deal negotiated last week which ended Summerhill School's appeal against the education secretary's attempt to take action against it - he seemed to be unhappy about nude pupils not attending classes - Court 40 of the Royal Courts of Justice was taken over by the students (fully clothed on this special occasion) for a lively discussion about their attitude to the settlement.
fields.body:
After the deal negotiated last week which ended Summerhill School's appeal against the education secretary's attempt to take action against it - he seemed to be unhappy about nude pupils not attending classes - Court 40 of the Royal Courts of Justice was taken over by the students (fully clothed on this special occasion) for a lively discussion about their attitude to the settlement.

The 15-year-old girl who chaired the meeting did so from the judges' bench. They approved it; if they hadn't, the deal might not have gone through. I do hope that this procedure has set a precedent. This was, admittedly, a special appeal under the Education Act, but why shouldn't the principle be extended?

There's a strong argument for following every trial or appeal with a courtroom debate to see if the parties liked the suggested result. I see a typical scenario. "No, I really think the 10 years the judge intends to impose is well out of order for my robbery," the villain proposes; "I think it's about right," his old mother chips in. "Remember, you've got two previous." "Besides," his criminal associate adds, "you showed no remorse." "Yeah, I'd forgotten that. OK, maybe 10 years is fair. Let's tell the judge we agree with his sentence."

I'm sure that such après-trial debates would take a lot of bitterness out of our justice system. If Mr Hamilton and Mr Fayed had adopted the Summerhill School approach, they would be best friends by now; and General Pinochet would happily have taken a plane to Spain.

Strangely, Messrs Hamilton and Fayed were absent from a party for the launch of David Hooper's jolly new book on the sensational libel cases of recent years (Reputations under Fire, published by Little, Brown). We had to make do with listening to a hilarious tape of the two men in acrimonious combat when Hamilton phoned in to a radio phone-in guested by Fayed.

Other absentees included Jonathan Aitken, Robert Maxwell and Gillian Taylforth, who also feature heavily in Hooper's book. We were not, alas, treated to a tape of anyone paying a bill at the Ritz, falling in the sea, or helping a boyfriend out of his pancreatic pain in a four-wheel drive on a lay-by off the A1. Hooper's book is full of splendid behind-the-scenes anecdotes, especially about Maxwell's promiscuous use of the libel laws. When he died, more than 100 libel suits - for and against - died with him. The law today militates against the grandiose libel trials of the past, with their ridiculous posturing of celebrities and absurd compensation awards. Hamilton-Fayed may have been the last of them. (The David Irving holocaust trial hasn't even got a jury, and, anyway, lacks real celebs). Entertainment's loss, though, is justice's gain.

More dustbins stuff. The whole question of who is to pay Neil Hamilton's legal bill has gone severely underground. The case was in the court lists on Thursday, but when I tried to find out what had happened the lawyers involved turned ashen and looked around furtively. You'll remember that Hamilton is trying to re-open the costs issue after it was discovered that documents in a dustbin outside his barrister's chambers had found their way to his opponent. To complicate things, the chap who allegedly raided the bin and sold the stuff to Fayed was recently arrested and faces trial soon, which caused Channel 4 to pull a scheduled documentary about him 10 days ago.

Strangely, Messrs Hamilton and Fayed were absent from a party for the launch of David Hooper's jolly new book on the sensational libel cases of recent years (Reputations under Fire, published by Little, Brown). We had to make do with listening to a hilarious tape of the two men in acrimonious combat when Hamilton phoned in to a radio phone-in guested by Fayed. Other absentees included Jonathan Aitken, Robert Maxwell and Gillian Taylforth, who also feature heavily in Hooper's book. We were not, alas, treated to a tape of anyone paying a bill at the Ritz, falling in the sea, or helping a boyfriend out of his pancreatic pain in a four-wheel drive on a lay-by off the A1.
