The case was in the court lists on Thursday, but when I tried to find out what had happened the lawyers involved turned ashen and looked around furtively. You'll remember that Hamilton is trying to re-open the costs issue after it was discovered that documents in a dustbin outside his barrister's chambers had found their way to his opponent. To complicate things, the chap who allegedly raided the bin and sold the stuff to Fayed was recently arrested and faces trial soon, which caused Channel 4 to pull a scheduled documentary about him 10 days ago.

fields.headline: Log on to the lawyers
fields.standfirst: We seem to be on the verge of a legal revolution thanks to the internet - even the lord chancellor is launching an online service next week, linking 400 advice and help websites. But are you better off down at the library?  Jolyon Jenkins  and our test panel investigate
fields.trailText: Next week, the lord chancellor's department launches its own advice website, Just Ask!, part of the new Community Legal Service. This is an attempt to make justice more accessible - without spending any money on it. The website, at www.justask.org.uk, is under wraps, but promises "co-ordinated access to some 400 online legal information and help websites through its Advice Search feature".
fields.body:
Next week, the lord chancellor's department launches its own advice website, Just Ask!, part of the new Community Legal Service. This is an attempt to make justice more accessible - without spending any money on it. The website, at www.justask.org.uk, is under wraps, but promises "co-ordinated access to some 400 online legal information and help websites through its Advice Search feature".

So what is available on the net for the ordinary person with a legal problem - and can you get anything useful without paying for it? To test the burgeoning number of legal websites, we recruited a panel of four, each of whom had a legal problem.

Philip had tripped on an uncovered gully in a shop, breaking his elbow and wrist and suffering months of pain; the shop had offered £800 in compensation and he wanted to know if this was reasonable.

Susan lets out a flat to tenants who have been playing loud music at all times of night and day, and breaching other terms of the tenancy agreement. She wanted to know if there was any way of getting them out.

Robert had bought a toaster, which broke after two months. The shop replaced it with another which broke in the same way after five months. They refused to replace the second one.

Alan wants to regain contact with his four-year-old daughter. He has a contact order, issued by a court, which allows him access every two months. But the child's mother has broken off all contact. Alan wants to know if, and how, he can enforce the order. We sat down and logged on, stopping off at various sites:

www.lawrights.co.uk

Lawrights offers free legal advice, in the form of questions and answers, on most areas of law the public is likely to be involved with, such as accident claims, family law and employment rights.

For example, the answer to "My children have been taken into care by social services. What can I do?" is: "You should see a solicitor if you want to try and get your children back. Usually social services will apply to the court for an order so that they can take your children into care. You can oppose this order. Even if an order has been made you might later be able to have the order changed."

This is correct advice, if a little cursory. The phrase "see a solicitor" makes up a substantial part of many answers. Lawrights itself offers personalised legal advice on a premium-rate phone number, at £1.50 a minute, and presumably a major reason for the website is to drum up business for this.

Our panel were not over-impressed. None of their specific questions were answered. Had Susan wanted to draw up a new assured shorthold tenancy for her flat, Lawrights would have sold her a "personalised" one for £35, although the personalisation went little further than including the names and addresses of the parties to the agreement, the rent payable and the items in the inventory.

"It's not a bargain," she says. "I usually just copy the standard AST agreement in The Which? Guide to Renting and Letting, which you can find in libraries or get from WH Smith. But it's cheaper than seeing a solicitor."

www.desktoplawyer.net

Run by barristers at 11 Stone Building in the Temple, London, this is another site that exists mainly to sell legal documents, and which will also "personalise" them for you, using its own software (which you have to download first). It's not particularly cheap: for instance, a simple will costs £19.99 and an assured shorthold tenancy agreement is £29.99. However, if you decide you need to rewrite your will in the middle of the night, it might be the solution.

Desktop lawyer also gives free general advice, which could charitably be described as patchy, giving the impression of having been written by someone paid by the word but without much to say. On divorce, for instance, the expert advice is: "More often than not a relationship will break down by degrees - there is very rarely a day upon which it could be said that a marriage came to an end . . .", advice which continues for another 150 words of waffle.

The advice on "crime and punishment" is limited to two subjects, "drinking and driving" and "mobile phones and driving". More verbiage ensues: "The mobile phone is becoming an increasing phenomenon in our lives. In fact, for many people, they cannot imagine how they ever managed without one."

www.adviceguide.org.uk

The National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux has been giving basic legal advice to the public for decades and since most of it is delivered by unqualified volunteers, they have developed expertise in simplifying the law to the bare essentials. Most CAB offices are overwhelmed with work and, unlike solicitors, volunteers have no interest in recruiting more clients. The result is a highly professional website likely to answer the kind of questions posed by CAB clients.

To get the most out of it you need to be prepared to invest a little time. There is more to it than meets the eye, and in some cases it takes the search facility to unlock the hidden secrets. There were no direct answers to our questions. Susan, looking for advice on how to deal with her tenants, found, not surprisingly, that the advice was aimed more at protecting the rights of tenants than landlords.

Robert's faulty toaster problem was either too obscure or too trivial, although there was sound advice about faulty goods in general. Alan found references to contact orders, with a reasonable explanation of what they were, but no advice on what to do if they were breached. Philip got useful advice on personal injury procedures, but nothing on how much money he might expect to get as compensation.

www.firstlaw.co.uk

If you propose to spend serious money on legal advice, this might be one for you. It claims to be the world's first internet-only law firm, but in fact it is more of a legal middle-man than a direct provider of advice. If you register your legal requirements with the firm, it will put the work out to tender with law firms registered with the site. The firms will then bid for your work, and you can negotiate a price with them on-line. FirstLaw will also manage the case on your behalf to make sure you get a proper level of service.

FirstLaw makes money by taking a cut from the fee you pay the lawyer. The competitive bidding process should drive the price down; on the other hand, the firms' need to pay commission might bump it up again. You can only use the service if you have budgeted to spend at least £500, which might seem a lot, but sadly, for clients without legal aid, is par for the course. Of our panel, only Susan saw it as worth investigating. "If you haven't used solicitors much before, then it's hard to know how to choose one that is competent, and very time-consuming to get quotes from several. At least this way I could let FirstLaw do that bit of the work. But I suspect that with the kind of firms that sign up for this sort of thing, £500 wouldn't go very far"

Individual lawyers

Quite a few solicitors claim to offer free initial legal advice by email. An excellent start is the website of Delia Venables at www.venables.co.uk This is mainly intended for lawyers and has many links to other legal resources and a list of law firms offering services online. Don't expect too much, or indeed, anything. For instance, www.lawfree.net promises that queries to advice@lawfree.net will be answered within 24 hours. This was not our experience.

Philip had more luck with his visit to www.collyer-bristow.co.uk where a solicitor responded swiftly to his query about compensation for his broken arm, suggesting that he was being offered too little and offering half an hour of free legal advice. Philip was reasonably impressed: "Clearly as much a sales pitch as a consultation, but it does contain some real information."

He could as easily have got half an hour's free consultation with a local solicitor specialising in personal injury claims under the Law Society's Accident Line scheme, by ringing 0500 192939 (more information at www.accident-line.org.uk).

Alan, anxious to re-establish contact with his small daughter, contacted solicitor David Terry through the website www.terry.co.uk and also got a quick response: "Frankly, I think you would be banging your head against a brick wall. If the custodial parent is determined to frustrate contact that is probably what she will do regardless of any court order." Alan's reaction? "I'm surprised this solicitor is telling me to give up before I've even started."

On the other hand, David Terry's website is one of the best around, with a wealth of well-written, practical and detailed advice. And, sadly, his comments on the difficulty of enforcing contact orders are borne out by the experiences of many men.

All four of the panellists emailed Warner Goodman and Streat at www.warnergoodman.co.uk whose site promises "we will try to answer any general questions you may have". Alan was told: "The order will be enforceable through the English courts. We would be happy to assist you."

Overall, it's hard to believe that we stand on the threshold of a net-driven legal revolution. None of the websites reviewed here can compete with traditional "know your rights" reference books. If you don't want to pay and don't qualify for legal aid, you are better off reading books than surfing the net.

fields.headline: 'The vodka was cheaper in Kazakhstan'
fields.standfirst:
It's freezing, dangerous and distinctly short on late-night entertainment. So what attracted almost 300 British tradesmen to war-ravaged Kosovo? Well, there is the karaoke.

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: It's freezing, dangerous and distinctly short on late-night entertainment. So what attracted almost 300 British tradesmen to war-ravaged Kosovo? Well, there is the karaoke.
fields.body:
Richie Hammond was putting in the plumbing at a Luton service station when he heard about a job going that confirmed his faith in how far drainage systems can take a man. He's 23 and built like an outhouse, with a squaddie's haircut. "I thought I'd see the world, have an adventure," he says. He rang the hastily scrawled number passed on to him by a workmate. A month later he was up a mountain in Kosovo, putting in the toilets at a British army camp and pitching his good humour against temperatures of minus 27C (minus 17F) and mercy missions from Jim Davidson and Rio from Gladiators.

The 5,000 British troops in Kosovo have a well-documented presence. Less visible are the 280 British tradesmen - plumbers and electricians, mainly - living under the wing of the military in a country that is at that surreal, post-conflict stage where ordinary life tries to arrange itself around extraordinary circumstances. While tanks cruise the streets of Pristina and gunfire cracks through the night, plumbers from Tyneside lag pipes and put in shower units, watch the football and send off lottery coupons. "Certain aspects of it remind me of Stoke on Trent," says Rick, an electrician from Blackburn. "I'm more likely to have a gun pulled on me in the pub at home."

The timetable observed by these men doesn't encourage them to take an anthropological view of the posting, which has a 10-20% dropout rate. They are housed, two to a room, in a terrace of customised Portakabins behind the bombed-out shell of a Serbian barracks. They rise at 5.30am, are bussed to one of 13 building sites by 7am and don't knock off until the light fades at 6pm, after which they have a choice of watching British Forces Television or venturing into Pristina, a mile away. When the first batch went out last summer they were strongly discouraged from leaving the MoD-protected compound.

And yet they still came. Hunting Engineering, the prime contractor for Britain's £100m troop accommodation in Kosovo, started asking for workers in August. "The phone didn't stop ringing," says Gerry Sherry, personnel manager on site in Pristina. "We didn't mention salary and worded it to make it sound exciting. A lot of people responded to the emotive tone of the ad - the romance of working in a designated war zone. For others it was just a question of economics." The economics, when they were finally disclosed, were an underwhelming £700 for a seven-day, 70-hour week, and Hunting had to re-advertise in areas of high unemployment to make up the numbers. It ended up with a selection of oil-rig veterans competing for the title of hardest plumber in the world and young adventurers from the Northeast.

When Hammond arrived in Kosovo, he was sent from base camp in Pristina to Goles, the 3,000ft (1,000m) mountain base within sight of the Serbian border, where three-metre snowdrifts bury the cabins and explosions go off at the mine clearance programme on the lower slopes. "We call it fantasy mountain up here," he says. Earlier this year, forces sweetheart Jim Davidson dropped in to boost troop morale. "I think he was half-cut," says Hammond, doubtfully, "but it was nice of him to make the effort."

The society that Hammond and his colleague, David Ingram, an electrician from Dumfries, found themselves in was not what they had expected. Both had come to Kosovo with the idea of seeing the country, and to that end hired a local driver to take them out of the camp and into the destroyed villages. Both were shocked by what they saw, and Ingram had a particularly nasty fright on his first night in Pristina, when a man was shot dead 200m from his hotel. "I was shaking for a couple of days afterwards," he says. "I wondered if I had made the right decision to come here."

What surprised them most was not the violence of the place, but the fact that their interest in life beyond the building site was not widely shared by the other Brits. The majority of workmen in Kosovo survive on two key fantasies: firstly that there is nothing remarkable about a country where 10-year-olds race the streets in stolen cars and snipers take occasional shots from the top of apartment blocks; and secondly that, if it came to it, they could have the Albanian mafia in a fight.

The standard reaction to Kosovo is the comical understatement. "The vodka was cheaper in Kazakhstan," says Jerry Brookes, a 47-year-old plumber from north Wales who has perfected the attitude. Brookes has been in Kosovo for three weeks and is struggling to remain unimpressed. "The worst thing is the boredom," he says, "and the weather." In February, temperatures in Kosovo sank so low that plumbers' fingers stuck to their tools and when they blew their noses the snot came out half-frozen.

"I'm tax-dodging," says Brookes's workmate, Sam Templeman, a 26-year-old electrician from Manchester whose last job was wiring the British embassy in Moscow. "I haven't worked in Britain for two years. It's OK here - there's karaoke and the beer is a deutschmark a bottle."

This carefully maintained insularity hasn't prevented the men from forming definite views about the troops in Kosovo: the French are thugs, the Americans, in spite of the enviable presence of a Burger King inside their base camp, don't have a clue about peacekeeping, and the Germans are so estranged from reality that they mistook a municipal satellite dish for one of their own installations and dismantled Pristina's access to the internet for the best part of a week. The Albanians, while largely viewed with sympathy, do not escape censure either. The wife of a senior engineer out visiting her husband can't hide her indignation at the rubbish that has piled up in the streets of the capital. "If this was Britain, we'd have set up committees to deal with it," she says.

Still, the approach generally taken by the tradesmen towards their Albanian workmates has, in the tradition of Brits in adversity, centred on the well-meaning piss-take. It was greeted as a day of great advancement in Anglo-Albanian relations when the word "tosspot" entered the local vocabulary.

"I call it contact humour," says Philip Lyell, an electrician from Teeside who came with the idea of learning Albanian and doing some good. Contact humour is his contribution to the rebuilding programme - he cites an exchange that took place in the Friday queue for wages. "Why do I only get 260 deutschmark this month?" an Albanian labourer asked. "Because you're a tosser," said the Brit behind him, to multi-ethnic appreciation.

Contact humour pervades the camp, but it is particularly strong in the kitchens, the nerve centre for Britain's tradesmen in Kosovo. They are run by three chefs, Andy Henderson, Brian Perrin and Dave Mackins - Henderson is from Edinburgh and wants to be a fireman; Perrin is from south London and used to be in the Territorial army; Mackins is from South Shields on Tyneside, and can only be photographed with a wide-angle lens. Together, they are known as the Fixers. "We try to keep in with everyone," says Henderson, a former army cook who, through his contacts with 80 Squadron, has set up a forces postal address, oiled the alcohol supply route and run a karaoke night for the camp. He got half way towards rigging up an illegal phone system before management stepped in and told him to cool it.

When they are off duty, the main alternative to the chefs' Butlins-style entertainment is a bar in Pristina called the Kukri, where the British manager, John Foreman, a former paratrooper from Sunderland who has acquired near-legendary status as (take your pick) an ex-member of the SAS, a spy for the Serbs and a gun-toting psychopath. In the first few seconds of meeting him, he appears to be practising the complex art of contact humour. "Bollocks to them," he says of the Albanian mafia, who have several times marched into the bar he leases from a Serb and threatened to kill him. This is not, however, intended as a joke. "Bollocks to them," is Foreman's signature response, and for this reason he is held up by the British builders in Kosovo as a paragon of national virtue.

At 8pm on a Saturday, the people in his bar illustrate the parallel realities coexisting in Kosovo. At one table, British telecommunications workers sip beer and watch televised football; at another, a group of young Albanians hunch together and talk quietly; there is a Serb by the window, and presiding over them all is Foreman, with an eye on the door and a hand on his holster. "The Brits that come out here are a nice enough bunch," he says. "But they don't know anything about the Balkans and they aren't interested."

This has led to some cultural problems. Sherry had to send one tradesman home when he got a local girl pregnant and started receiving threats from her family. "He went back to England like a rocket," he says. The locals on-site are paid £1 an hour and plenty of Brits are guilty of the casual superiority that has them referring to Albanians as "flip-flops", a term coined on the construction sites of Saudi Arabia, where local labourers worked in non-protective footwear.

And yet there has been a moment for each of the British workers when the war suddenly became real. If you catch them away from the group machismo, they are willing to admit that their time in Kosovo has changed them in some way. For Sam Templeman, it was working alongside an Albanian who had been shot in the face for refusing to tell Serbs the whereabouts of his brother. For Jason Edwards, a 29-year-old electrician from south Wales, it was driving up to one of the border camps and seeing children the same age as his own running dirty and unsupervised along the roadside.

For Hammond and Ingram, it was the slow opening out of their Albanian workmates. "When I first came here, the locals wouldn't talk about what had happened to them," says Ingram. "But now we have begun to build some trust up, they have started telling us these terrible stories."

The British response to these stories has been profound: to suspend their pretence of normal life and acknowledge that there are some cultural differences that can't be bridged by banter.

The economics, when they were finally disclosed, were an underwhelming £700 for a seven-day, 70-hour week, and Hunting had to re-advertise in areas of high unemployment to make up the numbers. It ended up with a selection of oil-rig veterans competing for the title of hardest plumber in the world and young adventurers from the Northeast. When Hammond arrived in Kosovo, he was sent from base camp in Pristina to Goles, the 3,000ft (1,000m) mountain base within sight of the Serbian border, where three-metre snowdrifts bury the cabins and explosions go off at the mine clearance programme on the lower slopes. "We call it fantasy mountain up here," he says. Earlier this year, forces sweetheart Jim Davidson dropped in to boost troop morale. "I think he was half-cut," says Hammond, doubtfully, "but it was nice of him to make the effort." The society that Hammond and his colleague, David Ingram, an electrician from Dumfries, found themselves in was not what they had expected. Both had come to Kosovo with the idea of seeing the country, and to that end hired a local driver to take them out of the camp and into the destroyed villages. Both were shocked by what they saw, and Ingram had a particularly nasty fright on his first night in Pristina, when a man was shot dead 200m from his hotel. "I was shaking for a couple of days afterwards," he says. "I wondered if I had made the right decision to come here." What surprised them most was not the violence of the place, but the fact that their interest in life beyond the building site was not widely shared by the other Brits. The majority of workmen in Kosovo survive on two key fantasies: firstly that there is nothing remarkable about a country where 10-year-olds race the streets in stolen cars and snipers take occasional shots from the top of apartment blocks; and secondly that, if it came to it, they could have the Albanian mafia in a fight. The standard reaction to Kosovo is the comical understatement. "The vodka was cheaper in Kazakhstan," says Jerry Brookes, a 47-year-old plumber from north Wales who has perfected the attitude. Brookes has been in Kosovo for three weeks and is struggling to remain unimpressed. "The worst thing is the boredom," he says, "and the weather." In February, temperatures in Kosovo sank so low that plumbers' fingers stuck to their tools and when they blew their noses the snot came out half-frozen. "I'm tax-dodging," says Brookes's workmate, Sam Templeman, a 26-year-old electrician from Manchester whose last job was wiring the British embassy in Moscow. "I haven't worked in Britain for two years. It's OK here - there's karaoke and the beer is a deutschmark a bottle." This carefully maintained insularity hasn't prevented the men from forming definite views about the troops in Kosovo: the French are thugs, the Americans, in spite of the enviable presence of a Burger King inside their base camp, don't have a clue about peacekeeping, and the Germans are so estranged from reality that they mistook a municipal satellite dish for one of their own installations and dismantled Pristina's access to the internet for the best part of a week. The Albanians, while largely viewed with sympathy, do not escape censure either. The wife of a senior engineer out visiting her husband can't hide her indignation at the rubbish that has piled up in the streets of the capital. "If this was Britain, we'd have set up committees to deal with it," she says. Still, the approach generally taken by the tradesmen towards their Albanian workmates has, in the tradition of Brits in adversity, centred on the well-meaning piss-take. It was greeted as a day of great advancement in Anglo-Albanian relations when the word "tosspot" entered the local vocabulary. "I call it contact humour," says Philip Lyell, an electrician from Teeside who came with the idea of learning Albanian and doing some good. Contact humour is his contribution to the rebuilding programme - he cites an exchange that took place in the Friday queue for wages. "Why do I only get 260 deutschmark this month?" an Albanian labourer asked. "Because you're a tosser," said the Brit behind him, to multi-ethnic appreciation. Contact humour pervades the camp, but it is particularly strong in the kitchens, the nerve centre for Britain's tradesmen in Kosovo. They are run by three chefs, Andy Henderson, Brian Perrin and Dave Mackins - Henderson is from Edinburgh and wants to be a fireman; Perrin is from south London and used to be in the Territorial army; Mackins is from South Shields on Tyneside, and can only be photographed with a wide-angle lens. Together, they are known as the Fixers. "We try to keep in with everyone," says Henderson, a former army cook who, through his contacts with 80 Squadron, has set up a forces postal address, oiled the alcohol supply route and run a karaoke night for the camp. He got half way towards rigging up an illegal phone system before management stepped in and told him to cool it. When they are off duty, the main alternative to the chefs' Butlins-style entertainment is a bar in Pristina called the Kukri, where the British manager, John Foreman, a former paratrooper from Sunderland who has acquired near-legendary status as (take your pick) an ex-member of the SAS, a spy for the Serbs and a gun-toting psychopath. In the first few seconds of meeting him, he appears to be practising the complex art of contact humour. "Bollocks to them," he says of the Albanian mafia, who have several times marched into the bar he leases from a Serb and threatened to kill him. This is not, however, intended as a joke. "Bollocks to them," is Foreman's signature response, and for this reason he is held up by the British builders in Kosovo as a paragon of national virtue. At 8pm on a Saturday, the people in his bar illustrate the parallel realities coexisting in Kosovo. At one table, British telecommunications workers sip beer and watch televised football; at another, a group of young Albanians hunch together and talk quietly; there is a Serb by the window, and presiding over them all is Foreman, with an eye on the door and a hand on his holster. "The Brits that come out here are a nice enough bunch," he says. "But they don't know anything about the Balkans and they aren't interested." This has led to some cultural problems. Sherry had to send one tradesman home when he got a local girl pregnant and started receiving threats from her family. "He went back to England like a rocket," he says. The locals on-site are paid £1 an hour and plenty of Brits are guilty of the casual superiority that has them referring to Albanians as "flip-flops", a term coined on the construction sites of Saudi Arabia, where local labourers worked in non-protective footwear. And yet there has been a moment for each of the British workers when the war suddenly became real. If you catch them away from the group machismo, they are willing to admit that their time in Kosovo has changed them in some way. For Sam Templeman, it was working alongside an Albanian who had been shot in the face for refusing to tell Serbs the whereabouts of his brother. For Jason Edwards, a 29-year-old electrician from south Wales, it was driving up to one of the border camps and seeing children the same age as his own running dirty and unsupervised along the roadside. For Hammond and Ingram, it was the slow opening out of their Albanian workmates. "When I first came here, the locals wouldn't talk about what had happened to them," says Ingram. "But now we have begun to build some trust up, they have started telling us these terrible stories." The British response to these stories has been profound: to suspend their pretence of normal life and acknowledge that there are some cultural differences that can't be bridged by banter.

webTitle: Middle East summit fails to deliver

fields.headline: Middle East summit fails to deliver
fields.standfirst:
Clinton and Assad part without kickstarting Syrian-Israeli talks

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The US president, Bill Clinton, yesterday met Syria's leader, Hafez al-Assad, in what was seen as a last-ditch effort to persuade him to restart peace talks with Israel and prevent renewed violence in the Middle East.
fields.byline: Peter Capella  in Geneva and Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The US president, Bill Clinton, yesterday met Syria's leader, Hafez al-Assad, in what was seen as a last-ditch effort to persuade him to restart peace talks with Israel and prevent renewed violence in the Middle East.

The success of those efforts is a matter of urgency for all three countries. Mr Clinton's presidency has entered its final months; Mr Assad, 69, is in poor health and wants to ensure a smooth succession to his son and heir; and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has pledged to withdraw troops from south Lebanon by July - a high-risk manoeuvre in the absence of a wider peace with Syria.

The summit in Geneva was the first between Mr Clinton and Mr Assad since 1994, and a rare appearance abroad for the ailing Syrian leader. The extraordinary nature of the encounter has stoked specula tion about a breakthrough.

The talks, at the Intercontinental Hotel overlooking Lake Geneva, opened with apparent warmth as the two leaders shook hands and exchanged smiles.

A flurry of recent reports has predicted an immediate resumption of Israeli-Syrian talks, but Israeli and US officials yesterday sought to lower expectations of a breakthrough. They said that no announcement would be made until Mr Clinton confers with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Mr Clinton has been holding three-way telephone negotiations with Mr Assad and Mr Barak, but they are believed to remain deadlocked on several key areas.

Mr Barak told a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem that he rated Mr Clinton's chances of salvaging the peace process at no higher than 50%.

"Either we have a partner, or we do not have a partner," he was quoted as saying. "But I cannot give more than a 50% chance to either option."

The US national security adviser, Sandy Berger, was equally cautious about the prospects for an immediate renewal of Syrian-Israeli talks. He said he hoped the two sides would resume negotiations within weeks, but added: "That is by no means certain."

Mr Berger said the differences between Israel and Syria were not irreconcilable, but "there needs to be a higher level of confidence - not certainty but confidence - that their respective needs can be met in an ultimate agreement".

There was no official statement from Damascus yesterday, but the state-controlled newspaper al-Wadi said: "Most of the political forces in Israel are not mature enough for a just peace."

The biggest obstacle to resuming the peace talks is Syria's insistence that Israel commits in advance to total withdrawal from the Golan Heights, returning to the ceasefire line that divided the territory before the 1967 war.

Israel maintains that it will accept no ultimatums in advance of talks. It has tried to persuade Syria to accept a proposal under which Israel would retain a strip of shore line around the Sea of Galilee, which would safeguard the source of 40% of its water. In return, Israel would trade another parcel of land near the strategic Golan Heights.

Analysts believe that other areas of dispute - including security guarantees, an early warning site on the Golan, and a pledge from Damascus to control Hizbullah guerrillas in south Lebanon - will be easier to resolve.

The urgency of yesterday's encounter has been underscored by the frailty of Mr Assad, who is reported to be seeking to complete a peace agreement with Israel to ensure a smooth handover to his designated heir, Bashar, when he leaves power.

For his part, Mr Barak has publicly recognised the risks of going ahead with his pledge to withdraw Israeli forces from south Lebanon by July in an absence of a wider agreement with Syria.

After a four-year freeze, Israeli-Syrian peace negotiations resumed late last year but broke off in January after Syria demanded that Israel agree to returning the entire Golan Heights before other issues could be discussed.

fields.headline: Body of evidence
fields.standfirst: Last week it was claimed that the male menopause, complete with hot flushes, really does exist. But if it does, why aren't more men complaining?  Terri Apter  on the links between sex and wellbeing
fields.trailText: The relation between a woman and her body is often seen as problematic. She is aware of herself as a "physical object", someone seen, assessed and known as a body. This self-awareness begins at an early age. Diaries of girls as young as eight show that they engage in what the author and academic Joan Jacobs Brumberg calls "the body project" - seeing themselves as something to change, mould, perfect. They form resolutions to pare down through dieting and build up through exercise. Being body beautiful becomes a moral mission.
fields.body:
The relation between a woman and her body is often seen as problematic. She is aware of herself as a "physical object", someone seen, assessed and known as a body. This self-awareness begins at an early age. Diaries of girls as young as eight show that they engage in what the author and academic Joan Jacobs Brumberg calls "the body project" - seeing themselves as something to change, mould, perfect. They form resolutions to pare down through dieting and build up through exercise. Being body beautiful becomes a moral mission.

The female as object can be traced throughout the lifespan: from puberty, when she becomes aware of her sexuality through others' responses, to midlife, when many women report becoming invisible socially, women note a link between being attractive and being significant.

Of course, men are not impervious to how they look. At the launch of a book of his collected essays, a university professor was asked whether he had any regrets. Caught charmingly off-guard, he blurted out, "I would have liked to be four inches taller." A retrospective of a brilliant career was clouded by a constant sense that he was "too short".

Men may objectify their bodies in other ways. They sometimes emphasize the body's performance more than their pleasure. They experience pain as something to be contained rather than expressed. They try to look strong, rather than as they are. Such objectification may go some way to explaining the current debate over the existence of the male menopause, dismissed by some clinicians, which was raging in the British Medical Journal last week.

Critical awareness of our own bodies in terms of how they look rather than in terms of how they work is an impediment to a good life. If we look in the mirror and despise ourselves because of our breasts or cellulite, or if we flare with envy for another woman who looks the way we think we ought to, then we collude in a way of seeing that diminishes us.

But recent research has highlighted another aspect of women's special body awareness: they may also be more aware of the body as subject. In other words, they are more attuned to what they feel, and have higher standards for feeling well.

Men and women have different bodies and different body chemistry. It should not be all that surprising that female and male pain follow different pathways to the brain. In all probability, the different pathways are a result of evolution. Men had to learn how to endure the traumatic pain of sudden injury while hunting, and women had to endure the more visceral pain of childbirth.

Some people find this argument compelling, and some find it infuriatingly speculative. But while the differences between the sexes, in terms of pain, are really very small, we can still learn much from looking at the different ways different people read their bodies.

The menstrual cycle teaches women how their moods are affected by their hormones. Few women need a pregnancy test to tell them they are pregnant: there are other, clear signs, such as the tenderness of their breasts - and acute irritability. They key into the different physical messages of different days, and are much quicker to know when something's wrong.

Whether what we feel is seen as intelligent or fantastic is a matter of constant revision. Women have fought hard to revise on their own terms. Menopausal symptoms now are widely recognized, but this wasn't always the case. Hot flushes may have been recognized as "real" (that is, as a symptom of lower oestrogen levels), but other menopausal effects were until very recently classified as symptoms of mental disturbance.

Dr Eleanor Birks, who now runs a menopause clinic in Cambridge, remembers being told by a patient that she felt "as though ants were crawling under my skin". Examining her, and finding nothing, Eleanor tranquillized her. Only years later, when she experienced menopause herself, did she realise her mistake: the itching, crawling sensations were, she now knew, associated with menopause. It was another lesson, she says, in valuing women's awareness.

Women tend to be precise and thorough in their descriptions of pain. Ask a man when his back gives out, and you will be told he was digging in the garden or manoeuvring a lawn mower. Ask a woman, and she will explain that her back gives out when she is under stress. She will tell you what she was thinking about as well as what she was doing. The current medical focus on the close links between psychological and physical wellbeing comes as a surprise to men and a confirmation to women.

Hence, men may be slow to link the midlife hormonal changes, in which testosterone levels are lowered, with their mental turmoil. Instead of addressing the body problem, sometimes called the "male menopause" or "manopause", they disrupt their families and their careers. Ignorant of body messages, they buy fast cars and pursue young women - or stick with what they have but lapse into depression. Certainly, they are slower to seek help and to put the problem in context.

Women do not have to be ill to seek medical advice. Hence, well-women clinics are proliferating in GP surgeries and some workplaces, while men's health clinics are few and far between. This can viewed in two ways. One is that women's natural conditions are somehow seen as abnormal, in need of medical intervention. Another slant says that men are reluctant to seek help. With an interpersonal perspective geared to hierarchy, they don't want to put themselves in a "one-down" position.

But if body knowledge becomes valued by everyone, then this could change. It would, indeed, be an immense social change, for then macho endurance loses its point. This could mean the end of any glorification of the soldier, but it would certainly mean that men would be quicker to seek medical treatment for all those embarrassing conditions (such as prostate and colon cancer) that women have never had an option to avoid.

As the medical profession becomes more interested in what and how people feel, they will help both men and women gain power over their lives and their bodies. After all, women may be quick to locate their pain, but they need new education in locating their pleasure.

This was a surprising outcome of research into teenage pregnancy released last week. Between 1994 and 1997, 836 practices were tracked. Areas of social deprivation had high rates of teenage pregnancy. But these rates could be cut by a staggering 25% where the practice had a female doctor under the age of 36. These young female GPs listened to young girls talk about their bodies. They were effective in switching the sexual education message of controlling or suppressing desire ("Just say no") to one of naming their desire. Girls who know they want to have sex have the power to say either yes or no, and they also have the power to plan ahead for safe sex. The difference in the gender of doctor led to a difference in young girls' body knowledge.

Knowledge of our bodies is often an interpersonal process. We may not believe ourselves until someone reveals that what we feel deep inside ourselves is valuable and worth knowing. Knowing our bodies means addressing the facts both of pain and of pleasure.

webTitle: Aitken: I lied but I was not corrupt

fields.headline: Aitken: I lied but I was not corrupt
fields.standfirst: The Aitken affair: special report
fields.trailText: Jonathan Aitken denied yesterday that any "hidden agenda" of corrupt arms deals lay behind his lie over who paid his bill at the Paris Ritz.
fields.body:
Jonathan Aitken denied yesterday that any "hidden agenda" of corrupt arms deals lay behind his lie over who paid his bill at the Paris Ritz.

The former cabinet minister, freed in January after six months in prison for perjury and perverting the course of justice, said: "There's no bigger story behind what was a disgraceful but very simple story of concealing a lie about a hotel bill. A very small and ... probably unnecessary lie ballooned into an achilles heel which was my downfall."

It had also been the downfall of his 1997 libel action against the Guardian, he said in a BBC Breakfast with Frost interview.

He was asked about a suggestion in a Guardian book that he had what David Frost called "a sort of three-pronged attack going" in which, as a minister, he pushed arms deals from which his Saudi Arabian friend, Said Ayas, would get a percentage. He replied: "It defininitely wasn't anything dramatic like that.

"I was fighting a libel case on many fronts. The principal front was the allegation of pimping. The second front was the allegation that I'd been a corrupt arms dealer.

"But in the middle of all this was a lie about the Ritz. However wrong it now seems, I felt I had to present, as it were, a seamless garment. I'm afraid it's the old adage - oh what a tangled web we weave when first we practice to deceive."

Replying to another question, he said: " The allegation, I think, has always been that secretly I was a corrupt pocketer of arms deals commissions. That is totally and absolutely untrue. I've never made a penny in any direct or indirect way from that source." Agreeing he had received a registered director's fee from a British company involved in arms, he said: "I don't see anything wrong."

Of the lie about the bill, he said (as author of a book on the downfall of Richard Nixon): "The actual offence was small. It was the cover-up... I should have learned from Nixon's mistake." Mr Aitken was on the programme because he is promoting a book giving his side of the affair.

webTitle: Tweed riversiders fight netsmen for rights to salmon

fields.headline: Tweed riversiders fight netsmen for rights to salmon
fields.trailText: The confrontation between landowners guarding their prime beats along the Scottish border and humble English drift netters offshore has become, according to some, a salmon war. Angry words are exchanged, threats sometimes made. "They're plundering the deep, public enemy number one," cry the owners. "Greedy, rich and arrogant," scream the netsmen.
fields.body:
The confrontation between landowners guarding their prime beats along the Scottish border and humble English drift netters offshore has become, according to some, a salmon war. Angry words are exchanged, threats sometimes made. "They're plundering the deep, public enemy number one," cry the owners. "Greedy, rich and arrogant," scream the netsmen.

At stake is the nationality of a fish whose complex lifestyle remains a mystery to many. The owners - who charge anything from £50 to £2,000 a rod for a day's fishing - claim it is Scottish because it was born in the Tweed before heading out to sea. The netters say it is multinational and can be caught off England.

Now Scottish angling proprietors, including some of Britain's biggest landowners, have been told by a committee established by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food that they should be prepared to pay millions in compensation if they want the netsmen to stop fishing. The aristos are crying foul.

"Not a chance," sighs the Duke of Roxburghe, whose three-mile stretch of the Tweed includes two of the best salmon beats on the river. "The north-east [English] drift netters pay zero towards the management of this river and benefit largely from the salmon which we know are coming to Scotland - they're indiscriminately, unfairly, harvesting a wild fish."

Derek Hesleton, a drift netter for almost 40 years, whose 45ft inshore trawler Nicola Joanne is being prepared for the new season, countered: "Some of them are just plain greedy.

"Ours is a family business. They are multi-millionaires, with vast resources at their disposal. As we say in these parts, they're certainly not waiting for next week's wages, are they?"

What no one disputes, however, is that last season marked a very good year for the netsmen. Although their number has dropped from 142 to just 72 in seven years, they bagged almost 25,000 fish - 7,500 more than 1998 - and much of it was apparently heading for the Tweed.

The MAFF committee, which has been been reviewing fishing legislation, says in a report that 80% of salmon netted off the north-east coast is probably of Scottish origin - born in rivers, like the Tweed, before heading for the north Atlantic and returning up to three years later.

It speaks of conflicting evidence, but concludes that a phase-out of netting would be "desirable". To achieve this, it recommends that the proprietors should pay a major element of compensation to the displaced netters - with the government chipping in with extra funds - on the grounds that they would gain "substantial economic benefits".

Sums of millions of pounds have already been mooted - and Derek Hesleton, who is also chairman of the National Federation of Fishermen's Organisations, says his members are certainly tempted by the cash. But he denies that drift netting in the North Sea has depleted salmon stocks in northern rivers.

Earl Haig, of Bemersyde, who owns a mile-long stretch of the Tweed, has described netting as "enemy number one". He says he has no spare cash to offer in compensation. "Fewer people are now coming to fish because catches are so poor."

Drift netting off the Scottish coast was banned in 1962 to conserve stocks.

fields.headline: Cancer link to 'Celtic mutation'
fields.trailText: A defect leading to strands of breast and ovarian cancer has been traced to Scotland, according to a team of cancer experts which has found a mutation in human cells which it believes is a common cause of the cancers.
fields.body:
A defect leading to strands of breast and ovarian cancer has been traced to Scotland, according to a team of cancer experts which has found a mutation in human cells which it believes is a common cause of the cancers.

It claims the defect, which leads to 3.8% of all breast cancers, originated from an unknown person living in the south-west of Scotland about 300 years ago and was passed on to hundreds of descendants. They have dubbed the gene the "Celtic mutation".

A team of scientists working in Scotland, Canada and the US examined the genes of families which suffer from cancer. It traced the mutated gene, which is called the BRCA1 mutation, to Scotland after finding around 20 families with the destructive flaw.

Brian Cohen, a researcher at St Andrews University, said the results suggested a single origin in Scotland. The mutated gene could have spread with Scots as they emigrated.

He said the discovery could offer some explanation for the high cancer rates among women in Scotland. "All the families have the same genetic markers around the gene, which means they have the same common ancestor."

The mutation can be carried without any effect by men. In women it results in up to an 87% chance of developing breast cancer and up to a 60% chance of ovarian cancer.

Professor Tim Bishop, of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said: "If a common ancestor is found, then it makes it easier to find the mutation."

fields.headline: Chewing gum 'stops dementia'
fields.trailText: A chewing gum could be used in the treatment of dementia.
fields.body:
A chewing gum could be used in the treatment of dementia.

Scientists in Japan have performed tests which proved that chewing prevents memory loss in the elderly. Now a new gum, Memory Plus, containing Phosphatidyl Serine (PS), a natural extract of soya lecithin, hopes to combine the stimulating action of chewing with ingredients to improve awareness and concentration.

Researchers at Gifu University medical school in Japan tested mice in a maze: young mice learned to find a hidden platform regardless of whether they had teeth missing, and old mice with a full set of teeth performed nearly as well; old molar-less mice could not remember how to find the platform. Tests found that mice who could not chew had lost cells called glia in the hippocampus, the learning area of the brain.

Nari Sadhuram, an importer of alternative and herbalist treatments who is marketing the Memory Plus gum, said: "PS is a relatively expensive nutrient and therefore not the first thing to experiment with for brain function.

"But if a two to four week trial produces noticeable results in memory and concentration in a person suffering loss in those areas, then it is probably worth its weight in gold."

webTitle: Doctor Who to return on Radio 4

fields.headline: Doctor Who to return on Radio 4
fields.trailText: Doctor Who is setting the controls of the Tardis for a return to earth in the 21st century, courtesy of Radio 4.
fields.body:
Doctor Who is setting the controls of the Tardis for a return to earth in the 21st century, courtesy of Radio 4.

The time-travel lord, whose eight incarnations sustained the longest science fiction series in TV history, is getting a pilot radio drama; if a hit, it could be a series next year.

Doctor Who began in 1963, to fill the gap between Grandstand and Juke Box Jury. Audiences hit 18m, before dropping to 4m by the end in 1989. Today his fans go round the world (making the BBC a fortune from merchandising), and write in to plead he come back.

The script is by Dan Freedman and Colin Meak of Radio 4's Loose Ends comedy show. Mr Freedman told Dr Who magazine: "This will not be comedy. I'm keen to develop a new take, to bring forward darker aspects of the character." Sylvester McCoy, the seventh doctor, is considering a comeback.

Yesterday, a BBC spokesman would not promise a series: "We don't want to build up fans' hopes."

webTitle: Police warned over point-blank use of CS spray

fields.headline: Police warned over point-blank use of CS spray
fields.trailText: A third of public complaints about CS result from police officers squirting the spray at near point-blank range in breach of guidelines, a report by the independent police complaints authority says today.
fields.body:
A third of public complaints about CS result from police officers squirting the spray at near point-blank range in breach of guidelines, a report by the independent police complaints authority says today.

A study for the authority warns that, at close range, the spray causes burns to the eyes and face - but it says there is no evidence of any target being permanently injured or worse, even though the risk is heightened if it is used in an enclosed area, like a car.

The safe limit is set for officers at between one and five metres from the target whom the spray is intended to subdue. The authority concludes there are no grounds on which to withdraw the spray but does call for a review of training in its use.

The report, CS Spray: Improving Public Safety?, describes how the overall number of assaults against police officers has fallen by 19% since it was introduced four years ago, in all but three forces in England and Wales. In Northamptonshire, Nottinghamshire and Sussex - which declined to use it on safety grounds - assaults have risen by an average 10%.

In the year to March 1999, the authority received 425 complaints about CS compared with 254 the previous year. Some 135 cases were examined for the report: in a third of them it was found that officers were accused of using CS within one metre, and that the victims were often injured.

"If CS is used at close range it may cause burns to the eyes and face," said Jo Dobry, the study's author. "However, if CS is used in accordance with the Association of Chief Police Officers' training guidelines, it is probably less dangerous than a baton."

The report finds other problems with the spray: in 18% of cases it failed to work at all. Officers are also urged to beware of "cross-contaminating" bystanders, sparking "panic and hysteria". An animal rights campaigner, Sylvia O'Brien, has received £10,000 in compensation plus legal costs from Gloucestershire constabulary in an out-of-court settlement after she was hit with CS spray at a demonstration in 1997.

The report also advises caution if the "victim" is vulnerable through either mental illness, alcohol or drugs. It also urges urgent research into a chemical, methyl isobutyl ketone (MBIK), which dissolves the solid CS "irritant" so that it can be directed more easily; two years ago Department of Health scientists warned that MBIK was too dangerous to use, although the Home Office and police forces ignored the advice.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke welcomed the report. "It confirms that there is no serious risk to the public from CS spray when it is used within operational guidelines. Assaults on officers have gone down."

webTitle: Three boys die in garden blaze

fields.headline: Three boys die in garden blaze
fields.trailText: A spring weather sleep-out in a garden den ended in tragedy yesterday for three families whose sons died when a candle set fire to bedding and carpets in a cramped shed.
fields.body:
A spring weather sleep-out in a garden den ended in tragedy yesterday for three families whose sons died when a candle set fire to bedding and carpets in a cramped shed.

Police in Birmingham are examining remains of a home-made nail-and-staple latch which may have prevented the three teenagers escaping as the creosoted wood and felt shack in the suburb of Kingstanding became an inferno.

Firefighters who responded in under four minutes to a call from a babysitter at the nearby house needed counselling after discovering that an apparently minor domestic fire was a catastrophe.

"Our crews were deeply shocked," said Allan Rotchell, divisional officer of West Midlands fire service.

"The last thing you expect to find in a situation like this is three kids, three young boys, dead in a shed at the bottom of the garden, three families devastated." Relatives were still in disbelief yesterday that a modest suburban adventure, which the youths had done several times before after carpeting the windowless shed and turning it into a den with a radio and duvets, could end so horribly.

The oldest boy was named by relatives as Matthew Collins, 17, from Short Heath, Birmingham, who worked locally as a fishmonger. It is understood the other two were 14-year-olds Blake Mountney, who lived at the house where the fire occurred, and Chris Williams, whose family are thought to live nearby.

Matthew had organised sleep-outs in the den on several occasions with the other boys. He was described as "well-liked and very pleasant" by his uncle, Ray Collier, 49, a motor mechanic from Castle Bromwich, Birmingham.

"As far as we know at the moment, they were all camping out in the shed like boys do and the next thing you know there was an explosion. Matthew lived with his parents and he was the life and soul of the house. He said he was going to stay over at this place with his mates."

Matthew's father, Michael, who was told the news at 4am yesterday with his wife Delaine, was taken to hospital with shock.

The parents at the house where the tragedy happened were out at the time and were told at 2am what had happened.

Mr Rotchell said that there were no suspicious circumstances and no gas canisters, lighter fuel or other highly combustible material had been found in the ashes.

But about 10 candles and a number of tea-lights had been recovered. "Young people enjoy sleeping out in tents or summerhouses but our warning to families is: please do not let them have candles or tea-lights or there will be more tragedies.

"They need to use torches or battery-operated lights."

Firemen have established that the eight foot by six foot shed had a proper door-handle outside but an only an amateur fixing inside.

Mr Rotchell said: "There was a nail and a piece of string which you had to fiddle about with to open the door. The fire spread very quickly and they could not get out in time."

A man aged 19 who had been at the house with the babysitter was taken to hospital with hand burns after trying vainly to reach the boys when the fire broke out at 11.30pm on Saturday. He also suffered minor facial injuries after being spattered with burning felt from the roof of the shed.

A neighbour was also taken to hospital suffering from shock.

Olive Hawkesford, who lives in the same street, said: "I saw all the flames coming from the shed and I thought someone had just set it on fire because we get a lot of vandalism around here."

Police are also examining a cigarette lighter found in the debris and further evidence is expected from a postmortem today.

webTitle: BAe's anti-gravity research braves X-Files ridicule

fields.headline: BAe's anti-gravity research braves X-Files ridicule
fields.standfirst: www.greenglow.co.uk
fields.trailText:
MAX: There are scientists in Finland who say that they've detected antigravity over the surface of a spinning superconducting disc. (He laughs.)...
- X-Files episode, March 1997
fields.body:
MAX: There are scientists in Finland who say that they've detected antigravity over the surface of a spinning superconducting disc. (He laughs.)...
- X-Files episode, March 1997

The cameo appearance in the TV sci-fi series of the "gravity shielding" experiments of the Finland-based Russian scientist Yevgeny Podkletnov summed up the reaction of the physics world to his work: it belonged in the realm of fantasy.

But not everyone sneered. The military wing of the hi-tech conglomerate BAe Systems took the Podkletnov experiment so seriously that it has launched an anti-gravity research programme, Project Greenglow. If the technology could be made to work it would make existing forms of transport obsolete.

BAe last week confirmed that the project, led by the mathematician Ron Evans, existed but would give no further details. Like many of the few scientists around the world exploring gravity shields and gravity beams, Dr Evans is believed to be fearful of ridicule. The cold fusion debacle, when scientists' claims to have created a solution to the world's energy problems in a lab flask were discredited, casts a long shadow.

Dr Evans, at BAe's stealth and electronic warfare department at Warton, Lancashire, is understood to be working with scientists at Lancaster University. There is a sparse website, www.greenglow.co.uk, which describes the project as "a speculative research programme - the beginning of an adventure which other enthusiastic scientists from academia, government and industry might like to join, particularly those who believe that the gravitational field is not restricted to passivity."

In 1996 Dr Podkletnov claimed to have discovered a way to shield objects from gravity by placing them over a superconducting disc which, in turn, rotated above powerful electromagnets.

His findings were to be published in a British physics journal, but news leaked out and, after press stories that scientists had made an anti-gravity device, he was booed by peers who accused him of breaking the laws of physics.He withdrew his paper and went into a huff. The unversity that had sponsored him, in Tampere, Finland, withdrew its support, and he has returned to Russia.

But the notion of a machine that could gently lift objects - people, freighters, spacecraft - with a hum of electricity gripped some people. A few serious scientists and engineers have been trying to reproduce Dr Podkletnov's results.

This month he slipped into Britain to give a lecture at Sheffield University, where he claimed that the latest Russian gravity shielding experiments had made objects 5% lighter, compared with 2% in the Finnish study.

fields.headline: Skin cancer fear over antibiotics
fields.trailText: Prescription drugs which make the skin more sensitive to sunlight could be linked to a rise in skin cancer, a leading health expert has warned.
fields.body:
Prescription drugs which make the skin more sensitive to sunlight could be linked to a rise in skin cancer, a leading health expert has warned.

James Ferguson, of Dundee University and Ninewells hospital, said his research suggested many common medications could be contributing to the danger, and he urged patients taking such drugs to avoid prolonged exposure to the sun while further tests were carried out.

Many prescribed medicines, including antibiotics used to treat sinus, respiratory and urinary infections, as well as diuretics prescribed for heart and water retention problems, are accepted to make the skin unusually sensitive to sunlight and carry warnings highlighting the danger.

Professor Ferguson tested antibiotics on mice and initial results have shown the animals to be at greater risk of developing skin cancer. He admits there is no necessarily similar pattern affecting humans but is calling for further studies to try to provide a definitive answer.

Prof Ferguson said: "It used to be just a sunburn inducing phenomenon but we now have a more sinister possibility. Many of those drugs which we know are sensitising could, in some way, contribute to skin cancer. We do not know whether they are safe or not."

About 2,000 people in the UK die from skin cancer every year. The number of cases has risen steeply in recent years, with the rise usually being blamed on the increased popularity of foreign travel. Prof Ferguson said the holiday link did not necessarily provide a full explanation.

He stressed that the message applied to all people, including those with darker skin which tanned easily.

Prof Ferguson's research was based on an American antibiotic, from the same family as similar drugs available in Britain. He regularly works on behalf of the US goverenment's federal drug agency, and received £660,000 this year to investigate drug-induced photosensitivity.

One drug caused the skin to react to one eightieth of the exposure to sun which was normally tolerated.

Many prescribed medicines, including antibiotics used to treat sinus, respiratory and urinary infections, as well as diuretics prescribed for heart and water retention problems, are accepted to make the skin unusually sensitive to sunlight and carry warnings highlighting the danger. Professor Ferguson tested antibiotics on mice and initial results have shown the animals to be at greater risk of developing skin cancer. He admits there is no necessarily similar pattern affecting humans but is calling for further studies to try to provide a definitive answer. Prof Ferguson said: "It used to be just a sunburn inducing phenomenon but we now have a more sinister possibility. Many of those drugs which we know are sensitising could, in some way, contribute to skin cancer. We do not know whether they are safe or not." About 2,000 people in the UK die from skin cancer every year. The number of cases has risen steeply in recent years, with the rise usually being blamed on the increased popularity of foreign travel. Prof Ferguson said the holiday link did not necessarily provide a full explanation. He stressed that the message applied to all people, including those with darker skin which tanned easily. Prof Ferguson's research was based on an American antibiotic, from the same family as similar drugs available in Britain. He regularly works on behalf of the US goverenment's federal drug agency, and received £660,000 this year to investigate drug-induced photosensitivity. One drug caused the skin to react to one eightieth of the exposure to sun which was normally tolerated.

webTitle: Scissorhands musical a Disney coup for dance company

fields.headline: Scissorhands musical a Disney coup for dance company
fields.trailText: A British dance company, has landed the job of creating the next worldwide Disney mega-musical - the first non-Americans trusted with so huge an enterprise.
fields.body:
A British dance company, has landed the job of creating the next worldwide Disney mega-musical - the first non-Americans trusted with so huge an enterprise.

Adventures In Motion Pictures, which put on a ground-breaking Swan Lake featuring a flock of male swans, hopes to premiere the musical of Edward Scissorhands, from the film directed by Tim Burton, in London next year.

Burton also wrote the fable of an automaton, played by Johnny Depp in the film, taught to feel emotion by his benign scientist-creator, and has a "strong creative role" in the musical. Danny Elfman is compos ing the music, having scored most of Burton's films including the recent Sleepy Hollow.

AMP's Swan Lake was seen by a staggering 75,000 in its short run last month, and it has been credited with bringing a new audience to dance, but the Disney contract is its first attempt at musical theatre.

Choreographer Matthew Bourneand producer Katherine Dore have led AMP since their days on the fringe working out of the back of a van. She said yesterday that working for Disney on a budget likely to exceed £10m held no fears.

The company was hugely excited, she said: "Disney trust us, and know we can come up with something very special."

webTitle: Are we turning into a nation of loners?

fields.headline: Are we turning into a nation of loners?
fields.standfirst: Marriage is down, and so is childbirth. But divorce is up, along with single-person living. This is Britain today
fields.trailText: A period of unprecedented change in British family life, where adults lead more isolated lives, bringing up children on their own or not having them at all, is described in a report today. The independent Family Policy Studies Centre paints a picture of an evolving society with fewer children, fewer marriages, more divorces and more solo living, where "marriage and partnerships are much more fragile than they were".
fields.body:
A period of unprecedented change in British family life, where adults lead more isolated lives, bringing up children on their own or not having them at all, is described in a report today. The independent Family Policy Studies Centre paints a picture of an evolving society with fewer children, fewer marriages, more divorces and more solo living, where "marriage and partnerships are much more fragile than they were".

Although the government has gone further than any other in developing explicit policies for parenting and marriage, ministers should become "more in tune with contemporary family life", it says. They need to consider the effect of these changes, the report says, not just on children affected by the breakdown of adult relationships, but on society as a whole and "right across the life cycle".

The report says it is still too early to talk of the death of the "traditional family", because four-fifths of dependent children still live in a family with two parents, and nine in 10 of those parents are married. But other statistics included in the report demonstrate significant changes in family demographics with profound if, often unexplored, consequences.

More than 6.5m people in Britain - about 28% of households - now live on their own, three times as many as 40 years ago, the report says. Nearly a quarter of women born in 1973 will still be childless at the age of 45, compared with about one in 10 of those born in 1943. Women are having children later, on average at 29 rather than at 26, as in the 1970s, and they are having fewer offspring.

The average of 1.73 children per woman in the late 1990s, though higher than in most EU countries, is well below the 2.1 needed to retain the population at its present level in the long term.

Lone parents trebled

The 21% of dependent children living in lone parent households (the vast majority with their mother) has trebled from the 7% in 1972. The number of lone parents has trebled in the past 25 years - there were about 1.6m such parents and 2.8m dependent children by the mid 1990s, compared with just over 500,000 lone parents and 1m dependent children in 1971. Within that 1.6m, the fastest growing group is single, never-married lone mothers. Their proportion, 42% in 1997, is nearly double the proportion of 24% for 1984.

"Twenty years ago such women would have married only to see their relationship end in separation or divorce," the report says. "Single lone mothers should be seen as the modern equivalent of teenagers in earlier generations whose shotgun marriages failed."

The annual marriages rate is at its lowest level since records began 160 years ago. In 1961 approximately 330,000 first- time marriages and 50,000 remarriages took place. By 1997 these figures had dropped to fewer than 200,000 first-time marriages and approximately 120,000 remarriages.

Of every five marriages, two will end in divorce. More than 150,000 children under 16 experience the divorce of their parents, and if present rates continue, 28% of children under 16 will experience divorce. The cost of family breakdown to the public purse has been estimated at about £5bn a year.

But marriage is still more stable than cohabiting, with couples who live together unmarried three or four times more likely to split up. Future research will show a rise in the proportion of cohabiting couples, from the one in 10 in the most recently available figures. And the presence of children in a cohabiting relationship does not appear to reduce the breakdown rate significantly.

Although the centre itself devotes some space in its report to children, it says ministers should broaden their scope to consider the wider implications of these changes. "The impact right across the life cycle, including that on the growing numbers of older people, must be fully taken on board, as must the effect of these family changes on society," said Ceridwen Roberts, director of the centre.

Ms Roberts said: "When we just talk about children, I think this fudges the issue sometimes. We have also got to look at the effects on adults. I think the government has a responsibility to look at the full social and economic cost of relationship fragility. We need to encourage a public debate about whether those costs should be borne by private individuals, or directly and indirectly by society. If we are going to have a serious discussion about whether there is a social policy impact on relationship breakdown you can't just ignore the cost."

Through his chairing of the ministerial group on the family, Jack Straw, the home secretary, has concentrated on the impact of family breakdown on children. That is unlikely to alter. "The main part of our family policy is about ensuring children are better supported, everything springs from that," said a Home Office source.

Misconceptions

The centre recommends introduction of family impact statements, spelling out the impact of any government policy.

In its report, the centre also dispels some common misconceptions: that people living alone are not part of a family, when in fact the family remains "the key social network and primary source of informal care and support for most people"; that most non-resident fathers do not keep in contact with their children, when nearly half in 1996 saw their children at least once a week. The extended family continues to be very important, although contact with relatives has lessened, and family members are the main providers of care for elderly relatives. Grandparents are still important in childcare.

Mr Straw last week confirmed his commitment to promoting the family, but he said he wanted to "develop policies that support people in families as they really are today, not according to some outdated ideal". He thought it unlikely that the traditional nuclear family ever really existed. "This government is committed to supporting families whatever form they take. This government will not preach about marriage," he said.

Patricia Morgan, author of an Institute of Economic Affairs book entitled Farewell to the Family?, claimed the government was "anti-marriage" and too willing to accept family breakdown and lower birth rates. She said the increased number of women having children late or not at all was made up largely of graduates.

"Some people might say it is those women who should have children because a mother's education does correlate quite significantly to the child's. I think it must have an effect on the population if more intelligent women are not having children or having them in smaller numbers."

She said the number of cohabiting couples was rising fast and did not lead to secure relationships. "Most go splat," she said. It took people five years on average to find another partner, and she thought there were insufficient penalties on those who break up a marriage.

The facts of life

 There are 16.3m families in Britain

 Almost 38% of babies are born outside marriage, compared with 7.2% in 1964

 The number of children living in poverty rose from 1.4m to 4.4m between 1968 and 1998

 The number of children living in a one-parent family has nearly trebled in 25 years, from 1m to 2.8m

 More than 40% of all marriages are remarriages, compared with 20% in 1971

 150,000 children live in families of divorced couples, nearly double the 1971 figure

 The average age of mothers giving birth is 29, compared with 26 in the 1970s

 Nearly 25% of women born in 1973 are expected to be still childless at age 45

 80% of dependent children still live in a family with two parents

 More than 80% of fathers still live with their children

 The birth rate is 1.73 per woman

 Except among those aged 50 to 59, nearly 75% of people are members of families including three living generations

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Scott cocoa goes to auction
fields.body:
Scott cocoa goes to auction

Four tins of cocoa recovered from Scott of the Antarctic's doomed expedition to the South Pole are to be auctioned at Christie's in London next month. The tins of Fry's cocoa powder were found in a supply base 43 years after Captain Robert Scott perished during the mission in 1912. Eleven tins were returned to Fry's factory in Keynsham near Bristol, where they have been preserved with their original labels.

Fall in legal complaints

Complaints against barristers have dropped from 631 in 1998 to 568 in 1999, according to a report published today. In his annual report for the general council of the Bar, the independent complaints commissioner Michael Scott said that there was no feeling of "self-satisfaction".

Three win lottery jackpot

Three people shared Saturday's £12.3m rollover lottery jackpot. Each won £4.1m for matching numbers 15, 22, 23, 27, 32 and 37. The bonus number was 43. One person won the £250,000 top prize in the Thunderball game. The numbers were 15, 21, 23, 26 and 32. The Thunderball number was 11.

fields.headline: Four-part series begins today
fields.trailText: Today, the Guardian begins a four-part series looking at the experiences of desperate asylum seekers as they make their hazardous way to Britain, at their reception here, and at the bitter politics that lie behind this emotive issue.
fields.body:
The flight of millions of people driven from their homes by wars, famine and ecological disaster in recent years has thrust the question of what to do about large-scale asylum emergencies high up the political agenda of every European country.

Amid the growing clamour of tabloid press hostility, Jack Straw's radical asylum law will come into force in Britain from next Monday. It is designed to clamp down on economic migrants, and it will disperse new asylum seekers over the country and require them to live by a system of vouchers.

Today, the Guardian begins a four-part series looking at the experiences of desperate asylum seekers as they make their hazardous way to Britain, at their reception here, and at the bitter politics that lie behind this emotive issue.

fields.headline: Activists occupy Atlantic oil rig
fields.trailText: Two Greenpeace activists occupied an oil exploration rig yesterday as part of a campaign to halt drilling operations in the Atlantic off Scotland.
fields.body:
Two Greenpeace activists occupied an oil exploration rig yesterday as part of a campaign to halt drilling operations in the Atlantic off Scotland.

The group said its activists would remain on the rig until the government stopped drilling on the Atlantic Frontier, an area west of the Outer Hebrides. It wants to protect the wildlife and stop the production of more fossil fuels, which are causing global warming and climate changes.

The activists climbed aboard the Jack Bates rig in the Cromarty Firth, 20 miles north of Inverness as it prepared to leave its winter anchorage to begin drilling work.They attached themselves to one of the rig's anchors, preventing it from starting its journey. The Northern constabulary said that it was investigating an incident at the Firth and confirmed the rig had been occupied.

Greenpeace said the rig was under charter to Enterprise Oil on behalf of Enterprise, Exxon and Mobil. It added the area was Europe's most important habitat for whales and coral reefs with 21 whale and dolphin species using it for breeding and as a feeding ground.

"This drilling hits wildlife when the oil is extracted and it punishes us all when the oil is burned and climate change gets worse," Rob Gueterbock of Greenpeace said.

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry, which issues licences to explore the Atlantic Frontier, said an independent panel had concluded there was no environmental risk from oil exploration in the area. An Enterprise Oil spokesman said: "We sympathise with their right to protest but we would prefer that having made their point, they would let us get on with our legitimate operation."
