fields.headline: Minister admits drug funds error
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday admitted that it had been underfunding drug rehabilitation - a key plank of its anti-drugs strategy - as it prepared to dismiss a call to reduce cannabis possession penalties.
fields.body:
The government yesterday admitted that it had been underfunding drug rehabilitation - a key plank of its anti-drugs strategy - as it prepared to dismiss a call to reduce cannabis possession penalties.

The Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said the government would not support any relaxation in anti-drugs laws because it would send a political signal leading to an increase in cannabis consumption.

A Police Foundation report, in part funded by the government, will this week call for a relaxation of the cannabis laws by saying the maximum penalty for possession should be cut from six months in jail to a £200 fine. The report, drawn up with the advice of chief constables and Lady Runciman, the former head of the government's drugs advisory service, will also call for a downgrading of ecstasy from a Class A drug.

Mr Clarke, who has admitted to using cannabis in his youth, said: "I believe the most likely impact of a relaxation of the law in any of these areas would be to increase the consumption of those drugs, and I think that would be bad for the people concerned and bad for society."

Sixty-five people had died from using ecstasy over the past 10 years, and he ruled out an early move to allow MS sufferers to use cannabis. The Home Office would await the results of clinical trials as long as a year away. "We will only act on medical evidence," he told BBC's On the Record.

He did, however, concede that police forces were implementing the laws with different vigour in different counties and called for greater uniformity.

He admitted it was a fair criticism that across the country there were not enough rehabilitation facilities for Class A and B drugs users.

Ministers have been frequently criticised for failing to increase the number of drug treatment centres. In some places it can take a year to get on to a scheme.

fields.headline: Out of sight
fields.trailText: At Westminster, embarrassing admissions or other regrettable press releases are often slipped into the House of Commons library late on the final day before a parliamentary recess, in the hope that they will go unnoticed.
fields.body:
At Westminster, embarrassing admissions or other regrettable press releases are often slipped into the House of Commons library late on the final day before a parliamentary recess, in the hope that they will go unnoticed.

Television schedulers also look for such fox-hole moments in their programming: times when failures can be hidden away. In television's days of financial plenty, expensive disasters might be left on the video library shelf. But tighter accounting now means that everything created must eventually be screened, so that pilots for unmade series are presented as one-off comedy specials.

Controllers also face an increasingly beady media. Twenty years ago, shows succeeded or failed in relative secrecy. These days, a favourite newspaper story is that a show - whether Gormenghast or Tonight With Trevor McDonald - has failed to attract the desired audience.

So can flops still be buried? This week, BBC1 Controller Peter Salmon tries to dig two quiet graves on the same day. Cry Wolf, starring Peter Egan, (Wednesday, 11.05pm) may be rather surprised to find this day and time in brackets after its name. This surgery sit-com was launched three weeks ago at 9.30pm on Mondays. But cruel reviews and empty sofas have led Salmon to take the step, common in American television but still rare in Britain, of confiscating the slot.

The new programming of the sick doctor sit-com is preceded on BBC1 by another piece of scheduling which winks: don't watch me.

The Great Gatsby (Wednesday, 9.30pm) is a BBC remake of F Scott Fitzgerald's great myth of American money and lies, most recently filmed in Hollywood with Robert Redford and Mia Farrow, their roles taken here by Toby Stephens and Mira Sorvino.

In theory, this has the feel of prestige drama made for Sunday nights or festival schedules. So why - as a whole row of bank holidays approach - is it anonymously slotted in on a random Wednesday? The Controller of BBC1 was noticed leaving the scene with a muddy spade.

fields.headline: That thinking feeling
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: "What need is there to weep over parts of life?" asked the Roman philosopher Seneca, when a friend's child had died. "The whole of it calls for tears." The friend's response is unrecorded, and may have been violent.
fields.body:
"What need is there to weep over parts of life?" asked the Roman philosopher Seneca, when a friend's child had died. "The whole of it calls for tears." The friend's response is unrecorded, and may have been violent.

Pessimism, as advocated by Alain de Botton in Philosophy: A Guide To Happiness (Sunday, Channel 4), has never seemed so attractive. Tell yourself before breakfast that life stinks, and for the rest of the day you will bask in a rosy glow of fulfilled expectations. De Botton preached Seneca's gospel of gloom with such charm that it was impossible not to be instantly converted. Never again will the TV listings pages be flung across the room in a fury of disappointment; no, henceforth we snuggle up with Seneca and positively look forward to the next series of My Hero.

Alain de Botton is to philosophy what Delia Smith is to cookery: a sensible, practical enthusiast. Big ideas, like soufflés, are no longer stumbling blocks but simple things that can, in his words, "make a real difference".

The closing episode of Casualty (Saturday, BBC1) was also full of philosophy. We learned that "we love people and lose people - and it hurts" and that "you mustn't beat yourself up over this". Also that "the hardest thing about this job is not letting it get to you". Nobody actually said "It never rains but it pours," but they should have done, as water poured from the sky throughout the entire episode, and misery piled upon misery in a way that might have tried even Seneca's patience. A mother attempted to kill her own daughter, a haemophiliac got his knees smashed up (we were spared no detail of the wounds), a man died of pneumonia and an irritating Scottish woman wandered around reception. As if this wasn't enough, Tina (Claire Goose) and Sean (Gerald Kyd) were transported to Australia and forced to star in a dreadful Oz soap with lines like "I love you, Mrs Sean Maddox".

As ever, they saved the best till last. Just when we'd been lulled into thinking that this series of Casualty would have a happy ending, Charlie (Derek Thompson) locked himself in the toilet and had a completely unexpected heart attack. Were the attentions of the irritating Scottish woman too much to bear? Was he, too, longing for a new life in Australia? Will the next series open with the funeral cortege, the name CHARLIE picked out in used swabs? Are the producers really so worried that nobody will watch the next series unless someone's life hangs in the balance?

It could so easily have been Robson Green lying there on the cold tiles - let us not forget that he was once known as Jimmy the porter out of Casualty. That was a long time ago, though, and now Green is a big star - which is just as well, because his latest vehicle, The Last Musketeer (Sunday, ITV) was an outrageous piece of hokum that only he could have pulled off.

Green played Steve McTear, fencing champ, ex-con (he was framed) and major stud. The secret of fencing, said Steve, is "good point control", and six minutes into the film he was demonstrating his technique with a posh blonde woman in a hotel bedroom. Steve was involved with some villains (we knew they were villains because they frequented the ITV pole-dancing club) and decamped to the Scottish coast where his girlfriend ran a boarding school. Here he secured a job as a fencing master, carried on with the headmistress and fended off the horny students. But, as is the way with these things, the teacher ended up getting taught. "You don't have to be working class to feel pain," said his star pupil Emily, before attempting to indulge in a spot of extra-curricular training. "You have to know where to draw the line," said Steve.

All of which mysteriously gave him the courage to face his gangland enemies in a deeply improbably denouement up on the roof (cue for a Robson and Jerome hit on the soundtrack, sadly overlooked). In anyone else's hands, The Last Musketeer would have been hilariously awful, but thanks to Green it rattled along with good humour and tongue-in-cheek. Special mention is due to the sex scenes, which must have taken a great deal of rehearsal. When Steve and headmistress Elizabeth (Arkie Whiteley) rekindled their passion after the third advert break, she gave a look of stunned delight at the moment of engagement that more than made up for the absence of any jokes about "weapons". One longed in vain for Steve to cry "touché!".

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Jeff Goldblum in California Split (Robert Altman, 1974)
fields.body:
Jeff Goldblum in California Split (Robert Altman, 1974)

Who? Bug-eyed actor who made his name playing the insect/human hybrid hero of The Fly. His co-star, Geena Davis, was his lover at the time. She split with Goldblum and went on to marry Rene Harlin, after he dumped his girlfriend, actress Laura Dern. Dern then co-starred with Goldblum in Jurassic Park, and the two were engaged for a while. Hollywood? Weird and incestuous? Nah. Goldblum, despite his less-than-leading man looks, has actually starred in two of the biggest grossing films ever, the aforementioned dinosaur epic, and the jingoistic alien flick Independence Day. His last few pictures have been fairly dismal, and most people will be more likely to have seen his adverts for Apple computers than his cinematic offerings. But his newest project is a film by bizarre Scandivanian directing collective Traktor which also features David Hyde Pierce, Elijah Wood, Salma Hayek and Claudia Schiffer. Go figure.

The role: Lloyd Harris, publisher of the magazine that inveterate gambler George Segal, who refers to him as "the dauphin", edits.

Best Line: He only has a couple, and "Did you tell him I wanted to see him?" is about the most interesting. Shame.

Cringe factor: He's really not on screen long enough to be embarassing. But the bow-tie was ill-advised.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin calls it a "Realistic but rambling look at two compulsive gamblers, their strange lifestyles and the emptiness of winning."

Also not starring in: Death Wish, as "Freak One".

California Split, Tuesday 28 March, 8pm, Sky Cinema

fields.headline: Hall of mirrors
fields.standfirst: Michael Barrymore's new series - about a troubled TV personality - inevitably invokes the ghost of Larry Sanders.  Mark Lawson applauds the star for taking on such an ambitious, if slightly flawed, project
fields.trailText: When they were young, television and film boasted of being windows on the world, but the window now often seems to be a mirror. Two of the Oscar contenders at last night's ceremony - Magnolia and The Insider - are based around the making of television programmes. Two of the stand-out comedy characters of recent years - Alan Partridge here, Larry Sanders in America - are broadcasters.
fields.body:
When they were young, television and film boasted of being windows on the world, but the window now often seems to be a mirror. Two of the Oscar contenders at last night's ceremony - Magnolia and The Insider - are based around the making of television programmes. Two of the stand-out comedy characters of recent years - Alan Partridge here, Larry Sanders in America - are broadcasters.

And now there's Bob Martin (Sunday, 10pm, ITV), in which Michael Barrymore plays a troubled television personality trying to re-energise his career with a new show. If you chuckle that Barrymore should know all about that, you're laughing in the right place. The show does it with mirrors wherever possible.

For fans of The Larry Sanders Show - the award-winning HBO series in which Garry Shandling played a monstrous talk-show host - there is an extra level of reflections. Like the American series, Bob Martin moves between a television show on screen and the offices where the programme is created. Larry's dependency/rejection relationship with his producer Artie is recalled in Bob's conversations with his boss. Just as Larry Sanders featured stars appearing as themselves, so does Bob Martin. In the first episode, Terry Wogan, in an entertainingly sinister version of himself, thwarts Bob's attempts to take over the Eurovision commentary.

While the producers might swear that they are doing something different from Larry Sanders, even the oaths in the programme hold an echo.

Transmitted on cable in America, the Sanders show established its distinction from mainstream comedy by allowing the copulatory swear-word (a network no-no) to be spoken frequently and in full. Barrymore speaks his first f-word within minutes, and there was a tabloid story this week that his mother had forced him to remove more from the scripts.

ITV is taking two impressive risks here. The Larry Sanders Show had an adoring but very small audience in Britain, and Michael Barrymore has never acted before.

Written by Bob Mills and Jeff Pope, the show works verbally, being especially good on executive euphemism. Told by a new associate producer that their show is "interesting", the team know at once that he hates it. In turn, when this new arrival is informed that his predecessor "drank the bleach", he takes it to be a smart new ironic term for dismissal before discovering that the man killed himself with domestic cleanser. One of the "ordinary" contestants on Quickfire is so programme-savvy that she asks "can we cut there?" and "which is my camera?" The words in Bob Martin deserve only words of praise.

But all television shows depend finally on their pictures, and a programme which takes the medium as its subject even more so. The Larry Sanders Show and Alan Partridge established two essential rules for the studio spoof series: the fictional television show must look plausible on screen, and the actor playing the presenter must be able to distinguish between the character on television and life.

The Alan Partridge chat-show might just have survived for one series in the ITV regions; Larry Sanders spoke to precisely the same Hollywood celebrities (appearing as themselves) who were to be seen sitting in identical chairs on the "real" talk-shows of Jay Leno and David Letterman.

And one of the subtleties of Garry Shandling's performance was that Larry Sanders was bigger, sexier and happier on screen than in the office.

Annoyingly, given the vibrancy of the writing, Bob Martin fails on both these points. The sequences in which Bob is presenting Quickfire lack the adrenaline headiness of a television recording. No game-show host would talk so slowly. Where Larry Sanders was shot as documentary, both studio and office sequences here never feel like anything except a sit-com.

This lack of realism is particularly surprising as Barrymore has hosted game shows, but here lies the problem with the project. Keen to establish himself as an actor, Barrymore tries desperately to avoid being Michael Barrymore and to sketch in someone called Bob Martin. But Barrymore's presence would only be justified as overlap casting, with the viewer drooling at the edges between his life and the dialogue. The jokes about Larry Sanders' vanity invite the audience to ponder Shandling's possible self-love.

Bob Martin, by contrast, keeps hanging curtains in the hall of mirrors. The first episode offers no evidence of Bob's private life and gives him no demons except a slight over-estimation of his own abilities.

The disappointment of the series is that Barrymore seems desperate to show that he can escape his headline personality, while the show would work much better if he were playfully rattling the cage.

But this is stylish, grown-up television, which deserves to be watched through a series. Despite the worries above, "it worked for me", to borrow a catchphrase from Bob's producers. While it can't be called original while the memory of Larry Sanders lives on, nor - let's be quite clear - is it in any way "interesting".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A Gallup survey has calculated that British industry loses nearly £5bn annually through inadequate basic skills in its adult work force - and the most significant missing skill is the ability to read.
fields.body:
A Gallup survey has calculated that British industry loses nearly £5bn annually through inadequate basic skills in its adult work force - and the most significant missing skill is the ability to read. The education secretary has put the all-round economic cost at £10,000 million. In Illiteracy: The Great British Secret (8.0pm, Radio 4) Vivian White reports on the scale of the problem and the part it may be playing in social exclusion.

The honey bee was sufficiently well-regarded by our ancestors to feature in their cave paintings. Moreover, pots of entombed Egyptian honey have proved edible after 3,000 years. As Gerry Northam reveals in The Hive (9.0pm, Radio 4), bees developed 100 million years ago when newly-evolved flowers began attracting their carnivorous wasp ancestors to pollen, an easier source of protein. Northam is a devoted apiarist and his programme grippingly explains his fascination with the world's 30,000 varieties of apoidea.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Becker
fields.body:
Becker

9.30pm, Paramount Comedy

After a mixed-bag of post-Cheers films roles, Ted Danson is back where he belongs, in a sitcom, spouting off one-liners with ease. He plays Dr John Becker, a gruff Bronx medic who seems to hate everything and everyone around him, but still finds time to take care of his patients. Yeah, yeah, you're thinking, that old shtick. But, this has potential: dippy surgery assistant, matronly head nurse, beautiful diner owner where Becker eats all his meals; and it's fun to see Danson playing against Sam Malone's nice guy routine.

The Lady And The Tramp

(Hamilton Luske, Clyde Geronimi, Wilfred Jackson, 1955)

7pm, Disney

The love story of the prim cocker spaniel and the mutt from the wrong side of the tracks is one of Disney's most successful and enjoyable animated adventures. OK, it's sloppy as a labrador's tongue, but it's full of vivid scenes and songs, from the Siamese cats' house demolition to the canoodling over the spaghetti and Tramp's fight with the rat.

How Green Was My Valley

(John Ford, 1941)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

A long way from the Monument Valley stamping grounds of his westerns, Ford's emotive account of a turn-of-the-century South Wales mining community is one of his masterpieces. It views the hard but mutually supportive lives of the pit families through the eyes of Huw (Roddy McDowall), youngest of six children of Sara Allgood and Oscar-winning Donald Crisp.

The Gingerbread Man

(Robert Altman, 1997)

12.35am, Sky Premier

An intriguing if flawed combination of director Altman and writer John Grisham. Adapted from one of the latter's stories, it stars a miscast Kenneth Branagh as Deep South lawyer Rick Magruder, who gets into bed with, and heavily into the case of, Embeth Davidtz's Mallory: a woman with a mad dad (Robert Duvall) threatening her life. With its primal elements and neurotic characters, Altman's film tries to inject a little chaos theory into the courtroom-orderly Grisham, but the suspense goes missing.

fields.headline: Peter Ware
fields.standfirst: Technician behind the Hillman Imp, the challenger to the Mini car
fields.trailText: Peter Ware, who has died aged 81, was technical director of the Rootes Group during the 60s, when it introduced the Hillman Imp, its rival to the Mini of the British Motor Corporation.
fields.body:
Peter Ware, who has died aged 81, was technical director of the Rootes Group during the 60s, when it introduced the Hillman Imp, its rival to the Mini of the British Motor Corporation.

The Rootes Group never did quite make it in Britain's motor industry. By the end of the 50s, it was a poor third in the home market after the BMC and Ford. A prolonged and damaging strike in 1961 lost one-third of that year's production and £3m profit, a blow from which the company never really recovered. So in 1964, the American Chrysler corporation bought a stake in the Rootes Group and in 1967 took full ownership.

The company's top management, mostly members of the Rootes family, had been long accustomed to dictate product policy. For detail, it relied on the services of Bernard Winter, the long-serving, loyal and conservative technical director, who retired in 1959. His replacement was Peter Ware.

Ware had been educated at the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth, and commissioned as an engineering officer in 1936, but in 1940 he was invalided out of the Navy. He then joined the Bristol Aeroplane Company, where he worked for the visionary but mercurial Sir Roy Fedden, and followed his chief on to the Admiralty's motor torpedo boat commission.

During the second world war, Fedden gathered a small team to design a rear-engined car, which was intended to be a British world-beater. Ware was a member of this group. The F-car project ended when the single prototype crashed because of the undesirable behaviour of its suspension. On Ware's advice, Fedden stopped work on the project, and his company was liquidated in 1947.

After a short spell at Leyland, Ware worked for CAV Ltd, part of the Lucas organisation, and Dowty Fuel Systems during the 50s. He was farsightedly convinced of the merit of the fuel-injection, turbo-charged diesel engine.

In 1958, he returned to the mainstream motor industry, accepting a job at Rootes, where he soon became chief executive engineer and a director. He did not actually design the Hillman Imp. Since 1955, a small rear-engined car, the creation of Mike Parkes and Tim Fry, had been on the Rootes drawingboard. The ugly bubble car-like Slug, with an air-cooled flat-twin engine, evolved into the more acceptable Apex with styling inspired by the 1959 Chevrolet Corvair.

Leo Kuzmicki adapted an all-aluminium single overhead camshaft four cylinder Coventry Climax engine to fit the car. Rootes, unable to extend its manufacturing base in Coventry, bought a redundant railway carriage factory at Linwood, Scotland from Pressed Steel to make the new model. Ware's contribution was to replace the primitive swing axle rear suspension of the Apex car with more sophisticated trailing arms. Unhappy experiences with the Fedden car must have been fresh in his mind.

The Imp bristled with innovation and was far more refined in appearance and equipment than BMC's contemporary Mini. Rootes's lack of a small car to compete with Austin, Ford and Morris had been the biggest barrier to further growth of the company. The Imp was always a gamble, and one that failed.

It was a misjudgment to introduce a rear-engined car when this concept was becoming out of date. The car was rushed to the market and was beset by teething troubles; it never had really competed with the ubiquitous Mini. And Ware, who had become the champion of the project on the Rootes board and in public, might have carried the can. Production problems and labour troubles at the Linwood factory could not be blamed on him, however.

But his next project, a medium-sized car with a rear engine, was shelved. A single prototype of this, the Swallow survives in the Museum of British Road Transport in Coventry. It was replaced by the Arrow range, launched as the Hillman Hunter in 1966, a conventional Ford Cortina look-alike saloon. It did well in the market, and enjoyed a long life as the Peykan, built in Iran, but could not save Rootes from being taken over by Chrysler.

By the takeover, Ware had left the company. Possibly disillusioned with future prospects under Chrysler, he took an appointment with Dunlop, where he worked on the Maxaret anti-skid braking system. He retired in 1977, but continued as a consulting engineer. The Imp had gone out of production a year earlier, with a total output of only 440,000 cars. fields.bodyText: Peter Ware, who has died aged 81, was technical director of the Rootes Group during the 60s, when it introduced the Hillman Imp, its rival to the Mini of the British Motor Corporation. The Rootes Group never did quite make it in Britain's motor industry. By the end of the 50s, it was a poor third in the home market after the BMC and Ford. A prolonged and damaging strike in 1961 lost one-third of that year's production and £3m profit, a blow from which the company never really recovered. So in 1964, the American Chrysler corporation bought a stake in the Rootes Group and in 1967 took full ownership. The company's top management, mostly members of the Rootes family, had been long accustomed to dictate product policy. For detail, it relied on the services of Bernard Winter, the long-serving, loyal and conservative technical director, who retired in 1959. His replacement was Peter Ware. Ware had been educated at the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth, and commissioned as an engineering officer in 1936, but in 1940 he was invalided out of the Navy. fields.headline: Hussein Issa
fields.standfirst: Founder of a school teaching peace to Palestinians and Israelis
fields.trailText: Hussein Ibrahim Issa, who has died aged 52 of a heart attack, quietly practised Arab-Israeli reconciliation near Bethlehem. He was the founder and principal of the Hope Flowers school, where underprivileged Palestinian children could meet, befriend, learn from and educate their Israeli counterparts.
fields.body:
Hussein Ibrahim Issa, who has died aged 52 of a heart attack, quietly practised Arab-Israeli reconciliation near Bethlehem. He was the founder and principal of the Hope Flowers school, where underprivileged Palestinian children could meet, befriend, learn from and educate their Israeli counterparts.

Issa brought numerous volunteers to Hope Flowers, convened symposiums of rabbis, priests and imams, ran democracy workshops on the eve of the first Palestinian elections, and attracted visits from the likes of Hillary Rodham Clinton. He even built an onsite farm to generate income and liberate his school from debt.

Issa's lack of bitterness was remarkable, considering his own upbringing. He was born into a Muslim family in Ramle, a town built in the 8th century as capital of Ummayad Palestine, and was just two months old in November 1947, when the UN voted to divide British Mandate territory into two states, one predominantly Jewish and the other Arab. Within a year, the family was expelled from Ramle and went to the Deheishe refugee camp where conditions were severe. They were poor and wretched. The experience inspired Issa to make sure that society should take care of its children.

He graduated with a BA in social work from Bethlehem university in 1979; the following year, he added an education diploma.

Most Palestinians wanted nothing to do with Israel. Yet Issa believed that only mutual understanding and self-sufficiency could restore Palestinian dignity. "Peace and democracy education should be given to infants with their mother's milk," he once wrote. In 1984, he founded a child care centre, al-Amal (the Hope) in al-Khader, west of Bethlehem; one rented room, 22 pupils and no chairs. Within five years it had grown into both a primary and secondary school, known as Hope Flowers.

Issa never felt constrained by traditions or borders. He led mothers and children on trips across the green line (the 1967 border between Israel and the West Bank), arguing that "Israeli and Palestinian destinies are inevitably tied. [We] have no choice but to work together to try and forge a peaceful coexistence."

His young Muslim and Christian pupils mixed with Jewish children at Jerusalem's Waldorf School and the Democratic School of Hadera. Together, they demolished stereotypes. But although students learned reconciliation in class, they experienced disruption on the streets. The Intifada of 1987 left many households without income to pay school fees. When public transport broke down, Issa picked up his students and drove them to school. After terrorism in Israel resulted in border closures, Issa condemned the "heinous" policies of both Hamas and Israeli "collective punishment". Settlers from nearby Efrat began encroaching on property owned by al-Khader's residents, with the full blessing of the Israeli government. Issa found another way to alleviate his students' frustration by reconnecting them to nature. Hence his field trips to Dead Sea reserves and Jericho, and training on the Hope farm.

The 1993 Oslo negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation brought new impetus to his work. Suddenly the programmes for peace-building and democracy became relevant to adults as well. In 1996, the school hosted enthusiastic meetings about the value of voting before the first Palestinian Council elections, and introduced candidates to parents. Issa also created an internet site.The publicity improved links with Israelis at the Peres Centre, the Givat Haviva Educational Centre, the Open House in Ramle, and the Arab/Jewish peace village, Neve Shalom.

By then, 28 Israeli and American volunteers regularly travelled to al-Khader to teach Hebrew, raise chickens, cultivate herbs and build another storey to the ever-growing school. However, Issa's cost-cutting exercises led to clashes with Israeli officials, who threatened to demolish his unauthorised renovations. The nascent Palestinian Authority did not subsidise the school.

Issa was a tireless campaigner, forever thinking up new schemes. He envisaged a teachers' course on how the Holocaust led Jews to crave a homeland of their own. Despite dealing daily with the results of historical tragedy, he was always sunny and loved a good joke.

Education for Issa covered all aspects of life, and determined attitudes to other people. He was succoured by his devoted family and his religion. His legacy will be the children whose lives he enriched, and who he infused "with the importance, beauty and necessity of peace".

He is survived by his wife, Hind Issa, and five children.

fields.headline: Hard man of the party
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble managed a pleasantry with his old friend David Burnside on Saturday as his Ulster Unionist Council meeting lurched from serious setback to disaster. But he was masking deep disappointment, and the British Airways public relations chief was to blame.
fields.body:
David Trimble managed a pleasantry with his old friend David Burnside on Saturday as his Ulster Unionist Council meeting lurched from serious setback to disaster. But he was masking deep disappointment, and the British Airways public relations chief was to blame.

Mr Burnside, 48, from Ballymoney, Co Antrim, had rebuffed all approaches to withdraw his motion seeking to rule out participation in a future government with Sinn Fein unless Peter Mandleson, the Northern Ireland secretary, kept the RUC's name. He had withdrawn a similar approach at a council meeting in February.

Lord Cranborne, the Tory peer and his long-term friend, had criticised him for his motion. So too had the current RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan.

Mr Burnside, though, was an important ally for Mr Trimble in the negotiations leading to the Good Friday agreement, and he still supports it. But the issue of policing cuts across the agreement, he says, and is keenly felt within the party.

Mr Burnside said last night: "I am no behind-the-scenes puppeteer. I am involved no more or less than I have ever been in 30 years in Unionist politics. I work in London, but Northern Ireland is my home, and I am back here every other week.

"I have a good relationship with David Trimble, and will continue to do so. It is important people realise how Unionists feel on this issue."

He stood first as a candidate while a student at Queen's University, losing in the elections to the Northern Ireland assembly. He also lost in in the 1982 assembly elections for north Antrim. Working in London weighed heavily against him.

He founded Friends of the Union, based in London, after the Anglo-Irish agree ment was adopted in 1985. He despised it as much as the framework document of 10 years later, regarded as a more pro-nationalist document than the agreement, and was accused of leaking it to the Times.

Mr Burnside, a former part-time member of the now defunct Ulster Defence Regiment, was press officer in the Vanguard movement, remaining loyal to its leader, William Craig, with Mr Trimble when others defected.

He later sealed a job as press officer at the Institute of Directors, admiring the portraits of Cromwell and William III. He joked: "With those on the walls, you can't fail to give me a job."

He moved on to British Airways, a director at the age of 33. He and Lord King, another caustic character, got on famously well. During the dirty tricks campaign BA was accused of cold-calling Virgin customers and persuading them to switch to BA, spreading harmful stories about the financial state of Branson's airline and using private investigators.

Mr Burnside resigned as BA's director of public affairs in the wake of the Virgin row, although he received a pay-off believed to be in the region of £500,000.

He is seen as a hard man - the cold blue eyes are his most mentioned feature - and he is regarded with some scepticism within the Ulster Unionist party. One delegate admitted that his business successes in London were one reason for the suspicion.

He now runs his own companies working in public relations, publishing and political lobbying.

fields.headline: Charles Ford
fields.standfirst: Trade union leader who foresaw the coming of the multinationals and first proposed the social clause
fields.trailText: Twenty-five years before demonstrators closed down last November's World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle, Charles Ford, who has died aged 76, was demanding that international trade and labour standards be linked.
fields.body:
Twenty-five years before demonstrators closed down last November's World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle, Charles Ford, who has died aged 76, was demanding that international trade and labour standards be linked.

Ford was one of the first trade union leaders to foresee the impact of globalisation on workers. He realised that the International Labour Organisation needed new teeth; he coined the phrase "the social clause" when he proposed that all international trade agreements make participation in world markets dependent on respect for basic workers' rights, including the freedom of association.

Ford's experience as general secretary of the International Textile, Garment and Leather Workers' Federation, coupled with his earlier work at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, made him a powerful proponent of international regulation of multinational companies, which were just beginning to drive the globalisation process. He was appalled at the multinationals' growing exploitation of workers, including women and children. He became a lead player in formulating and promoting the ILO's declaration of principles on multinational enterprises and social policy and in the development of the OECD's guidelines for multinational enterprise.

Ford was born to working-class parents in Hackney, east London, and won a London County Council scholarship to the Central School of Arts and Crafts; two years later, just short of his 16th birthday, he became a learner engraver at the Royal Mint. Although poor eyesight soon forced him to abandon this career, he maintained a lifelong interest in art and sculpture. While working for the Czechoslovakian government-in-exile in 1940, he began a series of evening classes at which Professor Barbara Wootton encouraged him to pursue his interest in economics. After intensive study, he gained admission to the London School of Economics, graduating in 1949.

Ford began his trade union career as a research economist with the Amalgamated Engineering Union. He was politically active, campaigning, writing, and lecturing for the Workers Educational Association. In the 1951 general election, he fought Wimbledon for Labour, and in 1955, Bournemouth West. Both times he was unsuccessful.

Time working on the reconstruction of Yugoslavia at the end of the second world war aroused his interest in internationalism, and in 1957 he went to work in Paris, at the trade union liaison office for the Marshall plan; he was important to the transformation of this into the Trade Union Advisory Committee (TUAC) to the OECD in 1962. He was instrumental in moving the direction of its work from promoting a trade union vision of the post-war reconstruction process to managing economies in an era of Keynesian policies and full employment. Later, he became assistant secretary, and then general secretary, of TUAC. He also served as secretary and later, general secretary, of the International Federation of the European regional organisation of the Free Trade Unions.

Ford was elected general secretary of the International Textile, Garment and Leather Workers' Federation in 1971 and set about making it into an effective, highly influential, global organisation with a high profile, particularly at the ILO. Ford travelled extensively, helping create and develop unions, building a training network, giving hope to exploited workers and often incurring the wrath of unscrupulous employers. When he retired in 1988, the federation had doubled its membership and represented 5m workers.

Ford was compassionate and charming; his friendship was freely given and never withdrawn. He transmitted his deep commitment to the workers' cause with a light touch and with recollections from all over the world. He was probably the only union leader arrested by the KGB for forgetting to leave his room key with the reception desk on leaving his Moscow hotel.

He is survived by three daughters and by his partner Patricia, with whom he found great happiness.

fields.headline: Unionists deliver ultimatum to Trimble
fields.standfirst:
RUC reform raises hackles of veteran campaigner as leader faces new challenge if he cuts Sinn Fein deal

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement last night promised another leadership challenge to David Trimble within months if he attempts to negotiate a return to a power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein before the IRA begins to decommission its weapons.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement last night promised another leadership challenge to David Trimble within months if he attempts to negotiate a return to a power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein before the IRA begins to decommission its weapons.

They suspect that Mr Trimble might try to cut a deal before May 22, the deadline in the agreement seeking the completion of all decommissioning, and embark on a final showdown with his party's ruling Ulster Unionist Council. They say that this time they will mount a concerted campaign, with the Lagan Valley MP, Jeffrey Donaldson, as their likely candidate.

Philip Weir, the leader of the Young Unionists, said last night: "We are ready to roll at a moment's notice. We have built up a complex database to target delegates, and it worked well for the two days of Martin Smyth's campaign."

Mr Smyth sent shock waves through the Trimble camp and the Northern Ireland peace process when he won 43% of the vote at Saturday's council meeting in south Belfast. He had announced he was standing against Mr Trimble only two days earlier.

Mr Trimble's woes intensified later when David Burnside, a businessman, forced through a motion that ties any return to government with Sinn Fein to the retention of the RUC's name and symbols. One delegate said: "The first vote tied Trimble's hands; the second cut them off."

The votes underlined the shift within unionism, including the Democratic Unionist party and other fringe groups. It split 55 to 45 in favour of the agreement during the referendum two years ago, but political pundits now believe that less than 40% back the Good Friday deal.

Mr Trimble's comments in Washington on St Patrick's Day that he would consider going back into government with Sinn Fein before the IRA decommissioned, provided he was convinced that decommissioning would quickly follow, were an international public relations triumph, but backfired badly at home.

Mr Smyth, 68, who polled much more strongly than the 35% the Trimble camp had feared, said last night that the Ulster Unionist leader could no longer refuse to take note of his MPs' views if he wanted to avoid another challenge. Six of the party's 10 MPs oppose the agreement.

Mr Smyth, the party's chief whip at Westminster, said: "I have advised him time and time again, privately, not only what the parliamentary party were thinking but what people in the country were thinking, and he went in other directions and did not really consult us. He will have to face up to that responsibility."

Mr Trimble has been re-elected but 60 delegates can force a no-confidence motion, and he has already promised to bring any plan to join the Northern Ireland government back to the ruling council.

His team was last night lamenting the party's archaic voting system, which accords 120 out of 858 votes to the Orange Order. Mr Smyth is a former grand master of the order.

There is no stipulation that Orangemen must be members of the party, and the leadership is to attempt to force through reform in the next few months. That would spark a fearsome row, but if won would make Mr Trimble's life much easier.

Mr Donaldson, at 37 the UUP's youngest MP - Mr Trimble is 55 - warned last night: "The party will have to be very careful that it does not do anything which will further divide the party. This is a time for reuniting and consolidation."

Mr Smyth, 68, who polled much more strongly than the 35% the Trimble camp had feared, said last night that the Ulster Unionist leader could no longer refuse to take note of his MPs' views if he wanted to avoid another challenge. Six of the party's 10 MPs oppose the agreement. Mr Smyth, the party's chief whip at Westminster, said: "I have advised him time and time again, privately, not only what the parliamentary party were thinking but what people in the country were thinking, and he went in other directions and did not really consult us. He will have to face up to that responsibility." Mr Trimble has been re-elected but 60 delegates can force a no-confidence motion, and he has already promised to bring any plan to join the Northern Ireland government back to the ruling council. His team was last night lamenting the party's archaic voting system, which accords 120 out of 858 votes to the Orange Order. Mr Smyth is a former grand master of the order. There is no stipulation that Orangemen must be members of the party, and the leadership is to attempt to force through reform in the next few months. That would spark a fearsome row, but if won would make Mr Trimble's life much easier. Mr Donaldson, at 37 the UUP's youngest MP - Mr Trimble is 55 - warned last night: "The party will have to be very careful that it does not do anything which will further divide the party. This is a time for reuniting and consolidation."

fields.trailText:
Police find more cult remains
Police believe they may have uncovered another mass grave linked to the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult after finding human remains behind the home of one of the cult's leaders, Father Dominic Kataribabo.

Police believe they may have uncovered another mass grave linked to the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult after finding human remains behind the home of one of the cult's leaders, Father Dominic Kataribabo.

Fr Kataribabo is the only one of four leaders known to have died in the March 17 fire at the group's headquarters at Kanungu.
Anna Borzello, Kampala

Seven dead in rafting tragedy
Seven people are known to have died and six remain missing after a flash flood catapulted 22 white-water rafters down rapids in the Storms river gorge, near Uitenhage in South Africa, on Saturday.

Rescuers braved sheer cliffs and a raging torrent yesterday in the search for survivors of one of the worst disasters to hit adventure tourism in South Africa.
AP, Johannesburg

Filipinos file war suits
Thousands of Filipinos will file a lawsuit against Japanese companies which allegedly forced them into slave labour during the second world war, a lawyer said yesterday.

Rod Domingo said the lawsuit will be consolidated with similar cases filed in California by former prisoners and civilians from Australia, Canada, China, England, Scotland and the Netherlands.
AP, Manila

Kashmir rebels kill soldier
Islamic militants hiding in a mosque fired at an Indian army cordon in Kashmir, killing one soldier, the army said yesterday. Three rebels were killed trying to escape.

The militants had taken shelter inside the mosque after they were spotted by soldiers patrolling near the town, 48 miles north of Srinagar.
AP, Srinagar

Inmates escape with guard
After three years in jail, the former governor of Afghanistan's western Herat province, Ismail Khan, and the son of another former governor escaped from Taliban custody in southern Kandahar yesterday, officials said. A guard they bribed escaped with them, the Taliban said.
AP, Islamabad

webTitle: British bribes get general the sack

fields.headline: British bribes get general the sack
fields.trailText: The former commander of the Papua New Guinea defence force, Major General Jerry Singirok, has been recommended for dismissal from the force for accepting a £31,000 bribe from a London-based defence contractor.
fields.body:
The former commander of the Papua New Guinea defence force, Major General Jerry Singirok, has been recommended for dismissal from the force for accepting a £31,000 bribe from a London-based defence contractor.

The general, who aborted a mercenary contract between the government and the British military company Sandline International in 1997, was ruled to have made serious breaches of the country's leadership code by accepting the money from J & S Franklin, one of Britain's leading defence suppliers and arms brokers.

The money was paid into a Visa account for the general's personal use at the Pall Mall branch of Lloyds Bank in London between April 1996 and February 1997.

Justice Moses Jalina, who presided over the judicial tribunal, said: "The commander of the armed forces is someone very special to the people of his country.

"People go about their lives with confidence that the armed forces are commanded by someone who has not secretly compromised their country's sovereignty.

"But when he conducts himself in a way that brings his integrity into question, especially when bribes are accepted from foreigners, the people's trust and confidence in their commander is eroded."

The general was originally charged with sedition, but the scandal led to elections and the country's new government substituted five charges under the leadership code.

The purpose of the bribes has been hotly disputed. Just before the first major transfer, Papua New Guinea's defence department paid Franklin £144,000 in settlement of an outstanding debt. The general denied the bribe was a reward for this.

webTitle: Riot at funeral of police victim

fields.headline: Riot at funeral of police victim
fields.standfirst:
Politicians wrangle after thousands protest at killing of fourth unarmed black man by NYPD in 13 months

Gun violence in the US: special report
fields.trailText: Four mourners and 23 police officers were injured this weekend when violence erupted at the funeral of the fourth unarmed black man to be shot dead by New York police in 13 months.
fields.body:
Four mourners and 23 police officers were injured this weekend when violence erupted at the funeral of the fourth unarmed black man to be shot dead by New York police in 13 months.

The row over the death has now emerged as a major campaign issue in the senatorial race between the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, and the First Lady, Hillary Clinton.

Patrick Dorismond, 25, a security guard who was the son of a Haitian immigrant, was killed on March 16 in a struggle with undercover drug squad officers engaged in a "buy and bust" operation outside a bar in Manhattan.

The funeral procession had started peacefully in the streets of Brooklyn on Saturday, with thousands following the coffin and lining the streets. But trouble began as the cortege arrived at a Roman Catholic church.

Some of the 5,000-strong crowd surged towards the church as the pallbearers removed the coffin, draped with US and Haitian flags, from the hearse. Several snatched the US flag and burned it.

Throughout the funeral, the crowd outside was hostile but relatively peaceful, confining its anger to shouts of derision against the mayor and the police, who now numbered about 300 officers in helmets and other riot gear.

Later, as the funeral ended and the procession set off for a cemetery, scuffling broke out between protesters and the police. People on fire escapes and in windows began hurling bottles on to the street. The police formed a human barricade, and officers used their batons to knock down flying glass.

A total of 27 people were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct offences.

The Rev Al Sharpton, who has been associated with the family since the shooting, did not condone the violence but said he blamed the police for provoking the fighting by arriving dressed in riot gear.

Mr Giuliani, who did not attend the scene, visited injured officers in hospital afterwards. "Police officers should receive the thanks of the entire community in the face of sustained hostility and abuse," he said.

"Unfortunately, when you allow demagogues to take over for political and divisive purposes, the American flag gets shredded and burned, steel barricades are hurled and bottles are thrown, injuring police officers and civilians."

Over the weekend, Detective Anthony Vasquez, the officer who shot Dorismond, issued a statement in which he expressed his sympathy.

"On behalf of my family and myself I wish to extend our heartfelt condolences to [the dead man's mother] and the Dorismond family. As a father and a son, I can only imagine the depth of your grief. Our prayers are with you at this sorrowful hour."

Dorismond had no drugs in his possession when he was shot to death during a scuffle with Det Vasquez.

Lawyers for Det Vasquez, who has now been assigned to desk duty, claim that the police officer's gun went off accidentally.

Part of the reason for the anger over the shooting has been connected with the decision by Mr Giuliani to release details of Dorismond's record, dating back to an arrest when he was 13. The dead man had been arrested in the past for robbery, attempted robbery, assault and illegal weapons possession but had been charged with the much lesser offence of disorderly conduct.

Following his death, the mayor had said that Dorismond was "no altar boy" and "had spent a good deal of his life punching people". This angered the dead man's friends and family as it was seen as a justification for his death.

Hillary Clinton, Mr Giuliani's opponent in the senate race this November, condemned his stance

"At just the moment when a real leader would have reached out to heal the wounds, he has chosen divisiveness," she said.

Mr Giuliani responded by accusing her of reading from a script prepared for her by Mr Sharpton.

fields.headline: Britain urges new bio-weapons deal
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain appealed to the international community yesterday to confront the key obstacles to a breakthrough in long drawn-out negotiations for an effective agreement outlawing biological weapons.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain appealed to the international community yesterday to confront the key obstacles to a breakthrough in long drawn-out negotiations for an effective agreement outlawing biological weapons.

Speaking on the 25th anniversary of the existing biological weapons convention - an agreement with many loopholes - Mr Hain said it was time to make "crunch decisions at a political level".

Britain and South Africa have taken a leading role in talks in Geneva for a new protocol which would lay down effective verification measures, which are lacking in the current convention.

A tougher agreement is becoming increasingly urgent because of the growth of the biotechnology industry, whose products can be used for medical and agriculture purposes, but also for what Mr Hain called "a deadly weapon of mass destruction".

The EU says a new protocol is needed to force states and companies to declare their production of biological and toxin agents, and to allow random inspections.

In the past the US biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries have objected to on-site inspections, claiming commercial confidentiality.

webTitle: Bhutan's net venture opens door to world

fields.headline: Bhutan's net venture opens door to world
fields.trailText: The remote Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan yesterday went a step further in casting off its reputation for isolationism with the opening of the country's first internet cafe.
fields.body:
The remote Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan yesterday went a step further in casting off its reputation for isolationism with the opening of the country's first internet cafe.

The cafe, in the capital Thimphu, offers internet access, email, printing and scanning facilities to the tiny Buddhist nation, which launched its first television station less than a year ago.

"The cafe is a place where students can bring their own software and either entertain themselves or learn something," Umesh Pradhan, the Internet Cafe's proprietor told Bhutan's official - and sole - newspaper, Kuensel.

Mr Pradhan said the cafe was a good way of interesting the public in the IT revolution, but admitted that most of Bhutan's estimated 600,000 people - many of them subsistence farmers - could not afford the rates for internet access.

"It is expensive for us also because at the moment there is not a lot of business and most people just use the internet for a few minutes to send email," he said.

webTitle: Istanbul at risk from oil tanker boom

fields.headline: Istanbul at risk from oil tanker boom
fields.trailText: The number of oil tankers passing through the Bosphorus straits will more than double in the next five years, raising the chances of a catastrophic collision in one of the world's most populous cities, an environmental conference was warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The number of oil tankers passing through the Bosphorus straits will more than double in the next five years, raising the chances of a catastrophic collision in one of the world's most populous cities, an environmental conference was warned yesterday.

Fears of a disaster have been growing as more vessels - triggered by the boom in Azerbaijan's oilfields - navigate the twisting channel between Istanbul's European and Asian shores. Most of the tankers are Russian, loading up with oil from Russian and Georgian pipeline terminals.

A spate of accidents in the last decade has heightened concerns about the dangers for Istanbul, which has a population of at least 10m. Many people live close to the waterway, which is always thronged with ferries, pleasure boats and fishing vessels.

Just after Christmas, a tanker ran aground and spilt 800 tonnes of diesel oil, which the authorities are still clearing up. In 1991, the Bosphorus was shut for 10 days after a Lebanese ship carrying 22,000 sheep sank following a collision with a Philippine vessel.

The Black Sea Borders conference, convened in Istanbul by the British Council, brought together British activists and environmental groups from the region. Among the speakers was the former Conservative minister, John Gummer, who runs an environmental consultancy.

"We are expecting traffic to double by the year 2005 because of the Caspian oil boom," Aykut Turker, of the Turkish group Society of Peace with Nature, said at the conference.

Fifty million tonnes of cargo pass through the Bosphorus every year. Vessels are not obliged to hire local pilots familiar with the treacherous currents. Mr Turker claimed that 85% of recent accidents involved ships which had tried to save money by not using a pilot.

Gulnur Tumbat, a researcher at the Middle East University in Ankara, said: "The Bosphoros handles three times as many ships as the Suez canal, has numerous blind curves where ships cannot see each other approaching, and 12 abrupt turns."

Turkey has been lobbying hard to encourage oil companies to support the construction of a much longer pipeline that would transport crude oil direct to Ceyhan by its Mediterranean coast.

The issue is moving up the international political agenda, but the costs - estimated at £2.3bn - are so high that neither Georgia nor Azerbaijan is prepared to start work without Turkish subsidies.

Turkey's commercial rivals in Russia and elsewhere claim the dangers to the Bosphorus are being talked up in order to make the Baku-Ceyhan pipeline appear more attractive.

But Professor Laurence Mee, of Plymouth University, who wrote a report entitled How to Save the Black Sea, yesterday added his voice at the conference to concerns about excessive shipping in the straits.

"Transporting this oil bonanza from the Caspian to the west by sea is a cheap way of doing it," he said. "It starts out free but someone pays the cost if anything goes wrong and there is a major accident."

Engin Ural, secretary general of the Environment Foundation of Turkey, wanted swift action. "Our country is very sensitive about this traffic but it is time to use our sovereignty and control the shipping," he said. "We can't stop vessels but we can slow them down. Perhaps we should only let one tanker through every two hours or so."

webTitle: Confessions of a cad: Greg Martin

fields.headline: Confessions of a cad: Greg Martin
fields.standfirst: George Martin's eldest son is more famous for his philandering than his acting career. And his new memoir isn't likely to change that.
fields.trailText: George Martin's eldest son is more famous for his philandering than his acting career. And his new memoir isn't likely to change that.
fields.body:
I have a weakness for Latin women," says Greg Martin, halfway through my glass of wine. "I love Latin women. I'm engaged now to an Italian girl. I just love people like that. And I mean, I'm a man. Like Zorba the Greek said, 'Aren't I a man? Aren't I stupid?' You know, I've got a libido. And when Tara walked in with Elton John that night, in that bikini and white sarong, she looked incredible. And she was really funny. She said Mick Jagger had said, 'Wanna come to Reykjavik with me?' and she'd said, 'I'll come if you can spell it.' And he said: 'I dunno. There's an "h" in there somewhere.' I thought that's very witty. She's witty."

He drinks the other half of my wine. "Oh, sorry," he says and returns to his own. He puffs his lips out in a noisy sigh. He rolls his denim-blue eyes. " But I had no idea what I was getting into . I wish I'd known she was straight out of rehab. She's sweet but she's loopy, an overindulged, spoilt brat. Two weeks later I'm knocked for six. I'm a scumbag, serial-philandering pig. I'm a creepy Casanova. I'm a con man. Twice in the Daily Mail Tara called me a con man. I'd like to see her prove that in court."

Greg Martin, 43, the eldest son of the record producer Sir George Martin, is the "failed actor" ("What is a failed actor? Is a failed actor someone who's starred in a mini-series with Richard Burton and Faye Dunaway, who's done over 60 plays all over the world?") who didn't marry Tara Palmer-Tomkinson last summer.

They met at Jagger's 56th birthday party in the south of France. Martin was with another socialite, Sabrina Guinness (he calls me Sabrina a couple of times and winces). But minutes later, Palmer-Tomkinson, who had been making an It of herself, had scrawled "Tara's getting married" in lipstick on her handbag and the papers were full of their whirlwind romance.

It was all over with the summer sales. Too many Latin women in the woodwork, not to mention American, Russian and Chinese, willing to sell their stories for the right price. Too many former marriages (one more than he had admitted to, anyway). Too many enemies. Maybe not quite enough money in the bank. Palmer-Tomkinson retreated to the bosom of her royally connected family. The portcullis came down. Society turned its back. And Martin, an ordinary red-blooded bachelor ("Before all the names, I honestly, honestly, honestly, from my heart, thought I was pretty normal. I've always loved women, I adore the little darlings, and I thought most men were the same") found himself, alone, in his rented flat in Knightsbridge, with certain "business ventures" in ruins, branded Love Rat, the James Hewitt of the Tatler-meets-Hello! reading classes.

He's written a book now, a memoir called Dirty Rotten Scoundrel. As an attempt to re-establish his reputation it's a disaster. A diary of his years at Rada and in the film and TV business in the US (among other things, he starred in Ellis Island, and co-starred in Ellen) as well as the events of last year, it is full of "birds" and "horny little slappers", of "sexy young blueblood vixens", and "gorgeous, sweet, hot-as-a-chilli-pepper-ridden-chicken-vindaloo beauties".

There is the time he slept with Madonna. The night he couldn't get it up with Sharon Stone. Tara and her G-string. But he has his defences ready. He said Tara stormed round recently and said, "'How dare you exploit our relationship for your own publicity ends?' and I said, 'Excuse me, isn't that the way you've lived your life?'"

When I told him I found some of it a bit dubious, he said, "Come on Sabrina, it's witty, it's humorous, it's tongue in cheek. I'm sending myself up. You know that." I got off lightly. Further down the bottle of wine, he tells me a female reviewer who didn't like it "is probably a lonely middle-aged woman who can't get laid".

So why does one feel sorry for him? Is it because he looks identical to his father, the same stooping, lopsided gait, the same flop of hair, though the son dyes his ("Yes, I do. So what? I've got bits of like silver in it and I'm too young. David Beckham dyes his"), the same prominent cheekbones and Adam's apple? The same charm: walking down the street, he greets the flower-stall man and the Evening Standard vendor by name; he introduces me to the bloke who sells him cigarettes; when he smiles at the waitress in the wine bar, she giggles. Or is it because this resemblance is his downfall?

Greg Martin may not have been what he appeared to be to the Palmer-Tomkinsons, but then he appears to be his father, whom he certainly isn't. George Martin: the English icon, the man who produced the Beatles in the maelstrom of the 60s and yet remained the embodiment of gentlemanliness and restraint. Just what an It Girl needs. "He's a god," says his son simply.

Or perhaps it's because he seems so isolated from the man he talks about all the time. Later, when we go back to his flat, there is one CD out on top of the stereo. The Beatles: 1967-70. Greg is from George Martin's first marriage, which finished when he was five. There is another son, the good son, who works with his dad, from the second. Did he feel usurped?

He suddenly forgets he's being interviewed, stops posturing. He says he was "over-sensitive" as a young man, "never felt he was good enough". He talks about how "wounded" his old mum was. "Maybe that's why I'm drawn to slightly off kilter women. Ha. Ha. Ha." He talks about his stepmother with the rawness of a teenager. He can't believe his father didn't speak up for him last year. "He could have said something and he didn't," says Martin. "It wasn't simply because he chose to maintain a distance. I think he was frightened. He was made frightened by those around him. All I'll say about my dad," he says, "is that if anybody appears to be pure as the driven snow don't believe it. If anyone appears to be the devil don't believe that either. Nobody is one or the other."

His family nickname is Poggy. What does his father call him? "Greg," he says coldly. We go back to his flat so he can give me some information about his new film company, Independence Films, and a tape of his appearance on Ellen.

On the way, he talks about the recent story in the Express claiming his mother's house has been put in his name with a mortgage taken out on it. "She did that of her own volition," he says. Though, he admits, his sister now isn't talking to him. He seems to have a habit of making enemies close to home. There are other family members out to get him, he says, "including someone who's a prominent silk. Put that in. I want him to know I'm on to him."

These are his real enemies he says. Not "Tara, who is a bit player in a drama that is nothing to do with her, a spear carrier". And what's the motive? "I'm sorry to say, absolute malice and jealousy. Jealousy. Jealousy. Jealousy." Jealousy of what? "My apparent prodigious success with women." He chuckles.

Martin's flat is plain and featureless. It is brightened by two things: lots of photographs of his son, Connor, who lives in New Hampshire with his ex-wife, with whom he is on good terms. (His other marriage was arranged to secure a green card.) And a 24-year-old Italian girl called Vittoria, who is curled up on a chair saying "Good Morning. Good Afternoon" into a tape recorder. They are getting married in Rome later this year, though Martin must first convert to Catholicism. He is in the process of getting his two previous marriages annulled. Can you get two marriages annulled? "Yeah," he says shortly. Then adds, "Hey. I hope so."

This relationship is going to last, he says. No more philandering. No more screwing around. Does he worry at all about the age difference? "You think she's too young? For me? In your opinion?" he barks. "Look at Salman Rushdie. Look at Michael Douglas. Look at John Paul Getty. Vittoria is amazing. She's got the mind of a businesswoman. She thinks the book's hysterical. She's proud of my past. I bet someone will say he's only with this girl to clean up his image, but I feel in all honesty she is my reward for last year. The secret of a good relationship is that the person is your best friend and I've never had that. Until now." He pauses. "Obviously a good sex life helps," he says. "Personally, I couldn't have a good relationship without that."

If in any doubt about their future together, about the laying of his past, he has the stars to help him. Martin is a firm believer in astrology. He says, looking at his chart, he should have seen what he was getting into last summer. "It's as clear as daylight. Aquarius with Scorpio rising. Public crisis." As for the future, he's got a dodgy few days this week, but the beginning of April, when his book is published, is going to be good for him - and a "lousy time" for his enemies. "So I'm looking forward to that."

He also believes in reincarnation. Who does he think he'll come back as next time? "Ha ha ha ha," he laughs. "The Dalai Lama?"

fields.headline: No: 1602 William of Warenne
fields.trailText: Age: Getting on.
fields.body:
Age: Getting on.

Occupation: Getting on.

Appearance: Martial.

Status: Britain's richest person.

An internet trillionaire presumably? No, don't think so.

Owner of a media empire? The odd tapestry perhaps.

Something in the City? Yes - Bayeux.

Dealer in bonds? Strictly feudal.

OK, that's enough stupid questions. I know there's a catch to this. Wealthy William's dead, right? Very smart. He died in 1088 but has belatedly been voted wealthiest Brit of the millennium in the Sunday Times richest of the rich list.

How so, my liege? Simple, serf. He came over with his namesake, the Conqueror, and a bunch of other Norman ne'er-do-wells, won 3-0 at Hastings, did a bit of pillaging and divided the country up with his cronies. He got the stockbrokery bits of southern England, which even then were worth a lot more than distant Derbyshire and Durham.

Poor transport links? Delays at Nottingham.

How big was his fortune? £10,000 then; or £57.6bn at today's prices.

Move over Bill Gates: Indeed, that makes the chainmail earl £4bn richer than the software king.

He knew all the angles? And quite a few of the Saxons.

Did wealth bring him happiness? No. He spent all his time dealing with his revolting subjects and died at the siege of Pevensey in 1088 when an arrow hit him in the leg.

Radix malorum est cupiditas: Quite.

Can we trust the rankings? Of course not. The methodology is madness and you could argue over the figures till Doomsday.

Not to be confused with: Robert, count of Mortain; Odo of Bayeux; Archie Norman.

Do say: "It's one in the eye for Richard Branson" (a lowly 168th with a trifling £2.4bn).

Don't say: "What about the Romans?"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We gave conflicting dates on separate pages of the paper, March 22, for the introduction of the new higher limit on savings (£6,000) up to which pensioners would still be able to claim income support. It comes into operation from April 2001, as we said on page 18 (not next month, page 15).
fields.body:
We gave conflicting dates on separate pages of the paper, March 22, for the introduction of the new higher limit on savings (£6,000) up to which pensioners would still be able to claim income support. It comes into operation from April 2001, as we said on page 18 (not next month, page 15).

In a report headed GM trials upset as farmers pull out, page 5, March 24, we quoted Colin Merritt, the biotechnology manager of Monsanto, saying that he expected some of the farms contracted to conduct trials to drop out. He went on to say, according to our report, that of more than 100 already submitted, 30 had been "solicited". What he actually said was "selected".

In a report, page 19, March 21, headed French take aim at lax gun laws, we said that the French parliament "has sent a fact-finding mission to Britain to gauge the success of gun control measures... " We were jumping the gun. The mission is still being planned and no firm arrangements or dates have yet been made.

We suggested, page 18, Friday Review, March 24, in the heading to a piece on the pianist, Rolf Hind, that our reporter had met him. They spoke on the telephone (Hind was in New Zealand at the time).

English department, in a piece in our round-up, page 12, March 23, we should have referred to "re-interment at the cemetery" (not re-internment).

webTitle: Putting property tax on solid footing

fields.headline: Putting property tax on solid footing
fields.trailText: The increase in stamp duty of half a percentage point on houses worth £250,000 or more will do little to dampen the property boom in substantial areas of the UK.
fields.body:
The increase in stamp duty of half a percentage point on houses worth £250,000 or more will do little to dampen the property boom in substantial areas of the UK.

In contrast, property tax reform could have been extremely effective against this and other economic problems. The table shows the evolution of the UK house prices/earnings ratio and the south-east minus UK difference in this ratio since 1970.

Many of the forces driving the market are comparable to those of the 1980s: higher incomes; easy loan conditions; relatively low interest rates; rises in financial asset prices; rises in house prices themselves which increase the equity cushion of owners; and the feeling of consumers that recent high rates of return in housing will continue.

Spectacular rates of return are being achieved, because mortgage borrowers are gearing up and so investing relatively little of their own cash. With the high returns believed to be available by many in London and the south-east, the rise in stamp duty will do little to dampen the market. Paradoxically, the impact of stamp duty will be felt more strongly in the next housing market downturn, when it will reduce mobility and have a larger effect on rates of return.

Property taxes are the most distorted part of the UK tax system. The current system is perverse: the largest houses in the most expensive locations, belonging to those with more than one home, attract the lowest tax rates. Moreover, small homes are proportionately the most highly taxed. Since almost half of those in the lowest tax band get council tax benefit, the tax also causes an unemployment trap.

If someone in a £40,000 house pays council tax of £500, the tax rate is 1.25%. The rate drops to 1.07% at £70,000, 0.47% at £320,000, and to 0.15% at £1m. Second or third houses attract only half the tax rate on first houses.

The New Policy Institute has suggested ways of making council tax less grossly unfair. Reforms that we have suggested go further.

They include allowing pensioners to defer council tax until the property is sold or it can be paid from their estate. This removes the biggest objection to a property tax, which is that pensioners in expensive houses often have little cash. We also propose regular revaluations and reducing the regional inequalities in council tax rates. A 35% income tax band could compensate the more affluent whose council tax bills would rise.

For the macro-economy, such a package would have helped to halt speculative fever in the property hot-spots and slowed the growth in spending in those areas, allowing interest rates and the exchange rate to fall.

Instead, sterling rose 1% against the euro after the Budget, in part reflecting the market view of what the monetary policy committee would have to do. The committee will surely push rates up only slowly, given the outcry over Rover and worries about other parts of manufacturing and agriculture which have to compete against continental Europe. And, with the public finances in good shape, gilt yields, against which fixed rate mortgages tend to be priced, will in any case remain low.

The high exchange rate will raise relative unemployment and cut relative earnings in the west midlands and other parts of the economy more exposed to European competition. Migration to the south-east will be supported by these trends, despite increasingly high housing costs, in turn tending to sustain higher house prices there.

A more level property tax playing field would have reduced many of these current and future problems - possibly saving Longbridge and Dagenham, and helping to rescue farmers from bankruptcy.

It would also prevent the waste of resources symbolized by empty homes in the north and overbuilding in the south-east.

 Gavin Cameron is a research fellow and John Muellbauer is professor of economics at Nuffield college, Oxford.
