webTitle: Brown pound will keep hammering industry

fields.headline: Brown pound will keep hammering industry
fields.trailText: Almost without exception, governments like strong currencies. This government is no exception. Industry was miffed to find that the chancellor in his Budget offered little but tea and sympathy about the level of sterling but it should not have been surprised. For Gordon Brown and Tony Blair, a strong pound is the love that dare not speak its name.
fields.body:
Almost without exception, governments like strong currencies. This government is no exception. Industry was miffed to find that the chancellor in his Budget offered little but tea and sympathy about the level of sterling but it should not have been surprised. For Gordon Brown and Tony Blair, a strong pound is the love that dare not speak its name.

A strong-currency strategy is not without risks. As one industrialist said last week: "The pound was not really to blame for what happened at Longbridge, but it would be if Ford decided to shut Dagenham." Losing one car plant would be unfortunate: losing two would look like criminal negligence.

But, as far as Brown and Blair are concerned, if the alternative to a strong-pound strategy is a weak-currency strategy, they will opt for the former, because to an extent it is an expression of overseas confidence in Labour. Ten years ago, the idea that industry would be screaming at a Labour government to bring down the level of the pound would have been laughable. Getting the pound down was what Labour governments did with metronomic regularity. Fat lot of good it did them.

Last week, the prime minister made it clear there would be no attempts to massage the pound down. It would be counterproductive. What's more, industry was learning to live with it.

This is not something the prime minister would dream of saying in the Longbridge sports and social club, but the government believes the strong pound is popular. It means cheaper imports. It means more pesetas for the pound. Crudely, it means a stronger feelgood factor, while devaluation means a feelbad factor. Over the medium term, ministers would probably prefer the pound to be a bit lower than it is, but not by too much and certainly not too rapidly.

The prime minister is broadly right about the lack of attractive options. Self-evidently, the best way to get the level of the pound down would be to cut interest rates, but that will only happen when the Bank of England is convinced cheaper borrowing is compatible with hitting the government's 2.5% inflation target. It will take some convincing.

In addition, should the currency take a nosedive of its own accord, the respite for industry would be shortlived, since the monetary policy committee would fear the prospect of more expensive imports adding to domestic inflationary pressure. The result would be an increase in interest rates that would affect all businesses and not exporters.

Theoretically, it would be possible to mop up excess liquidity caused by cheaper borrowing through tighter fiscal policy, by either raising taxes or cutting spending. Adding to the tax burden when the government is running hefty annual surpluses and is already under sustained (if fatuous) attack from the opposition for clearing up the budgetary mess left in 1997 lacks political appeal. As for cutting public spending, that is even more of a non-starter.

Where critics of the government's exchange rate strategy have a point is when they say the Budget did little to help matters because a looser fiscal policy and a tight monetary policy tend to lead to a higher exchange rate. They are also right to say ministers would do well to stop wittering on about how well industry is coping with a strong pound, because the effect of that is to push the currency higher.

Mr Blair is also part-right when he says industry is making a good fist of surviving, perhaps because survivors of the past quarter century know how to cut costs, boost productivity and stay competitive. While Friday's trade figures showed a deficit in trade in goods of £8bn in the three months to January, all but £1.3bn of this was with countries outside the European Union. During the period of sterling's appreciation against European currencies, its deficit in goods with the EU rose from £4bn in 1997 to £6.2bn in 1999. That is a substantial deterioration but dwarfed by what has happened to trade with the rest of the world, where the deficit has gone from £7.9bn to £20.4bn.

Even so, appreciation of the pound against the euro is clearly having a deleterious effect on profit margins. But the government's view is that the problem is not sterling strength but euro weakness, which will eventually turn around, as sentiment changes on the foreign exchanges. That analysis has a ring of truth about it. Sterling has remained rock steady against the strong dollar since the mid-90s but has jumped by close on 20% against the euro since its launch 15 months ago. This has caused enthusiasts for Britain's membership of the single currency one or two headaches because their original sales pitch was Britain needed to join a strong euro as a bulwark against inflation. Now there has been a complete about-turn and immediate entry into a weak euro is vital to save jobs in manufacturing.

The presumption that the euro is grotesquely under-valued and due for a sustained rally has been around for some time. There looks to be only one way for the dollar to go and that is down. There looks to be only one way for the euro to go and that is up. Nick Parsons at Commerzbank, for example believes that there is a herd mentality at work. At 0.96 to the dollar the euro is a sell because everybody is selling it, even though it looks cheap. However, if it rose to 1.06 everybody would be buying it, even though it would be 10% dearer. But, as Parsons says, as far as the foreign exchange markets are concerned a degree in behavioural psychology is more useful than a degree in economics.

There are those who say there will be no early bounce in the euro. Marc Hendriks at Société Générale says that a cursory glance at what is happening to euroland's capital account suggests the currency could have further to fall against the dollar. Direct investment into the single currency zone last year was about 25% down on the previous year, and there was a less favourable balance for portfolio flows. There was a an acceleration of equity outflows, which Hendriks puts down to diversification, while equity inflows were unchanged even though European shares looked cheap relative to those in the US.

At the Bank, there is no longer the same confidence that the pound is about to fall against the euro. It is possible the pound will stay high for some time, increasing the chances of further high-profile manufacturing casualties. The Rover case has certainly caused some members of the government - especially those with a high concentration of exporters in their constituency - to think carefully about the implications of sterling's strength. Actually, the Longbridge saga was more about global economic trends than about currencies. The reason the plant had troubles was that it was less productive than other factories at a time when a global glut of cars has made brand loyalty all the more important. BMW had it; Rover did not.

So where does the government go from here? Looking at what the government does rather than what it says, the strategy seems to be to try to skip an industrial generation. Deep down, ministers see no long-term future for industries where Britain has been struggling to keep up over the past three or four decades and would rather devote resources to boosting the sunrise industries of the third industrial revolution. These industries, based on innovation, are much less price sensitive because, as yet, there is no developing-country competition.

The risk is that Britain does not cut it in the sunrise industries either and that, instead of humming with biotechnology companies, internet start-up firms and audio-visual entrepreneurs, the UK is transformed into Europe's offshore call centre. But it is a risk the government seems willing to take.

Industry was miffed to find that the chancellor in his Budget offered little but tea and sympathy about the level of sterling but it should not have been surprised. For Gordon Brown and Tony Blair, a strong pound is the love that dare not speak its name. A strong-currency strategy is not without risks. As one industrialist said last week: "The pound was not really to blame for what happened at Longbridge, but it would be if Ford decided to shut Dagenham." Losing one car plant would be unfortunate: losing two would look like criminal negligence. webTitle: Vivendi denies plan for £63bn Seagram deal

fields.headline: Vivendi denies plan for £63bn Seagram deal
fields.standfirst: Internet mega-mergers put French under pressure
fields.trailText: Vivendi, the French communications and utilities group yesterday dismissed reports that it was about to sign up for the latest industry mega-merger.
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French communications and utilities group yesterday dismissed reports that it was about to sign up for the latest industry mega-merger.

The company quashed suggestions that it was seeking a three-way £63bn all-share merger with Seagram and Cox Communications.

Internet mania has forced a string of global alliances, such as the AOL-Time Warner and EMI-Warner Music Group deals, and continues to exert pressure on other companies to respond to protect their stock market valuations.

Vivendi denied rumours that its board was meeting yesterday to discuss a deal.

A spokesman for the French group said it was impossible that talks could be under way with Seagram or Cox without his knowledge.

"I deny the Seagram-Cox Communications report," he said. "I globally deny it. In fact I don't even know who Cox Communications is."

Earlier this month Seagram's chief executive, Edgar Bronfman Jr, whose family controls the Canadian drinks and media empire, attempted to dampen the merger rumours which have caused his company's share price to soar.

At the time, Mr Bronfman said: "I'm unable to announce today our much rumoured business combination with News Corp, AT&T, Canal Plus, Viacom, Disney, Bertelsmann, Yahoo!, Vivendi, USA Networks, NBC, Sony, Microsoft or any Paul Allen-affiliated company."

An alliance with Seagram and Cox Communications, however, would not have been without its difficulties - given Vivendi's relationship with News Corp through a 24.9% shareholding in BSkyB. Such a deal would have created a direct rival to News Corp, as well as to Walt Disney and Time Warner. Vivendi also has a 40% shareholding in French broadcaster Canal Plus.

Seagram, which owns Universal studios in Hollywood and record companies Polygram and MCA, has been trying to shore up its position, given the convergence between media and internet companies. Music, its largest business, is being transformed by the internet more rapidly than film or television.

Cox Communications, which owns an extensive American cable network, has been less open about its desire to form ties with another company but is in a strong position with six million customers. The company also provides digital television and other broadband cable services.

Media speculation suggested that Vivendi had found a buyer or merger partner for Seagram's drinks business, which includes Chivas Regal and Glenlivet whisky, Martell cognac and Captain Morgan rum. Potential partners were thought to range from Allied Domecq, Bacardi or Brown Forman.

One news agency quoted advisers to the three-way merger as saying that most of the deal would be completed by a share swap giving each company a stake in the enlarged group.

The deal would have valued Seagram at £20bn, with Vivendi prepared to pay 25% in cash.

The French group has a market value of around £44bn, while Cox Communications is valued at about £16bn.

fields.headline: Asia shelves IMF challenge
fields.trailText: South-east Asian finance ministers yesterday succumbed to international pressure and suspended plans to create a regional crisis management fund. They agreed instead to expand existing currency swap facilities to bolster economies experiencing balance of payment difficulties.
fields.body:
South-east Asian finance ministers yesterday succumbed to international pressure and suspended plans to create a regional crisis management fund. They agreed instead to expand existing currency swap facilities to bolster economies experiencing balance of payment difficulties.

However, ministers from the Association of South-East Asian Nations (Asean) said after two days of talks in the oil-rich sultanate of Brunei that they were still considering establishing an asian monetary fund, and would discuss it again later in the year.

Recognising the need for the availability of financial resources in times of crisis, the ministers agreed to "conduct a study on the modalities of a mechanism for a regional fi nancing arrangement to supplement the existing international facilities".

Asean secretary general Rodolfo Severino said that the plan was shelved following a presentation by the International Monetary Fund to the ministers. "The IMF and several western nations have expressed opposition to the creation of an AMF," he said. "They feel we are not yet ready for such an institution."

Mr Severino also said the 10 Asean ministers were not united on the mechanisms for setting up an AMF.

Malaysia is the driving force behind the scheme. In 1998 its prime minister, Mahathir Muhammad, ignored IMF prescriptions for his country's economy and imposed hefty currency controls.

Asean comprises Brunei, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philip pines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. The proposals for an AMF would also include South Korea and Asian powerhouses Japan and China.

South-east Asia is still struggling to recover from the economic collapse that started in Thailand in July 1997 and rapidly spread around the region. Official regional growth for the year 2000 is predicted at 4.5% to 5.0%. That is a far cry from pre-crisis levels but still considered optimistic by many western officials.

Analysts believe IMF opposition to an AMF is driven by selfish motives. "The west, and the IMF in particular, is worried about losing influence and leverage in the region if an AMF is established," a senior Singaporean banker said yesterday. "They want to be able to continue to dictate to governments over how to handle monetary crises."

webTitle: Alwaleed takes hotel group to market

fields.headline: Alwaleed takes hotel group to market
fields.trailText: The Saudi prince who has built up a $15bn (£9.4bn) fortune via investments in underperforming high-profile companies such as EuroDisney, Canary Wharf and Planet Hollywood, is seeking outside investment to expand his $1bn international hotel portfolio.
fields.body:
The Saudi prince who has built up a $15bn (£9.4bn) fortune via investments in underperforming high-profile companies such as EuroDisney, Canary Wharf and Planet Hollywood, is seeking outside investment to expand his $1bn international hotel portfolio.

Prince Alwaleed bin Talal also said that there are plans for a new EuroDisney theme park, and announced that he had committed a further $10m to the troubled Planet Hollywood restaurant chain.

"I am going to take all my hotel group investments, now worth $1bn, and offer them under an umbrella to investors," he said in an interview with journal the Middle East Economic Digest.

"We are seeking to raise $300m to $500m in a private placement that will take place between April and June this year," he said.

Prince Alwaleed's hotel investments, owned through his Kingdom Holding Company, include New York's Plaza Hotel, the George V in Paris and stakes in the Four Seasons and Movenpick chains.

The nephew of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd has climbed to eighth position on the Forbes "rich list" by pursuing a strategy of investing heavily in troubled high-profile assets and turning them around.

"EuroDisney was almost bankrupt when we got into it, and our investment saved the theme park from going under," he said. "Now there is going to be another major studio investing in the project with plans to develop a second theme park under way."

Universal, which has theme parks in the US, is rumoured as a possible partner.

fields.headline: EBRD seeks chief - and probity
fields.trailText: With Horst Köhler officially confirmed as the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund, the search for his successor at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is creaking into gear.
fields.body:
With Horst Köhler officially confirmed as the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund, the search for his successor at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is creaking into gear.

Shareholders at the London-based EBRD face a dual task in their deliberations. Not only do they have to find the right person for the job, they have to do so in a manner which will help reassure outsiders that there is more to the whole process of appointing the heads of international financial institutions than back stairs political horse-trading.

Mr Köhler himself is understood to have told staff last week that the process of choosing his successor needs to be speedy, fair and transparent. He should know. His own appointment at the IMF was a messy affair, with Germany failing to secure the job for its first choice, Caio Koch-Weser.

Now the EBRD needs to show its selection procedures are an improvement. The auspices are not encouraging. When the first president, Jacques Attali, was forced out in disgrace, Paris insisted that another Frenchman take over. Jacques de Larosière proved a safer pair of hands but when he retired, the EBRD was still unable to get his successor in place until seven months later.

Nor does there appear to be any sense of urgency this time around. Giuliano Amato, the Italian treasury minister, indicated that finance ministers had discussed the issue last week but that the question was unlikely to be resolved be fore the end of May. According to Mr Amato, the ministers did not get down to talking about names or even nationalities, but already the battle is taking a familiar shape.

The French government is understood to be pressing the claims of treasury director Jean Lemierre. Paris should be able to rely on Berlin for support - but not everyone is keen on another Frenchman at the top of the EBRD.

There are suggestions that the bank should appoint someone from one of the bank's countries of operation. Polish finance minister Leszek Balcerowicz has been mentioned; another possibility is Claes de Neergaard, a Swede who was until recently a vice-president at the European Investment Bank.

Whoever does take over will face a testing time. The EBRD is back in the black after being hit by heavy losses in Russia in the wake of the debt crisis. But although Russia will always remain a crucial area for the bank, the impact it will be able to have on an economy of that size is bound to be limited. It also remains to be seen what effect progress by Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia and Estonia towards membership of the European Union will have on the bank's operations in those countries.

The case for continuing EBRD input after accession to the EU will not be easy to make. In the Balkans, the EBRD is deeply involved in the efforts to bring economic stability, seeking to create an economic base by encouraging the growth of small and medium sized enterprises.

But this type of bottom-up approach is likely to be overshadowed by big infrastructure projects, and the bank remains handicapped by the need to conform to sound banking practices in areas where other banks are reluctant to operate.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Talks are under way between the government and Ford to avert the end of car production at Dagenham . Such a move would cut 4,000 jobs. As the crisis deepened at Ford and Rover it emerged that the future of Rolls-Royce Motors is also in jeopardy. Fears are mounting that BMW will be forced to abandon plans to take over the world's most famous marque from Volkswagen in 2003.

Gas group BG is planning to build a national broadband cable network within two years at a cost of up to £2bn. The pipeline and exploration group is believed to favour BSkyB and Kingston Communications as partners in the venture.

Sunday Times

The expansion of public spending in the Budget will push up interest rates , dashing hopes that rates are near their peak, analysts say. The fear that the Budget will provoke a rise in borrowing costs comes as it emerges that the Treasury is privately assuming higher rates in its new economic projections. Close reading of the Budget reveals that the Treasury is expecting headline inflation to hit 3.5% by September, implying a further rise in mortgage rates.

A windfall payment of about £750m is in store for directors and staff at investment bank Robert Fleming if its proposed sale goes ahead. The figure Chase Manhattan has put on Fleming is thought to be close to £5bn, far higher than estimates published so far. Staff own 15% of Fleming shares.

BAE Systems has clinched a deal with Boeing that will bring military and civil orders worth more than $1.2bn to Britain.

Sunday Telegraph Wireless Group , the radio operator run by Kelvin MacKenzie, is preparing for a flotation next month valuing it at up to £150m. The deal will reap the former editor of the Sun newspaper an estimated £10m fortune. The company has hired WestLB Panmure as a broker on the float, designed to raise funds for further expansion and capitalise on the present stock market appetite for radio companies.

National Power may be forced to ditch plans to demerge its domestic and international operations because of the slump in the company's share price.

The electricity generator, once the largest in Britain - is thought to be considering other options including a bid for the group.

Mail on Sunday

The crisis sparked by BMW 's disposal of Rover escalated this weekend as tens of millions of pounds of investment was pulled from the West Midlands by foreign component suppliers and car dealers reported a plunge in sales. At least 10 parts companies expected to employ about 2,000 people have cancelled inward investment projects, but the final figure is almost certain to be higher.

Billions of pounds worth of banking businesses may be sold as a result of Don Cruickshank's hard-hitting-report on the industry.

Link , the network which oversees the banks' 27,000 cash machines, is expected to be the first to be hived off as an independent profit-making business. It is at present a mutual operation owned by the big banks and building societies.

Sunday Business

Volkswagen is seeking to buy Rolls-Royce Motors from BMW ahead of a hand-over of the marque to its German rival in two years time. VW wants to pay no more than the $30m BMW paid to acquire the rights to the name from Rolls-Royce

Don Cruickshank , who headed the government's banking review and has won a formidable reputation for probity, is set to join Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery group in its attempt to win the next National Lottery licence.

IoS

Britain's venture capital industry is being threatened by Budget proposals on foreign firms and double taxation, the City has warned.

The moves, which have drawn criticism from multinationals such as Anglo American, appear likely to force big venture capital firms to relocate in mainland Europe.

fields.bodyText: Observer Talks are under way between the government and Ford to avert the end of car production at Dagenham . Such a move would cut 4,000 jobs. As the crisis deepened at Ford and Rover it emerged that the future of Rolls-Royce Motors is also in jeopardy. Fears are mounting that BMW will be forced to abandon plans to take over the world's most famous marque from Volkswagen in 2003. Gas group BG is planning to build a national broadband cable network within two years at a cost of up to £2bn. The pipeline and exploration group is believed to favour BSkyB and Kingston Communications as partners in the venture. Sunday Times The expansion of public spending in the Budget will push up interest rates , dashing hopes that rates are near their peak, analysts say. The fear that the Budget will provoke a rise in borrowing costs comes as it emerges that the Treasury is privately assuming higher rates in its new economic projections. Close reading of the Budget reveals that the Treasury is expecting headline inflation to hit 3.5% by September, implying a further rise in mortgage rates. A windfall payment of about £750m is in store for directors and staff at investment bank Robert Fleming if its proposed sale goes ahead. The figure Chase Manhattan has put on Fleming is thought to be close to £5bn, far higher than estimates published so far. Staff own 15% of Fleming shares. BAE Systems has clinched a deal with Boeing that will bring military and civil orders worth more than $1.2bn to Britain. Sunday Telegraph Wireless Group , the radio operator run by Kelvin MacKenzie, is preparing for a flotation next month valuing it at up to £150m. The deal will reap the former editor of the Sun newspaper an estimated £10m fortune. The company has hired WestLB Panmure as a broker on the float, designed to raise funds for further expansion and capitalise on the present stock market appetite for radio companies. National Power may be forced to ditch plans to demerge its domestic and international operations because of the slump in the company's share price. The electricity generator, once the largest in Britain - is thought to be considering other options including a bid for the group. Mail on Sunday The crisis sparked by BMW 's disposal of Rover escalated this weekend as tens of millions of pounds of investment was pulled from the West Midlands by foreign component suppliers and car dealers reported a plunge in sales. At least 10 parts companies expected to employ about 2,000 people have cancelled inward investment projects, but the final figure is almost certain to be higher. Billions of pounds worth of banking businesses may be sold as a result of Don Cruickshank's hard-hitting-report on the industry. Link , the network which oversees the banks' 27,000 cash machines, is expected to be the first to be hived off as an independent profit-making business. It is at present a mutual operation owned by the big banks and building societies. Sunday Business Volkswagen is seeking to buy Rolls-Royce Motors from BMW ahead of a hand-over of the marque to its German rival in two years time. VW wants to pay no more than the $30m BMW paid to acquire the rights to the name from Rolls-Royce Don Cruickshank , who headed the government's banking review and has won a formidable reputation for probity, is set to join Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery group in its attempt to win the next National Lottery licence. IoS Britain's venture capital industry is being threatened by Budget proposals on foreign firms and double taxation, the City has warned. The moves, which have drawn criticism from multinationals such as Anglo American, appear likely to force big venture capital firms to relocate in mainland Europe. fields.headline: Final warning for hedge funds
fields.trailText: A group of international top level regulators, headed by the financial services authority chairman, Howard Davies, has ordered tougher regulation of hedge funds in the wake of the 1998 crisis which threatened to cause an international financial meltdown.
fields.body:
A group of international top level regulators, headed by the financial services authority chairman, Howard Davies, has ordered tougher regulation of hedge funds in the wake of the 1998 crisis which threatened to cause an international financial meltdown.

But it has stopped short of recommending direct regulation of highly leveraged institutions (HLIs), primarily hedge funds.

However, the group - set up under the auspices of the Financial Stability Forum, which is backed by the Group of Seven - warned that if its plans for tighter regulation proved ineffective it would look again at the idea of direct supervision.

The inquiry into the regulation of highly leveraged institutions followed the near collapse of the hedge fund Long Term Capital Management in 1998.

This raised concerns about potential risks to the world's financial system and about the impact HLIs could have on a number of small and medium size economies which were open to sharp movements in capital.

The working group recommended a series of measures designed to counter the perceived risks.

They include stronger risk management both for HLIs and the firms with which they do business and tougher regulation of institutions which provide them with credit. The regulators also called for greater public disclosure, new guidelines on foreign exchange trading and a stronger market infrastructure.

In a statement after the weekend meeting in Singapore the forum said: "The group also considered, but did not recommend, at this stage, direct regulation of currently unregulated HLIs.

"The forum emphasised that direct regulation would be reconsidered if, upon review, the implementation of the report's recommendations were not adequately addressing the concerns identified."

webTitle: And they want to turn this into a pub?

fields.headline: And they want to turn this into a pub?
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey visits Bexhill's threatened De La Warr Pavilion
fields.trailText: The Dome at Worthing. The Moorings at Largs. The West Pier, Brighton. The Regency terraces of Ramsgate. All gone, going or very much down on their luck. We are careless with our best and most enjoyable seaside architecture. We let it fall to pieces, destroy it or undermine it, as if the sea itself were not threat enough.
fields.body:
The Dome at Worthing. The Moorings at Largs. The West Pier, Brighton. The Regency terraces of Ramsgate. All gone, going or very much down on their luck. We are careless with our best and most enjoyable seaside architecture. We let it fall to pieces, destroy it or undermine it, as if the sea itself were not threat enough.

Now the same fate hangs over the De La Warr Pavilion in Bexhill-on-Sea, a Modern masterpiece that shares its Grade I listing with cathedrals and great country houses.

This spacious, streamlined, light structure is a perfect foil to both the boisterous grey of the English Channel and the harsh brick Edwardian buildings that stretch along much of Bexhill's shoreline. When it opened on December 12, 1935, visitors felt as if they were inside an ocean liner. The walls were painted ivory-cream, the floors covered in cork or cream terrazzo. Diners sat on bentwood chairs at beechwood tables lit by Bauhaus globe lamps. The public had seen nothing like it.

Sir Charles Reilly, then professor of architecture at Liverpool University, described the pavilion, with its welded-steel frame, as "a revelation from another planet in the rococo redness of that terrible town". More than six decades on, a recent poll for English Heritage ranked the De La Warr Pavilion the country's third best-loved building of the past 100 years.

Since 1989 it has been cared for by the Pavilion Trust, established by Jill Theis, a former local councillor, and by Troughton McAslan, the architects charged with its renovation. But now Rother District Council is thinking of selling the place to the Watford-based pub chain JD Wetherspoon. Theis and her colleagues are not happy about it. Wetherspoon, they fear, may not respect the spirit of this rare and elegant structure, and the sale itself ignores its special history as a public building.

Arts minister Alan Howarth recently said he was "strongly opposed" to the proposal to turn the building over to a commercial concern. But this is the choice: cultural centre with sun and fun included at a cost of £750,000 a year, or a commercially-driven leisure centre (including a 1,000-seat theatre) revolving around a pub. The council wants to reduce running costs for local taxpayers, but the trust is already in negotiation with the Arts Council, which says it has earmarked £4m to help guarantee the building's future. A previous bid for lottery money was rejected, though it is hard to understand why.

In Wetherspoon's favour, it must be said that it is unlikely to damage the pavilion. The company has a policy of taking over impressive buildings, especially ones, like old banks and post offices, that appeared to have little future until bars and pubs started moving in 10 or 15 years ago.

Wetherspoon has also won Civic Trust and Camra/English Heritage awards for the design of its pubs. "When we took a look at the old opera house in Tunbridge Wells some years ago," says spokesman Eddie Gerschon, "we were attacked in no uncertain terms: we would do this and that to destroy the place. In fact, the opera house had been left to rot for quite some time and had been a bingo hall. We took it on, looked after it and some months later some of the same people who had berated us were instrumental in our winning a Civic Trust award." He also proudly cites the Commercial Rooms in Bristol, the Half Moon in east London and the Billiard Hall in West Bromwich. "About 15 per cent of our buildings are listed. We do care about them."

Fair enough, but the De La Warr pavilion is not some neglected white elephant. Since its restoration over the past decade, it has offered a programme of music, dances, theatre, children's shows, comedy, conferences (on architecture, especially), as well a place for the famously elderly population of Bexhill to while away the afternoon.

But there's more than a building or a local resource at stake here. There's a fascinating history that should not be reduced to a series of prints on a bar wall. It began in the early 30s when the town invited private companies to come up with a design and programme for a new leisure development on the seafront. The local grandee, Earl de la Warr, a wealthy socialist, stepped in with his influence and chequebook (to the tune of £100,000). He persuaded the council that it should develop the site itself. A new publicly owned building would be designed only after a competition was held and judged according to rules established by the Royal Institute of British Architects.

This was the first significant competition in Britain that called specifically for a Modern building. There were no fewer than 230 entries, but the contract was finally awarded to Erich Mendelsohn, who had arrived in England from Nazi Germany just three months before, and the flamboyant Serge Chermayeff, an interior designer and ballroom dancer. Chermayeff was all but unknown; Mendelsohn, however, was considered to be one of Weimar Germany's finest architects.

Born in Allenstein, East Prussia in 1887, he made his name with a sequence of at first curious and then magnificent streamlined buildings. His Schocken department store in Chemnitz led directly to William Crabtree's Peter Jones store in Chelsea. But, while Peter Jones stands unchanged today, the Schocken store was obliterated by Allied bombers; Nazi bombers, meanwhile, strafed Bexhill-on-Sea, winging the pavilion.

Mendelsohn and Chermayeff were, of course, delighted by their victory. Not so some of their British colleagues, who wrote aggressive letters to the Architects' Journal attacking the design by these "aliens". An article in Fascist Week railed, inevitably, against the employment of German and Russian Jews.

Mendelsohn and Chermayeff set to work all the same, ably assisted by the likes of Peter Moro (who later worked on the design of the Royal Festival Hall, which was greatly influenced by the pavilion), Felix Samuely and Cyril Sweett, a quantity surveyor specialising in Modern design. What they produced was the first modern "people's palace".

So it's easy to understand why those who have fought so hard to bring the De La Warr pavilion back to life are worried about it being taken out of public ownership. JD Wetherspoon, with 370 pubs under its belt, may well insist that it works with architects "whose job is to respect the architecture and make each pub look different from the next". But this is one of our most important 20th-century buildings.

Meanwhile, deep inland, the residents of Hinchley Wood in Surrey have succeeded in saving their pub from being turned into a McDonald's. There are already 1,116 branches of the burger joint in Britain. Suddenly Wetherspoon seems like small beer. If not in Bexhill-on-Sea.
